Propose a semantic-guided, dynamic sparsification in activation space to guide subspace orientation and rank.

Method: Introduce Semantic-Guided Dynamic Sparsification (SGDS) that enforces class-specific sparse activation subspaces. Similar classes share compact subspaces; dissimilar classes have non-overlapping subspaces. Subspace shaping is driven by semantic guidance and dynamic sparsification, aiming to improve knowledge transfer and reduce interference without rigid parameter constraints.

Result: Claims state-of-the-art performance on multiple benchmark datasets for CIL, demonstrating effectiveness of activation-space sparsification over traditional parameter-space constraints.

Conclusion: SGDS mitigates interference by sculpting activation-space subspaces rather than constraining parameters, enabling improved plasticity and knowledge transfer in CIL.

Abstract: Class-Incremental Learning (CIL) requires a model to continually learn new classes without forgetting old ones. A common and efficient solution freezes a pre-trained model and employs lightweight adapters, whose parameters are often forced to be orthogonal to prevent inter-task interference. However, we argue that this parameter-constraining method is detrimental to plasticity. To this end, we propose Semantic-Guided Dynamic Sparsification (SGDS), a novel method that proactively guides the activation space by governing the orientation and rank of its subspaces through targeted sparsification. Specifically, SGDS promotes knowledge transfer by encouraging similar classes to share a compact activation subspace, while simultaneously preventing interference by assigning non-overlapping activation subspaces to dissimilar classes. By sculpting class-specific sparse subspaces in the activation space, SGDS effectively mitigates interference without imposing rigid constraints on the parameter space. Extensive experiments on various benchmark datasets demonstrate the state-of-the-art performance of SGDS.

</details>


### [29] [Rectifying Geometry-Induced Similarity Distortions for Real-World Aerial-Ground Person Re-Identification](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21405)
*Kailash A. Hambarde,Hugo Proença*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Geometry distortions break geometry-agnostic attention in aerial-ground ReID; the paper proposes GIQT to rectify query-key similarity via a geometry-conditioned, low-rank transform and adds a geometry-aware prompt generator, yielding robust cross-view matching with low overhead.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Extreme camera viewpoints and distances create severe geometric distortions that invalidate the assumption of a shared geometry-invariant similarity space in attention-based ReID. Existing methods relying on geometry-aware features or prompting fail to correct the underlying query-key similarity space.

Method: Introduce Geometry-Induced Query-Key Transformation (GIQT), a lightweight low-rank module that conditions query-key interactions on camera geometry to rectify the similarity space without altering feature representations or the attention mechanism. Additionally, implement a geometry-conditioned prompt generation mechanism that provides global, view-adaptive priors derived from geometry.

Result: Empirical evaluation on four aerial-ground ReID benchmarks shows consistent robustness gains under extreme and unseen geometric conditions, with minimal computational overhead compared to state-of-the-art methods.

Conclusion: GIQT effectively rectifies geometry-induced distortions in the query-key similarity space and, together with geometry-conditioned prompts, enhances cross-view ReID robustness while maintaining efficiency.

Abstract: Aerial-ground person re-identification (AG-ReID) is fundamentally challenged by extreme viewpoint and distance discrepancies between aerial and ground cameras, which induce severe geometric distortions and invalidate the assumption of a shared similarity space across views. Existing methods primarily rely on geometry-aware feature learning or appearance-conditioned prompting, while implicitly assuming that the geometry-invariant dot-product similarity used in attention mechanisms remains reliable under large viewpoint and scale variations. We argue that this assumption does not hold. Extreme camera geometry systematically distorts the query-key similarity space and degrades attention-based matching, even when feature representations are partially aligned.
  To address this issue, we introduce Geometry-Induced Query-Key Transformation (GIQT), a lightweight low-rank module that explicitly rectifies the similarity space by conditioning query-key interactions on camera geometry. Rather than modifying feature representations or the attention formulation itself, GIQT adapts the similarity computation to compensate for dominant geometry-induced anisotropic distortions. Building on this local similarity rectification, we further incorporate a geometry-conditioned prompt generation mechanism that provides global, view-adaptive representation priors derived directly from camera geometry.
  Experiments on four aerial-ground person re-identification benchmarks demonstrate that the proposed framework consistently improves robustness under extreme and previously unseen geometric conditions, while introducing minimal computational overhead compared to state-of-the-art methods.

</details>


### [30] [Generation Enhances Understanding in Unified Multimodal Models via Multi-Representation Generation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21406)
*Zihan Su,Hongyang Wei,Kangrui Cen,Yong Wang,Guanhua Chen,Chun Yuan,Xiangxiang Chu*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: UniMRG is a post-training, architecture-agnostic method that adds auxiliary generation tasks (pixel reconstruction, depth, and segmentation) to unified multimodal models, yielding improved understanding (perception, spatial reasoning, reduced hallucinations) and enhanced generation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Fill the gap where generation feedback improves understanding in unified multimodal models by leveraging diverse intrinsic representations to capture appearance, geometry, and structure.

Method: Post-training framework UniMRG adds auxiliary generation objectives (pixel-level reconstruction, depth estimation, and segmentation map synthesis) alongside standard understanding losses, in an architecture-agnostic manner, to UMMs.

Result: Across multiple UMM architectures, UniMRG improves fine-grained perception and spatial understanding, reduces hallucinations, and yields gains in generation quality, demonstrating the effectiveness and generality of generation-guided understanding.

Conclusion: Generating intrinsic representations during post-training enriches UMMs’ representations, enabling better perception and reasoning while simultaneously boosting generation, suggesting broad applicability of multi-representation generation for unified multimodal systems.

Abstract: Unified Multimodal Models (UMMs) integrate both visual understanding and generation within a single framework. Their ultimate aspiration is to create a cycle where understanding and generation mutually reinforce each other. While recent post-training methods have successfully leveraged understanding to enhance generation, the reverse direction of utilizing generation to improve understanding remains largely unexplored. In this work, we propose UniMRG (Unified Multi-Representation Generation), a simple yet effective architecture-agnostic post-training method. UniMRG enhances the understanding capabilities of UMMs by incorporating auxiliary generation tasks. Specifically, we train UMMs to generate multiple intrinsic representations of input images, namely pixel (reconstruction), depth (geometry), and segmentation (structure), alongside standard visual understanding objectives. By synthesizing these diverse representations, UMMs capture complementary information regarding appearance, spatial relations, and structural layout. Consequently, UMMs develop a deeper and more comprehensive understanding of visual inputs. Extensive experiments across diverse UMM architectures demonstrate that our method notably enhances fine-grained perception, reduces hallucinations, and improves spatial understanding, while simultaneously boosting generation capabilities.

</details>


### [31] [MPF-Net: Exposing High-Fidelity AI-Generated Video Forgeries via Hierarchical Manifold Deviation and Micro-Temporal Fluctuations](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21408)
*Xinan He,Kaiqing Lin,Yue Zhou,Jiaming Zhong,Wei Ye,Wenhui Yi,Bing Fan,Feng Ding,Haodong Li,Bo Cao,Bin Li*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A new MPF-based forensic framework detects AI-generated videos by exploiting Manifold Projection Fluctuations via a two-branch hierarchical filter: Static Manifold Deviation Branch (off-manifold spatial anomalies using VFMs) and Micro-Temporal Fluctuation Branch (on-manifold subtle temporal fingerprints).


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Despite high visual fidelity, AI videos reveal structured MPF due to the manifold-fitting process; there is a need robust detectors that leverage both spatial and temporal residuals to distinguish synthetic content from real video.

Method: Proposes a hierarchical dual-path framework that acts as a sequential filter. The Static Manifold Deviation Branch uses refined perceptual boundaries of Large-Scale Vision Foundation Models to detect residual spatial anomalies that deviate from the real-world manifold (off-manifold). For videos on-manifold, the Micro-Temporal Fluctuation Branch serves as a secondary, fine-grained filter to capture persistent micro-temporal fluctuations.

Result: Conceptual framework with the goal of exposing forgeries that either show off-manifold spatial deviations or subtle on-manifold computational fingerprints; no empirical results are provided in the abstract.

Conclusion: MPF-based hierarchical detection offers robust multi-level scrutiny for AI-generated videos by leveraging both spatial deviations and micro-temporal patterns, enabling detection even when macro realism is preserved.

Abstract: With the rapid advancement of video generation models such as Veo and Wan, the visual quality of synthetic content has reached a level where macro-level semantic errors and temporal inconsistencies are no longer prominent. However, this does not imply that the distinction between real and cutting-edge high-fidelity fake is untraceable. We argue that AI-generated videos are essentially products of a manifold-fitting process rather than a physical recording. Consequently, the pixel composition logic of consecutive adjacent frames residual in AI videos exhibits a structured and homogenous characteristic. We term this phenomenon `Manifold Projection Fluctuations' (MPF). Driven by this insight, we propose a hierarchical dual-path framework that operates as a sequential filtering process. The first, the Static Manifold Deviation Branch, leverages the refined perceptual boundaries of Large-Scale Vision Foundation Models (VFMs) to capture residual spatial anomalies or physical violations that deviate from the natural real-world manifold (off-manifold). For the remaining high-fidelity videos that successfully reside on-manifold and evade spatial detection, we introduce the Micro-Temporal Fluctuation Branch as a secondary, fine-grained filter. By analyzing the structured MPF that persists even in visually perfect sequences, our framework ensures that forgeries are exposed regardless of whether they manifest as global real-world manifold deviations or subtle computational fingerprints.

</details>


### [32] [From Implicit Ambiguity to Explicit Solidity: Diagnosing Interior Geometric Degradation in Neural Radiance Fields for Dense 3D Scene Understanding](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21421)
*Jiangsan Zhao,Jakob Geipel,Kryzysztof Kusnierek*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Implicit NeRFs fail under heavy occlusion due to Interior Geometric Degradation; explicit SfM-based geometry with Sparse Voxel Rasterization (SVRaster) improves instance recovery to ~95.8% in dense scenes.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Assess reliability of neural radiance fields for quantitative 3D analysis in dense, self-occluding scenes; identify a fundamental failure mode and propose a robust alternative.

Method: Diagnose Interior Geometric Degradation (IGD) in transmittance-based volumetric optimization; conduct synthetic occlusion experiments showing ~89% recovery for state-of-the-art mask-supervised NeRFs; introduce explicit geometry pipeline (SVRaster) initialized from SfM feature geometry; project 2D instance masks onto a voxel grid; enforce geometric separation via recursive splitting; evaluate against degraded supervision.

Result: Implicit NeRFs saturate at ~89% instance recovery in dense scenes; SVRaster-based explicit geometry achieves 95.8% recovery; explicit geometry is more robust to supervision failure, recovering 43% more instances than implicit baselines.

Conclusion: Explicit geometric priors are a prerequisite for reliable quantitative analysis in highly self-occluding 3D scenes; coupling SfM geometry with voxel-based representations mitigates Interior Geometric Degradation and improves solidity and recoverability of instances.

Abstract: Neural Radiance Fields (NeRFs) have emerged as a powerful paradigm for multi-view reconstruction, complementing classical photogrammetric pipelines based on Structure-from-Motion (SfM) and Multi-View Stereo (MVS). However, their reliability for quantitative 3D analysis in dense, self-occluding scenes remains poorly understood. In this study, we identify a fundamental failure mode of implicit density fields under heavy occlusion, which we term Interior Geometric Degradation (IGD). We show that transmittance-based volumetric optimization satisfies photometric supervision by reconstructing hollow or fragmented structures rather than solid interiors, leading to systematic instance undercounting. Through controlled experiments on synthetic datasets with increasing occlusion, we demonstrate that state-of-the-art mask-supervised NeRFs saturate at approximately 89% instance recovery in dense scenes, despite improved surface coherence and mask quality. To overcome this limitation, we introduce an explicit geometric pipeline based on Sparse Voxel Rasterization (SVRaster), initialized from SfM feature geometry. By projecting 2D instance masks onto an explicit voxel grid and enforcing geometric separation via recursive splitting, our approach preserves physical solidity and achieves a 95.8% recovery rate in dense clusters. A sensitivity analysis using degraded segmentation masks further shows that explicit SfM-based geometry is substantially more robust to supervision failure, recovering 43% more instances than implicit baselines. These results demonstrate that explicit geometric priors are a prerequisite for reliable quantitative analysis in highly self-occluding 3D scenes.

</details>


### [33] [MultiModal Fine-tuning with Synthetic Captions](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21426)
*Shohei Enomoto,Shin'ya Yamaguchi*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Transforms unimodal datasets into multimodal ones by generating synthetic image captions with multimodal LLMs for fine-tuning, using a supervised contrastive loss and class-averaged text embeddings to achieve strong gains, especially in few-shot settings.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: There is a disconnect between multimodal pre-training and unimodal fine-tuning; leveraging rich multimodal representations during fine-tuning could improve downstream classification performance by providing synthetic multimodal signals.

Method: Use Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) to generate high-quality captions for images by prompts that incorporate class labels and domain context. Train with a multimodal objective on the synthetic captions. Introduce a supervised contrastive loss to pull same-class representations together during fine-tuning. For inference, use class-averaged text embeddings drawn from multiple synthetic captions per image.

Result: Extensive experiments on 13 image classification benchmarks show the proposed method outperforms baselines, with particularly large gains in few-shot learning.

Conclusion: Proposes a new dataset enhancement paradigm that bridges multimodal pre-training and fine-tuning, demonstrating that synthetic multimodal data can significantly improve classification; code is available at the provided GitHub URL.

Abstract: In this paper, we address a fundamental gap between pre-training and fine-tuning of deep neural networks: while pre-training has shifted from unimodal to multimodal learning with enhanced visual understanding, fine-tuning predominantly remains unimodal, limiting the benefits of rich pre-trained representations. To bridge this gap, we propose a novel approach that transforms unimodal datasets into multimodal ones using Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) to generate synthetic image captions for fine-tuning models with a multimodal objective. Our method employs carefully designed prompts incorporating class labels and domain context to produce high-quality captions tailored for classification tasks. Furthermore, we introduce a supervised contrastive loss function that explicitly encourages clustering of same-class representations during fine-tuning, along with a new inference technique that leverages class-averaged text embeddings from multiple synthetic captions per image. Extensive experiments across 13 image classification benchmarks demonstrate that our approach outperforms baseline methods, with particularly significant improvements in few-shot learning scenarios. Our work establishes a new paradigm for dataset enhancement that effectively bridges the gap between multimodal pre-training and fine-tuning. Our code is available at https://github.com/s-enmt/MMFT.

</details>


### [34] [Spava: Accelerating Long-Video Understanding via Sequence-Parallelism-aware Approximate Attention](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21444)
*Yuxiang Huang,Mingye Li,Xu Han,Chaojun Xiao,Weilin Zhao,Ao Sun,Ziqi Yuan,Hao Zhou,Fandong Meng,Zhiyuan Liu*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Spava is a sequence-parallel framework for long-video inference in large multimodal models (LMMs) that distributes approximate attention across multiple GPUs, avoiding embedding compression, and uses system-level optimizations to achieve substantial speedups over existing attention schemes without significant accuracy loss.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Long-video inference is bottlenecked by dense computation in the prefill stage of LMMs. Existing approaches either compress visual embeddings or apply sparse attention on a single GPU, which fails to scale to longer, more complex videos.

Method: Introduce Spava, a sequence-parallel framework that distributes approximate attention across multiple GPUs. It preserves visual embeddings without compression, employs optimized attention, and incorporates system-level enhancements such as load balancing and fused forward passes to maximize GPU utilization.

Result: Achieves speedups of 12.72x over FlashAttn, 1.70x over ZigZagRing, and 1.18x over APB in long-video inference tasks, with no notable performance loss. Code is released at the provided GitHub URL.

Conclusion: Spava enables efficient, scalable long-video inference for LMMs on multi-GPU systems, outperforming relevant baselines and facilitating processing of longer, more complex videos.

Abstract: The efficiency of long-video inference remains a critical bottleneck, mainly due to the dense computation in the prefill stage of Large Multimodal Models (LMMs). Existing methods either compress visual embeddings or apply sparse attention on a single GPU, yielding limited acceleration or degraded performance and restricting LMMs from handling longer, more complex videos. To overcome these issues, we propose Spava, a sequence-parallel framework with optimized attention that accelerates long-video inference across multiple GPUs. By distributing approximate attention, Spava reduces computation and increases parallelism, enabling efficient processing of more visual embeddings without compression and thereby improving task performance. System-level optimizations, such as load balancing and fused forward passes, further unleash the potential of Spava, delivering speedups of 12.72x, 1.70x, and 1.18x over FlashAttn, ZigZagRing, and APB, without notable performance loss. Code available at https://github.com/thunlp/APB

</details>


### [35] [Variance & Greediness: A comparative study of metric-learning losses](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21450)
*Donghuo Zeng,Hao Niu,Zhi Li,Masato Taya*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A diagnostic comparison of seven metric-learning losses (Contrastive, Triplet, N-pair, InfoNCE, ArcFace, SCL, CCL) using VARIANCE and GREEDINESS across five datasets; finds Triplet/SCL preserve within-class variance and margins, aiding top-1 in fine-grained tasks; Contrastive/InfoNCE yield fast convergence with compact embeddings; N-pair offers large mean separation with uneven spacing; frames an efficiency–granularity trade-off and practical guidance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To reveal how loss choice shapes embedding geometry and optimization dynamics in image retrieval, enabling informed loss selection for different data regimes and retrieval goals.

Method: Introduce VARIANCE (intra-/inter-class variance) and GREEDINESS (active ratio and gradient norms) as diagnostic metrics; evaluate seven losses across five image-retrieval datasets.

Result: Triplet and SCL preserve higher within-class variance and clearer inter-class margins, improving top-1 retrieval in fine-grained settings; Contrastive and InfoNCE achieve compact embeddings rapidly via many small updates, accelerating convergence but potentially oversimplifying class structure; N-pair achieves large mean separation but with uneven spacing.

Conclusion: Highlights an efficiency–granularity trade-off in metric learning; guidance for practitioners: prefer Triplet or SCL when preserving diversity and hard-sample discrimination are crucial; opt for Contrastive or InfoNCE when fast embedding compaction is desired; provides actionable recommendations for loss selection in image retrieval.

Abstract: Metric learning is central to retrieval, yet its effects on embedding geometry and optimization dynamics are not well understood. We introduce a diagnostic framework, VARIANCE (intra-/inter-class variance) and GREEDINESS (active ratio and gradient norms), to compare seven representative losses, i.e., Contrastive, Triplet, N-pair, InfoNCE, ArcFace, SCL, and CCL, across five image-retrieval datasets. Our analysis reveals that Triplet and SCL preserve higher within-class variance and clearer inter-class margins, leading to stronger top-1 retrieval in fine-grained settings. In contrast, Contrastive and InfoNCE compact embeddings are achieved quickly through many small updates, accelerating convergence but potentially oversimplifying class structures. N-pair achieves a large mean separation but with uneven spacing. These insights reveal a form of efficiency-granularity trade-off and provide practical guidance: prefer Triplet/SCL when diversity preservation and hard-sample discrimination are critical, and Contrastive/InfoNCE when faster embedding compaction is desired.

</details>


### [36] [Mining Forgery Traces from Reconstruction Error: A Weakly Supervised Framework for Multimodal Deepfake Temporal Localization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21458)
*Midou Guo,Qilin Yin,Wei Lu,Xiangyang Luo,Rui Yang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Introduces RT-DeepLoc, a weakly supervised temporal deepfake localization framework using a Masked Autoencoder (MAE) trained on authentic data and an Asymmetric Intra-video Contrastive Loss (AICL) to localize forgeries via reconstruction errors, achieving state-of-the-art results on LAV-DF.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Frame-level annotations for video forgery are costly; there is a need for weakly supervised methods that can localize localized and intermittent manipulations using only video-level labels.

Method: Train a Masked Autoencoder on authentic videos to learn normal spatiotemporal patterns. Forgery segments yield larger reconstruction errors, serving as localization cues. Introduce Asymmetric Intra-video Contrastive Loss to encourage authentic feature compactness guided by reconstruction cues, creating a stable decision boundary and improving local discrimination while generalizing to unseen forgeries.

Result: Extensive experiments on large-scale datasets, including LAV-DF, show RT-DeepLoc achieves state-of-the-art performance in weakly supervised temporal forgery localization.

Conclusion: Reconstruction-based weak supervision combined with AICL effectively localizes forgeries under weak supervision, with strong empirical performance and potential for generalization to unseen manipulations; further work could explore robustness to diverse manipulation types and parameter sensitivity.

Abstract: Modern deepfakes have evolved into localized and intermittent manipulations that require fine-grained temporal localization. The prohibitive cost of frame-level annotation makes weakly supervised methods a practical necessity, which rely only on video-level labels. To this end, we propose Reconstruction-based Temporal Deepfake Localization (RT-DeepLoc), a weakly supervised temporal forgery localization framework that identifies forgeries via reconstruction errors. Our framework uses a Masked Autoencoder (MAE) trained exclusively on authentic data to learn its intrinsic spatiotemporal patterns; this allows the model to produce significant reconstruction discrepancies for forged segments, effectively providing the missing fine-grained cues for localization. To robustly leverage these indicators, we introduce a novel Asymmetric Intra-video Contrastive Loss (AICL). By focusing on the compactness of authentic features guided by these reconstruction cues, AICL establishes a stable decision boundary that enhances local discrimination while preserving generalization to unseen forgeries. Extensive experiments on large-scale datasets, including LAV-DF, demonstrate that RT-DeepLoc achieves state-of-the-art performance in weakly-supervised temporal forgery localization.

</details>


### [37] [Hypernetwork-Based Adaptive Aggregation for Multimodal Multiple-Instance Learning in Predicting Coronary Calcium Debulking](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21479)
*Kaito Shiku,Ichika Seo,Tetsuya Matoba,Rissei Hino,Yasuhiro Nakano,Ryoma Bise*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: First MIL attempt to estimate the necessity of debulking coronary artery calcifications from CT images using a hypernetwork-conditioned adaptive aggregation transformer (HyperAdAgFormer); incorporates tabular patient data; code available.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Physician device-use decisions rely on patient-specific tabular data, which standard MIL on imaging alone may not capture; there is a need for adaptive aggregation that leverages non-imaging data to inform decisions.

Method: Propose HyperAdAgFormer, a hypernetwork that generates per-patient aggregation parameters for a transformer-based MIL, conditioned on tabular data to adapt the feature aggregation strategy for each patient.

Result: Clinical dataset experiments demonstrate effectiveness of HyperAdAgFormer; code publicly available at the provided GitHub link.

Conclusion: The work presents a first attempt at patient-specific adaptive MIL for device-use decisions from CT images and shows feasibility of integrating tabular data into MIL; releases code for reproducibility.

Abstract: In this paper, we present the first attempt to estimate the necessity of debulking coronary artery calcifications from computed tomography (CT) images. We formulate this task as a Multiple-instance Learning (MIL) problem. The difficulty of this task lies in that physicians adjust their focus and decision criteria for device usage according to tabular data representing each patient's condition. To address this issue, we propose a hypernetwork-based adaptive aggregation transformer (HyperAdAgFormer), which adaptively modifies the feature aggregation strategy for each patient based on tabular data through a hypernetwork. The experiments using the clinical dataset demonstrated the effectiveness of HyperAdAgFormer. The code is publicly available at https://github.com/Shiku-Kaito/HyperAdAgFormer.

</details>


### [38] [SimGraph: A Unified Framework for Scene Graph-Based Image Generation and Editing](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21498)
*Thanh-Nhan Vo,Trong-Thuan Nguyen,Tam V. Nguyen,Minh-Triet Tran*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: SimGraph is a unified scene-graph-driven framework that combines token-based generation and diffusion-based editing for image generation and editing, enabling precise control over object interactions, layouts, and spatial coherence, and it outperforms current SOTA methods.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current GenAI image generation and editing approaches are often treated as separate tasks, causing inefficiencies and difficulties in maintaining spatial consistency and semantic coherence; scene graph representations offer structured control over object relations and layouts, but there is a lack of a unified framework that leverages this for both generation and editing.

Method: Propose SimGraph, a single model that uses a scene-graph representation to guide both generation and editing. It integrates token-based generation and diffusion-based editing within a single scene-graph-driven framework, ensuring precise control over object interactions and spatial arrangements.

Result: Extensive experiments demonstrate that SimGraph outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods, delivering high-quality, consistent results with improved spatial coherence and semantic alignment between content and edits.

Conclusion: A unified scene-graph-driven framework enables precise control over object interactions and layouts across generation and editing tasks, yielding high-quality, coherent results that surpass existing approaches.

Abstract: Recent advancements in Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) have significantly enhanced the capabilities of both image generation and editing. However, current approaches often treat these tasks separately, leading to inefficiencies and challenges in maintaining spatial consistency and semantic coherence between generated content and edits. Moreover, a major obstacle is the lack of structured control over object relationships and spatial arrangements. Scene graph-based methods, which represent objects and their interrelationships in a structured format, offer a solution by providing greater control over composition and interactions in both image generation and editing. To address this, we introduce SimGraph, a unified framework that integrates scene graph-based image generation and editing, enabling precise control over object interactions, layouts, and spatial coherence. In particular, our framework integrates token-based generation and diffusion-based editing within a single scene graph-driven model, ensuring high-quality and consistent results. Through extensive experiments, we empirically demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods.

</details>


### [39] [HERS: Hidden-Pattern Expert Learning for Risk-Specific Vehicle Damage Adaptation in Diffusion Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21517)
*Teerapong Panboonyuen*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: HERS: domain-specific expert adaptation for diffusion-generated vehicle-damage images; improves fidelity, controllability, and domain alignment via per-damage experts and self-supervised data; gains observed across four backbones; discusses safety implications for auto-insurance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Mitigate misuse and unreliability of text-to-image diffusion in auto-insurance workflows by enabling high-fidelity, controllable, and auditable damage imagery through domain-aligned generation.

Method: Fine-tune a base diffusion model with domain-specific experts: train separate experts for each damage category (dents, scratches, broken lights, cracked paint) using self-supervised image-text pairs generated by an LLM and a T2I pipeline; integrate experts into a unified multi-damage model that balances specialization and generalization; validate across four diffusion backbones.

Result: Consistent improvements: +5.5% in text faithfulness and +2.3% in human preference over baselines; improvements observed across all four backbones; discussion extends to fraud detection, auditability, and safe deployment.

Conclusion: Demonstrates a feasible approach to domain-aligned, high-stakes diffusion generation; highlights opportunities for trustworthy automation in insurance while also acknowledging risks and governance needs.

Abstract: Recent advances in text-to-image (T2I) diffusion models have enabled increasingly realistic synthesis of vehicle damage, raising concerns about their reliability in automated insurance workflows. The ability to generate crash-like imagery challenges the boundary between authentic and synthetic data, introducing new risks of misuse in fraud or claim manipulation. To address these issues, we propose HERS (Hidden-Pattern Expert Learning for Risk-Specific Damage Adaptation), a framework designed to improve fidelity, controllability, and domain alignment of diffusion-generated damage images. HERS fine-tunes a base diffusion model via domain-specific expert adaptation without requiring manual annotation. Using self-supervised image-text pairs automatically generated by a large language model and T2I pipeline, HERS models each damage category, such as dents, scratches, broken lights, or cracked paint, as a separate expert. These experts are later integrated into a unified multi-damage model that balances specialization with generalization. We evaluate HERS across four diffusion backbones and observe consistent improvements: plus 5.5 percent in text faithfulness and plus 2.3 percent in human preference ratings compared to baselines. Beyond image fidelity, we discuss implications for fraud detection, auditability, and safe deployment of generative models in high-stakes domains. Our findings highlight both the opportunities and risks of domain-specific diffusion, underscoring the importance of trustworthy generation in safety-critical applications such as auto insurance.

</details>


### [40] [Causal World Modeling for Robot Control](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21998)
*Lin Li,Qihang Zhang,Yiming Luo,Shuai Yang,Ruilin Wang,Fei Han,Mingrui Yu,Zelin Gao,Nan Xue,Xing Zhu,Yujun Shen,Yinghao Xu*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: LingBot-VA is an autoregressive diffusion framework that jointly learns frame prediction and policy execution for robots, using a shared latent space with vision-action tokens, a Mixture-of-Transformers, closed-loop rollout, and asynchronous inference; it achieves strong long-horizon manipulation and data efficiency with good generalization, and its code is released for the community.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To establish a robust, integrative foundation for robot learning by leveraging video world modeling and vision-language pre-training, enabling the robot to imagine near-future outcomes and understand causality between actions and visual dynamics.

Method: Propose LingBot-VA, an autoregressive diffusion model with three design pillars: (1) a shared latent space combining vision and action tokens via a Mixture-of-Transformers, (2) a closed-loop rollout mechanism for continual environmental feedback with ground-truth observations, and (3) an asynchronous inference pipeline that parallelizes action prediction and motor execution for efficient control.

Result: Evaluated on both simulation benchmarks and real-world scenarios, showing promise in long-horizon manipulation, data efficiency after training, and strong generalization to novel configurations.

Conclusion: Code and model are publicly available, enabling community use and further development of video world modeling for robot learning.

Abstract: This work highlights that video world modeling, alongside vision-language pre-training, establishes a fresh and independent foundation for robot learning. Intuitively, video world models provide the ability to imagine the near future by understanding the causality between actions and visual dynamics. Inspired by this, we introduce LingBot-VA, an autoregressive diffusion framework that learns frame prediction and policy execution simultaneously. Our model features three carefully crafted designs: (1) a shared latent space, integrating vision and action tokens, driven by a Mixture-of-Transformers (MoT) architecture, (2) a closed-loop rollout mechanism, allowing for ongoing acquisition of environmental feedback with ground-truth observations, (3) an asynchronous inference pipeline, parallelizing action prediction and motor execution to support efficient control. We evaluate our model on both simulation benchmarks and real-world scenarios, where it shows significant promise in long-horizon manipulation, data efficiency in post-training, and strong generalizability to novel configurations. The code and model are made publicly available to facilitate the community.

</details>


### [41] [Vision KAN: Towards an Attention-Free Backbone for Vision with Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21541)
*Zhuoqin Yang,Jiansong Zhang,Xiaoling Luo,Xu Wu,Zheng Lu,Linlin Shen*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: ViK is an attention-free vision backbone that uses MultiPatch-RBFKAN to enable efficient token mixing with linear complexity, achieving competitive ImageNet-1K accuracy and offering a theoretically grounded alternative to attention.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the quadratic complexity and limited interpretability of attention mechanisms in vision transformers, by exploring an attention-free architecture that can still model long-range dependencies.

Method: Introduce Vision KAN (ViK) with MultiPatch-RBFKAN as the core token mixer. It combines (i) patch-wise nonlinear transform with Radial Basis Function-based Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KANs), (ii) axis-wise separable mixing for efficient local propagation, and (iii) low-rank global mapping for long-range interactions. A patch-wise grouping strategy with lightweight operators enables ViK to be a drop-in replacement for attention modules while reducing the cost of full KANs on high-resolution features.

Result: On ImageNet-1K, ViK achieves competitive accuracy with linear (i.e., O(N)) complexity, demonstrating that KAN-based token mixing can serve as an efficient, theoretically grounded alternative to attention.

Conclusion: KAN-based token mixing in ViK offers a promising, scalable, and interpretable alternative to attention for vision backbones, validating the potential of attention-free architectures and highlighting directions for efficient long-range interaction modeling.

Abstract: Attention mechanisms have become a key module in modern vision backbones due to their ability to model long-range dependencies. However, their quadratic complexity in sequence length and the difficulty of interpreting attention weights limit both scalability and clarity. Recent attention-free architectures demonstrate that strong performance can be achieved without pairwise attention, motivating the search for alternatives. In this work, we introduce Vision KAN (ViK), an attention-free backbone inspired by the Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks. At its core lies MultiPatch-RBFKAN, a unified token mixer that combines (a) patch-wise nonlinear transform with Radial Basis Function-based KANs, (b) axis-wise separable mixing for efficient local propagation, and (c) low-rank global mapping for long-range interaction. Employing as a drop-in replacement for attention modules, this formulation tackles the prohibitive cost of full KANs on high-resolution features by adopting a patch-wise grouping strategy with lightweight operators to restore cross-patch dependencies. Experiments on ImageNet-1K show that ViK achieves competitive accuracy with linear complexity, demonstrating the potential of KAN-based token mixing as an efficient and theoretically grounded alternative to attention.

</details>


### [42] [Bi-Anchor Interpolation Solver for Accelerating Generative Modeling](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21542)
*Hongxu Chen,Hongxiang Li,Zhen Wang,Long Chen*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: BA-solver introduces a lightweight SideNet to accelerate Flow Matching-based generation by densifying trajectories via bidirectional temporal perception and bi-anchor velocity integration. It achieves high-quality samples with 5–10 NFEs, maintains negligible training cost, and remains plug-and-play-compatible with existing pipelines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Flow Matching (FM) models rely on iterative ODE solving, which incurs a latency bottleneck. Training-free solvers degrade at low NFEs, while training-based methods incur high costs and lack versatility. A method that blends speed, accuracy, and plug-and-play compatibility is needed.

Method: BA-solver uses a frozen backbone for high-precision anchors and a lightweight SideNet (1-2% of backbone) trained to provide bidirectional velocity estimates. It employs Bi-Anchor Velocity Integration, leveraging two anchor velocities to approximate intermediate velocities for high-order integration. The backbone supplies anchors; SideNet densifies the trajectory to enable large intervals with minimal error.

Result: Empirical evaluation on ImageNet-256^2 shows BA-solver delivers generation quality comparable to 100+ NFEs of Euler solver using only 10 NFEs, with high fidelity achievable at 5 NFEs. It incurs negligible training costs and integrates seamlessly with existing generative pipelines.

Conclusion: BA-solver offers a versatile, efficient, plug-and-play acceleration for FM-based generation. It achieves substantial speedups with limited training overhead and preserves high generation quality, enabling practical deployment and downstream tasks such as image editing.

Abstract: Flow Matching (FM) models have emerged as a leading paradigm for high-fidelity synthesis. However, their reliance on iterative Ordinary Differential Equation (ODE) solving creates a significant latency bottleneck. Existing solutions face a dichotomy: training-free solvers suffer from significant performance degradation at low Neural Function Evaluations (NFEs), while training-based one- or few-steps generation methods incur prohibitive training costs and lack plug-and-play versatility. To bridge this gap, we propose the Bi-Anchor Interpolation Solver (BA-solver). BA-solver retains the versatility of standard training-free solvers while achieving significant acceleration by introducing a lightweight SideNet (1-2% backbone size) alongside the frozen backbone. Specifically, our method is founded on two synergistic components: \textbf{1) Bidirectional Temporal Perception}, where the SideNet learns to approximate both future and historical velocities without retraining the heavy backbone; and 2) Bi-Anchor Velocity Integration, which utilizes the SideNet with two anchor velocities to efficiently approximate intermediate velocities for batched high-order integration. By utilizing the backbone to establish high-precision ``anchors'' and the SideNet to densify the trajectory, BA-solver enables large interval sizes with minimized error. Empirical results on ImageNet-256^2 demonstrate that BA-solver achieves generation quality comparable to 100+ NFEs Euler solver in just 10 NFEs and maintains high fidelity in as few as 5 NFEs, incurring negligible training costs. Furthermore, BA-solver ensures seamless integration with existing generative pipelines, facilitating downstream tasks such as image editing.

</details>


### [43] [Unifying Heterogeneous Degradations: Uncertainty-Aware Diffusion Bridge Model for All-in-One Image Restoration](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21592)
*Luwei Tu,Jiawei Wu,Xing Luo,Zhi Jin*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Uncertainty-aware diffusion bridge reformulates AiOIR as a stochastic transport problem with relaxed constraints and dual modulation, enabling single-pass, state-of-the-art restoration across diverse degradations.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: AiOIR must reconcile conflicting objectives from heterogeneous degradations; existing coarse control and fixed schedules yield suboptimal adaptation. A principled, uncertainty-aware framework is needed to unify restoration tasks.

Method: Introduce UDBM: a diffusion-bridge with relaxed terminal constraint to model degradation uncertainty and resolve drift singularity. Employ dual modulation: (1) a noise schedule that maps diverse degradations into a shared high-entropy latent space, (2) a path schedule that adaptively regulates transport dynamics via entropy-regularization-inspired viscous effects.

Result: Achieves state-of-the-art restoration performance across diverse tasks in a single inference step.

Conclusion: UDBM rectifies transport geometry/dynamics under uncertainty, providing a theoretically grounded, unified AiOIR framework that handles heterogeneous degradations more effectively than prior methods.

Abstract: All-in-One Image Restoration (AiOIR) faces the fundamental challenge in reconciling conflicting optimization objectives across heterogeneous degradations. Existing methods are often constrained by coarse-grained control mechanisms or fixed mapping schedules, yielding suboptimal adaptation. To address this, we propose an Uncertainty-Aware Diffusion Bridge Model (UDBM), which innovatively reformulates AiOIR as a stochastic transport problem steered by pixel-wise uncertainty. By introducing a relaxed diffusion bridge formulation which replaces the strict terminal constraint with a relaxed constraint, we model the uncertainty of degradations while theoretically resolving the drift singularity inherent in standard diffusion bridges. Furthermore, we devise a dual modulation strategy: the noise schedule aligns diverse degradations into a shared high-entropy latent space, while the path schedule adaptively regulates the transport trajectory motivated by the viscous dynamics of entropy regularization. By effectively rectifying the transport geometry and dynamics, UDBM achieves state-of-the-art performance across diverse restoration tasks within a single inference step.

</details>


### [44] [HydroSense: A Dual-Microcontroller IoT Framework for Real-Time Multi-Parameter Water Quality Monitoring with Edge Processing and Cloud Analytics](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21595)
*Abdul Hasib,A. S. M. Ahsanul Sarkar Akib,Anish Giri*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: HydroSense is an IoT-based six-parameter water-quality monitor using a dual-MCU design (Arduino Uno for precise analog sensing with five-point pH calibration; ESP32 for wireless edge processing and cloud integration). It features median-filtered TDS, temperature compensation, robust error handling, and Firebase real-time database. Validated over 90 days with high accuracy and 99.8% cloud reliability, at ≈$300 cost, about 85% cheaper than commercial systems.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address the global water crisis by delivering affordable, accurate, and real-time water quality monitoring in resource-constrained environments, overcoming the limitations of manual sampling and expensive commercial systems.

Method: A dual-microcontroller architecture: Arduino Uno handles precision analog measurements with five-point calibrations; ESP32 provides wireless connectivity, edge processing, and cloud integration. Six parameters are monitored (pH, DO, temperature, TDS, estimated nitrogen, water level). Signal processing includes median filtering for TDS, temperature compensation, and robust error handling. Data are transmitted to Firebase Real-time Database.

Result: Experimental validation over 90 days shows pH accuracy ±0.08 units (0–14), DO ±0.2 mg/L, TDS ±1.9% (0–1000 ppm); cloud transmission reliability 99.8%. Total cost ~32,983 BDT (~$300); ~85% cost reduction vs commercial systems.

Conclusion: HydroSense demonstrates that professional-grade water-quality assessment can be achieved through intelligent system architecture and cost-effective components, establishing a new paradigm for accessible environmental monitoring.

Abstract: The global water crisis necessitates affordable, accurate, and real-time water quality monitoring solutions. Traditional approaches relying on manual sampling or expensive commercial systems fail to address accessibility challenges in resource-constrained environments. This paper presents HydroSense, an innovative Internet of Things framework that integrates six critical water quality parameters including pH, dissolved oxygen (DO), temperature, total dissolved solids (TDS), estimated nitrogen, and water level into a unified monitoring system. HydroSense employs a novel dual-microcontroller architecture, utilizing Arduino Uno for precision analog measurements with five-point calibration algorithms and ESP32 for wireless connectivity, edge processing, and cloud integration. The system implements advanced signal processing techniques including median filtering for TDS measurement, temperature compensation algorithms, and robust error handling. Experimental validation over 90 days demonstrates exceptional performance metrics: pH accuracy of plus or minus 0.08 units across the 0 to 14 range, DO measurement stability within plus or minus 0.2 mg/L, TDS accuracy of plus or minus 1.9 percent across 0 to 1000 ppm, and 99.8 percent cloud data transmission reliability. With a total implementation cost of 32,983 BDT (approximately 300 USD), HydroSense achieves an 85 percent cost reduction compared to commercial systems while providing enhanced connectivity through the Firebase real-time database. This research establishes a new paradigm for accessible environmental monitoring, demonstrating that professional-grade water quality assessment can be achieved through intelligent system architecture and cost-effective component selection.

</details>


### [45] [WMVLM: Evaluating Diffusion Model Image Watermarking via Vision-Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21610)
*Zijin Yang,Yu Sun,Kejiang Chen,Jiawei Zhao,Jun Jiang,Weiming Zhang,Nenghai Yu*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A unified, interpretable evaluation framework (WMVLM) for diffusion-model image watermarking via vision-language models, featuring residual and semantic watermark metrics, a three-stage training pipeline, and strong generalization across datasets and methods.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current evaluation methods lack a unified framework for residual and semantic watermarks, interpretability, and comprehensive security considerations in diffusion-model watermarking; existing metrics are often inappropriate for semantic watermarks.

Method: Introduce WMVLM, redefine quality/security metrics (artifact strength and erasure resistance for residual watermarks; latent distribution shifts for semantic watermarks), and implement a three-stage training strategy to enable classification, scoring, and interpretable text generation in a VLM-based evaluator; validate generalization across datasets, diffusion models, and watermarking methods.

Result: WMVLM outperforms state-of-the-art VLMs and generalizes well across datasets, diffusion models, and watermarking methods.

Conclusion: WMVLM provides a unified, interpretable framework for evaluating diffusion-model image watermarking, addressing previous gaps and enabling robust, generalizable assessment across watermark types.

Abstract: Digital watermarking is essential for securing generated images from diffusion models. Accurate watermark evaluation is critical for algorithm development, yet existing methods have significant limitations: they lack a unified framework for both residual and semantic watermarks, provide results without interpretability, neglect comprehensive security considerations, and often use inappropriate metrics for semantic watermarks. To address these gaps, we propose WMVLM, the first unified and interpretable evaluation framework for diffusion model image watermarking via vision-language models (VLMs). We redefine quality and security metrics for each watermark type: residual watermarks are evaluated by artifact strength and erasure resistance, while semantic watermarks are assessed through latent distribution shifts. Moreover, we introduce a three-stage training strategy to progressively enable the model to achieve classification, scoring, and interpretable text generation. Experiments show WMVLM outperforms state-of-the-art VLMs with strong generalization across datasets, diffusion models, and watermarking methods.

</details>


### [46] [PathReasoner-R1: Instilling Structured Reasoning into Pathology Vision-Language Model via Knowledge-Guided Policy Optimization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21617)
*Songhan Jiang,Fengchun Liu,Ziyue Wang,Linghan Cai,Yongbing Zhang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: PathReasoner introduces PathReasoner, a large-scale WSI reasoning dataset, and PathReasoner-R1, a model trained with trajectory-masked supervised fine-tuning and reasoning-oriented reinforcement learning, guided by knowledge graphs to produce verifiable, chain-of-thought reasoning for pathology. It claims state-of-the-art results and provides dataset/code.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address lack of verifiable, evidence-linked reasoning in vision-language models for pathology, which undermines clinical trust and error rectification.

Method: Create PathReasoner dataset via a knowledge-guided generation pipeline using medical knowledge graphs to align findings and diagnoses; train PathReasoner-R1 with trajectory-masked supervised fine-tuning and reasoning-oriented RL; apply a knowledge-aware multi-granular reward with an Entity Reward aligned to knowledge graphs to enforce logical consistency.

Result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance on PathReasoner and public benchmarks across multiple image scales; demonstrates transparent, clinically grounded reasoning; dataset and code are available.

Conclusion: PathReasoner-R1 provides robust, interpretable reasoning for pathology VLMs, enabling clinical trust and error rectification; the approach integrates explicit knowledge graphs and structured reasoning into training and evaluation.

Abstract: Vision-Language Models (VLMs) are advancing computational pathology with superior visual understanding capabilities. However, current systems often reduce diagnosis to directly output conclusions without verifiable evidence-linked reasoning, which severely limits clinical trust and hinders expert error rectification. To address these barriers, we construct PathReasoner, the first large-scale dataset of whole-slide image (WSI) reasoning. Unlike previous work reliant on unverified distillation, we develop a rigorous knowledge-guided generation pipeline. By leveraging medical knowledge graphs, we explicitly align structured pathological findings and clinical reasoning with diagnoses, generating over 20K high-quality instructional samples. Based on the database, we propose PathReasoner-R1, which synergizes trajectory-masked supervised fine-tuning with reasoning-oriented reinforcement learning to instill structured chain-of-thought capabilities. To ensure medical rigor, we engineer a knowledge-aware multi-granular reward function incorporating an Entity Reward mechanism strictly aligned with knowledge graphs. This effectively guides the model to optimize for logical consistency rather than mere outcome matching, thereby enhancing robustness. Extensive experiments demonstrate that PathReasoner-R1 achieves state-of-the-art performance on both PathReasoner and public benchmarks across various image scales, equipping pathology models with transparent, clinically grounded reasoning capabilities. Dataset and code are available at https://github.com/cyclexfy/PathReasoner-R1.

</details>


### [47] [Similarity of Processing Steps in Vision Model Representations](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21621)
*Matéo Mahaut,Marco Baroni*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: The paper investigates how vision models converge to similar representations, focusing on the intermediate steps and processes that lead to convergence. It quantifies how representations evolve across layers and models to identify where they differ most.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand not just end-state representation convergence across models, but the dynamics and intermediate steps that produce similar representations across different architectures, objectives, datasets, and modalities.

Method: Quantify distances between model representations at multiple stages across different models (e.g., CNNs, Transformers, and classifier heads). Track the evolution of these distances through layers to identify steps with the greatest divergence; compare intra-model layer progression for CNNs vs. Transformers.

Result: Layers at similar positions across models show the most similar representations, but substantial differences remain. Classifier models tend to discard low-level image statistics in their final layers. Transformers exhibit smoother layer-to-layer changes in representations, while CNNs show a different progression, highlighting distinct dynamical paths to convergence.

Conclusion: The work delineates the level and nature of representation convergence and provides a qualitative account of the intermediate processes in image models that lead to similar end-state representations across architectures.

Abstract: Recent literature suggests that the bigger the model, the more likely it is to converge to similar, ``universal'' representations, despite different training objectives, datasets, or modalities. While this literature shows that there is an area where model representations are similar, we study here how vision models might get to those representations -- in particular, do they also converge to the same intermediate steps and operations? We therefore study the processes that lead to convergent representations in different models. First, we quantify distance between different model representations at different stages. We follow the evolution of distances between models throughout processing, identifying the processing steps which are most different between models. We find that while layers at similar positions in different models have the most similar representations, strong differences remain. Classifier models, unlike the others, will discard information about low-level image statistics in their final layers. CNN- and transformer-based models also behave differently, with transformer models applying smoother changes to representations from one layer to the next. These distinctions clarify the level and nature of convergence between model representations, and enables a more qualitative account of the underlying processes in image models.

</details>


### [48] [A Tilted Seesaw: Revisiting Autoencoder Trade-off for Controllable Diffusion](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21633)
*Pu Cao,Yiyang Ma,Feng Zhou,Xuedan Yin,Qing Song,Lu Yang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: ImageNet-scale autoencoders biased toward gFID over reconstruction; this skews AE selection and harms controllability due to condition drift; reconstruction fidelity, especially instance-level, better predicts controllability; gFID weakly predicts condition preservation; empirical validation with multiple ImageNet AEs and ControlNet supports this; implies benchmarking should prioritize reconstruction and condition-preservation metrics.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Explain why gFID-dominant AE evaluation can be misleading for scalable controllable diffusion and how condition drift affects controllability; propose evaluation approaches that align with controllability needs.

Method: Theoretical analysis of how autoencoders induce condition drift; design of a multi-dimensional condition-drift evaluation protocol; empirical tests on several ImageNet AEs; controlNet experiments to measure controllability; comparison of gFID vs reconstruction metrics as predictors of condition preservation.

Result: gFID is only weakly predictive of condition preservation; reconstruction-oriented metrics (particularly instance-level) strongly align with controllability; tilting AE selection toward gFID degrades controllability; ControlNet experiments confirm condition-preservation as the key driver of controllability.

Conclusion: There is a gap between ImageNet-centric AE evaluation and requirements of scalable controllable diffusion; benchmarking should prioritize reconstruction fidelity and condition-preservation; adopt multi-dimensional drift assessment for reliable model selection.

Abstract: In latent diffusion models, the autoencoder (AE) is typically expected to balance two capabilities: faithful reconstruction and a generation-friendly latent space (e.g., low gFID). In recent ImageNet-scale AE studies, we observe a systematic bias toward generative metrics in handling this trade-off: reconstruction metrics are increasingly under-reported, and ablation-based AE selection often favors the best-gFID configuration even when reconstruction fidelity degrades. We theoretically analyze why this gFID-dominant preference can appear unproblematic for ImageNet generation, yet becomes risky when scaling to controllable diffusion: AEs can induce condition drift, which limits achievable condition alignment. Meanwhile, we find that reconstruction fidelity, especially instance-level measures, better indicates controllability. We empirically validate the impact of tilted autoencoder evaluation on controllability by studying several recent ImageNet AEs. Using a multi-dimensional condition-drift evaluation protocol reflecting controllable generation tasks, we find that gFID is only weakly predictive of condition preservation, whereas reconstruction-oriented metrics are substantially more aligned. ControlNet experiments further confirm that controllability tracks condition preservation rather than gFID. Overall, our results expose a gap between ImageNet-centric AE evaluation and the requirements of scalable controllable diffusion, offering practical guidance for more reliable benchmarking and model selection.

</details>


### [49] [RSGround-R1: Rethinking Remote Sensing Visual Grounding through Spatial Reasoning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21634)
*Shiqi Huang,Shuting He,Bihan Wen*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A post-training framework, RSGround-R1, enhances spatial reasoning for remote sensing visual grounding by chain-of-thought supervised fine-tuning with synthetic data, reinforced fine-tuning with a positional reward, and a spatial-consistency optimization to ensure coherent localization.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Remote sensing imagery is vast in scale with high semantic ambiguity, causing descriptions to lean on positional cues. Standard multimodal models struggle with precise spatial localization in this domain, necessitating targeted spatial reasoning.

Method: 1) CoT-SFT using synthetically generated RSVG reasoning data to instill explicit position awareness. 2) Reinforcement Fine-Tuning (RFT) with a novel positional reward that provides continuous, distance-aware localization guidance. 3) Spatial consistency guided optimization that adapts policy updates based on spatial coherence to stabilize rollouts across training.

Result: Extensive experiments on RSVG benchmarks show superior performance and better generalization compared to baselines.

Conclusion: RSGround-R1 effectively enhances spatial understanding for RS visual grounding, yielding robust, coherent localization and improved generalization in large-scale aerial scenes.

Abstract: Remote Sensing Visual Grounding (RSVG) aims to localize target objects in large-scale aerial imagery based on natural language descriptions. Owing to the vast spatial scale and high semantic ambiguity of remote sensing scenes, these descriptions often rely heavily on positional cues, posing unique challenges for Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) in spatial reasoning. To leverage this unique feature, we propose a reasoning-guided, position-aware post-training framework, dubbed \textbf{RSGround-R1}, to progressively enhance spatial understanding. Specifically, we first introduce Chain-of-Thought Supervised Fine-Tuning (CoT-SFT) using synthetically generated RSVG reasoning data to establish explicit position awareness. Reinforcement Fine-Tuning (RFT) is then applied, augmented by our newly designed positional reward that provides continuous and distance-aware guidance toward accurate localization. Moreover, to mitigate incoherent localization behaviors across rollouts, we introduce a spatial consistency guided optimization scheme that dynamically adjusts policy updates based on their spatial coherence, ensuring stable and robust convergence. Extensive experiments on RSVG benchmarks demonstrate superior performance and generalization of our model.

</details>


### [50] [OCRVerse: Towards Holistic OCR in End-to-End Vision-Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21639)
*Yufeng Zhong,Lei Chen,Xuanle Zhao,Wenkang Han,Liming Zheng,Jing Huang,Deyang Jiang,Yilin Cao,Lin Ma,Zhixiong Zeng*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: OCRVerse is a unified, end-to-end OCR model that handles both text-centric (documents) and vision-centric (charts, web pages, scientific plots) data. It uses a two-stage SFT-RL training regime to fuse cross-domain knowledge while allowing domain-specific rewards.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To fill the gap between traditional text-centric OCR and the demand to extract information from visually dense images common on the web and in science, enabling a single model for diverse multimodal OCR tasks.

Method: Develop comprehensive data engineering for both text-centric documents and vision-centric composites; employ a two-stage training: supervised fine-tuning (SFT) on mixed-domain data to bootstrap cross-domain knowledge, followed by reinforcement learning (RL) with domain-specific reward signals to tailor outputs for each domain and support flexible reward design during cross-domain fusion.

Result: OCRVerse achieves competitive performance on both text-centric and vision-centric data, approaching or matching large-scale open-source and closed-source models.

Conclusion: A holistic end-to-end OCR framework is feasible for extracting text and visual elements across dense images; the SFT-RL training strategy enables effective cross-domain generalization and customizable domain outputs.

Abstract: The development of large vision language models drives the demand for managing, and applying massive amounts of multimodal data, making OCR technology, which extracts information from visual images, increasingly popular. However, existing OCR methods primarily focus on recognizing text elements from images or scanned documents (\textbf{Text-centric OCR}), neglecting the identification of visual elements from visually information-dense image sources (\textbf{Vision-centric OCR}), such as charts, web pages and science plots. In reality, these visually information-dense images are widespread on the internet and have significant real-world application value, such as data visualization and web page analysis. In this technical report, we propose \textbf{OCRVerse}, the first holistic OCR method in end-to-end manner that enables unified text-centric OCR and vision-centric OCR. To this end, we constructe comprehensive data engineering to cover a wide range of text-centric documents, such as newspapers, magazines and books, as well as vision-centric rendered composites, including charts, web pages and scientific plots. Moreover, we propose a two-stage SFT-RL multi-domain training method for OCRVerse. SFT directly mixes cross-domain data to train and establish initial domain knowledge, while RL focuses on designing personalized reward strategies for the characteristics of each domain. Specifically, since different domains require various output formats and expected outputs, we provide sufficient flexibility in the RL stage to customize flexible reward signals for each domain, thereby improving cross-domain fusion and avoiding data conflicts. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of OCRVerse, achieving competitive results across text-centric and vision-centric data types, even comparable to large-scale open-source and closed-source models.

</details>


### [51] [CAF-Mamba: Mamba-Based Cross-Modal Adaptive Attention Fusion for Multimodal Depression Detection](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21648)
*Bowen Zhou,Marc-André Fiedler,Ayoub Al-Hamadi*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: CAF-Mamba proposes a Mamba-based cross-modal adaptive attention fusion for depression detection, enabling explicit/implicit cross-modal interactions with dynamic modality weighting, achieving state-of-the-art results on LMVD and D-Vlog.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Depression is detectable via multiple modalities (e.g., audio, visual, text), but prior deep learning models use limited feature types, ignore cross-modal interactions, and rely on simple fusion; thus, there is a need for a fusion framework that models cross-modal interactions explicitly and adapts modality contributions dynamically for robust multimodal depression detection.

Method: CAF-Mamba introduces a Mamba-based cross-modal adaptive attention fusion framework. It captures cross-modal interactions explicitly and implicitly and employs a modality-wise attention mechanism to dynamically adjust the contribution of each modality, enabling effective multimodal fusion for depression detection.

Result: Empirical evaluation on two in-the-wild benchmarks, LMVD and D-Vlog, shows that CAF-Mamba consistently outperforms existing methods and achieves state-of-the-art performance.

Conclusion: The work advances multimodal depression detection by explicitly modeling cross-modal interactions and adopting adaptive fusion to weigh modalities according to their reliability. It demonstrates strong performance on diverse, in-the-wild datasets, suggesting good generalization; future work could explore ablations, robustness to noise, and broader modality sets.

Abstract: Depression is a prevalent mental health disorder that severely impairs daily functioning and quality of life. While recent deep learning approaches for depression detection have shown promise, most rely on limited feature types, overlook explicit cross-modal interactions, and employ simple concatenation or static weighting for fusion. To overcome these limitations, we propose CAF-Mamba, a novel Mamba-based cross-modal adaptive attention fusion framework. CAF-Mamba not only captures cross-modal interactions explicitly and implicitly, but also dynamically adjusts modality contributions through a modality-wise attention mechanism, enabling more effective multimodal fusion. Experiments on two in-the-wild benchmark datasets, LMVD and D-Vlog, demonstrate that CAF-Mamba consistently outperforms existing methods and achieves state-of-the-art performance.

</details>


### [52] [Few-Shot Domain Adaptation with Temporal References and Static Priors for Glacier Calving Front Delineation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21663)
*Marcel Dreier,Nora Gourmelon,Dakota Pyles,Thorsten Seehaus,Matthias H. Braun,Andreas Maier,Vincent Christlein*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Few-shot domain adaptation with priors and summer references dramatically improves glacier calving front delineation in a novel site, reducing error from ~1.13 km to ~69 m without changing model architecture.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Overcome domain shift when applying benchmark-trained delineation models to unseen study sites, enabling reliable, scalable calving-front monitoring.

Method: Apply a few-shot domain adaptation strategy, incorporate spatial static prior knowledge, and include summer reference images in the input time series; no architectural modifications.

Result: Delineation error decreased from 1131.6 m to 68.7 m.

Conclusion: The approach establishes a practical framework for generalizing deep learning-based calving-front segmentation to new sites, facilitating global-scale monitoring.

Abstract: During benchmarking, the state-of-the-art model for glacier calving front delineation achieves near-human performance. However, when applied in a real-world setting at a novel study site, its delineation accuracy is insufficient for calving front products intended for further scientific analyses. This site represents an out-of-distribution domain for a model trained solely on the benchmark dataset. By employing a few-shot domain adaptation strategy, incorporating spatial static prior knowledge, and including summer reference images in the input time series, the delineation error is reduced from 1131.6 m to 68.7 m without any architectural modifications. These methodological advancements establish a framework for applying deep learning-based calving front segmentation to novel study sites, enabling calving front monitoring on a global scale.

</details>


### [53] [When Gradient Optimization Is Not Enough: $\dagger$ Dispersive and Anchoring Geometric Regularizer for Multimodal Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21670)
*Zixuan Xia,Hao Wang,Pengcheng Weng,Yanyu Qian,Yangxin Xu,William Dan,Fei Wang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Proposes a geometry-aware regularization framework (REGName) for multimodal learning to address intra-modal representation collapse and cross-modal drift. It adds two plug-and-play constraints—intra-modal dispersive and inter-modal anchoring—on intermediate embeddings, improving both multimodal fusion and unimodal robustness without architectural changes.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Multimodal models often suffer from representation geometry pathologies such as intra-modal collapse and sample-level cross-modal drift, which degrade unimodal robustness and multimodal fusion. A robust control axis on geometry is lacking.

Method: Introduce REGName with two complementary, placement-on-embedding constraints: (1) intra-modal dispersive regularization to promote diversity within each modality, and (2) inter-modal anchoring regularization to bound cross-modal drift at the sample level without rigid alignment. The regularizer is lightweight, plug-and-play, architecture-agnostic, and compatible with various training paradigms.

Result: Empirical evaluations across multiple multimodal benchmarks show consistent improvements in both multimodal performance and unimodal robustness, indicating that geometry-aware regularization mitigates modality trade-offs and enhances overall representation quality.

Conclusion: Explicitly regulating representation geometry is effective for multimodal learning. REGName provides a lightweight, versatile, and easy-to-apply regularization framework that improves fusion and robustness without changing model architectures.

Abstract: Multimodal learning aims to integrate complementary information from heterogeneous modalities, yet strong optimization alone does not guaranty well-structured representations. Even under carefully balanced training schemes, multimodal models often exhibit geometric pathologies, including intra-modal representation collapse and sample-level cross-modal inconsistency, which degrade both unimodal robustness and multimodal fusion.
  We identify representation geometry as a missing control axis in multimodal learning and propose \regName, a lightweight geometry-aware regularization framework. \regName enforces two complementary constraints on intermediate embeddings: an intra-modal dispersive regularization that promotes representation diversity, and an inter-modal anchoring regularization that bounds sample-level cross-modal drift without rigid alignment. The proposed regularizer is plug-and-play, requires no architectural modifications, and is compatible with various training paradigms.
  Extensive experiments across multiple multimodal benchmarks demonstrate consistent improvements in both multimodal and unimodal performance, showing that explicitly regulating representation geometry effectively mitigates modality trade-offs.

</details>


### [54] [Multimodal Visual Surrogate Compression for Alzheimer's Disease Classification](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21673)
*Dexuan Ding,Ciyuan Peng,Endrowednes Kuantama,Jingcai Guo,Jia Wu,Jian Yang,Amin Beheshti,Ming-Hsuan Yang,Yuankai Qi*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: MVSC compresses 3D sMRI into compact 2D visual surrogates to enable efficient, discriminative AD classification by aligning with frozen 2D foundation models, using a Volume Context Encoder guided by text and an Adaptive Slice Fusion module.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address high computational cost of 3D CNNs, loss of cross-slice information in slice-wise methods, and limited discriminative power of 2D foundation-model features when applied to 3D MRI.

Method: Two-stage architecture: Volume Context Encoder captures global cross-slice context under textual guidance; Adaptive Slice Fusion aggregates slice-level features in a text-enhanced, patch-wise manner; compresses 3D volume into 2D visual surrogates optimized to work with frozen 2D foundation models. Evaluated on three AD benchmarks with binary and multi-class tasks.

Result: MVSC achieves favorable performance compared to state-of-the-art methods on three large-scale AD benchmarks for both binary and multi-class classification. (Details not provided in abstract).

Conclusion: MVSC provides a computationally efficient, cross-slice-aware representation learning approach by leveraging 2D foundation models through surrogate 2D features, showing promise across benchmarks and potential for broader applications.

Abstract: High-dimensional structural MRI (sMRI) images are widely used for Alzheimer's Disease (AD) diagnosis. Most existing methods for sMRI representation learning rely on 3D architectures (e.g., 3D CNNs), slice-wise feature extraction with late aggregation, or apply training-free feature extractions using 2D foundation models (e.g., DINO). However, these three paradigms suffer from high computational cost, loss of cross-slice relations, and limited ability to extract discriminative features, respectively. To address these challenges, we propose Multimodal Visual Surrogate Compression (MVSC). It learns to compress and adapt large 3D sMRI volumes into compact 2D features, termed as visual surrogates, which are better aligned with frozen 2D foundation models to extract powerful representations for final AD classification. MVSC has two key components: a Volume Context Encoder that captures global cross-slice context under textual guidance, and an Adaptive Slice Fusion module that aggregates slice-level information in a text-enhanced, patch-wise manner. Extensive experiments on three large-scale Alzheimer's disease benchmarks demonstrate our MVSC performs favourably on both binary and multi-class classification tasks compared against state-of-the-art methods.

</details>
