### [55] [ChartE$^{3}$: A Comprehensive Benchmark for End-to-End Chart Editing](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21694)
*Shuo Li,Jiajun Sun,Zhekai Wang,Xiaoran Fan,Hui Li,Dingwen Yang,Zhiheng Xi,Yijun Wang,Zifei Shan,Tao Gui,Qi Zhang,Xuanjing Huang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: ChartE^3 is a new end-to-end chart-editing benchmark that evaluates local (appearance) and global (data-centric) edits without relying on intermediate NL/code, using chart image, code, and multimodal instructions; results show gaps in SOTA models, especially for global edits.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: End-to-end chart editing is practical but challenging due to the need for fine-grained control and global consistency; existing pipeline-based approaches restrict faithful execution; a benchmark is needed to measure true end-to-end capability.

Method: Construct ChartE^3 with 1,200+ curated samples, each as (chart image, underlying code, multimodal editing instruction); two editing dimensions (local and global); data pipeline with human curation; evaluate state-of-the-art multimodal LLMs on these tasks.

Result: SOTA multimodal LLMs exhibit substantial performance gaps, especially on global editing tasks, indicating critical limitations in current end-to-end chart editing capabilities.

Conclusion: ChartE^3 provides a rigorous evaluation platform for end-to-end chart editing, underscoring the need for improved models that can perform holistic, data-centric edits without intermediate representations.

Abstract: Charts are a fundamental visualization format for structured data analysis. Enabling end-to-end chart editing according to user intent is of great practical value, yet remains challenging due to the need for both fine-grained control and global structural consistency. Most existing approaches adopt pipeline-based designs, where natural language or code serves as an intermediate representation, limiting their ability to faithfully execute complex edits. We introduce ChartE$^{3}$, an End-to-End Chart Editing benchmark that directly evaluates models without relying on intermediate natural language programs or code-level supervision. ChartE$^{3}$ focuses on two complementary editing dimensions: local editing, which involves fine-grained appearance changes such as font or color adjustments, and global editing, which requires holistic, data-centric transformations including data filtering and trend line addition. ChartE$^{3}$ contains over 1,200 high-quality samples constructed via a well-designed data pipeline with human curation. Each sample is provided as a triplet of a chart image, its underlying code, and a multimodal editing instruction, enabling evaluation from both objective and subjective perspectives. Extensive benchmarking of state-of-the-art multimodal large language models reveals substantial performance gaps, particularly on global editing tasks, highlighting critical limitations in current end-to-end chart editing capabilities.

</details>


### [56] [DreamActor-M2: Universal Character Image Animation via Spatiotemporal In-Context Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21716)
*Mingshuang Luo,Shuang Liang,Zhengkun Rong,Yuxuan Luo,Tianshu Hu,Ruibing Hou,Hong Chang,Yong Li,Yuan Zhang,Mingyuan Gao*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: DreamActor-M2: a universal, RGB-driven character animation framework that reinterprets motion conditioning as in-context learning, using a two-stage process (unified latent fusion of appearance and motion cues, plus a self-bootstrapped data synthesis pipeline) to improve identity preservation, motion consistency, and generalization across diverse characters; introduced AW Bench for evaluation; achieves state-of-the-art results.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address two core limitations: (1) suboptimal motion injection causing a trade-off between identity preservation and motion consistency, and (2) heavy reliance on explicit pose priors (e.g., skeletons) that fail to capture rich dynamics and hinder generalization to non-humanoid characters.

Method: Two-stage approach: (1) fuse reference appearance and motion cues into a unified latent space to enable joint reasoning about spatial identity and temporal dynamics using the priors of foundational generative models; (2) employ a self-bootstrapped data synthesis pipeline to create pseudo cross-identity training pairs, enabling a progression from pose-dependent control to end-to-end RGB-driven animation.

Result: Extensive experiments show DreamActor-M2 achieves state-of-the-art visual fidelity and robust cross-domain generalization across diverse characters and motions, outperforming prior methods.

Conclusion: DreamActor-M2 offers a universal animation framework capable of generalizing across character types and motion scenarios, supported by the AW Bench benchmark for comprehensive evaluation.

Abstract: Character image animation aims to synthesize high-fidelity videos by transferring motion from a driving sequence to a static reference image. Despite recent advancements, existing methods suffer from two fundamental challenges: (1) suboptimal motion injection strategies that lead to a trade-off between identity preservation and motion consistency, manifesting as a "see-saw", and (2) an over-reliance on explicit pose priors (e.g., skeletons), which inadequately capture intricate dynamics and hinder generalization to arbitrary, non-humanoid characters. To address these challenges, we present DreamActor-M2, a universal animation framework that reimagines motion conditioning as an in-context learning problem. Our approach follows a two-stage paradigm. First, we bridge the input modality gap by fusing reference appearance and motion cues into a unified latent space, enabling the model to jointly reason about spatial identity and temporal dynamics by leveraging the generative prior of foundational models. Second, we introduce a self-bootstrapped data synthesis pipeline that curates pseudo cross-identity training pairs, facilitating a seamless transition from pose-dependent control to direct, end-to-end RGB-driven animation. This strategy significantly enhances generalization across diverse characters and motion scenarios. To facilitate comprehensive evaluation, we further introduce AW Bench, a versatile benchmark encompassing a wide spectrum of characters types and motion scenarios. Extensive experiments demonstrate that DreamActor-M2 achieves state-of-the-art performance, delivering superior visual fidelity and robust cross-domain generalization. Project Page: https://grisoon.github.io/DreamActor-M2/

</details>


### [57] [From Global to Granular: Revealing IQA Model Performance via Correlation Surface](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21738)
*Baoliang Chen,Danni Huang,Hanwei Zhu,Lingyu Zhu,Wei Zhou,Shiqi Wang,Yuming Fang,Weisi Lin*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Introduces Granularity-Modulated Correlation (GMC) for IQA evaluation, producing a 3D correlation surface over MOS and |ΔMOS| to reveal local ranking behaviors hidden by global metrics.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Global correlation metrics (PLCC, SRCC) reduce model performance to a single scalar and fail to capture how ranking consistency varies across the MOS spectrum; they are sensitive to test-sample distributions, hindering cross-dataset comparisons. A fine-grained, distribution-aware analysis is needed.

Method: Granularity Modulator applies Gaussian-weighted correlations conditioned on absolute MOS values and pairwise MOS differences (|ΔMOS|) to analyze local performance variations; Distribution Regulator regularizes correlations to mitigate biases from non-uniform quality distributions; results are presented as a 3D correlation surface mapping correlation as a function of MOS and |ΔMOS|.

Result: GMC yields a correlation surface that uncovers local performance characteristics invisible to scalar metrics; experiments on standard IQA benchmarks demonstrate its diagnostic value and reliability; implementation code is released at GitHub.

Conclusion: GMC provides a more informative and reliable framework for analyzing, comparing, and deploying IQA models through a granularity-aware, distribution-regularized correlation analysis.

Abstract: Evaluation of Image Quality Assessment (IQA) models has long been dominated by global correlation metrics, such as Pearson Linear Correlation Coefficient (PLCC) and Spearman Rank-Order Correlation Coefficient (SRCC). While widely adopted, these metrics reduce performance to a single scalar, failing to capture how ranking consistency varies across the local quality spectrum. For example, two IQA models may achieve identical SRCC values, yet one ranks high-quality images (related to high Mean Opinion Score, MOS) more reliably, while the other better discriminates image pairs with small quality/MOS differences (related to $|Δ$MOS$|$). Such complementary behaviors are invisible under global metrics. Moreover, SRCC and PLCC are sensitive to test-sample quality distributions, yielding unstable comparisons across test sets. To address these limitations, we propose \textbf{Granularity-Modulated Correlation (GMC)}, which provides a structured, fine-grained analysis of IQA performance. GMC includes: (1) a \textbf{Granularity Modulator} that applies Gaussian-weighted correlations conditioned on absolute MOS values and pairwise MOS differences ($|Δ$MOS$|$) to examine local performance variations, and (2) a \textbf{Distribution Regulator} that regularizes correlations to mitigate biases from non-uniform quality distributions. The resulting \textbf{correlation surface} maps correlation values as a joint function of MOS and $|Δ$MOS$|$, providing a 3D representation of IQA performance. Experiments on standard benchmarks show that GMC reveals performance characteristics invisible to scalar metrics, offering a more informative and reliable paradigm for analyzing, comparing, and deploying IQA models. Codes are available at https://github.com/Dniaaa/GMC.

</details>


### [58] [Dynamic Topology Awareness: Breaking the Granularity Rigidity in Vision-Language Navigation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21751)
*Jiankun Peng,Jianyuan Guo,Ying Xu,Yue Liu,Jiashuang Yan,Xuanwei Ye,Houhua Li,Xiaoming Wang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: DGNav: Dynamic Topological Navigation for VLN-CE that resolves Granularity Rigidity via scene-aware graph densification and a Dynamic Graph Transformer. It adaptively modulates map density based on waypoint dispersion and fuses visual, linguistic, and geometric cues to compute dynamic edge weights, improving instruction adherence, safety, and generalization on R2R-CE and RxR-CE; code released.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Topological maps in Vision-Language Navigation in Continuous Environments (VLN-CE) suffer Granularity Rigidity due to fixed sampling thresholds, causing over-sampling in easy regions and under-sampling in uncertain ones. This harms efficiency and safety, particularly for long-horizon instructions.

Method: 1) Scene-Aware Adaptive Strategy: dynamically adjusts graph construction thresholds according to dispersion of predicted waypoints to densify on challenging areas. 2) Dynamic Graph Transformer: rebuilds graph connectivity by fusing visual, linguistic, and geometric cues into dynamic edge weights to filter noise and improve instruction adherence.

Result: Extensive experiments on R2R-CE and RxR-CE show DGNav achieves superior navigation performance and strong generalization; ablations confirm a favorable trade-off between navigation efficiency and safe exploration.

Conclusion: DGNav addresses Granularity Rigidity with adaptive density and multimodal dynamic connectivity, enabling robust, efficient VLN-CE navigation. Code is available at the provided GitHub URL.

Abstract: Vision-Language Navigation in Continuous Environments (VLN-CE) presents a core challenge: grounding high-level linguistic instructions into precise, safe, and long-horizon spatial actions. Explicit topological maps have proven to be a vital solution for providing robust spatial memory in such tasks. However, existing topological planning methods suffer from a "Granularity Rigidity" problem. Specifically, these methods typically rely on fixed geometric thresholds to sample nodes, which fails to adapt to varying environmental complexities. This rigidity leads to a critical mismatch: the model tends to over-sample in simple areas, causing computational redundancy, while under-sampling in high-uncertainty regions, increasing collision risks and compromising precision. To address this, we propose DGNav, a framework for Dynamic Topological Navigation, introducing a context-aware mechanism to modulate map density and connectivity on-the-fly. Our approach comprises two core innovations: (1) A Scene-Aware Adaptive Strategy that dynamically modulates graph construction thresholds based on the dispersion of predicted waypoints, enabling "densification on demand" in challenging environments; (2) A Dynamic Graph Transformer that reconstructs graph connectivity by fusing visual, linguistic, and geometric cues into dynamic edge weights, enabling the agent to filter out topological noise and enhancing instruction adherence. Extensive experiments on the R2R-CE and RxR-CE benchmarks demonstrate DGNav exhibits superior navigation performance and strong generalization capabilities. Furthermore, ablation studies confirm that our framework achieves an optimal trade-off between navigation efficiency and safe exploration. The code is available at https://github.com/shannanshouyin/DGNav.

</details>


### [59] [Synthetic-to-Real Domain Bridging for Single-View 3D Reconstruction of Ships for Maritime Monitoring](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21786)
*Borja Carrillo-Perez,Felix Sattler,Angel Bueno Rodriguez,Maurice Stephan,Sarah Barnes*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Single-view 3D ship reconstruction from synthetic data using Splatter Image network with 3D Gaussian representation, complemented by YOLOv8-based segmentation and postprocessing for georeferenced map placement; achieves efficient, annotation-free 3D ships suitable for real-time maritime monitoring.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Enable real-time, single-view 3D ship visualization without multi-view supervision or real 3D ground-truth, addressing practicality gaps in maritime monitoring.

Method: Train Splatter Image network to represent ships as sparse 3D Gaussians; pretrain on synthetic ShapeNet vessels and refine with a custom 3D ship dataset; integrate YOLOv8 segmentation; apply preprocessing; scale/center/orient; georeference and map onto interactive web map using AIS metadata and homography; evaluate on synthetic data and test qualitatively on ShipSG images.

Result: Quantitative tests on synthetic validation show strong reconstruction fidelity; qualitative results on ShipSG demonstrate transfer to real-world imagery; final system enables interactive 3D inspection of real ships without real-world 3D annotations.

Conclusion: Efficient, scalable single-view 3D ship reconstruction pipeline bridging synthetic and real domains, enabling practical real-time visualization for maritime monitoring without 3D ground-truth data.

Abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) reconstruction of ships is an important part of maritime monitoring, allowing improved visualization, inspection, and decision-making in real-world monitoring environments. However, most state-ofthe-art 3D reconstruction methods require multi-view supervision, annotated 3D ground truth, or are computationally intensive, making them impractical for real-time maritime deployment. In this work, we present an efficient pipeline for single-view 3D reconstruction of real ships by training entirely on synthetic data and requiring only a single view at inference. Our approach uses the Splatter Image network, which represents objects as sparse sets of 3D Gaussians for rapid and accurate reconstruction from single images. The model is first fine-tuned on synthetic ShapeNet vessels and further refined with a diverse custom dataset of 3D ships, bridging the domain gap between synthetic and real-world imagery. We integrate a state-of-the-art segmentation module based on YOLOv8 and custom preprocessing to ensure compatibility with the reconstruction network. Postprocessing steps include real-world scaling, centering, and orientation alignment, followed by georeferenced placement on an interactive web map using AIS metadata and homography-based mapping. Quantitative evaluation on synthetic validation data demonstrates strong reconstruction fidelity, while qualitative results on real maritime images from the ShipSG dataset confirm the potential for transfer to operational maritime settings. The final system provides interactive 3D inspection of real ships without requiring real-world 3D annotations. This pipeline provides an efficient, scalable solution for maritime monitoring and highlights a path toward real-time 3D ship visualization in practical applications. Interactive demo: https://dlr-mi.github.io/ship3d-demo/.

</details>


### [60] [CG-MLLM: Captioning and Generating 3D content via Multi-modal Large Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21798)
*Junming Huang,Weiwei Xu*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: CG-MLLM: a multi-modal LLM enabling 3D captioning and high-resolution 3D generation via a mixture-of-transformers that decouples token-level (TokenAR) and block-level (BlockAR) content, integrated with a 3D VAE latent space and a vision-language backbone, achieving state-of-the-art 3D fidelity.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: 3D content generation remains underexplored; existing MLLMs often produce low-res meshes or coarse proxies and struggle with fine-grained geometry; a unified architecture is needed for native high-resolution 3D content and long-context cross-modal interactions.

Method: Mixture-of-Transformer (MoT): TokenAR handles token-level content; BlockAR handles block-level content. A pre-trained vision-language backbone is integrated with a specialized 3D VAE latent space to enable long-context interactions between standard tokens and spatial blocks in a single architecture.

Result: Experimental results indicate CG-MLLM significantly outperforms existing MLLMs in generating high-fidelity, high-resolution 3D objects within a single framework.

Conclusion: Presents a unified, high-resolution 3D-capable MLLM that brings high-fidelity 3D content creation into mainstream LLMs by decoupling content modeling and leveraging a 3D latent space.

Abstract: Large Language Models(LLMs) have revolutionized text generation and multimodal perception, but their capabilities in 3D content generation remain underexplored. Existing methods compromise by producing either low-resolution meshes or coarse structural proxies, failing to capture fine-grained geometry natively. In this paper, we propose CG-MLLM, a novel Multi-modal Large Language Model (MLLM) capable of 3D captioning and high-resolution 3D generation in a single framework. Leveraging the Mixture-of-Transformer architecture, CG-MLLM decouples disparate modeling needs, where the Token-level Autoregressive (TokenAR) Transformer handles token-level content, and the Block-level Autoregressive (BlockAR) Transformer handles block-level content. By integrating a pre-trained vision-language backbone with a specialized 3D VAE latent space, CG-MLLM facilitates long-context interactions between standard tokens and spatial blocks within a single integrated architecture. Experimental results show that CG-MLLM significantly outperforms existing MLLMs in generating high-fidelity 3D objects, effectively bringing high-resolution 3D content creation into the mainstream LLM paradigm.

</details>


### [61] [MMFineReason: Closing the Multimodal Reasoning Gap via Open Data-Centric Methods](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21821)
*Honglin Lin,Zheng Liu,Yun Zhu,Chonghan Qin,Juekai Lin,Xiaoran Shang,Conghui He,Wentao Zhang,Lijun Wu*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: MMFineReason is a large-scale multimodal reasoning dataset (1.8M samples, 5.1B tokens) built via a three-stage pipeline to induce high-quality, visually grounded Chain-of-Thought; fine-tuning Qwen3-VL-Instruct yields MMFineReason-2B/4B/8B that set state-of-the-art results for their size, with smaller models sometimes outperforming larger baselines. A 7% subset achieves comparable performance to the full dataset, highlighting a 'less is more' phenomenon and a positive synergy between reasoning data and general capabilities.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Open-source vision-language models still lag behind proprietary systems due to scarcity of high-quality, diverse reasoning data, especially for STEM diagrams and visual puzzles. Long-form CoT annotations are crucial to elicit strong reasoning in multimodal models.

Method: A three-stage pipeline: (1) large-scale data collection and standardization; (2) generation of chain-of-thought rationals; (3) quality- and difficulty-aware selection to obtain high-quality, visually grounded reasoning traces across STEM problems, visual puzzles, games, and diagrams. The dataset is used to fine-tune Qwen3-VL-Instruct to produce MMFineReason-2B/4B/8B models.

Result: MMFineReason achieves new state-of-the-art results for their size class. Specifically, MMFineReason-4B surpasses Qwen3-VL-8B-Thinking, and MMFineReason-8B outperforms Qwen3-VL-30B-A3B-Thinking while nearing Qwen3-VL-32B-Thinking. A small 7% subset (123K samples) matches full-dataset performance, illustrating a strong 'less is more' effect. Reasoning-oriented data composition also enhances general capabilities.

Conclusion: High-quality, reasoning-focused multimodal data and thoughtful dataset curation enable efficient, high-performing VLMs. The findings highlight both the value of targeted CoT data and the existence of synergistic effects between reasoning annotation and broad multimodal competence.

Abstract: Recent advances in Vision Language Models (VLMs) have driven significant progress in visual reasoning. However, open-source VLMs still lag behind proprietary systems, largely due to the lack of high-quality reasoning data. Existing datasets offer limited coverage of challenging domains such as STEM diagrams and visual puzzles, and lack consistent, long-form Chain-of-Thought (CoT) annotations essential for eliciting strong reasoning capabilities. To bridge this gap, we introduce MMFineReason, a large-scale multimodal reasoning dataset comprising 1.8M samples and 5.1B solution tokens, featuring high-quality reasoning annotations distilled from Qwen3-VL-235B-A22B-Thinking. The dataset is established via a systematic three-stage pipeline: (1) large-scale data collection and standardization, (2) CoT rationale generation, and (3) comprehensive selection based on reasoning quality and difficulty awareness. The resulting dataset spans STEM problems, visual puzzles, games, and complex diagrams, with each sample annotated with visually grounded reasoning traces. We fine-tune Qwen3-VL-Instruct on MMFineReason to develop MMFineReason-2B/4B/8B versions. Our models establish new state-of-the-art results for their size class. Notably, MMFineReason-4B succesfully surpasses Qwen3-VL-8B-Thinking, and MMFineReason-8B even outperforms Qwen3-VL-30B-A3B-Thinking while approaching Qwen3-VL-32B-Thinking, demonstrating remarkable parameter efficiency. Crucially, we uncover a "less is more" phenomenon via our difficulty-aware filtering strategy: a subset of just 7\% (123K samples) achieves performance comparable to the full dataset. Notably, we reveal a synergistic effect where reasoning-oriented data composition simultaneously boosts general capabilities.

</details>


### [62] [Trajectory-Guided Diffusion for Foreground-Preserving Background Generation in Multi-Layer Documents](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21857)
*Taewon Kang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Diffusion-based background generation for document pages that preserves foregrounds and achieves multi-page stylistic consistency by designing latent-space trajectories rather than applying explicit constraints; uses initial noise shaping and cached latent style directions; training-free and compatible with existing diffusion backbones.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address foreground preservation in document-centric generation and across-page style drift, enabling stable, readable content without masking or repeated prompt-based styling.

Method: Recast diffusion as evolution of stochastic trajectories on a structured latent manifold. Shape initial noise and its geometric alignment to steer generation away from foreground regions. Decouple style control from text conditioning and introduce cached style directions as persistent latent vectors that constrain diffusion to a shared stylistic subspace. The approach is training-free and compatible with existing diffusion backbones.

Result: Produces visually coherent, foreground-preserving outputs across complex multi-page documents with consistent appearance and editing stability, without explicit masking or prompt-based style specification.

Conclusion: Framing diffusion as latent-space trajectory design provides a principled, training-free pathway for achieving foreground preservation and cross-page style consistency in document generation, leveraging geometry-driven latent-space constraints over explicit heuristics.

Abstract: We present a diffusion-based framework for document-centric background generation that achieves foreground preservation and multi-page stylistic consistency through latent-space design rather than explicit constraints. Instead of suppressing diffusion updates or applying masking heuristics, our approach reinterprets diffusion as the evolution of stochastic trajectories through a structured latent space. By shaping the initial noise and its geometric alignment, background generation naturally avoids designated foreground regions, allowing readable content to remain intact without auxiliary mechanisms. To address the long-standing issue of stylistic drift across pages, we decouple style control from text conditioning and introduce cached style directions as persistent vectors in latent space. Once selected, these directions constrain diffusion trajectories to a shared stylistic subspace, ensuring consistent appearance across pages and editing iterations. This formulation eliminates the need for repeated prompt-based style specification and provides a more stable foundation for multi-page generation. Our framework admits a geometric and physical interpretation, where diffusion paths evolve on a latent manifold shaped by preferred directions, and foreground regions are rarely traversed as a consequence of trajectory initialization rather than explicit exclusion. The proposed method is training-free, compatible with existing diffusion backbones, and produces visually coherent, foreground-preserving results across complex documents. By reframing diffusion as trajectory design in latent space, we offer a principled approach to consistent and structured generative modeling.

</details>


### [63] [Improving Classifier-Free Guidance of Flow Matching via Manifold Projection](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21892)
*Jian-Feng Cai,Haixia Liu,Zhengyi Su,Chao Wang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: CFG is interpreted as an optimization process where the diffusion/flow velocity field equals the gradient of smoothed distance functions toward a scaled target image set. The standard CFG is an approximation of this gradient via prediction gap. A homotopy optimization with a manifold constraint is proposed, requiring a manifold projection via incremental gradient descent; Anderson Acceleration improves convergence without extra model calls. The approach is training-free and improves fidelity, alignment, and robustness to guidance scale on large models.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To provide a principled, optimization-based understanding of classifier-free guidance (CFG) and to reduce its sensitivity to guidance scale without retraining, enhancing controllable generation in diffusion/flow models.

Method: 1) Interpret the diffusion/flow velocity as the gradient of a sequence of smoothed distance functions to the target image set; 2) show CFG as an approximation governed by the prediction gap; 3) cast CFG sampling as a homotopy optimization with a manifold constraint; 4) implement manifold projection via incremental gradient descent during sampling; 5) improve this with Anderson Acceleration, avoiding extra model evaluations; 6) ensure the approach is training-free.

Result: The proposed iterative projection with Anderson Acceleration yields improved generation fidelity, prompt alignment, and robustness to guidance scale across large models (DiT-XL-2-256, Flux, Stable Diffusion 3.5) without additional training.

Conclusion: The approach provides a principled, training-free framework for CFG, linking it to gradient-based optimization on smoothed distance manifolds, and delivering practical gains in fidelity and robustness through an efficient projection-based refinement during sampling.

Abstract: Classifier-free guidance (CFG) is a widely used technique for controllable generation in diffusion and flow-based models. Despite its empirical success, CFG relies on a heuristic linear extrapolation that is often sensitive to the guidance scale. In this work, we provide a principled interpretation of CFG through the lens of optimization. We demonstrate that the velocity field in flow matching corresponds to the gradient of a sequence of smoothed distance functions, which guides latent variables toward the scaled target image set. This perspective reveals that the standard CFG formulation is an approximation of this gradient, where the prediction gap, the discrepancy between conditional and unconditional outputs, governs guidance sensitivity. Leveraging this insight, we reformulate the CFG sampling as a homotopy optimization with a manifold constraint. This formulation necessitates a manifold projection step, which we implement via an incremental gradient descent scheme during sampling. To improve computational efficiency and stability, we further enhance this iterative process with Anderson Acceleration without requiring additional model evaluations. Our proposed methods are training-free and consistently refine generation fidelity, prompt alignment, and robustness to the guidance scale. We validate their effectiveness across diverse benchmarks, demonstrating significant improvements on large-scale models such as DiT-XL-2-256, Flux, and Stable Diffusion 3.5.

</details>


### [64] [Past- and Future-Informed KV Cache Policy with Salience Estimation in Autoregressive Video Diffusion](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21896)
*Hanmo Chen,Chenghao Xu,Xu Yang,Xuan Chen,Cheng Deng*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Introduces PaFu-KV, a past- and future-informed KV cache policy for autoregressive video generation, using a lightweight salience head distilled from a bidirectional teacher to retain informative tokens and discard less relevant ones, improving speed and maintaining fidelity.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current KV cache policies are heuristic and ignore token importance, causing information loss and cache bloat in long-horizon video generation; there is a need to capture time-heterogeneous token contributions to balance generation quality with efficiency.

Method: Proposes PaFu-KV with a Salience Estimation Head distilled from a bidirectional teacher to estimate token salience. The cache stores informative tokens while discarding less relevant ones, effectively shrinking KV cache capacity and reducing memory footprint at inference, leveraging Past- and Future-informed guidance for long-horizon video generation.

Result: Extensive experiments on benchmarks show preserved high-fidelity video generation quality while enabling accelerated inference, achieving a better quality-efficiency trade-off. The authors will release code upon acceptance.

Conclusion: PaFu-KV improves efficiency in long-horizon autoregressive video generation without sacrificing quality by using salience-guided, bidirectionally-informed KV caching.

Abstract: Video generation is pivotal to digital media creation, and recent advances in autoregressive video generation have markedly enhanced the efficiency of real-time video synthesis. However, existing approaches generally rely on heuristic KV Cache policies, which ignore differences in token importance in long-term video generation. This leads to the loss of critical spatiotemporal information and the accumulation of redundant, invalid cache, thereby degrading video generation quality and efficiency. To address this limitation, we first observe that token contributions to video generation are highly time-heterogeneous and accordingly propose a novel Past- and Future-Informed KV Cache Policy (PaFu-KV). Specifically, PaFu-KV introduces a lightweight Salience Estimation Head distilled from a bidirectional teacher to estimate salience scores, allowing the KV cache to retain informative tokens while discarding less relevant ones. This policy yields a better quality-efficiency trade-off by shrinking KV cache capacity and reducing memory footprint at inference time. Extensive experiments on benchmarks demonstrate that our method preserves high-fidelity video generation quality while enables accelerated inference, thereby enabling more efficient long-horizon video generation. Our code will be released upon paper acceptance.

</details>


### [65] [TraceRouter: Robust Safety for Large Foundation Models via Path-Level Intervention](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21900)
*Chuancheng Shi,Shangze Li,Wenjun Lu,Wenhua Wu,Cong Wang,Zifeng Cheng,Fei Shen,Tat-Seng Chua*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: TraceRouter is a path-level defense for large foundation models that traces and disconnects illicit semantics by identifying a sensitive onset layer through attention divergence, disentangling malicious features with sparse autoencoders and differential activation analysis, and mapping these features to downstream causal pathways using feature influence scores derived from zero-out interventions to suppress harmful causality while preserving orthogonal computation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Local defenses based on suppressing isolated neurons or features (locality hypothesis) are brittle because harmful semantics appear as distributed, cross-layer circuits that can bypass localized interventions. A path-level framework aims to sever causal chains of illicit semantics to preserve utility.

Method: Three-stage approach: (1) detect onset layer via attention divergence; (2) use sparse autoencoders and differential activation to disentangle/isolate malicious features; (3) map features to downstream causal pathways using feature influence scores from zero-out interventions, then selectively suppress the causal chains.

Result: Reportedly outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, achieving a better robustness-utility trade-off on experiments; code will be released.

Conclusion: TraceRouter introduces a novel path-level mechanism to defend LFMs against adversarial manipulation by severing cross-layer causal pathways of malicious semantics while preserving non-harmful computation; promising results accompany a public code release, with a caveat about unsafe model responses in the discussed paper.

Abstract: Despite their capabilities, large foundation models (LFMs) remain susceptible to adversarial manipulation. Current defenses predominantly rely on the "locality hypothesis", suppressing isolated neurons or features. However, harmful semantics act as distributed, cross-layer circuits, rendering such localized interventions brittle and detrimental to utility. To bridge this gap, we propose \textbf{TraceRouter}, a path-level framework that traces and disconnects the causal propagation circuits of illicit semantics. TraceRouter operates in three stages: (1) it pinpoints a sensitive onset layer by analyzing attention divergence; (2) it leverages sparse autoencoders (SAEs) and differential activation analysis to disentangle and isolate malicious features; and (3) it maps these features to downstream causal pathways via feature influence scores (FIS) derived from zero-out interventions. By selectively suppressing these causal chains, TraceRouter physically severs the flow of harmful information while leaving orthogonal computation routes intact. Extensive experiments demonstrate that TraceRouter significantly outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, achieving a superior trade-off between adversarial robustness and general utility. Our code will be publicly released. WARNING: This paper contains unsafe model responses.

</details>


### [66] [Beyond Global Alignment: Fine-Grained Motion-Language Retrieval via Pyramidal Shapley-Taylor Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21904)
*Hanmo Chen,Guangtao Lyu,Chenghao Xu,Jiexi Yan,Xu Yang,Cheng Deng*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: PST framework for fine-grained motion-language retrieval that decomposes motion into joints and segments and uses progressive pyramidal Shapley-Taylor alignment to surpass global-centric methods.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Global-centric alignment between whole motion sequences and global text representations overlooks fine-grained interactions between local motion segments, body joints, and individual text tokens, limiting retrieval performance.

Method: Decompose motion into temporal segments and spatial joints. Learn cross-modal correspondences through progressive joint-wise and segment-wise alignment in a pyramidal fashion using a Pyramidal Shapley-Taylor framework to capture local semantic details and hierarchical structure.

Result: Experiments on public benchmarks show state-of-the-art performance, with precise alignment between motion segments, joints, and corresponding text tokens; code to be released upon acceptance.

Conclusion: The PST framework effectively bridges the semantic gap via fine-grained, hierarchical cross-modal alignment, improving motion-language retrieval over global-centric approaches.

Abstract: As a foundational task in human-centric cross-modal intelligence, motion-language retrieval aims to bridge the semantic gap between natural language and human motion, enabling intuitive motion analysis, yet existing approaches predominantly focus on aligning entire motion sequences with global textual representations. This global-centric paradigm overlooks fine-grained interactions between local motion segments and individual body joints and text tokens, inevitably leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. To address this limitation, we draw inspiration from the pyramidal process of human motion perception (from joint dynamics to segment coherence, and finally to holistic comprehension) and propose a novel Pyramidal Shapley-Taylor (PST) learning framework for fine-grained motion-language retrieval. Specifically, the framework decomposes human motion into temporal segments and spatial body joints, and learns cross-modal correspondences through progressive joint-wise and segment-wise alignment in a pyramidal fashion, effectively capturing both local semantic details and hierarchical structural relationships. Extensive experiments on multiple public benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving precise alignment between motion segments and body joints and their corresponding text tokens. The code of this work will be released upon acceptance.

</details>


### [67] [VideoAesBench: Benchmarking the Video Aesthetics Perception Capabilities of Large Multimodal Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21915)
*Yunhao Li,Sijing Wu,Zhilin Gao,Zicheng Zhang,Qi Jia,Huiyu Duan,Xiongkuo Min,Guangtao Zhai*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: VideoAesBench—comprehensive benchmark to evaluate LMMs' understanding of video aesthetic quality, with 1,804 diverse videos, multiple question formats including open-ended, and evaluation of 23 models; reveals limitations in current LMMs; aims as testbed for explainable video aesthetics assessment.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: LMMs perform well on many visual tasks, but video aesthetic quality assessment is underexplored; a standardized benchmark across content types and question formats is needed to measure and explain LMMs' aesthetics understanding.

Method: Construct VideoAesBench using 1,804 videos from diverse sources (UGC, AIGC, compressed, robotic-generated, game); include traditional single-choice, multi-choice, True/False, and novel open-ended questions; cover holistic aesthetics dimensions: 5 visual-form aspects, 4 visual-style aspects, 3 visual-affectiveness aspects; benchmark 23 open-source and commercial LMMs.

Result: Current LMMs exhibit only basic video aesthetics perception; performance is incomplete and imprecise.

Conclusion: VideoAesBench can serve as a strong testbed and provide insights for explainable video aesthetics assessment.

Abstract: Large multimodal models (LMMs) have demonstrated outstanding capabilities in various visual perception tasks, which has in turn made the evaluation of LMMs significant. However, the capability of video aesthetic quality assessment, which is a fundamental ability for human, remains underexplored for LMMs. To address this, we introduce VideoAesBench, a comprehensive benchmark for evaluating LMMs' understanding of video aesthetic quality. VideoAesBench has several significant characteristics: (1) Diverse content including 1,804 videos from multiple video sources including user-generated (UGC), AI-generated (AIGC), compressed, robotic-generated (RGC), and game videos. (2) Multiple question formats containing traditional single-choice questions, multi-choice questions, True or False questions, and a novel open-ended questions for video aesthetics description. (3) Holistic video aesthetics dimensions including visual form related questions from 5 aspects, visual style related questions from 4 aspects, and visual affectiveness questions from 3 aspects. Based on VideoAesBench, we benchmark 23 open-source and commercial large multimodal models. Our findings show that current LMMs only contain basic video aesthetics perception ability, their performance remains incomplete and imprecise. We hope our VideoAesBench can be served as a strong testbed and offer insights for explainable video aesthetics assessment.

</details>


### [68] [Zero-Shot Video Restoration and Enhancement with Assistance of Video Diffusion Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21922)
*Cong Cao,Huanjing Yue,Shangbin Xie,Xin Liu,Jingyu Yang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Training-free framework that blends image-based restoration with video diffusion models to reduce temporal flicker in zero-shot video restoration/enhancement via homologous/heterogeneous latents fusion, a COT-based fusion ratio, and temporal-strengthening post-processing.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Video diffusion methods often cause temporal flicker when adapted to video restoration. A training-free approach is needed to leverage pre-trained video diffusion models to stabilize temporality while preserving restoration quality.

Method: Propose homologous latents fusion and heterogeneous latents fusion to combine latent codes from same and different diffusion models; employ a COT-based fusion ratio strategy to balance contributions; add temporal-strengthening post-processing; fully training-free and compatible with any diffusion-based image restoration method.

Result: Experimental results demonstrate superiority over baselines in temporal consistency and restoration quality, without requiring training.

Conclusion: A versatile, training-free framework that uses video diffusion models to assist image-based restoration, achieving improved temporal consistency in zero-shot video restoration/enhancement.

Abstract: Although diffusion-based zero-shot image restoration and enhancement methods have achieved great success, applying them to video restoration or enhancement will lead to severe temporal flickering. In this paper, we propose the first framework that utilizes the rapidly-developed video diffusion model to assist the image-based method in maintaining more temporal consistency for zero-shot video restoration and enhancement. We propose homologous latents fusion, heterogenous latents fusion, and a COT-based fusion ratio strategy to utilize both homologous and heterogenous text-to-video diffusion models to complement the image method. Moreover, we propose temporal-strengthening post-processing to utilize the image-to-video diffusion model to further improve temporal consistency. Our method is training-free and can be applied to any diffusion-based image restoration and enhancement methods. Experimental results demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method.

</details>


### [69] [Just Noticeable Difference Modeling for Deep Visual Features](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21933)
*Rui Zhao,Wenrui Li,Lin Zhu,Yajing Zheng,Weisi Lin*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A task-aligned perceptual distortion bound for deep features (FeatJND) that estimates per-feature tolerances to preserve downstream vision tasks, enabling more efficient, dynamic feature quantization and robustness to constrained resources.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Extend the notion of just noticeable difference (JND) from pixel space to deep feature space to control feature quality for machine perception, ensuring that perturbations do not degrade downstream task performance under resource constraints.

Method: Introduce FeatJND estimator at standardized split points to produce a per-feature perturbation map. Validate across image classification, detection, and instance segmentation. Compare FeatJND-guided distortions against unstructured Gaussian perturbations under matched distortion strength. Use attribution visualizations to assess region-specific sensitivity. Apply FeatJND to token-wise dynamic quantization with targeted step-size allocation and compare to random/permuted or globally uniform step sizes.

Result: FeatJND distortions, when matched for distortion strength, consistently preserve higher task performance than Gaussian perturbations. Attribution analyses indicate suppression of non-critical feature regions guided by FeatJND. In token-wise dynamic quantization, FeatJND-guided step-size allocation yields clear gains over baseline strategies under the same noise budget.

Conclusion: FeatJND provides a practical, task-aligned boundary for controlling feature quality in deep visual representations, with demonstrated benefits for robustness and efficiency in downstream vision tasks and dynamic quantization setups; code release planned.

Abstract: Deep visual features are increasingly used as the interface in vision systems, motivating the need to describe feature characteristics and control feature quality for machine perception. Just noticeable difference (JND) characterizes the maximum imperceptible distortion for images under human or machine vision. Extending it to deep visual features naturally meets the above demand by providing a task-aligned tolerance boundary in feature space, offering a practical reference for controlling feature quality under constrained resources. We propose FeatJND, a task-aligned JND formulation that predicts the maximum tolerable per-feature perturbation map while preserving downstream task performance. We propose a FeatJND estimator at standardized split points and validate it across image classification, detection, and instance segmentation. Under matched distortion strength, FeatJND-based distortions consistently preserve higher task performance than unstructured Gaussian perturbations, and attribution visualizations suggest FeatJND can suppress non-critical feature regions. As an application, we further apply FeatJND to token-wise dynamic quantization and show that FeatJND-guided step-size allocation yields clear gains over random step-size permutation and global uniform step size under the same noise budget. Our code will be released after publication.

</details>


### [70] [BookNet: Book Image Rectification via Cross-Page Attention Network](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21938)
*Shaokai Liu,Hao Feng,Bozhi Luan,Min Hou,Jiajun Deng,Wengang Zhou*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Proposes BookNet, a dual-page deep learning framework for rectifying book images by modeling cross-page interactions, paired with synthetic and real datasets (Book3D and Book100); achieves state-of-the-art performance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Single-page rectification misses the coupled, asymmetric distortions of adjacent pages caused by book binding; a model that jointly handles both pages is needed.

Method: A dual-branch architecture with cross-page attention to estimate warping flows for each page and the full book spread; end-to-end training; synthetic Book3D for training and Book100 for evaluation.

Result: BookNet outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods on book image rectification across experiments; dataset/code will be released publicly.

Conclusion: Introduces a novel dual-page rectification framework and accompanying datasets, demonstrating the importance of inter-page coupling in book image rectification.

Abstract: Book image rectification presents unique challenges in document image processing due to complex geometric distortions from binding constraints, where left and right pages exhibit distinctly asymmetric curvature patterns. However, existing single-page document image rectification methods fail to capture the coupled geometric relationships between adjacent pages in books. In this work, we introduce BookNet, the first end-to-end deep learning framework specifically designed for dual-page book image rectification. BookNet adopts a dual-branch architecture with cross-page attention mechanisms, enabling it to estimate warping flows for both individual pages and the complete book spread, explicitly modeling how left and right pages influence each other. Moreover, to address the absence of specialized datasets, we present Book3D, a large-scale synthetic dataset for training, and Book100, a comprehensive real-world benchmark for evaluation. Extensive experiments demonstrate that BookNet outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods on book image rectification. Code and dataset will be made publicly available.

</details>


### [71] [Deep Models, Shallow Alignment: Uncovering the Granularity Mismatch in Neural Decoding](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21948)
*Yang Du,Siyuan Dai,Yonghao Song,Paul M. Thompson,Haoteng Tang,Liang Zhan*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Shallow Alignment aligns neural signals with intermediate visual representations instead of final outputs, addressing a granularity mismatch and enabling improved neural visual decoding with scalable gains.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: There is a granularity mismatch between human and machine vision: deep models emphasize semantic invariance and suppress texture details, while neural signals preserve a mix of low-level and high-level attributes. This misalignment limits decoding performance.

Method: A contrastive learning strategy that aligns neural signals with intermediate (not final) representations of visual encoders, leveraging multiple layers to balance texture details and semantic content; evaluated across diverse backbones and benchmarks; includes analyses to understand mechanisms.

Result: Outperforms standard final-layer alignment by 22%–58% across vision backbones; reveals a scaling law where decoding performance scales with backbone capacity; demonstrated across multiple benchmarks with systematic empirical analyses.

Conclusion: Shallow Alignment provides a more faithful alignment between neural data and visual representations, boosting decoding performance, enabling scalable improvements with backbone models, and offering mechanistic insights.

Abstract: Neural visual decoding is a central problem in brain computer interface research, aiming to reconstruct human visual perception and to elucidate the structure of neural representations. However, existing approaches overlook a fundamental granularity mismatch between human and machine vision, where deep vision models emphasize semantic invariance by suppressing local texture information, whereas neural signals preserve an intricate mixture of low-level visual attributes and high-level semantic content. To address this mismatch, we propose Shallow Alignment, a novel contrastive learning strategy that aligns neural signals with intermediate representations of visual encoders rather than their final outputs, thereby striking a better balance between low-level texture details and high-level semantic features. Extensive experiments across multiple benchmarks demonstrate that Shallow Alignment significantly outperforms standard final-layer alignment, with performance gains ranging from 22% to 58% across diverse vision backbones. Notably, our approach effectively unlocks the scaling law in neural visual decoding, enabling decoding performance to scale predictably with the capacity of pre-trained vision backbones. We further conduct systematic empirical analyses to shed light on the mechanisms underlying the observed performance gains.

</details>


### [72] [PaddleOCR-VL-1.5: Towards a Multi-Task 0.9B VLM for Robust In-the-Wild Document Parsing](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21957)
*Cheng Cui,Ting Sun,Suyin Liang,Tingquan Gao,Zelun Zhang,Jiaxuan Liu,Xueqing Wang,Changda Zhou,Hongen Liu,Manhui Lin,Yue Zhang,Yubo Zhang,Yi Liu,Dianhai Yu,Yanjun Ma*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: PaddleOCR-VL-1.5 is a compact 0.9B visual-language model achieving 94.5% SOTA on OmniDocBench v1.5, introduces Real5-OmniDocBench for robustness to real-world distortions, and adds seal recognition and text spotting capabilities while remaining efficient and open-source.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Improve OCR performance in multimodal models while ensuring robustness to real-world distortions and expanding functional tasks, all within an ultra-compact, practical model.

Method: Upgrade to PaddleOCR-VL-1.5; propose Real5-OmniDocBench benchmark for physical distortions; extend model with seal recognition and text spotting heads; maintain ~0.9B parameters for high efficiency; release code.

Result: Achieves SOTA accuracy (94.5%) on OmniDocBench v1.5; strong performance on Real5-OmniDocBench for robustness; adds seal recognition and text spotting capabilities; maintains ultra-compact and efficient profile.

Conclusion: Demonstrates that a compact visual-language model can deliver high OCR accuracy, robustness to real-world distortions, and multi-task capabilities, with open-source availability.

Abstract: We introduce PaddleOCR-VL-1.5, an upgraded model achieving a new state-of-the-art (SOTA) accuracy of 94.5% on OmniDocBench v1.5. To rigorously evaluate robustness against real-world physical distortions, including scanning, skew, warping, screen-photography, and illumination, we propose the Real5-OmniDocBench benchmark. Experimental results demonstrate that this enhanced model attains SOTA performance on the newly curated benchmark. Furthermore, we extend the model's capabilities by incorporating seal recognition and text spotting tasks, while remaining a 0.9B ultra-compact VLM with high efficiency. Code: https://github.com/PaddlePaddle/PaddleOCR

</details>


### [73] [Drive-JEPA: Video JEPA Meets Multimodal Trajectory Distillation for End-to-End Driving](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22032)
*Linhan Wang,Zichong Yang,Chen Bai,Guoxiang Zhang,Xiaotong Liu,Xiaoyin Zheng,Xiao-Xiao Long,Chang-Tien Lu,Cheng Lu*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Drive-JEPA combines Video Joint-Embedding Predictive Architecture (V-JEPA) with multimodal trajectory distillation for end-to-end driving, addressing multimodality and ambiguity by distilling diverse simulated and human trajectories. It achieves state-of-the-art on NAVSIM: 93.3 PDMS (v1) and 87.8 EPDMS (v2).


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: End-to-end driving can leverage self-supervised video pretraining to learn planning representations, but video world-model pretraining provides limited gains due to scene ambiguity and a single human trajectory per scene. There is a need for multimodal planning representations that can capture diverse feasible behaviors.

Method: Adapt V-JEPA for driving by pretraining a ViT encoder on large-scale driving videos to yield predictive representations aligned with trajectory planning. Introduce a proposal-centric planner that distills diverse simulator-generated trajectories along with human trajectories, using a momentum-aware selection mechanism to promote stable and safe behavior. A transformer-based decoder uses the V-JEPA representations.

Result: On NAVSIM, the V-JEPA representation with a simple transformer decoder outperforms prior methods by ~3 PDMS in the perception-free setting. The full Drive-JEPA framework achieves 93.3 PDMS on v1 and 87.8 EPDMS on v2, establishing new state-of-the-art.

Conclusion: Drive-JEPA demonstrates that integrating self-supervised video pretraining with multimodal trajectory distillation yields strong planning representations for end-to-end driving, achieving state-of-the-art results on NAVSIM and highlighting the value of multimodal trajectory distillation and momentum-based selection in stable, safe planning.

Abstract: End-to-end autonomous driving increasingly leverages self-supervised video pretraining to learn transferable planning representations. However, pretraining video world models for scene understanding has so far brought only limited improvements. This limitation is compounded by the inherent ambiguity of driving: each scene typically provides only a single human trajectory, making it difficult to learn multimodal behaviors. In this work, we propose Drive-JEPA, a framework that integrates Video Joint-Embedding Predictive Architecture (V-JEPA) with multimodal trajectory distillation for end-to-end driving. First, we adapt V-JEPA for end-to-end driving, pretraining a ViT encoder on large-scale driving videos to produce predictive representations aligned with trajectory planning. Second, we introduce a proposal-centric planner that distills diverse simulator-generated trajectories alongside human trajectories, with a momentum-aware selection mechanism to promote stable and safe behavior. When evaluated on NAVSIM, the V-JEPA representation combined with a simple transformer-based decoder outperforms prior methods by 3 PDMS in the perception-free setting. The complete Drive-JEPA framework achieves 93.3 PDMS on v1 and 87.8 EPDMS on v2, setting a new state-of-the-art.

</details>


### [74] [Urban Neural Surface Reconstruction from Constrained Sparse Aerial Imagery with 3D SAR Fusion](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22045)
*Da Li,Chen Yao,Tong Mao,Jiacheng Bao,Houjun Sun*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Fusing 3D SAR with aerial imagery in neural surface reconstruction improves accuracy, completeness, and robustness under sparse, oblique urban-view conditions; introduces a new SAR-augmented NSR framework and a co-registered cross-modal dataset.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: NSR for urban 3D reconstruction from sparse aerial views suffers from geometric ambiguity and instability. 3D SAR provides robust priors that capture large-scale geometry even from side-looking paths, offering complementary information to optical imagery.

Method: Propose an urban NSR framework that integrates 3D SAR point clouds as spatial constraints into an SDF-based NSR backbone. This guides structure-aware ray selection and adaptive sampling during optimization. Construct the first benchmark dataset with co-registered 3D SAR point clouds and aerial imagery for cross-modal evaluation.

Result: Incorporating 3D SAR markedly enhances reconstruction accuracy, completeness, and robustness compared with single-modality baselines under highly sparse and oblique-view conditions. The approach demonstrates strong potential for scalable, high-fidelity urban reconstruction using optical-SAR sensing.

Conclusion: Cross-modal fusion of optical imagery and 3D SAR is a viable route to robust, high-fidelity urban NSR under constrained data acquisition, enabling scalable reconstruction with both airborne and spaceborne sensing.

Abstract: Neural surface reconstruction (NSR) has recently shown strong potential for urban 3D reconstruction from multi-view aerial imagery. However, existing NSR methods often suffer from geometric ambiguity and instability, particularly under sparse-view conditions. This issue is critical in large-scale urban remote sensing, where aerial image acquisition is limited by flight paths, terrain, and cost. To address this challenge, we present the first urban NSR framework that fuses 3D synthetic aperture radar (SAR) point clouds with aerial imagery for high-fidelity reconstruction under constrained, sparse-view settings. 3D SAR can efficiently capture large-scale geometry even from a single side-looking flight path, providing robust priors that complement photometric cues from images. Our framework integrates radar-derived spatial constraints into an SDF-based NSR backbone, guiding structure-aware ray selection and adaptive sampling for stable and efficient optimization. We also construct the first benchmark dataset with co-registered 3D SAR point clouds and aerial imagery, facilitating systematic evaluation of cross-modal 3D reconstruction. Extensive experiments show that incorporating 3D SAR markedly enhances reconstruction accuracy, completeness, and robustness compared with single-modality baselines under highly sparse and oblique-view conditions, highlighting a viable route toward scalable high-fidelity urban reconstruction with advanced airborne and spaceborne optical-SAR sensing.

</details>


### [75] [PLANING: A Loosely Coupled Triangle-Gaussian Framework for Streaming 3D Reconstruction](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22046)
*Changjian Jiang,Kerui Ren,Xudong Li,Kaiwen Song,Linning Xu,Tao Lu,Junting Dong,Yu Zhang,Bo Dai,Mulin Yu*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: PLANING introduces an online reconstruction framework that hybrids explicit geometric primitives with neural Gaussians to decouple geometry and appearance, enabling efficient streaming monocular reconstruction with competitive quality. It achieves notable gains over baselines in Chamfer-L2 and PSNR, reconstructs ScanNetV2 rapidly, and is suitable for large-scale scene modeling and embodied AI.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Streaming monocular reconstruction struggles to simultaneously achieve high-quality rendering and accurate geometry; online initialization and efficient updates are needed to reduce redundancy and enable real-time or near-real-time performance without sacrificing quality.

Method: A hybrid representation that loosely couples explicit geometric primitives with neural Gaussians. Geometry and appearance updates are decoupled, enabling online initialization and separate optimization for each component. This yields stable streaming reconstruction with reduced structural redundancy and improved computational efficiency.

Result: Dense mesh Chamfer-L2 improves by 18.52% over PGSR; PSNR exceeds ARTDECO by 1.31 dB. Reconstructs ScanNetV2 scenes in under 100 seconds, more than 5× faster than 2D Gaussian Splatting, while matching offline per-scene optimization quality.

Conclusion: PLANING provides a stable, efficient streaming reconstruction framework that decouples geometry and appearance, suitable for large-scale scene modeling and simulation-ready environments for embodied AI; the approach balances quality and efficiency and demonstrates strong empirical performance.

Abstract: Streaming reconstruction from monocular image sequences remains challenging, as existing methods typically favor either high-quality rendering or accurate geometry, but rarely both. We present PLANING, an efficient on-the-fly reconstruction framework built on a hybrid representation that loosely couples explicit geometric primitives with neural Gaussians, enabling geometry and appearance to be modeled in a decoupled manner. This decoupling supports an online initialization and optimization strategy that separates geometry and appearance updates, yielding stable streaming reconstruction with substantially reduced structural redundancy. PLANING improves dense mesh Chamfer-L2 by 18.52% over PGSR, surpasses ARTDECO by 1.31 dB PSNR, and reconstructs ScanNetV2 scenes in under 100 seconds, over 5x faster than 2D Gaussian Splatting, while matching the quality of offline per-scene optimization. Beyond reconstruction quality, the structural clarity and computational efficiency of \modelname~make it well suited for a broad range of downstream applications, such as enabling large-scale scene modeling and simulation-ready environments for embodied AI. Project page: https://city-super.github.io/PLANING/ .

</details>


### [76] [MetricAnything: Scaling Metric Depth Pretraining with Noisy Heterogeneous Sources](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22054)
*Baorui Ma,Jiahui Yang,Donglin Di,Xuancheng Zhang,Jianxun Cui,Hao Li,Yan Xie,Wei Chen*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A scalable pretraining framework, Metric Anything, learns metric depth from diverse, noisy 3D sources via Sparse Metric Prompts, enabling prompt-driven depth tasks and a strong prompt-free student for monocular depth estimation; demonstrates scaling in depth tracking and improves cross-modal spatial reasoning, with open-source release.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Metric depth estimation is hindered by heterogeneous sensor noise, camera biases, and metric ambiguity in cross-source data. Scaling up data and model capacity, as with vision foundation models, may unlock robust metric depth perception across diverse sources.

Method: Train a model using Sparse Metric Prompts created by randomly masking depth maps to decouple spatial reasoning from sensor biases. Use ~20M image-depth pairs from reconstructed, captured, and rendered 3D data across ~10,000 camera models. Develop a prompt-driven pretrained model for depth-related tasks and a distilled prompt-free student for monocular depth estimation, camera intrinsics recovery, 3D reconstruction, and planning. Use pretrained ViT as visual encoder to boost multimodal LLM spatial capabilities.

Result: First demonstration of a clear scaling trend in metric depth estimation. The prompt-driven model excels at depth completion, super-resolution, and radar-camera fusion; the distilled student achieves state-of-the-art monocular depth estimation, intrinsics recovery, single/multi-view 3D reconstruction, and planning. Open-source release enables community use; ViT-based encoders enhance multimodal LLM spatial reasoning.

Conclusion: The work argues that metric depth estimation can leverage scaling laws akin to vision foundation models, enabling scalable, efficient real-world metric perception. Metric Anything sets a foundation for broad pretraining on diverse 3D data and supports prompt-based and distilled pipelines.

Abstract: Scaling has powered recent advances in vision foundation models, yet extending this paradigm to metric depth estimation remains challenging due to heterogeneous sensor noise, camera-dependent biases, and metric ambiguity in noisy cross-source 3D data. We introduce Metric Anything, a simple and scalable pretraining framework that learns metric depth from noisy, diverse 3D sources without manually engineered prompts, camera-specific modeling, or task-specific architectures. Central to our approach is the Sparse Metric Prompt, created by randomly masking depth maps, which serves as a universal interface that decouples spatial reasoning from sensor and camera biases. Using about 20M image-depth pairs spanning reconstructed, captured, and rendered 3D data across 10000 camera models, we demonstrate-for the first time-a clear scaling trend in the metric depth track. The pretrained model excels at prompt-driven tasks such as depth completion, super-resolution and Radar-camera fusion, while its distilled prompt-free student achieves state-of-the-art results on monocular depth estimation, camera intrinsics recovery, single/multi-view metric 3D reconstruction, and VLA planning. We also show that using pretrained ViT of Metric Anything as a visual encoder significantly boosts Multimodal Large Language Model capabilities in spatial intelligence. These results show that metric depth estimation can benefit from the same scaling laws that drive modern foundation models, establishing a new path toward scalable and efficient real-world metric perception. We open-source MetricAnything at http://metric-anything.github.io/metric-anything-io/ to support community research.

</details>


### [77] [Unsupervised Decomposition and Recombination with Discriminator-Driven Diffusion Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22057)
*Archer Wang,Emile Anand,Yilun Du,Marin Soljačić*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A diffusion-based model learns factorized latent representations without factor-level supervision, using an adversarial signal to improve compositional recombinations; achieves better generation quality and disentanglement across datasets and enables diverse robotic trajectories.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reveal reusable components in complex data by learning latent factors and improve recomposition quality through an adversarial discriminator that enforces consistency between single-source and recombined samples.

Method: Train a generator with a discriminator that distinguishes single-source samples from recombined samples created by mixing factors from multiple sources. The discriminator guides the factorized latent space to produce physically and semantically consistent recombinations. Evaluate on CelebA-HQ, Virtual KITTI, CLEVR, Falcor3D with FID, MIG, MCC; demonstrate robotic video trajectory generation on LIBERO by recombining learned action components.

Result: Outperforms prior baselines on multiple datasets with lower FID and higher disentanglement scores (MIG, MCC). Demonstrates a novel robotic-trajectory application, producing diverse sequences and increasing state-space coverage for exploration on LIBERO.

Conclusion: Adversarial recombination promotes coherent, semantically meaningful factor recombinations and validates that factorized latent spaces can be learned without explicit factor-level supervision, with practical benefits for image synthesis and robotics exploration.

Abstract: Decomposing complex data into factorized representations can reveal reusable components and enable synthesizing new samples via component recombination. We investigate this in the context of diffusion-based models that learn factorized latent spaces without factor-level supervision. In images, factors can capture background, illumination, and object attributes; in robotic videos, they can capture reusable motion components. To improve both latent factor discovery and quality of compositional generation, we introduce an adversarial training signal via a discriminator trained to distinguish between single-source samples and those generated by recombining factors across sources. By optimizing the generator to fool this discriminator, we encourage physical and semantic consistency in the resulting recombinations. Our method outperforms implementations of prior baselines on CelebA-HQ, Virtual KITTI, CLEVR, and Falcor3D, achieving lower FID scores and better disentanglement as measured by MIG and MCC. Furthermore, we demonstrate a novel application to robotic video trajectories: by recombining learned action components, we generate diverse sequences that significantly increase state-space coverage for exploration on the LIBERO benchmark.

</details>


### [78] [Vision-DeepResearch: Incentivizing DeepResearch Capability in Multimodal Large Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22060)
*Wenxuan Huang,Yu Zeng,Qiuchen Wang,Zhen Fang,Shaosheng Cao,Zheng Chu,Qingyu Yin,Shuang Chen,Zhenfei Yin,Lin Chen,Zehui Chen,Yao Hu,Philip Torr,Feng Zhao,Wanli Ouyang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Vision-DeepResearch introduces a multimodal deep-research paradigm for MLLMs that enables multi-turn, multi-entity, and multi-scale visual/textual search to robustly gather evidence in noisy real-world scenarios, outperforming existing multimodal deep-research MLLMs and closed-source workflows; code will be released.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current reasoning-then-tool-call approaches rely on naive single-shot queries and limited search depth, making them fragile to noise and unable to aggregate evidence across diverse sources. There is a need for iterative, multi-entity, multi-scale retrieval integrated into MLLMs to handle complex questions.

Method: Proposes Vision-DeepResearch: a multi-turn, multi-entity, multi-scale multimodal search framework integrated into an end-to-end MLLM. It supports dozens of reasoning steps and hundreds of engine interactions, with deep-research capabilities internalized via cold-start supervision and reinforcement learning. The approach aims to robustly hit real-world search engines and integrate external evidence, with code to be released at GitHub.

Result: Claims substantial performance gains over existing multimodal deep-research MLLMs and workflows built on strong closed-source models such as GPT-5, Gemini-2.5-pro, and Claude-4-Sonnet.

Conclusion: If validated empirically, Vision-DeepResearch could set a new standard for robust multimodal deep-reasoning under noisy conditions by extensive external search and iterative reasoning; practical success will depend on empirical evaluation, data, and compute resources for training and inference.

Abstract: Multimodal large language models (MLLMs) have achieved remarkable success across a broad range of vision tasks. However, constrained by the capacity of their internal world knowledge, prior work has proposed augmenting MLLMs by ``reasoning-then-tool-call'' for visual and textual search engines to obtain substantial gains on tasks requiring extensive factual information. However, these approaches typically define multimodal search in a naive setting, assuming that a single full-level or entity-level image query and few text query suffices to retrieve the key evidence needed to answer the question, which is unrealistic in real-world scenarios with substantial visual noise. Moreover, they are often limited in the reasoning depth and search breadth, making it difficult to solve complex questions that require aggregating evidence from diverse visual and textual sources. Building on this, we propose Vision-DeepResearch, which proposes one new multimodal deep-research paradigm, i.e., performs multi-turn, multi-entity and multi-scale visual and textual search to robustly hit real-world search engines under heavy noise. Our Vision-DeepResearch supports dozens of reasoning steps and hundreds of engine interactions, while internalizing deep-research capabilities into the MLLM via cold-start supervision and RL training, resulting in a strong end-to-end multimodal deep-research MLLM. It substantially outperforming existing multimodal deep-research MLLMs, and workflows built on strong closed-source foundation model such as GPT-5, Gemini-2.5-pro and Claude-4-Sonnet. The code will be released in https://github.com/Osilly/Vision-DeepResearch.

</details>


### [79] [BLO-Inst: Bi-Level Optimization Based Alignment of YOLO and SAM for Robust Instance Segmentation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22061)
*Li Zhang,Pengtao Xie*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: BLO-Inst introduces a bi-level optimization framework that aligns object detection with segmentation objectives to produce segmentation-aware prompts for SAM, enabling automated prompting and improved mask quality across general and biomedical domains.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: SAM's zero-shot segmentation relies on manual prompts; replacing prompts with detectors offers automation but suffers objective mismatch (localization vs prompting context) and alignment overfitting in joint training. A unified approach is needed to optimize prompts for segmentation performance rather than localization alone.

Method: Formulate as nested optimization with disjoint data splits D1 and D2. Lower-level: fine-tune SAM on D1 to maximize segmentation fidelity given detector proposals. Upper-level: update the detector to minimize the validation loss of the fine-tuned SAM on D2, turning the detector into a segmentation-aware prompt generator.

Result: Empirical results show BLO-Inst surpasses standard baselines in both general and biomedical segmentation tasks.

Conclusion: Bi-level alignment provides a principled way to align detection and segmentation objectives, delivering improved automated prompting for SAM and better generalization.

Abstract: The Segment Anything Model has revolutionized image segmentation with its zero-shot capabilities, yet its reliance on manual prompts hinders fully automated deployment. While integrating object detectors as prompt generators offers a pathway to automation, existing pipelines suffer from two fundamental limitations: objective mismatch, where detectors optimized for geometric localization do not correspond to the optimal prompting context required by SAM, and alignment overfitting in standard joint training, where the detector simply memorizes specific prompt adjustments for training samples rather than learning a generalizable policy. To bridge this gap, we introduce BLO-Inst, a unified framework that aligns detection and segmentation objectives by bi-level optimization. We formulate the alignment as a nested optimization problem over disjoint data splits. In the lower level, the SAM is fine-tuned to maximize segmentation fidelity given the current detection proposals on a subset ($D_1$). In the upper level, the detector is updated to generate bounding boxes that explicitly minimize the validation loss of the fine-tuned SAM on a separate subset ($D_2$). This effectively transforms the detector into a segmentation-aware prompt generator, optimizing the bounding boxes not just for localization accuracy, but for downstream mask quality. Extensive experiments demonstrate that BLO-Inst achieves superior performance, outperforming standard baselines on tasks in general and biomedical domains.

</details>


### [80] [RefAny3D: 3D Asset-Referenced Diffusion Models for Image Generation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22094)
*Hanzhuo Huang,Qingyang Bao,Zekai Gu,Zhongshuo Du,Cheng Lin,Yuan Liu,Sibei Yang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A cross-domain diffusion model uses multi-view RGB and 3D asset point maps to jointly model colors and canonical coordinates, achieving RGB image and point-map outputs that are spatially aligned with 3D references; aims to overcome single-image reference limitation by leveraging 3D assets.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To expand reference-based image generation beyond single-image references by incorporating 3D assets, enabling consistent generation with 3D references and enabling two aligned outputs (RGB and point maps).
