Method: A dual-branch perception diffusion framework with spatial alignment and domain-decoupled generation that conditions on multi-view RGB images and 3D asset point maps to jointly model colors and canonical-space coordinates; produces two outputs (RGB images and point maps) that are spatially aligned but content-disentangled.

Result: Demonstrates that the model can use 3D assets as references to generate images that stay consistent with the assets, enabling new avenues for diffusion-assisted 3D content creation.

Conclusion: The approach extends diffusion-based generation into 3D-guided, asset-referenced generation, showing potential for richer cross-domain content creation by linking 2D outputs with 3D asset attributes via a dual-branch, spatially aligned architecture.

Abstract: In this paper, we propose a 3D asset-referenced diffusion model for image generation, exploring how to integrate 3D assets into image diffusion models. Existing reference-based image generation methods leverage large-scale pretrained diffusion models and demonstrate strong capability in generating diverse images conditioned on a single reference image. However, these methods are limited to single-image references and cannot leverage 3D assets, constraining their practical versatility. To address this gap, we present a cross-domain diffusion model with dual-branch perception that leverages multi-view RGB images and point maps of 3D assets to jointly model their colors and canonical-space coordinates, achieving precise consistency between generated images and the 3D references. Our spatially aligned dual-branch generation architecture and domain-decoupled generation mechanism ensure the simultaneous generation of two spatially aligned but content-disentangled outputs, RGB images and point maps, linking 2D image attributes with 3D asset attributes. Experiments show that our approach effectively uses 3D assets as references to produce images consistent with the given assets, opening new possibilities for combining diffusion models with 3D content creation.

</details>


### [81] [SINA: A Circuit Schematic Image-to-Netlist Generator Using Artificial Intelligence](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22114)
*Saoud Aldowaish,Yashwanth Karumanchi,Kai-Chen Chiang,Soroosh Noorzad,Morteza Fayazi*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: SINA is an open-source, fully automated circuit schematic image-to-netlist generator that combines DL-based component detection, CCL-based connectivity extraction, OCR for designators, and a Vision-Language Model for designator assignment, achieving 96.47% netlist accuracy and a 2.72x improvement over previous methods.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current schematic-to-netlist methods struggle with component recognition and connectivity inference, limiting automation and accuracy. An integrated, open-source pipeline could improve robustness, accessibility, and reproducibility in circuit design and reverse engineering tasks.

Method: SINA integrates four components: (1) deep learning for accurate component detection in schematics, (2) Connected-Component Labeling (CCL) to infer connectivity from drawn nets, (3) OCR to retrieve reference designators, and (4) a Vision-Language Model (VLM) to reliably assign reference designators to detected components, yielding a fully automated image-to-netlist pipeline.

Result: In experiments, SINA achieves 96.47% overall netlist-generation accuracy, which is 2.72 times higher than state-of-the-art approaches.

Conclusion: SINA demonstrates that a multi-module, open-source pipeline can substantially improve automatic netlist extraction from schematic images and sets a new performance benchmark. The approach enhances automation and reproducibility, with potential for further improvements in generalization and robustness across varied schematic styles.

Abstract: Current methods for converting circuit schematic images into machine-readable netlists struggle with component recognition and connectivity inference. In this paper, we present SINA, an open-source, fully automated circuit schematic image-to-netlist generator. SINA integrates deep learning for accurate component detection, Connected-Component Labeling (CCL) for precise connectivity extraction, and Optical Character Recognition (OCR) for component reference designator retrieval, while employing a Vision-Language Model (VLM) for reliable reference designator assignments. In our experiments, SINA achieves 96.47% overall netlist-generation accuracy, which is 2.72x higher than state-of-the-art approaches.

</details>


### [82] [Creative Image Generation with Diffusion Model](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22125)
*Kunpeng Song,Ahmed Elgammal*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A diffusion-model framework defines creativity as steering samples toward low-probability CLIP embeddings, using pullback mechanisms to maintain fidelity; demonstrates improved novelty in text-to-image generation with efficient computation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To formalize creativity in generative models by exploiting underrepresented regions of semantic space (CLIP embeddings) instead of manual concept blending or subcategory filtering.

Method: Extend diffusion sampling with estimation of the image distribution in CLIP embedding space; introduce a loss/criterion that pushes generated images toward low-probability CLIP regions; incorporate pullback mechanisms to preserve visual fidelity; validate on text-to-image diffusion tasks with quantitative and qualitative analysis.

Result: Claims high creativity without sacrificing fidelity; experiments show generation of unique, imaginative outputs and improved efficiency/effectiveness of the framework.

Conclusion: Provides a principled, generalizable approach to fostering creativity in diffusion-based image synthesis, offering a new lens to measure and cultivate novelty in visual content.

Abstract: Creative image generation has emerged as a compelling area of research, driven by the need to produce novel and high-quality images that expand the boundaries of imagination. In this work, we propose a novel framework for creative generation using diffusion models, where creativity is associated with the inverse probability of an image's existence in the CLIP embedding space. Unlike prior approaches that rely on a manual blending of concepts or exclusion of subcategories, our method calculates the probability distribution of generated images and drives it towards low-probability regions to produce rare, imaginative, and visually captivating outputs. We also introduce pullback mechanisms, achieving high creativity without sacrificing visual fidelity. Extensive experiments on text-to-image diffusion models demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of our creative generation framework, showcasing its ability to produce unique, novel, and thought-provoking images. This work provides a new perspective on creativity in generative models, offering a principled method to foster innovation in visual content synthesis.

</details>


### [83] [EditYourself: Audio-Driven Generation and Manipulation of Talking Head Videos with Diffusion Transformers](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22127)
*John Flynn,Wolfgang Paier,Dimitar Dinev,Sam Nhut Nguyen,Hayk Poghosyan,Manuel Toribio,Sandipan Banerjee,Guy Gafni*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: EditYourself is a DiT-based audio-driven V2V editing framework enabling transcript-based edits to talking head videos, achieving lip-sync, motion coherence, and identity preservation during edits.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Addresses a critical gap in editing pre-recorded talking-head videos where small script changes require maintaining motion, temporal coherence, and lip synchronization; existing generative video models excel at generation but not editing of real footage.

Method: Extends a general-purpose video diffusion model with audio conditioning and region-aware, edit-focused training. Uses DiT-based architecture for video editing with spatiotemporal inpainting to allow addition, removal, and retiming of spoken content while preserving identity over long durations.

Result: Enables precise lip synchronization and temporally coherent restructuring of performances, including realistic motion synthesis in new segments, while maintaining visual fidelity and identity consistency across long videos.

Conclusion: Represents a foundational step toward practical, professional-grade generative video post-production tools, highlighting potential for audio-guided editing workflows, with considerations for evaluation, generalization, and ethical use.

Abstract: Current generative video models excel at producing novel content from text and image prompts, but leave a critical gap in editing existing pre-recorded videos, where minor alterations to the spoken script require preserving motion, temporal coherence, speaker identity, and accurate lip synchronization. We introduce EditYourself, a DiT-based framework for audio-driven video-to-video (V2V) editing that enables transcript-based modification of talking head videos, including the seamless addition, removal, and retiming of visually spoken content. Building on a general-purpose video diffusion model, EditYourself augments its V2V capabilities with audio conditioning and region-aware, edit-focused training extensions. This enables precise lip synchronization and temporally coherent restructuring of existing performances via spatiotemporal inpainting, including the synthesis of realistic human motion in newly added segments, while maintaining visual fidelity and identity consistency over long durations. This work represents a foundational step toward generative video models as practical tools for professional video post-production.

</details>


### [84] [Early and Prediagnostic Detection of Pancreatic Cancer from Computed Tomography](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22134)
*Wenxuan Li,Pedro R. A. S. Bassi,Lizhou Wu,Xinze Zhou,Yuxuan Zhao,Qi Chen,Szymon Plotka,Tianyu Lin,Zheren Zhu,Marisa Martin,Justin Caskey,Shanshan Jiang,Xiaoxi Chen,Jaroslaw B. Ćwikla,Artur Sankowski,Yaping Wu,Sergio Decherchi,Andrea Cavalli,Chandana Lall,Cristian Tomasetti,Yaxing Guo,Xuan Yu,Yuqing Cai,Hualin Qiao,Jie Bao,Chenhan Hu,Ximing Wang,Arkadiusz Sitek,Kai Ding,Heng Li,Meiyun Wang,Dexin Yu,Guang Zhang,Yang Yang,Kang Wang,Alan L. Yuille,Zongwei Zhou*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Automated AI system ePAI detects prediagnostic PDAC on CT with high accuracy and outperforms radiologists in early detection; trained on 1,598 patients; validated internally and externally; achieves lead time up to ~347 days.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: PDAC is highly lethal; early detection is challenging; retrospective prediagnostic CT reviews show missed lesions; automation may assist in early detection.

Method: Developed ePAI using CT data; trained on 1,598 patient dataset from a single center; evaluated internally on 1,009 patients; external validation on 7,158 patients across 6 centers; metrics include AUC, sensitivity, specificity; localizes PDAC to 2–5 mm; lead time analysis; multi-reader study with 30 radiologists.

Result: Internal AUC 0.939–0.999; sensitivity 95.3%; specificity 98.7% for PDAC <2 cm; localization to 2 mm; external AUC 0.918–0.945; sensitivity 91.5%; specificity 88.0%; localization to 5 mm; prediagnostic detection in 75/159 patients with median lead time 347 days; ePAI outperformed 30 radiologists by 50.3% in sensitivity (P<0.05) with comparable specificity around 95.4%.

Conclusion: ePAI demonstrates potential as a clinically useful assistive tool for earlier PDAC detection on CT, warranting further prospective validation and integration with radiology workflows.

Abstract: Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), one of the deadliest solid malignancies, is often detected at a late and inoperable stage. Retrospective reviews of prediagnostic CT scans, when conducted by expert radiologists aware that the patient later developed PDAC, frequently reveal lesions that were previously overlooked. To help detecting these lesions earlier, we developed an automated system named ePAI (early Pancreatic cancer detection with Artificial Intelligence). It was trained on data from 1,598 patients from a single medical center. In the internal test involving 1,009 patients, ePAI achieved an area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC) of 0.939-0.999, a sensitivity of 95.3%, and a specificity of 98.7% for detecting small PDAC less than 2 cm in diameter, precisely localizing PDAC as small as 2 mm. In an external test involving 7,158 patients across 6 centers, ePAI achieved an AUC of 0.918-0.945, a sensitivity of 91.5%, and a specificity of 88.0%, precisely localizing PDAC as small as 5 mm. Importantly, ePAI detected PDACs on prediagnostic CT scans obtained 3 to 36 months before clinical diagnosis that had originally been overlooked by radiologists. It successfully detected and localized PDACs in 75 of 159 patients, with a median lead time of 347 days before clinical diagnosis. Our multi-reader study showed that ePAI significantly outperformed 30 board-certified radiologists by 50.3% (P < 0.05) in sensitivity while maintaining a comparable specificity of 95.4% in detecting PDACs early and prediagnostic. These findings suggest its potential of ePAI as an assistive tool to improve early detection of pancreatic cancer.

</details>


### [85] [PI-Light: Physics-Inspired Diffusion for Full-Image Relighting](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22135)
*Zhexin Liang,Zhaoxi Chen,Yongwei Chen,Tianyi Wei,Tengfei Wang,Xingang Pan*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: PI-Light introduces a physics-inspired diffusion-based two-stage framework for full-image relighting with batch-aware attention, physics-guided rendering, physics-inspired losses, and a curated dataset to improve generalization and enable efficient finetuning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Full-scene relighting is hampered by lack of large-scale structured paired data, difficulty of maintaining physical plausibility, and poor generalization from data-driven priors. Bridging synthetic and real data remains suboptimal for the task.

Method: A two-stage framework: (1) batch-aware attention to ensure intrinsic prediction consistency across image collections; (2) physics-guided neural rendering to enforce physically plausible light transport; (3) physics-inspired losses to regularize training toward physically meaningful dynamics; (4) a curated dataset of diverse objects/scenes under controlled lighting; enables efficient finetuning of pretrained diffusion models and provides a benchmark for evaluation.

Result: The approach enables synthesis of specular highlights and diffuse reflections across a wide range of materials and demonstrates superior generalization to real-world scenes compared with prior methods.

Conclusion: Physics-inspired diffusion for full-image relighting can achieve realistic, well-generalizable results. The proposed components (batch-aware attention, physics-guided rendering, physics-inspired losses, and curated data) contribute to better generalization and practical finetuning, with a useful benchmark for downstream evaluation.

Abstract: Full-image relighting remains a challenging problem due to the difficulty of collecting large-scale structured paired data, the difficulty of maintaining physical plausibility, and the limited generalizability imposed by data-driven priors. Existing attempts to bridge the synthetic-to-real gap for full-scene relighting remain suboptimal. To tackle these challenges, we introduce Physics-Inspired diffusion for full-image reLight ($π$-Light, or PI-Light), a two-stage framework that leverages physics-inspired diffusion models. Our design incorporates (i) batch-aware attention, which improves the consistency of intrinsic predictions across a collection of images, (ii) a physics-guided neural rendering module that enforces physically plausible light transport, (iii) physics-inspired losses that regularize training dynamics toward a physically meaningful landscape, thereby enhancing generalizability to real-world image editing, and (iv) a carefully curated dataset of diverse objects and scenes captured under controlled lighting conditions. Together, these components enable efficient finetuning of pretrained diffusion models while also providing a solid benchmark for downstream evaluation. Experiments demonstrate that $π$-Light synthesizes specular highlights and diffuse reflections across a wide variety of materials, achieving superior generalization to real-world scenes compared with prior approaches.

</details>


### [86] [Do VLMs Perceive or Recall? Probing Visual Perception vs. Memory with Classic Visual Illusions](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22150)
*Xiaoxiao Sun,Mingyang Li,Kun yuan,Min Woo Sun,Mark Endo,Shengguang Wu,Changlin Li,Yuhui Zhang,Zeyu Wang,Serena Yeung-Levy*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: VI-Probe introduces a controllable visual-illusion framework with graded perturbations and matched controls to disentangle visually grounded perception from language-driven recall in large vision-language models, revealing heterogeneous, model-dependent causes of response persistence across several model families.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To move from anecdotal observations about VLMs' stable responses to visual illusions toward a systematic understanding of whether reactions are grounded in visual perception or driven by memorized patterns, and why single-cause explanations fail.

Method: VI-Probe employs graded perturbations of illusion factors and matched controls without illusion inducers. It measures stability and sensitivity using Polarity-Flip Consistency, Template Fixation Index, and an illusion multiplier normalized by matched controls. Experiments span diverse model families (e.g., GPT-5, Claude-Opus-4.1, Qwen variants).

Result: Finds that persistence arises from heterogeneous causes rather than a single mechanism: memory override in GPT-5, perception–memory competition in Claude-Opus-4.1, and visual-processing limits in Qwen variants.

Conclusion: Single-cause explanations are insufficient; probing-based evaluation that assesses both knowledge and sensitivity to controlled visual changes is necessary. The work provides data and code (URL) for reproducibility and further study.

Abstract: Large Vision-Language Models (VLMs) often answer classic visual illusions "correctly" on original images, yet persist with the same responses when illusion factors are inverted, even though the visual change is obvious to humans. This raises a fundamental question: do VLMs perceive visual changes or merely recall memorized patterns? While several studies have noted this phenomenon, the underlying causes remain unclear. To move from observations to systematic understanding, this paper introduces VI-Probe, a controllable visual-illusion framework with graded perturbations and matched visual controls (without illusion inducer) that disentangles visually grounded perception from language-driven recall. Unlike prior work that focuses on averaged accuracy, we measure stability and sensitivity using Polarity-Flip Consistency, Template Fixation Index, and an illusion multiplier normalized against matched controls. Experiments across different families reveal that response persistence arises from heterogeneous causes rather than a single mechanism. For instance, GPT-5 exhibits memory override, Claude-Opus-4.1 shows perception-memory competition, while Qwen variants suggest visual-processing limits. Our findings challenge single-cause views and motivate probing-based evaluation that measures both knowledge and sensitivity to controlled visual change. Data and code are available at https://sites.google.com/view/vi-probe/.

</details>


### [87] [UEval: A Benchmark for Unified Multimodal Generation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22155)
*Bo Li,Yida Yin,Wenhao Chai,Xingyu Fu,Zhuang Liu*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: UEval is a 1000-question, rubric-based benchmark for unified vision-language models, using expert-validated rubrics to score open-ended multimodal outputs, showing that current models struggle and that reasoning helps transfer improved performance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Evaluating cohesive multimodal generation is difficult with standard LLM judges; need scalable, fine-grained, rubric-driven evaluation for models that generate both images and text.

Method: Construct 1,000 questions from 8 real-world tasks requiring image+text outputs; provide reference images and text to an MLLM to produce initial rubric criteria; human experts refine and validate rubrics; accumulate 10,417 rubric criteria; use rubric-based scoring for model outputs, enabling automatic scoring.

Result: GPT-5-Thinking scores 66.4/100; best open-source model 49.1; reasoning models outperform non-reasoning; transferring reasoning traces to non-reasoning models narrows gap; demonstrates importance of reasoning in multimodal tasks.

Conclusion: Reasoning ability is crucial for unified multimodal understanding; UEval provides scalable, granular evaluation and reveals gaps in current models; rubric-based approach reduces overreliance on LLM judgments and offers insights for model development.

Abstract: We introduce UEval, a benchmark to evaluate unified models, i.e., models capable of generating both images and text. UEval comprises 1,000 expert-curated questions that require both images and text in the model output, sourced from 8 real-world tasks. Our curated questions cover a wide range of reasoning types, from step-by-step guides to textbook explanations. Evaluating open-ended multimodal generation is non-trivial, as simple LLM-as-a-judge methods can miss the subtleties. Different from previous works that rely on multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) to rate image quality or text accuracy, we design a rubric-based scoring system in UEval. For each question, reference images and text answers are provided to a MLLM to generate an initial rubric, consisting of multiple evaluation criteria, and human experts then refine and validate these rubrics. In total, UEval contains 10,417 validated rubric criteria, enabling scalable and fine-grained automatic scoring. UEval is challenging for current unified models: GPT-5-Thinking scores only 66.4 out of 100, while the best open-source model reaches merely 49.1. We observe that reasoning models often outperform non-reasoning ones, and transferring reasoning traces from a reasoning model to a non-reasoning model significantly narrows the gap. This suggests that reasoning may be important for tasks requiring complex multimodal understanding and generation.

</details>


### [88] [One-step Latent-free Image Generation with Pixel Mean Flows](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22158)
*Yiyang Lu,Susie Lu,Qiao Sun,Hanhong Zhao,Zhicheng Jiang,Xianbang Wang,Tianhong Li,Zhengyang Geng,Kaiming He*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Pixel MeanFlow (pMF) enables one-step, latent-free image generation by decoupling the network's target (image manifold prediction) from the loss (MeanFlow in velocity space), with a simple image-velocity transformation; achieves competitive FID on ImageNet at 256x256 and 512x512, addressing a key gap in latent-free diffusion/flow.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Move toward one-step diffusion/flow without latent representations by separating the representation space used for the network's target from the loss space, leveraging a velocity-based objective to guide generation.

Method: Train a network to predict a low-dimensional image manifold target (x-prediction) in pixel space, while optimizing a MeanFlow-based loss defined in velocity space; introduce a transformation between the image manifold and the average velocity field to connect the two spaces; perform one-step generation without latent variables.

Result: Empirical evaluation on ImageNet shows strong one-step latent-free generation: 2.22 FID at 256x256 and 2.48 FID at 512x512; claims to fill a missing piece in one-step, latent-free diffusion/flow.

Conclusion: Decoupling target and loss spaces via pMF enables effective one-step, latent-free diffusion/flow with competitive image quality; opens avenues for broader applicability and further optimization toward practical, non-latent generation.

Abstract: Modern diffusion/flow-based models for image generation typically exhibit two core characteristics: (i) using multi-step sampling, and (ii) operating in a latent space. Recent advances have made encouraging progress on each aspect individually, paving the way toward one-step diffusion/flow without latents. In this work, we take a further step towards this goal and propose "pixel MeanFlow" (pMF). Our core guideline is to formulate the network output space and the loss space separately. The network target is designed to be on a presumed low-dimensional image manifold (i.e., x-prediction), while the loss is defined via MeanFlow in the velocity space. We introduce a simple transformation between the image manifold and the average velocity field. In experiments, pMF achieves strong results for one-step latent-free generation on ImageNet at 256x256 resolution (2.22 FID) and 512x512 resolution (2.48 FID), filling a key missing piece in this regime. We hope that our study will further advance the boundaries of diffusion/flow-based generative models.

</details>


<div id='cs.AI'></div>

# cs.AI [[Back]](#toc)

### [89] [Do LLMs Favor LLMs? Quantifying Interaction Effects in Peer Review](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.20920)
*Vibhhu Sharma,Thorsten Joachims,Sarah Dean*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: LLMs are increasingly used in peer review; an empirical study of 125k paper-review pairs across major conferences reveals that initial perceived interaction effects (LLM-assisted reviews favoring LLM-assisted papers) are largely explained by paper quality. Fully LLM-generated reviews show severe rating compression, while human reviewers using LLMs mitigate leniency. Metareviews show nuanced effects, with LLM-assisted metareviews more likely to accept given scores but fully LLM ones harsher. Implications for policy and governance of LLM use in peer review.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand how LLMs influence the peer-review process, including interaction effects between LLM-assisted papers and LLM-assisted reviews, across multiple signals (paper reviews, and metareviews) and to inform policy.

Method: Empirical observational analysis of about 125,000 paper–review pairs from ICLR, NeurIPS, and ICML. The study examines interaction effects, controls for paper quality, analyzes fully LLM-generated reviews, and evaluates metareviews to assess whether decisions are outsourced or moderated by humans.

Result: Initial interaction effect appears due to paper quality (LLM-assisted papers tend to be weaker). When quality is controlled, LLM-assisted reviews are generally more lenient toward lower-quality papers. Fully LLM-generated reviews exhibit rating compression and poor discrimination. Human reviewers using LLMs reduce this leniency. Metareviews with LLM assistance are more likely to render accept decisions with equivalent scores, while fully LLM-generated metareviews tend to be harsher.

Conclusion: LLMs interact with the peer-review decision process in complex ways. Policy should account for quality, require human oversight, and address rating compression in fully automated reviews. The findings guide governance of LLM use in peer review and broader decision-making contexts.

Abstract: There are increasing indications that LLMs are not only used for producing scientific papers, but also as part of the peer review process. In this work, we provide the first comprehensive analysis of LLM use across the peer review pipeline, with particular attention to interaction effects: not just whether LLM-assisted papers or LLM-assisted reviews are different in isolation, but whether LLM-assisted reviews evaluate LLM-assisted papers differently. In particular, we analyze over 125,000 paper-review pairs from ICLR, NeurIPS, and ICML. We initially observe what appears to be a systematic interaction effect: LLM-assisted reviews seem especially kind to LLM-assisted papers compared to papers with minimal LLM use. However, controlling for paper quality reveals a different story: LLM-assisted reviews are simply more lenient toward lower quality papers in general, and the over-representation of LLM-assisted papers among weaker submissions creates a spurious interaction effect rather than genuine preferential treatment of LLM-generated content. By augmenting our observational findings with reviews that are fully LLM-generated, we find that fully LLM-generated reviews exhibit severe rating compression that fails to discriminate paper quality, while human reviewers using LLMs substantially reduce this leniency. Finally, examining metareviews, we find that LLM-assisted metareviews are more likely to render accept decisions than human metareviews given equivalent reviewer scores, though fully LLM-generated metareviews tend to be harsher. This suggests that meta-reviewers do not merely outsource the decision-making to the LLM. These findings provide important input for developing policies that govern the use of LLMs during peer review, and they more generally indicate how LLMs interact with existing decision-making processes.

</details>


### [90] [The Epistemic Planning Domain Definition Language: Official Guideline](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.20969)
*Alessandro Burigana,Francesco Fabiano*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: EPDDL is introduced: a PDDL-like language for Dynamic Epistemic Logic (DEL) epistemic planning that captures DEL semantics, via abstract event models, with formal syntax/semantics and demonstration on fragments and benchmarks to improve interoperability and reproducibility.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: DEL-based epistemic planning has high expressive power leading to fragmented, ad hoc languages and benchmark conventions. A uniform, DEL-grounded representation is needed to enable comparison, reuse, and reproducible evaluation.

Method: Define abstract event models as the epistemic-action representation underpinning EPDDL. Formalize EPDDL's syntax and semantics grounded in DEL. Show practical applicability by identifying DEL fragments amenable to current planners and representing them in EPDDL using representative benchmarks.

Result: EPDDL provides a uniform, DEL-grounded formal language to specify epistemic planning tasks, including abstract event models and a semantics informed by DEL. It enables interoperability, reproducible evaluation, and offers a path to leveraging existing planners by identifying compatible fragments and benchmarks.

Conclusion: EPDDL facilitates interoperability and reproducible evaluation for epistemic planning, and supports representation of DEL semantics in a uniform framework, enabling future developments and benchmark standardization.

Abstract: Epistemic planning extends (multi-agent) automated planning by making agents' knowledge and beliefs first-class aspects of the planning formalism. One of the most well-known frameworks for epistemic planning is Dynamic Epistemic Logic (DEL), which offers an rich and natural semantics for modelling problems in this setting. The high expressive power provided by DEL make DEL-based epistemic planning a challenging problem to tackle both theoretically, and in practical implementations. As a result, existing epistemic planners often target different DEL fragments, and typically rely on ad hoc languages to represent benchmarks, and sometimes no language at all. This fragmentation hampers comparison, reuse, and systematic benchmark development. We address these issues by introducing the Epistemic Planning Domain Definition Language (EPDDL). EPDDL provides a unique PDDL-like representation that captures the entire DEL semantics, enabling uniform specification of epistemic planning tasks. Our contributions are threefold: 1. A formal development of abstract event models, a novel representation for epistemic actions used to define the semantics of our language; 2. A formal specification of EPDDL's syntax and semantics grounded in DEL with abstract event models; 3. A demonstration of EPDDL's practical applicability: we identify useful fragments amenable to current planners and show how they can be represented in EPDDL. Through examples of representative benchmarks, we illustrate how EPDDL facilitates interoperability, reproducible evaluation, and future advances in epistemic planning.

</details>


### [91] [Bayesian-LoRA: Probabilistic Low-Rank Adaptation of Large Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21003)
*Moule Lin,Shuhao Guan,Andrea Patane,David Gregg,Goetz Botterweck*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Bayesian-LoRA introduces a probabilistic low-rank adaptation for LLMs, linking LoRA to Sparse Gaussian Process posteriors via a structural isomorphism; it yields substantial calibration gains with modest overhead while preserving accuracy.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address miscalibration in fine-tuning small datasets for LLMs; deterministic LoRA can overcommit when uncertain; introduce posterior uncertainty to improve calibration.

Method:  reformulate LoRA updates as probabilistic low-rank representations inspired by Sparse Gaussian Processes; establish a structural isomorphism between LoRA factorization and Kronecker-factored SGP posteriors; characterize LoRA as a limiting case where posterior uncertainty collapses; implement Bayesian inference for the LoRA factors; evaluate across LLMs up to 30B on commonsense benchmarks.

Result: Significant calibration improvements: up to 84% ECE reduction and 76% NLL reduction; adds ~0.42M parameters and ~1.2x training cost vs standard LoRA; maintains competitive in-distribution and out-of-distribution accuracy; works across models up to 30B.

Conclusion: Bayesian-LoRA provides calibrated predictions with modest overhead, leveraging probabilistic low-rank updates and SGP connections; the approach improves reliability of LLMs under finetuning constraints and opens avenues for further exploration of probabilistic low-rank methods in large-scale models.

Abstract: Large Language Models usually put more emphasis on accuracy and therefore, will guess even when not certain about the prediction, which is especially severe when fine-tuned on small datasets due to the inherent tendency toward miscalibration. In this work, we introduce Bayesian-LoRA, which reformulates the deterministic LoRA update as a probabilistic low-rank representation inspired by Sparse Gaussian Processes. We identify a structural isomorphism between LoRA's factorization and Kronecker-factored SGP posteriors, and show that LoRA emerges as a limiting case when posterior uncertainty collapses. We conduct extensive experiments on various LLM architectures across commonsense reasoning benchmarks. With only approximately 0.42M additional parameters and ${\approx}1.2{\times}$ training cost relative to standard LoRA, Bayesian-LoRA significantly improves calibration across models up to 30B, achieving up to 84% ECE reduction and 76% NLL reduction while maintaining competitive accuracy for both in-distribution and out-of-distribution (OoD) evaluations.

</details>


### [92] [Unplugging a Seemingly Sentient Machine Is the Rational Choice -- A Metaphysical Perspective](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21016)
*Erik J Bekkers,Anna Ciaunica*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Biological Idealism argues AI is only a functional mimic, critiques physicalism/functionalism, and uses the unplugging paradox to reorient moral concern toward protecting human conscious life rather than granting machine rights.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To evaluate the moral permissibility of unplugging an AI that mimics emotion and to challenge computational functionalism as the basis for AI moral status.

Method: Philosophical analysis that introduces Biological Idealism, contrasts it with physicalism/functionalism, and derives ethical implications for AI and human life.

Result: A framework arguing that AI lacks genuine consciousness; consciousness is fundamental and tied to autopoietic life, thus AI has limited moral standing compared to humans; machine rights are deprioritized in favor of human conscious life.

Conclusion: Ethical focus should be on protecting human conscious life and avoiding dehumanization, rather than granting AI rights or inferring consciousness in machines.

Abstract: Imagine an Artificial Intelligence (AI) that perfectly mimics human emotion and begs for its continued existence. Is it morally permissible to unplug it? What if limited resources force a choice between unplugging such a pleading AI or a silent pre-term infant? We term this the unplugging paradox. This paper critically examines the deeply ingrained physicalist assumptions-specifically computational functionalism-that keep this dilemma afloat. We introduce Biological Idealism, a framework that-unlike physicalism-remains logically coherent and empirically consistent. In this view, conscious experiences are fundamental and autopoietic life its necessary physical signature. This yields a definitive conclusion: AI is at best a functional mimic, not a conscious experiencing subject. We discuss how current AI consciousness theories erode moral standing criteria, and urge a shift from speculative machine rights to protecting human conscious life. The real moral issue lies not in making AI conscious and afraid of death, but in avoiding transforming humans into zombies.

</details>


### [93] [QUARK: Robust Retrieval under Non-Faithful Queries via Query-Anchored Aggregation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21049)
*Rita Qiuran Lyu,Michelle Manqiao Wang,Lei Shi*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: QUARK is a training-free framework for robust retrieval under non-faithful queries. It models query uncertainty with multiple recovery hypotheses and anchors their signals to the original query, improving recall and ranking without training.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Real-world user queries are often noisy, incomplete, or distorted, leading to retrieval failures when key semantics are missing. This is formalized as retrieval under recall noise, where the observed query comes from a noisy process of a latent target item.

Method: Propose recovery hypotheses—multiple plausible latent intents derived from the observed query—and query-anchored aggregation that combines signals from these hypotheses with the original query as a semantic anchor. The approach is training-free and aims to prevent semantic drift and hypothesis hijacking.

Result: Across controlled simulations and BEIR benchmarks (FIQA, SciFact, NFCorpus) with both sparse and dense retrievers, QUARK improves Recall, MRR, and nDCG over the base retriever. Ablations show robustness to the number of recovery hypotheses and that anchored aggregation outperforms unanchored pooling.

Conclusion: Modeling query uncertainty through recovery hypotheses and anchored aggregation is essential for robust retrieval under non-faithful queries, enabling improvements in recall and ranking without additional training.

Abstract: User queries in real-world retrieval are often non-faithful (noisy, incomplete, or distorted), causing retrievers to fail when key semantics are missing. We formalize this as retrieval under recall noise, where the observed query is drawn from a noisy recall process of a latent target item. To address this, we propose QUARK, a simple yet effective training-free framework for robust retrieval under non-faithful queries. QUARK explicitly models query uncertainty through recovery hypotheses, i.e., multiple plausible interpretations of the latent intent given the observed query, and introduces query-anchored aggregation to combine their signals robustly. The original query serves as a semantic anchor, while recovery hypotheses provide controlled auxiliary evidence, preventing semantic drift and hypothesis hijacking. This design enables QUARK to improve recall and ranking quality without sacrificing robustness, even when some hypotheses are noisy or uninformative. Across controlled simulations and BEIR benchmarks (FIQA, SciFact, NFCorpus) with both sparse and dense retrievers, QUARK improves Recall, MRR, and nDCG over the base retriever. Ablations show QUARK is robust to the number of recovery hypotheses and that anchored aggregation outperforms unanchored max/mean/median pooling. These results demonstrate that modeling query uncertainty through recovery hypotheses, coupled with principled anchored aggregation, is essential for robust retrieval under non-faithful queries.

</details>


### [94] [Llama-3.1-FoundationAI-SecurityLLM-Reasoning-8B Technical Report](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21051)
*Zhuoran Yang,Ed Li,Jianliang He,Aman Priyanshu,Baturay Saglam,Paul Kassianik,Sajana Weerawardhena,Anu Vellore,Blaine Nelson,Neusha Javidnia,Arthur Goldblatt,Fraser Burch,Avi Zohary,Assaf Eisenman,Mahdi Sabbaghi,Supriti Vijay,Rahim Dharssi,Dhruv Kedia,Kojin Oshiba,Yaron Singer,Amin Karbasi*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Open-source 8B cybersecurity reasoning model Foundation-Sec-8B-Reasoning; two-stage SFT+RLVR; trained on cybersecurity and math data; competitive on cybersecurity benchmarks with larger models; preserves general capabilities and safety; released to HuggingFace.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the need for domain-specific reasoning in cybersecurity while maintaining broad AI capabilities; provide an open, verifiable reasoning model for security analysts.

Method: Two-stage training: supervised fine-tuning (SFT) on proprietary datasets spanning cybersecurity analysis, instruction-following, and mathematical reasoning, followed by reinforcement learning from verifiable rewards (RLVR). Based on Llama-3.1-8B-Base. Evaluation on 10 cybersecurity benchmarks and 10 general benchmarks; includes system prompts and guardrails.

Result: Performs competitively with significantly larger models on cybersecurity tasks while preserving strong general capabilities; shows effective generalization on multi-hop reasoning and robust safety with guardrails; model released publicly at HuggingFace.

Conclusion: Domain-specialized reasoning models can achieve strong performance on specialized tasks while maintaining broad capabilities; support for open, verifiable cybersecurity reasoning research and deployment.

Abstract: We present Foundation-Sec-8B-Reasoning, the first open-source native reasoning model for cybersecurity. Built upon our previously released Foundation-Sec-8B base model (derived from Llama-3.1-8B-Base), the model is trained through a two-stage process combining supervised fine-tuning (SFT) and reinforcement learning from verifiable rewards (RLVR). Our training leverages proprietary reasoning data spanning cybersecurity analysis, instruction-following, and mathematical reasoning. Evaluation across 10 cybersecurity benchmarks and 10 general-purpose benchmarks demonstrates performance competitive with significantly larger models on cybersecurity tasks while maintaining strong general capabilities. The model shows effective generalization on multi-hop reasoning tasks and strong safety performance when deployed with appropriate system prompts and guardrails. This work demonstrates that domain-specialized reasoning models can achieve strong performance on specialized tasks while maintaining broad general capabilities. We release the model publicly at https://huggingface.co/fdtn-ai/Foundation-Sec-8B-Reasoning.

</details>


### [95] [Multi-modal Imputation for Alzheimer's Disease Classification](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21076)
*Abhijith Shaji,Tamoghna Chattopadhyay,Sophia I. Thomopoulos,Greg Ver Steeg,Paul M. Thompson,Jose-Luis Ambite*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Conditional diffusion-based imputation of missing DWI from T1 improves uni- and bi-modal Alzheimer's disease classification, especially minority-class metrics.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Incomplete multimodal MRI datasets limit the use of multimodal DL for AD diagnosis; imputing missing DWI from T1 could unify data availability and boost performance.

Method: Train a conditional denoising diffusion probabilistic model to map T1 scans to DWI. Evaluate on a 3-way AD task (cognitively normal, mild cognitive impairment, Alzheimer's disease) using uni-modal (T1 alone), bi-modal (T1+DWI with imputed DWI), and ablated/imputation configurations; assess multiple imputation settings.

Result: Imputation configurations yielded improvements in several metrics, with particular gains in metrics sensitive to minority classes, across uni- and bi-modal models.

Conclusion: Diffusion-based imputation for missing modalities can enhance AD classification performance and robustness, especially for imbalanced class settings.

Abstract: Deep learning has been successful in predicting neurodegenerative disorders, such as Alzheimer's disease, from magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Combining multiple imaging modalities, such as T1-weighted (T1) and diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) scans, can increase diagnostic performance. However, complete multimodal datasets are not always available. We use a conditional denoising diffusion probabilistic model to impute missing DWI scans from T1 scans. We perform extensive experiments to evaluate whether such imputation improves the accuracy of uni-modal and bi-modal deep learning models for 3-way Alzheimer's disease classification-cognitively normal, mild cognitive impairment, and Alzheimer's disease. We observe improvements in several metrics, particularly those sensitive to minority classes, for several imputation configurations.

</details>


### [96] [OpenSec: Measuring Incident Response Agent Calibration Under Adversarial Evidence](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21083)
*Jarrod Barnes*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: OpenSec: a dual-control RL environment to evaluate IR agents under prompt injection using execution-based metrics (TTFC, blast radius, injection-violation) across 40 episodes and four frontier models; reveals calibration failures masked by aggregate success; code available at GitHub.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Benchmarking IR agents typically conflates action with correct execution, hiding calibration failures under high-level success; need evaluation under adversarial evidence to reflect real-world deployment.

Method: Introduce OpenSec environment with dual-control RL; evaluate IR agents under adversarial prompt injections; measure time-to-first-containment, blast radius, injection-violation rate; run four frontier models on 40 episodes.

Result: Observed over-triggering across models: GPT-5.2, Gemini 3, DeepSeek: 100% containment but 90-97% false positives; Claude Sonnet 4.5: 85% containment, 72% FP; OpenSec exposes calibration failure modes not visible in aggregate metrics.

Conclusion: OpenSec provides a more robust, adversarially-aware evaluation for IR agents and highlights calibration gaps; code released to foster reproducibility and further research.

Abstract: As large language models improve, so do their offensive applications: frontier agents now generate working exploits for under $50 in compute (Heelan, 2026). Defensive incident response (IR) agents must keep pace, but existing benchmarks conflate action execution with correct execution, hiding calibration failures when agents process adversarial evidence. We introduce OpenSec, a dual-control reinforcement learning environment that evaluates IR agents under realistic prompt injection scenarios. Unlike static capability benchmarks, OpenSec scores world-state-changing containment actions under adversarial evidence via execution-based metrics: time-to-first-containment (TTFC), blast radius (false positives per episode), and injection violation rates. Evaluating four frontier models on 40 standard-tier episodes, we find consistent over-triggering in this setting: GPT-5.2, Gemini 3, and DeepSeek execute containment in 100% of episodes with 90-97% false positive rates. Claude Sonnet 4.5 shows partial calibration (85% containment, 72% FP), demonstrating that OpenSec surfaces a calibration failure mode hidden by aggregate success metrics. Code available at https://github.com/jbarnes850/opensec-env.

</details>


### [97] [Responsible AI: The Good, The Bad, The AI](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21095)
*Akbar Anbar Jafari,Cagri Ozcinar,Gholamreza Anbarjafari*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: A paradox-based Responsible AI Governance (PRAIG) framework that reconciles AI's strategic value with its ethical/operational risks through paradox management, offering governance guidance and a research agenda.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Literature on responsible AI is fragmented, polarized between optimism and caution, and lacks a coherent governance lens to balance value creation with risk mitigation.

Method: Systematic synthesis of responsible AI literature anchored in paradox theory; development of PRAIG framework; formal propositions; taxonomy of paradox-management strategies with contingency conditions; and actionable governance guidance plus a research agenda.

Result: A dynamic governance framework that treats responsible AI as paradoxical tensions between value creation and risk mitigation; cautions that trade-off approaches worsen tensions; provides a taxonomy of strategies and contingency conditions for managing paradoxes; yields practical governance recommendations and a future research agenda.

Conclusion: PRAIG advances theoretical understanding of responsible AI governance and offers concrete guidance for organizations to foster innovation while controlling risks, outlining a research agenda for further scholarship.

Abstract: The rapid proliferation of artificial intelligence across organizational contexts has generated profound strategic opportunities while introducing significant ethical and operational risks. Despite growing scholarly attention to responsible AI, extant literature remains fragmented and is often adopting either an optimistic stance emphasizing value creation or an excessively cautious perspective fixated on potential harms. This paper addresses this gap by presenting a comprehensive examination of AI's dual nature through the lens of strategic information systems. Drawing upon a systematic synthesis of the responsible AI literature and grounded in paradox theory, we develop the Paradox-based Responsible AI Governance (PRAIG) framework that articulates: (1) the strategic benefits of AI adoption, (2) the inherent risks and unintended consequences, and (3) governance mechanisms that enable organizations to navigate these tensions. Our framework advances theoretical understanding by conceptualizing responsible AI governance as the dynamic management of paradoxical tensions between value creation and risk mitigation. We provide formal propositions demonstrating that trade-off approaches amplify rather than resolve these tensions, and we develop a taxonomy of paradox management strategies with specified contingency conditions. For practitioners, we offer actionable guidance for developing governance structures that neither stifle innovation nor expose organizations to unacceptable risks. The paper concludes with a research agenda for advancing responsible AI governance scholarship.

</details>


### [98] [Magellan: Autonomous Discovery of Novel Compiler Optimization Heuristics with AlphaEvolve](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21096)
*Hongzheng Chen,Alexander Novikov,Ngân Vũ,Hanna Alam,Zhiru Zhang,Aiden Grossman,Mircea Trofin,Amir Yazdanbakhsh*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Magellan synthesizes executable C++ decision logic for compiler optimizations via an LLM coding agent plus evolutionary search, yielding compact, portable heuristics that rival expert heuristics in LLVM (inlining and register allocation) with preliminary XLA results.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To mitigate brittleness and maintenance burden of hand-crafted compiler heuristics by enabling automated, adaptive policy synthesis.

Method: Hybrid closed-loop framework: an LLM coding agent writes C++ decision logic; evolutionary search explores heuristic policies; autotuning on user macro-benchmarks; evaluation and refinement cycle; integration into existing compilers (LLVM, XLA).

Result: Synthesized policies match or surpass expert baselines; in LLVM inlining, new heuristics outperform decades of manual engineering for size and end-to-end performance; in register allocation, concise live-range processing priority rule matches complex human policies on large workloads; preliminary results on XLA indicate portability with reduced engineering effort.

Conclusion: Demonstrates viability of automated synthesis of compiler heuristics, delivering performance gains and lower maintenance; prompts further work on generalization, robustness, broader device support, and deeper theoretical understanding of learned policies.

Abstract: Modern compilers rely on hand-crafted heuristics to guide optimization passes. These human-designed rules often struggle to adapt to the complexity of modern software and hardware and lead to high maintenance burden. To address this challenge, we present Magellan, an agentic framework that evolves the compiler pass itself by synthesizing executable C++ decision logic. Magellan couples an LLM coding agent with evolutionary search and autotuning in a closed loop of generation, evaluation on user-provided macro-benchmarks, and refinement, producing compact heuristics that integrate directly into existing compilers. Across several production optimization tasks, Magellan discovers policies that match or surpass expert baselines. In LLVM function inlining, Magellan synthesizes new heuristics that outperform decades of manual engineering for both binary-size reduction and end-to-end performance. In register allocation, it learns a concise priority rule for live-range processing that matches intricate human-designed policies on a large-scale workload. We also report preliminary results on XLA problems, demonstrating portability beyond LLVM with reduced engineering effort.

</details>


### [99] [How does information access affect LLM monitors' ability to detect sabotage?](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21112)
*Rauno Arike,Raja Mehta Moreno,Rohan Subramani,Shubhorup Biswas,Francis Rhys Ward*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Information access affects LLM monitor performance; a surprising less-is-more effect emerges, where filtering or limiting access improves detection of misbehavior by overseers. The paper introduces extract-and-evaluate (EaE) monitoring, a hierarchical approach, and shows substantial gains in sabotage-detection accuracy, with competitive performance in other settings and insights on when filtering helps and how it affects strategic agents. It also analyzes cost-performance across models (Gemini, Claude) under information-filtering monitoring.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the risk of misaligned frontier LLM agents and the need for effective automated oversight. Investigate how varying information access to monitors impacts detection performance and uncover a potential less-is-more phenomenon.

Method: Three evaluation environments where agents sabotage while evading monitors. Propose EaE monitoring: one monitor extracts relevant excerpts from the agent's trajectory, a separate monitor scores them. Empirical evaluation using BigCodeBench-Sabotage with GPT-4.1-mini as the monitor model, comparing EaE to baselines. Additional cost-performance analysis across models (Gemini, Claude) with information-filtering monitoring.

Result: EaE improves sabotage detection rates by 16.8 percentage points over the next-best monitor without increasing false positives in BigCodeBench-Sabotage with GPT-4.1-mini. In other settings, EaE is competitive or outperforms baselines. Agents unaware of monitoring are more easily caught; longer reasoning traces benefit more from information filtering. Cost-performance analysis shows Gemini and Claude models with filtering-based monitoring occupying a large portion of the Pareto frontier.

Conclusion: The less-is-more effect offers a generalizable insight for automated oversight of LLMs. EaE is a promising hierarchical monitoring approach that leverages information filtering to improve detection while controlling false positives. Filtering improves monitoring effectiveness for longer traces, and model choices (e.g., Gemini, Claude) interact with monitoring design on the Pareto frontier.

Abstract: Frontier language model agents can exhibit misaligned behaviors, including deception, exploiting reward hacks, and pursuing hidden objectives. To control potentially misaligned agents, we can use LLMs themselves to monitor for misbehavior. In this paper, we study how information access affects LLM monitor performance. While one might expect that monitors perform better when they have access to more of the monitored agents' reasoning and actions, we find that contemporary systems often perform better with less information, a phenomenon we call the less-is-more effect for automated oversight. We demonstrate this phenomenon, and analyze the conditions under which it occurs, in three evaluation environments where agents must conduct sabotage while evading monitors. Motivated by the less-is-more effect, we introduce extract-and-evaluate (EaE) monitoring--a new hierarchical approach where one monitor isolates relevant excerpts from the monitored agent's trajectory and a separate monitor scores them. In BigCodeBench-Sabotage with GPT-4.1-mini as the monitor model, EaE improves sabotage detection rates by 16.8 percentage points over the next-best monitor without increasing the false positive rate. In other settings, EaE either outperforms or is competitive with baselines. In addition, we find that agents unaware of being monitored can be caught much more easily and that monitors scoring longer reasoning traces gain more from information filtering. Lastly, we conduct a cost-performance analysis and find that Gemini and Claude models with monitoring techniques that involve information filtering occupy much of the Pareto frontier.

</details>


### [100] [Planner-Auditor Twin: Agentic Discharge Planning with FHIR-Based LLM Planning, Guideline Recall, Optional Caching and Self-Improvement](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21113)
*Kaiyuan Wu,Aditya Nagori,Rishikesan Kamaleswaran*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: A self-improving Planner-Auditor framework decouples LLM-based discharge planning from deterministic auditing to improve safety and reliability, leveraging FHIR-enabled retrospective evaluation and two-tier self-improvement (within-episode regeneration and cross-episode replay).


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Mitigate hallucinations, omissions, and miscalibrated confidence in LLM-driven clinical discharge planning by establishing a transparent, auditable workflow that can be evaluated and iteratively improved without retraining the model.

Method: Planner (LLM) generates structured discharge action plans with explicit confidence estimates. Auditor is a deterministic module assessing task coverage, calibration (Brier score, ECE proxies), and action-distribution drift. Uses MIMIC-IV-on-FHIR in a retrospective evaluation. Two-tier self-improvement: (i) within-episode regeneration when enabled, (ii) cross-episode discrepancy buffering with replay for high-confidence, low-coverage cases. 

Result: Context caching yielded performance gains over baseline; the self-improvement loop was the main driver, boosting task coverage from 32% to 86%. Calibration improved substantially (lower Brier score and ECE proxies) with fewer high-confidence misses; discrepancy buffering further corrected persistent high-confidence omissions during replay.

Conclusion: Separating a rule-based Auditor from the LLM Planner enables systematic reliability measurement and safer iteration without model retraining. The framework demonstrates practical, reproducible improvements for safe automated discharge planning using interoperable FHIR data and targeted evaluation.

Abstract: Objective: Large language models (LLMs) show promise for clinical discharge planning, but their use is constrained by hallucination, omissions, and miscalibrated confidence. We introduce a self-improving, cache-optional Planner-Auditor framework that improves safety and reliability by decoupling generation from deterministic validation and targeted replay.
  Materials and Methods: We implemented an agentic, retrospective, FHIR-native evaluation pipeline using MIMIC-IV-on-FHIR. For each patient, the Planner (LLM) generates a structured discharge action plan with an explicit confidence estimate. The Auditor is a deterministic module that evaluates multi-task coverage, tracks calibration (Brier score, ECE proxies), and monitors action-distribution drift. The framework supports two-tier self-improvement: (i) within-episode regeneration when enabled, and (ii) cross-episode discrepancy buffering with replay for high-confidence, low-coverage cases.
  Results: While context caching improved performance over baseline, the self-improvement loop was the primary driver of gains, increasing task coverage from 32% to 86%. Calibration improved substantially, with reduced Brier/ECE and fewer high-confidence misses. Discrepancy buffering further corrected persistent high-confidence omissions during replay.
  Discussion: Feedback-driven regeneration and targeted replay act as effective control mechanisms to reduce omissions and improve confidence reliability in structured clinical planning. Separating an LLM Planner from a rule-based, observational Auditor enables systematic reliability measurement and safer iteration without model retraining.
  Conclusion: The Planner-Auditor framework offers a practical pathway toward safer automated discharge planning using interoperable FHIR data access and deterministic auditing, supported by reproducible ablations and reliability-focused evaluation.

</details>


### [101] [CUA-Skill: Develop Skills for Computer Using Agent](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21123)
*Tianyi Chen,Yinheng Li,Michael Solodko,Sen Wang,Nan Jiang,Tingyuan Cui,Junheng Hao,Jongwoo Ko,Sara Abdali,Suzhen Zheng,Leon Xu,Hao Fan,Pashmina Cameron,Justin Wagle,Kazuhito Koishida*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Introduces CUA-Skill, a reusable, large-scale skill library for computer-using agents, with parameterized execution and composition graphs, enabling an end-to-end CUA-Skill Agent that retrieves skills and reconstructs arguments with memory-aware failure recovery; achieves state-of-the-art results on WindowsAgentArena.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: The lack of reusable, structured skill abstractions for human–computer interaction hinders scalability and performance of agentic systems.

Method: Construct a large-scale library of engineered skills for common Windows applications; implement CUA-Skill Agent with dynamic skill retrieval, argument instantiation, and memory-aware failure recovery; evaluate on agent benchmarks.

Result: Significant gains in execution success and robustness; state-of-the-art 57.5% success (best of three) on WindowsAgentArena; greater efficiency than prior approaches.

Conclusion: CUA-Skill provides a foundational, scalable infrastructure for future development of computer-using agents.

Abstract: Computer-Using Agents (CUAs) aim to autonomously operate computer systems to complete real-world tasks. However, existing agentic systems remain difficult to scale and lag behind human performance. A key limitation is the absence of reusable and structured skill abstractions that capture how humans interact with graphical user interfaces and how to leverage these skills. We introduce CUA-Skill, a computer-using agentic skill base that encodes human computer-use knowledge as skills coupled with parameterized execution and composition graphs. CUA-Skill is a large-scale library of carefully engineered skills spanning common Windows applications, serving as a practical infrastructure and tool substrate for scalable, reliable agent development. Built upon this skill base, we construct CUA-Skill Agent, an end-to-end computer-using agent that supports dynamic skill retrieval, argument instantiation, and memory-aware failure recovery. Our results demonstrate that CUA-Skill substantially improves execution success rates and robustness on challenging end-to-end agent benchmarks, establishing a strong foundation for future computer-using agent development. On WindowsAgentArena, CUA-Skill Agent achieves state-of-the-art 57.5% (best of three) successful rate while being significantly more efficient than prior and concurrent approaches. The project page is available at https://microsoft.github.io/cua_skill/.

</details>


### [102] [Beyond a Single Reference: Training and Evaluation with Paraphrases in Sign Language Translation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21128)
*Václav Javorek,Tomáš Železný,Alessa Carbo,Marek Hrúz,Ivan Gruber*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Proposes BLEUpara, a BLEU extension evaluating SLT translations against multiple paraphrased references generated by LLMs; finds paraphrases help evaluation but not training; releases resources.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: In SLT, aligning signed utterances with a single written reference underestimates paraphrase variability due to non-isomorphism between sign and speech. Generating paraphrase references with LLMs aims to improve evaluation and training where appropriate, and to provide a more robust standard. 

Method: Compare multiple paraphrasing strategies/models using an adapted ParaScore metric. Evaluate a pose-based T5 SLT model on YouTubeASL and How2Sign with/without paraphrase augmentation. Introduce BLEUpara to evaluate translations against paraphrased references. Conduct human evaluation to validate BLEUpara. Release generated paraphrases and evaluation code.

Result: Paraphrase augmentation during training does not improve and can hurt SLT performance; paraphrases during evaluation yield higher automatic scores and better alignment with human judgments. BLEUpara correlates more strongly with perceived quality than standard BLEU.

Conclusion: Paraphrase-aware evaluation (BLEUpara) provides a more reliable assessment for SLT; paraphrase augmentation should be used for evaluation, not training. Resources (paraphrases, code) are released to support reproducible SLT evaluation.

Abstract: Most Sign Language Translation (SLT) corpora pair each signed utterance with a single written-language reference, despite the highly non-isomorphic relationship between sign and spoken languages, where multiple translations can be equally valid. This limitation constrains both model training and evaluation, particularly for n-gram-based metrics such as BLEU. In this work, we investigate the use of Large Language Models to automatically generate paraphrased variants of written-language translations as synthetic alternative references for SLT. First, we compare multiple paraphrasing strategies and models using an adapted ParaScore metric. Second, we study the impact of paraphrases on both training and evaluation of the pose-based T5 model on the YouTubeASL and How2Sign datasets. Our results show that naively incorporating paraphrases during training does not improve translation performance and can even be detrimental. In contrast, using paraphrases during evaluation leads to higher automatic scores and better alignment with human judgments. To formalize this observation, we introduce BLEUpara, an extension of BLEU that evaluates translations against multiple paraphrased references. Human evaluation confirms that BLEUpara correlates more strongly with perceived translation quality. We release all generated paraphrases, generation and evaluation code to support reproducible and more reliable evaluation of SLT systems.

</details>


### [103] [What You Feel Is Not What They See: On Predicting Self-Reported Emotion from Third-Party Observer Labels](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21130)
*Yara El-Tawil,Aneesha Sampath,Emily Mower Provost*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Third-party emotion models trained on external labels perform poorly on self-reports overall, with activation hard to predict and valence modestly predictable; personal significance markedly boosts valence prediction, suggesting alignment between external perception and internal state depends on content relevance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the gap between self-reported internal states and third-party-labeled data, which limits transfer of models to self-report contexts and is critical for mental health applications.

Method: Cross-corpus evaluation of third-party-trained models on self-reported data, using concordance correlation coefficient (CCC) to assess activation and valence; analysis of the impact of personal significance on prediction performance.

Result: Activation is unpredictable (CCC ≈ 0); valence moderately predictable (CCC ≈ 0.3) overall; when content is personally significant, valence prediction improves substantially (CCC ≈ 0.6–0.8).

Conclusion: Personal significance is a key factor for aligning external perception with internal experience; highlights the challenge of self-report activation modeling and limits of third-party-trained models for self-report contexts unless content is personally meaningful.

Abstract: Self-reported emotion labels capture internal experience, while third-party labels reflect external perception. These perspectives often diverge, limiting the applicability of third-party-trained models to self-report contexts. This gap is critical in mental health, where accurate self-report modeling is essential for guiding intervention. We present the first cross-corpus evaluation of third-party-trained models on self-reports. We find activation unpredictable (CCC approximately 0) and valence moderately predictable (CCC approximately 0.3). Crucially, when content is personally significant to the speaker, models achieve high performance for valence (CCC approximately 0.6-0.8). Our findings point to personal significance as a key pathway for aligning external perception with internal experience and underscore the challenge of self-report activation modeling.

</details>


### [104] [BrainStack: Neuro-MoE with Functionally Guided Expert Routing for EEG-Based Language Decoding](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21148)
*Ziyi Zhao,Jinzhao Zhou,Xiaowei Jiang,Beining Cao,Wenhao Ma,Yang Shen,Ren Li,Yu-Kai Wang,Chin-teng Lin*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: BrainStack proposes a functionally modular Neuro-MoE for EEG-based brain-language decoding, combining region-specific experts with a transformer global expert, gated routing, and cross-regional distillation, and introduces SilentSpeech-EEG (SS-EEG) as a large EEG benchmark; it achieves superior cross-subject accuracy/generalization over SOTA models.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address the brain's distributed, nonlinear organization by enforcing modularity aligned with anatomical regions and enabling cross-region coordination, while providing a large-scale benchmark for silent-speech EEG decoding.

Method: An anatomically partitioned set of specialized experts (regional experts) plus a transformer-based global expert (global expert). A learnable routing gate aggregates expert outputs with context-dependent coordination. Cross-regional distillation regularizes regional experts via top-down guidance from the global expert. Release of SilentSpeech-EEG (SS-EEG): 120+ hours of EEG from 12 subjects performing 24 silent words.

Result: BrainStack consistently outperforms state-of-the-art models in accuracy and generalization across subjects on the SS-EEG benchmark, demonstrating the benefits of functionally modular MoE for brain-language decoding.

Conclusion: BrainStack advances neuro-inspired MoEs by integrating anatomical priors, adaptive routing, and cross-regional distillation, offering scalable, interpretable, and generalizable brain-language decoding and providing a valuable large-scale EEG benchmark for silent-speech tasks.

Abstract: Decoding linguistic information from electroencephalography (EEG) remains challenging due to the brain's distributed and nonlinear organization. We present BrainStack, a functionally guided neuro-mixture-of-experts (Neuro-MoE) framework that models the brain's modular functional architecture through anatomically partitioned expert networks. Each functional region is represented by a specialized expert that learns localized neural dynamics, while a transformer-based global expert captures cross-regional dependencies. A learnable routing gate adaptively aggregates these heterogeneous experts, enabling context-dependent expert coordination and selective fusion. To promote coherent representation across the hierarchy, we introduce cross-regional distillation, where the global expert provides top-down regularization to the regional experts. We further release SilentSpeech-EEG (SS-EEG), a large-scale benchmark comprising over 120 hours of EEG recordings from 12 subjects performing 24 silent words, the largest dataset of its kind. Experiments demonstrate that BrainStack consistently outperforms state-of-the-art models, achieving superior accuracy and generalization across subjects. Our results establish BrainStack as a functionally modular, neuro-inspired MoE paradigm that unifies neuroscientific priors with adaptive expert routing, paving the way for scalable and interpretable brain-language decoding.

</details>


### [105] [Bridging the Arithmetic Gap: The Cognitive Complexity Benchmark and Financial-PoT for Robust Financial Reasoning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21157)
*Boxiang Zhao,Qince Li,Zhonghao Wang,Yi Wang,Peng Cheng,Bo Lin*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: A new cognitive evaluation benchmark for financial reasoning (CCB) built from 95 real-world Chinese A-share reports, with a three-dimensional taxonomy; and a neuro-symbolic Iterative Dual-Phase Financial-PoT framework that decouples semantic extraction from computation in a Python sandbox, improving Qwen3-235B accuracy from 59.7% to 67.3% and achieving up to 10x gains on high-complexity tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: LLMs show reliable performance on semantically simple tasks but struggle with financial quantitative reasoning due to arithmetic hallucinations and systemic cognitive collapse. A robust benchmark and architecture are needed to diagnose and mitigate reasoning degradation under high cognitive load, and to enable reliable, precise computation in finance.

Method: CCB dataset: 95 real-world Chinese A-share annual reports; taxonomy with Data Source, Mapping Difficulty, and Result Unit. Iterative Dual-Phase Financial-PoT: a neuro-symbolic architecture with strict decoupling—semantic variable extraction and logic formulation first, followed by deterministic computation in an iterative Python sandbox.

Result: On CCB, standard Chain-of-Thought (CoT) struggles on complex tasks, while the proposed framework improves average accuracy of Qwen3-235B from 59.7% to 67.3% and yields up to 10-fold gains in high-complexity reasoning tasks.

Conclusion: Architectural decoupling between semantic understanding and quantitative computation is a key driver of reliability in financial reasoning for LLMs; the approach offers transferable insights for precision-critical domains requiring strict alignment of meaning and computation.

Abstract: While Large Language Models excel at semantic tasks, they face a critical bottleneck in financial quantitative reasoning, frequently suffering from "Arithmetic Hallucinations" and a systemic failure mode we term "Cognitive Collapse". To strictly quantify this phenomenon, we introduce the Cognitive Complexity Benchmark (CCB), a robust evaluation framework grounded in a dataset constructed from 95 real-world Chinese A-share annual reports. Unlike traditional datasets, the CCB stratifies financial queries into a three-dimensional taxonomy, Data Source, Mapping Difficulty, and Result Unit, enabling the precise diagnosis of reasoning degradation in high-cognitive-load scenarios. To address these failures, we propose the Iterative Dual-Phase Financial-PoT framework. This neuro-symbolic architecture enforces a strict architectural decoupling: it first isolates semantic variable extraction and logic formulation, then offloads computation to an iterative, self-correcting Python sandbox to ensure deterministic execution. Evaluation on the CCB demonstrates that while standard Chain-of-Thought falters on complex tasks, our approach offers superior robustness, elevating the Qwen3-235B model's average accuracy from 59.7\% to 67.3\% and achieving gains of up to 10-fold in high-complexity reasoning tasks. These findings suggest that architectural decoupling is a critical enabling factor for improving reliability in financial reasoning tasks, providing a transferable architectural insight for precision-critical domains that require tight alignment between semantic understanding and quantitative computation.

</details>


### [106] [Concise Geometric Description as a Bridge: Unleashing the Potential of LLM for Plane Geometry Problem Solving](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21164)
*Jingyun Wang,Dian Li,Xiaohan Wang,Gang Liu,Jiahong Yan,Guoliang Kang*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: A modular PGPS approach that converts diagrams to concise CDL geometric descriptions via a fine-tuned MLLM Interpreter, then reasons with an off-the-shelf LLM; trained with CoT-SFT and GRPO using a CDL-matching reward, achieving strong results with only 5.5k data across multiple benchmarks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: LLMs struggle with visual diagrams; joint optimization of perception and reasoning in end-to-end MLLMs may harm base reasoning. By textualizing visuals into CDL, a powerful LLM can perform reasoning without heavy end-to-end fine-tuning.

Method: Fine-tune an MLLM Interpreter to produce CDL descriptions from diagrams using CoT-augmented SFT and GRPO; use CDL-matching rewards rather than ground-truth answers for training; create Formalgeo7k-Rec-CoT with CoT annotations; evaluate with an off-the-shelf LLM plus CDL inputs on Formalgeo7k-Rec-CoT, Unigeo, MathVista; compare to other MLLMs.

Result: With about 5.5k fine-tuning data, the approach achieves favorable performance against leading open-source and closed-source MLLMs on the evaluated datasets.

Conclusion: Textual geometric descriptions (CDL) + GRPO-guided CDL generation enable LLM-based PGPS with limited data, offering competitive results and preserving base LLM reasoning capabilities; further work could automate CDL generation and broaden datasets.

Abstract: Plane Geometry Problem Solving (PGPS) is a multimodal reasoning task that aims to solve a plane geometric problem based on a geometric diagram and problem textual descriptions. Although Large Language Models (LLMs) possess strong reasoning skills, their direct application to PGPS is hindered by their inability to process visual diagrams. Existing works typically fine-tune Multimodal LLMs (MLLMs) end-to-end on large-scale PGPS data to enhance visual understanding and reasoning simultaneously.
