Motivation: Extend conceptual spaces to temporally realized, goal-directed concepts and enable interpretable recognition in sequential decision domains; support learning/knowledge evolution.

Method: Define strategy concepts as geometric regions in interpretable quality dimensions; encode chess games as trajectories in this space; analyze directional movement toward strategy regions; incorporate dual-perspective interpretations to capture differing viewpoints.

Result: Feasibility demonstrated: movement patterns align with expert commentary; confirms trajectory-based concept recognition and applicability to sequential decision tasks; supports extension to knowledge evolution/learning mechanisms.

Conclusion: Extends conceptual spaces to temporally realized, goal-directed concepts; establishes a foundation for broadly applicable sequential decision-making and for learning/refinement of abstract concepts over time.

Abstract: We present a conceptual space framework for modelling abstract concepts that unfold over time, demonstrated through a chess-based proof-of-concept. Strategy concepts, such as attack or sacrifice, are represented as geometric regions across interpretable quality dimensions, with chess games instantiated and analysed as trajectories whose directional movement toward regions enables recognition of intended strategies. This approach also supports dual-perspective modelling, capturing how players interpret identical situations differently. Our implementation demonstrates the feasibility of trajectory-based concept recognition, with movement patterns aligning with expert commentary. This work explores extending the conceptual spaces theory to temporally realised, goal-directed concepts. The approach establishes a foundation for broader applications involving sequential decision-making and supports integration with knowledge evolution mechanisms for learning and refining abstract concepts over time.

</details>


### [162] [BioAgent Bench: An AI Agent Evaluation Suite for Bioinformatics](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21800)
*Dionizije Fa,Marko Čuljak,Bruno Pandža,Mateo Čupić*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: BioAgent Bench: a benchmark dataset and evaluation suite for AI agents in bioinformatics pipelines, examining end-to-end tasks and robustness; compares frontier closed-source and open-weight models; finds reliable final artifacts but vulnerabilities to perturbations; privacy implications; dataset released.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Standardize and automate evaluation of AI agents on bioinformatics workflows, enabling stress testing, automatic scoring, and privacy-aware benchmarking across models.

Method: Curate end-to-end bioinformatics tasks (e.g., RNA-seq, variant calling, metagenomics) with prompts specifying concrete output artifacts; evaluate frontier closed-source and open-weight models across multiple agent harnesses; employ an LLM-based grader for pipeline progress and outcome validity; conduct robustness tests with controlled perturbations (corrupted inputs, decoy files, prompt bloat).

Result: Frontier agents can complete multi-step pipelines without elaborate scaffolding, often producing the requested final artifacts reliably; robustness tests reveal failure modes under perturbations, indicating high-level pipeline correctness does not guarantee reliable step-level reasoning; closed-source models may be unsuitable under strict privacy constraints, making open-weight models preferable despite lower completion rates.

Conclusion: Public release of the dataset and evaluation suite enables broader benchmarking; highlights the need to improve step-level reasoning and perturbation resilience; privacy considerations influence model choice in sensitive bioinformatics contexts.

Abstract: This paper introduces BioAgent Bench, a benchmark dataset and an evaluation suite designed for measuring the performance and robustness of AI agents in common bioinformatics tasks. The benchmark contains curated end-to-end tasks (e.g., RNA-seq, variant calling, metagenomics) with prompts that specify concrete output artifacts to support automated assessment, including stress testing under controlled perturbations. We evaluate frontier closed-source and open-weight models across multiple agent harnesses, and use an LLM-based grader to score pipeline progress and outcome validity. We find that frontier agents can complete multi-step bioinformatics pipelines without elaborate custom scaffolding, often producing the requested final artifacts reliably. However, robustness tests reveal failure modes under controlled perturbations (corrupted inputs, decoy files, and prompt bloat), indicating that correct high-level pipeline construction does not guarantee reliable step-level reasoning. Finally, because bioinformatics workflows may involve sensitive patient data, proprietary references, or unpublished IP, closed-source models can be unsuitable under strict privacy constraints; in such settings, open-weight models may be preferable despite lower completion rates. We release the dataset and evaluation suite publicly.

</details>


### [163] [A Unified XAI-LLM Approach for EndotrachealSuctioning Activity Recognition](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21802)
*Hoang Khang Phan,Quang Vinh Dang,Noriyo Colley,Christina Garcia,Nhat Tan Le*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: LLM-centered, video-based endotracheal suctioning recognition framework with explainable feedback and anomaly-aware student support; shows 15–20% gains over baselines in accuracy and F1; aims to enhance nursing education and patient safety.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the lack of automated recognition and feedback for endotracheal suctioning training, especially in home and educational settings with limited supervision, where conventional ML/DL approaches underperform.

Method: Proposes a unified framework with a central LLM performing spatiotemporal activity recognition and explainable decision analysis on video data; enables natural-language feedback generation. Includes a pilot student-support module based on anomaly detection and XAI to provide interpretable guidance highlighting correct actions and improvements.

Result: Experimental results indicate the approach outperforms baseline models with approximately 15–20% gains in both accuracy and F1 score.

Conclusion: The framework offers a scalable, interpretable, and data-driven foundation for advancing nursing education, improving training efficiency, and enhancing patient safety through automated recognition and natural-language feedback.

Abstract: Endotracheal suctioning (ES) is an invasive yet essential clinical procedure that requires a high degree of skill to minimize patient risk - particularly in home care and educational settings, where consistent supervision may be limited. Despite its critical importance, automated recognition and feedback systems for ES training remain underexplored. To address this gap, this study proposes a unified, LLM-centered framework for video-based activity recognition benchmarked against conventional machine learning and deep learning approaches, and a pilot study on feedback generation. Within this framework, the Large Language Model (LLM) serves as the central reasoning module, performing both spatiotemporal activity recognition and explainable decision analysis from video data. Furthermore, the LLM is capable of verbalizing feedback in natural language, thereby translating complex technical insights into accessible, human-understandable guidance for trainees. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed LLM-based approach outperforms baseline models, achieving an improvement of approximately 15-20\% in both accuracy and F1 score. Beyond recognition, the framework incorporates a pilot student-support module built upon anomaly detection and explainable AI (XAI) principles, which provides automated, interpretable feedback highlighting correct actions and suggesting targeted improvements. Collectively, these contributions establish a scalable, interpretable, and data-driven foundation for advancing nursing education, enhancing training efficiency, and ultimately improving patient safety.

</details>


### [164] [CORE:Toward Ubiquitous 6G Intelligence Through Collaborative Orchestration of Large Language Model Agents Over Hierarchical Edge](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21822)
*Zitong Yu,Boquan Sun,Yang Li,Zheyan Qu,Xing Zhang*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: CORE enables collaborative, edge-based LLM orchestration across hierarchical networks for efficient multi-agent reasoning, using role-based distribution, real-time perception, dynamic scheduling, and pipeline-parallel execution to leverage dispersed resources.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Fragmented, heterogeneous computing resources across edge hierarchies hinder individual LLM agents from performing complex reasoning; there is a need for distributed collaboration among LLMs to exploit edge resources efficiently in 6G settings.

Method: Deploy multiple LLMs on mobile devices and tiered edge servers, assign each a distinct functional role, and integrate three optimization modules: real-time perception, dynamic role orchestration, and pipeline-parallel execution. Introduce a role affinity scheduling algorithm to dynamically assign LLM roles across the edge hierarchy, matching computational demands to available resources.

Result: Through case studies and performance evaluations in diverse 6G scenarios, CORE improves system efficiency and task completion rates; results are validated on a real-world edge platform, showing robust performance in operational environments.

Conclusion: CORE demonstrates a practical, scalable approach to collaborative AI at the edge, enabling rapid, efficient multi-agent LLM reasoning across distributed resources in 6G networks.

Abstract: Rapid advancements in sixth-generation (6G) networks and large language models (LLMs) have paved the way for ubiquitous intelligence, wherein seamless connectivity and distributed artificial intelligence (AI) have revolutionized various aspects of our lives.However, realizing this vision faces significant challenges owing to the fragmented and heterogeneous computing resources across hierarchical networks, which are insufficient for individual LLM agents to perform complex reasoning tasks.To address this issue, we propose Collaborative Orchestration Role at Edge (CORE), an innovative framework that employs a collaborative learning system in which multiple LLMs, each assigned a distinct functional role, are distributed across mobile devices and tiered edge servers. The system integrates three optimization modules, encompassing real-time perception,dynamic role orchestration, and pipeline-parallel execution, to facilitate efficient and rapid collaboration among distributed agents. Furthermore, we introduce a novel role affinity scheduling algorithm for dynamically orchestrating LLM role assignments across the hierarchical edge infrastructure, intelligently matching computational demands with available dispersed resources.Finally, comprehensive case studies and performance evaluations across various 6G application scenarios demonstrated the efficacy of CORE, revealing significant enhancements in the system efficiency and task completion rates. Building on these promising outcomes, we further validated the practical applicability of CORE by deploying it on a real-world edge-computing platform,that exhibits robust performance in operational environments.

</details>


### [165] [Looking Beyond Accuracy: A Holistic Benchmark of ECG Foundation Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21830)
*Francesca Filice,Edoardo De Rose,Simone Bartucci,Francesco Calimeri,Simona Perri*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Proposes a comprehensive benchmarking framework for ECG-expert Foundation Models that adds representation-level analysis (SHAP, UMAP) to performance benchmarks, evaluated across diverse cross-continental datasets and data-scarcity settings to assess generalizability of embeddings.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address the gap that existing benchmarks focus on downstream performance, by evaluating how generalizable the embeddings produced by ECG-expert FMs are, ensuring safe and effective deployment in error-sensitive healthcare settings.

Method: Develops a benchmark methodology that combines traditional performance evaluation with representation-level analysis using SHAP and UMAP; applies it to several ECG-expert FMs pretrained with state-of-the-art techniques across multiple datasets with varying availability and cross-continental splits.

Result: The protocol yields rich insights into the embedded representation patterns and generalizability of ECG-expert FMs, revealing aspects not captured by performance alone.

Conclusion: The benchmarking framework enables deeper understanding of the representational structure of ECG-expert FMs and their generalizability, supporting more responsible and robust use in ECG interpretation.

Abstract: The electrocardiogram (ECG) is a cost-effective, highly accessible and widely employed diagnostic tool. With the advent of Foundation Models (FMs), the field of AI-assisted ECG interpretation has begun to evolve, as they enable model reuse across different tasks by relying on embeddings. However, to responsibly employ FMs, it is crucial to rigorously assess to which extent the embeddings they produce are generalizable, particularly in error-sensitive domains such as healthcare. Although prior works have already addressed the problem of benchmarking ECG-expert FMs, they focus predominantly on the evaluation of downstream performance. To fill this gap, this study aims to find an in-depth, comprehensive benchmarking framework for FMs, with a specific focus on ECG-expert ones. To this aim, we introduce a benchmark methodology that complements performance-based evaluation with representation-level analysis, leveraging SHAP and UMAP techniques. Furthermore, we rely on the methodology for carrying out an extensive evaluation of several ECG-expert FMs pretrained via state-of-the-art techniques over different cross-continental datasets and data availability settings; this includes ones featuring data scarcity, a fairly common situation in real-world medical scenarios. Experimental results show that our benchmarking protocol provides a rich insight of ECG-expert FMs' embedded patterns, enabling a deeper understanding of their representational structure and generalizability.

</details>


### [166] [Bridging Forecast Accuracy and Inventory KPIs: A Simulation-Based Software Framework](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21844)
*So Fukuhara,Abdallah Alabdallah,Nuwan Gunasekara,Slawomir Nowaczyk*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: A decision-centric simulation framework links forecasting to inventory management in automotive aftermarket, showing that forecast accuracy alone does not guarantee better operational performance; it enables evaluating models by operational KPIs via a closed-loop simulation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Forecast accuracy metrics (MAE, RMSE) may not reflect the impact on inventory KPIs (cost, service level). There is a need to evaluate forecasting models within a realistic inventory management context to understand trade-offs and improve model selection.

Method: Develop a decision-centric simulation software framework with three components: (i) a synthetic spare-parts demand generator, (ii) a flexible forecasting module for arbitrary models, and (iii) an inventory control simulator that uses forecasts to compute KPIs in a closed-loop setup.

Result: Demonstrates that improvements in conventional accuracy metrics do not always translate to better operational performance; models with similar statistical error can cause different cost-service trade-offs. The framework reveals how forecast aspects affect inventory outcomes and provides guidance for model selection.

Conclusion: The framework operationalizes the demand-forecasting–inventory-management linkage and shifts evaluation from predictive accuracy to operational relevance in the automotive aftermarket and related domains.

Abstract: Efficient management of spare parts inventory is crucial in the automotive aftermarket, where demand is highly intermittent and uncertainty drives substantial cost and service risks. Forecasting is therefore central, but the quality of a forecasting model should be judged not by statistical accuracy (e.g., MAE, RMSE, IAE) but rather by its impact on key operational performance indicators (KPIs), such as total cost and service level. Yet most existing work evaluates models exclusively using accuracy metrics, and the relationship between these metrics and operational KPIs remains poorly understood. To address this gap, we propose a decision-centric simulation software framework that enables systematic evaluation of forecasting model in realistic inventory management setting. The framework comprises: (i) a synthetic demand generator tailored to spare-parts demand characteristics, (ii) a flexible forecasting module that can host arbitrary predictive models, and (iii) an inventory control simulator that consumes the forecasts and computes operational KPIs. This closed-loop setup enables researchers to evaluate models not only in terms of statistical error but also in terms of their downstream implications for inventory decisions. Using a wide range of simulation scenarios, we show that improvements in conventional accuracy metrics do not necessarily translate into better operational performance, and that models with similar statistical error profiles can induce markedly different cost-service trade-offs. We analyze these discrepancies to characterize how specific aspects of forecast performance affect inventory outcomes and derive guidance for model selection. Overall, the framework operationalizes the link between demand forecasting and inventory management, shifting evaluation from purely predictive accuracy toward operational relevance in the automotive aftermarket and related domains.

</details>


### [167] [KnowBias: Mitigating Social Bias in LLMs via Know-Bias Neuron Enhancement](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21864)
*Jinhao Pan,Chahat Raj,Anjishnu Mukherjee,Sina Mansouri,Bowen Wei,Shloka Yada,Ziwei Zhu*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: KnowBias is a lightweight, inference-time debiasing method that strengthens, rather than suppresses, bias-related knowledge by identifying bias-knowledge neurons through attribution-based analysis on a small set of bias-knowledge questions and selectively enhancing them—achieving strong debiasing with minimal impact on general capability without retraining.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Debiasing LLMs with suppression (parameter, prompt, or neuron-level edits) often yields brittle, data-inefficient solutions that degrade overall capabilities. There is a need for a data-efficient, generalizable method that preserves general performance while reducing biased outputs.

Method: Identify neurons encoding bias knowledge using attribution-based analysis on a small set of bias-knowledge questions. At inference time, selectively enhance these neurons (no retraining). This lightweight approach strengthens the bias-knowledge pathways to reduce biased behavior.

Result: Experiments across multiple benchmarks and LLMs show consistent state-of-the-art debiasing with minimal utility degradation. The method is data-efficient (requires only a handful of yes/no questions) and does not require retraining; data and code are publicly available.

Conclusion: KnowBias demonstrates that debiasing can be achieved by strengthening bias-knowledge representations rather than suppressing biased behavior, yielding robust, generalizable, and data-efficient improvements with preserved general capabilities across biases and demographics.

Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) exhibit social biases that reinforce harmful stereotypes, limiting their safe deployment. Most existing debiasing methods adopt a suppressive paradigm by modifying parameters, prompts, or neurons associated with biased behavior; however, such approaches are often brittle, weakly generalizable, data-inefficient, and prone to degrading general capability. We propose \textbf{KnowBias}, a lightweight and conceptually distinct framework that mitigates bias by strengthening, rather than suppressing, neurons encoding bias-knowledge. KnowBias identifies neurons encoding bias knowledge using a small set of bias-knowledge questions via attribution-based analysis, and selectively enhances them at inference time. This design enables strong debiasing while preserving general capabilities, generalizes across bias types and demographics, and is highly data efficient, requiring only a handful of simple yes/no questions and no retraining. Experiments across multiple benchmarks and LLMs demonstrate consistent state-of-the-art debiasing performance with minimal utility degradation. Data and code are available at https://github.com/JP-25/KnowBias.

</details>


### [168] [WebArbiter: A Principle-Guided Reasoning Process Reward Model for Web Agents](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21872)
*Yao Zhang,Shijie Tang,Zeyu Li,Zhen Han,Volker Tresp*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: WebArbiter reframes reward modeling for web navigation as text-generation-based reasoning, achieving state-of-the-art performance on benchmark tests.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Addresses long-horizon, sequential decision-making in web tasks with sparse, delayed rewards; existing WebPRMs are coarse, brittle, and poorly interpretable.

Method: Introduces WebArbiter, a reasoning-first WebPRM with two-stage training: reasoning distillation to acquire principled reasoning, then reinforcement learning to align verdicts with correctness. The model generates structured justifications that end with a preference verdict and identifies the action most conducive to task completion. Evaluation uses WebPRMBench and WebArena-Lite for reward-guided trajectory search.

Result: WebArbiter-7B outperforms the strongest baseline (GPT-5) by 9.1 points on WebPRMBench. In reward-guided trajectory search on WebArena-Lite, it surpasses the best prior WebPRM by up to 7.2 points.

Conclusion: Demonstrates robustness and practical value for complex web tasks, provides a comprehensive WebPRMBench benchmark, and advances state-of-the-art in reward-model-based web navigation.

Abstract: Web agents hold great potential for automating complex computer tasks, yet their interactions involve long-horizon, sequential decision-making with irreversible actions. In such settings, outcome-based supervision is sparse and delayed, often rewarding incorrect trajectories and failing to support inference-time scaling. This motivates the use of Process Reward Models (WebPRMs) for web navigation, but existing approaches remain limited: scalar WebPRMs collapse progress into coarse, weakly grounded signals, while checklist-based WebPRMs rely on brittle template matching that fails under layout or semantic changes and often mislabels superficially correct actions as successful, providing little insight or interpretability. To address these challenges, we introduce WebArbiter, a reasoning-first, principle-inducing WebPRM that formulates reward modeling as text generation, producing structured justifications that conclude with a preference verdict and identify the action most conducive to task completion under the current context. Training follows a two-stage pipeline: reasoning distillation equips the model with coherent principle-guided reasoning, and reinforcement learning corrects teacher biases by directly aligning verdicts with correctness, enabling stronger generalization. To support systematic evaluation, we release WebPRMBench, a comprehensive benchmark spanning four diverse web environments with rich tasks and high-quality preference annotations. On WebPRMBench, WebArbiter-7B outperforms the strongest baseline, GPT-5, by 9.1 points. In reward-guided trajectory search on WebArena-Lite, it surpasses the best prior WebPRM by up to 7.2 points, underscoring its robustness and practical value in real-world complex web tasks.

</details>


### [169] [astra-langchain4j: Experiences Combining LLMs and Agent Programming](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21879)
*Rem Collier,Katharine Beaumont,Andrei Ciortea*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: An abstract describing the integration of a prototype LLM into the ASTRA programming language, examining how Generative/Agentic AI interacts with traditional Agent Toolkits through three example implementations and reflective experiences.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Motivated by the rise of Generative and Agentic AI, the paper investigates how such technologies affect traditional agent toolkits and how established toolkit knowledge can inform the design of agentic platforms; focuses on bridging LLM capabilities with ASTRA.

Method: Describes the ASTRA toolkit briefly, presents three concrete implementations of an LLM integration as case studies, and discusses the experiences and lessons learned from these implementations.

Result: Provides qualitative insights and practical experiences from building a prototype LLM integration for ASTRA across three use cases, including design considerations and potential implications for toolkit-driven agent platforms.

Conclusion: Argues that integrating LLMs with established toolkits yields valuable lessons for both augmenting and steering agentic platforms, and offers guidance for future development of such integrations.

Abstract: Given the emergence of Generative AI over the last two years and the increasing focus on Agentic AI as a form of Multi-Agent System it is important to explore both how such technologies can impact the use of traditional Agent Toolkits and how the wealth of experience encapsulated in those toolkits can influence the design of the new agentic platforms. This paper presents an overview of our experience developing a prototype large language model (LLM) integration for the ASTRA programming language. It presents a brief overview of the toolkit, followed by three example implementations, concluding with a discussion of the experiences garnered through the examples.

</details>


### [170] [Making Models Unmergeable via Scaling-Sensitive Loss Landscape](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21898)
*Minwoo Jang,Hoyoung Kim,Jabin Koo,Jungseul Ok*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Trap^2 is an architecture-agnostic protection framework that embeds protection into fine-tuning updates via weight scaling, preserving standalone use but degrading under weight re-scaling common in merging, to prevent unauthorized model merging.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Model hubs enable recombination of released weights, creating a governance gap where safety alignment or licensing terms can be bypassed. Existing defenses are architecture-specific and post-hoc, failing to provide consistent protection across architectures and release formats.

Method: Trap^2 encodes protection into the update during fine-tuning. It uses weight re-scaling as a simple proxy for the merging process, so protection is architecture-agnostic and independent of adapters vs full models. Released weights remain usable standalone, but re-scaling during merging reduces their effectiveness.

Result: Protection that preserves standalone usefulness while degrading under typical re-scaling merges, thereby undermining unauthorized merging. Architecture-agnostic and compatible with adapters or full-model releases.

Conclusion: Trap^2 closes the governance gap by providing a lightweight, architecture-agnostic defense against unauthorized recombination of model components through weight scaling, addressing limitations of architecture-dependent post-hoc defenses.

Abstract: The rise of model hubs has made it easier to access reusable model components, making model merging a practical tool for combining capabilities. Yet, this modularity also creates a \emph{governance gap}: downstream users can recompose released weights into unauthorized mixtures that bypass safety alignment or licensing terms. Because existing defenses are largely post-hoc and architecture-specific, they provide inconsistent protection across diverse architectures and release formats in practice. To close this gap, we propose \textsc{Trap}$^{2}$, an architecture-agnostic protection framework that encodes protection into the update during fine-tuning, regardless of whether they are released as adapters or full models. Instead of relying on architecture-dependent approaches, \textsc{Trap}$^{2}$ uses weight re-scaling as a simple proxy for the merging process. It keeps released weights effective in standalone use, but degrades them under re-scaling that often arises in merging, undermining unauthorized merging.

</details>


### [171] [From Meta-Thought to Execution: Cognitively Aligned Post-Training for Generalizable and Reliable LLM Reasoning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21909)
*Shaojie Wang,Liang Zhang*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: A cognitively-inspired two-stage post-training framework (CoMT for abstract meta-knowledge and CCRL for confident task adaptation) improves generalization and efficiency vs standard SFT+RL across multiple models/benchmarks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current post-training methods optimize complete reasoning trajectories, conflating abstract strategies with problem-specific execution. Humans solve problems by first acquiring abstract, generalizable strategies and then adapting them to instances; aligning training with this two-stage process can reduce error cascades and improve generalization.

Method: Chain-of-Meta-Thought (CoMT) uses supervised learning to capture abstract reasoning patterns (meta-knowledge) without solving specific tasks; Confidence-Calibrated Reinforcement Learning (CCRL) optimizes adaptation with confidence-aware rewards on intermediate steps to prevent overconfident errors and improve execution reliability.

Result: Experiments over four models and eight benchmarks show improvements of 2.19% (in-distribution) and 4.63% (out-of-distribution); training time reduced by 65–70% and token consumption by 50%.

Conclusion: Aligning post-training with human cognitive principles yields better generalization and efficiency, demonstrating the viability of a two-stage, cognitively-inspired post-training paradigm.

Abstract: Current LLM post-training methods optimize complete reasoning trajectories through Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) followed by outcome-based Reinforcement Learning (RL). While effective, a closer examination reveals a fundamental gap: this approach does not align with how humans actually solve problems. Human cognition naturally decomposes problem-solving into two distinct stages: first acquiring abstract strategies (i.e., meta-knowledge) that generalize across problems, then adapting them to specific instances. In contrast, by treating complete trajectories as basic units, current methods are inherently problem-centric, entangling abstract strategies with problem-specific execution. To address this misalignment, we propose a cognitively-inspired framework that explicitly mirrors the two-stage human cognitive process. Specifically, Chain-of-Meta-Thought (CoMT) focuses supervised learning on abstract reasoning patterns without specific executions, enabling acquisition of generalizable strategies. Confidence-Calibrated Reinforcement Learning (CCRL) then optimizes task adaptation via confidence-aware rewards on intermediate steps, preventing overconfident errors from cascading and improving execution reliability. Experiments across four models and eight benchmarks show 2.19\% and 4.63\% improvements in-distribution and out-of-distribution respectively over standard methods, while reducing training time by 65-70% and token consumption by 50%, demonstrating that aligning post-training with human cognitive principles yields not only superior generalization but also enhanced training efficiency.

</details>


### [172] [ProRAG: Process-Supervised Reinforcement Learning for Retrieval-Augmented Generation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21912)
*Zhao Wang,Ziliang Zhao,Zhicheng Dou*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: ProRAG introduces a process-supervised RL framework for Retrieval-Augmented Generation to tackle reward sparsity and process hallucinations by providing step-level feedback through an MCTS-based Process Reward Model and a four-stage training pipeline that blends supervised warmup, process rewards, and RL with dual-granularity signals.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Traditional outcome-only RL struggles with long-horizon tasks in RAG due to sparse rewards and poor credit assignment; process-aware methods lack on-policy exploration to decouple step-level credit from global outcomes, leading to process hallucinations and inefficient optimization.

Method: ProRAG comprises four stages: (1) supervised policy warmup to instill structured reasoning; (2) build an MCTS-based Process Reward Model (PRM) to quantify intermediate reasoning; (3) PRM-guided reasoning refinement to align policy with process preferences; (4) process-supervised RL with a dual-granularity advantage mechanism that aggregates step-level rewards with global outcomes during online learning.

Result: On five multi-hop reasoning benchmarks, ProRAG achieves superior performance compared with strong outcome-based and process-aware RL baselines, especially on complex long-horizon tasks; results validate the benefit of fine-grained process supervision and integrated step-level feedback.

Conclusion: Fine-grained, on-policy process supervision via a PRM-guided, dual-granularity RL framework can effectively mitigate process hallucinations and reward sparsity in RAG, enabling more accurate, efficient, and robust long-horizon reasoning.

Abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) has become a promising paradigm for optimizing Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) in complex reasoning tasks. However, traditional outcome-based RL approaches often suffer from reward sparsity and inefficient credit assignment, as coarse-grained scalar rewards fail to identify specific erroneous steps within long-horizon trajectories. This ambiguity frequently leads to "process hallucinations", where models reach correct answers through flawed logic or redundant retrieval steps. Although recent process-aware approaches attempt to mitigate this via static preference learning or heuristic reward shaping, they often lack the on-policy exploration capabilities required to decouple step-level credit from global outcomes. To address these challenges, we propose ProRAG, a process-supervised reinforcement learning framework designed to integrate learned step-level supervision into the online optimization loop. Our framework consists of four stages: (1) Supervised Policy Warmup to initialize the model with a structured reasoning format; (2) construction of an MCTS-based Process Reward Model (PRM) to quantify intermediate reasoning quality; (3) PRM-Guided Reasoning Refinement to align the policy with fine-grained process preferences; and (4) Process-Supervised Reinforcement Learning with a dual-granularity advantage mechanism. By aggregating step-level process rewards with global outcome signals, ProRAG provides precise feedback for every action. Extensive experiments on five multi-hop reasoning benchmarks demonstrate that ProRAG achieves superior overall performance compared to strong outcome-based and process-aware RL baselines, particularly on complex long-horizon tasks, validating the effectiveness of fine-grained process supervision. The code and model are available at https://github.com/lilinwz/ProRAG.

</details>


### [173] [JADE: Bridging the Strategic-Operational Gap in Dynamic Agentic RAG](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21916)
*Yiqun Chen,Erhan Zhang,Tianyi Hu,Shijie Wang,Zixuan Yang,Meizhi Zhong,Xiaochi Wei,Yan Gao,Yi Wu,Yao Hu,Jiaxin Mao*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: JADE introduces joint optimization of planning and execution in dynamic, multi-turn retrieval-augmented workflows, enabling co-adaptation between planner and executors via a shared backbone and outcome-based rewards, yielding performance gains over decoupled designs.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current RAG pipelines either optimize components within fixed architectures or dynamic plans with frozen executors, leading to a strategic-operational mismatch where sophisticated planning cannot realize gains due to unadapted executors; this limits efficiency and effectiveness.

Method: JADE models the system as a cooperative multi-agent team under a single shared backbone, enabling end-to-end learning with outcome-based rewards to jointly optimize planning and execution and promote co-adaptation between planners and executors.

Result: Empirical results show JADE converts disjoint modules into a synergistic system, achieving notable performance improvements through joint optimization and providing a flexible balance between efficiency and effectiveness via dynamic workflow orchestration.

Conclusion: Joint optimization with JADE mitigates decoupled optimization limitations, aligning planning and execution to unlock improved performance in dynamic, multi-turn workflows.

Abstract: The evolution of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) has shifted from static retrieval pipelines to dynamic, agentic workflows where a central planner orchestrates multi-turn reasoning. However, existing paradigms face a critical dichotomy: they either optimize modules jointly within rigid, fixed-graph architectures, or empower dynamic planning while treating executors as frozen, black-box tools. We identify that this \textit{decoupled optimization} creates a ``strategic-operational mismatch,'' where sophisticated planning strategies fail to materialize due to unadapted local executors, often leading to negative performance gains despite increased system complexity. In this paper, we propose \textbf{JADE} (\textbf{J}oint \textbf{A}gentic \textbf{D}ynamic \textbf{E}xecution), a unified framework for the joint optimization of planning and execution within dynamic, multi-turn workflows. By modeling the system as a cooperative multi-agent team unified under a single shared backbone, JADE enables end-to-end learning driven by outcome-based rewards. This approach facilitates \textit{co-adaptation}: the planner learns to operate within the capability boundaries of the executors, while the executors evolve to align with high-level strategic intent. Empirical results demonstrate that JADE transforms disjoint modules into a synergistic system, yielding remarkable performance improvements via joint optimization and enabling a flexible balance between efficiency and effectiveness through dynamic workflow orchestration.

</details>


### [174] [Self-Compression of Chain-of-Thought via Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21919)
*Yiqun Chen,Jinyuan Feng,Wei Yang,Meizhi Zhong,Zhengliang Shi,Rui Li,Xiaochi Wei,Yan Gao,Yi Wu,Yao Hu,Zhiqiang Pu,Jiaxin Mao*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: A multi-agent RL framework (SCMA) uses a Segmentation Agent and a Scoring Agent to apply an importance-weighted length penalty, reducing reasoning overhead while improving accuracy in Large Reasoning Models.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Inference overhead from redundant reasoning in large models degrades interactivity; simplistic length penalties conflict with preserving essential reasoning steps.

Method: Propose Self-Compression via MARL (SCMA) with two specialized agents (Segmentation and Scoring) that decompose reasoning into chunks and assess their significance, collaboratively shaping an importance-weighted penalty to train a Reasoning Agent.

Result: SCMA reduces response length by 11.1% to 39.0% and increases accuracy by 4.33% to 10.02% across model scales; ablations and qualitative analysis show emergent beneficial behavior and improved performance over vanilla RL.

Conclusion: A coordinated MARL framework effectively trims redundant reasoning without sacrificing, and often improving, accuracy, indicating a robust approach to reducing inference overhead in LRMs.

Abstract: The inference overhead induced by redundant reasoning undermines the interactive experience and severely bottlenecks the deployment of Large Reasoning Models. Existing reinforcement learning (RL)-based solutions tackle this problem by coupling a length penalty with outcome-based rewards. This simplistic reward weighting struggles to reconcile brevity with accuracy, as enforcing brevity may compromise critical reasoning logic. In this work, we address this limitation by proposing a multi-agent RL framework that selectively penalizes redundant chunks, while preserving essential reasoning logic. Our framework, Self-Compression via MARL (SCMA), instantiates redundancy detection and evaluation through two specialized agents: \textbf{a Segmentation Agent} for decomposing the reasoning process into logical chunks, and \textbf{a Scoring Agent} for quantifying the significance of each chunk. The Segmentation and Scoring agents collaboratively define an importance-weighted length penalty during training, incentivizing \textbf{a Reasoning Agent} to prioritize essential logic without introducing inference overhead during deployment. Empirical evaluations across model scales demonstrate that SCMA reduces response length by 11.1\% to 39.0\% while boosting accuracy by 4.33\% to 10.02\%. Furthermore, ablation studies and qualitative analysis validate that the synergistic optimization within the MARL framework fosters emergent behaviors, yielding more powerful LRMs compared to vanilla RL paradigms.

</details>


### [175] [AgenticSimLaw: A Juvenile Courtroom Multi-Agent Debate Simulation for Explainable High-Stakes Tabular Decision Making](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21936)
*Jon Chun,Kathrine Elkins,Yong Suk Lee*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: AgenticSimLaw introduces a role-structured, multi-agent debate framework for transparent, auditable high-stakes decision making, evaluated on recidivism prediction and outperforming chain-of-thought prompting across many configurations.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Tackle opacity, fragility, and governance gaps in single-agent LLM reasoning by enabling auditable, controllable, and transparent deliberations in high-stakes tasks.

Method: Courtroom-style orchestration with prosecutor, defense, and judge, 7-turn structured debate, private reasoning strategies, full interaction logs; evaluation on NLSY97 recidivism data against chain-of-thought prompts across ~90 model/strategy combos.

Result: Structured multi-agent debate yields more stable, generalizable performance with stronger accuracy–F1 correlation; provides complete transcripts, fine-grained control, and behavior profiling; results and code to be released under MIT license.

Conclusion: Addresses organization, observability, and responsibility challenges in LLM-based multi-agent systems; generalizes to any deliberative, high-stakes decision task requiring transparency and oversight; enables governance-ready reasoning.

Abstract: We introduce AgenticSimLaw, a role-structured, multi-agent debate framework that provides transparent and controllable test-time reasoning for high-stakes tabular decision-making tasks. Unlike black-box approaches, our courtroom-style orchestration explicitly defines agent roles (prosecutor, defense, judge), interaction protocols (7-turn structured debate), and private reasoning strategies, creating a fully auditable decision-making process. We benchmark this framework on young adult recidivism prediction using the NLSY97 dataset, comparing it against traditional chain-of-thought (CoT) prompting across almost 90 unique combinations of models and strategies. Our results demonstrate that structured multi-agent debate provides more stable and generalizable performance compared to single-agent reasoning, with stronger correlation between accuracy and F1-score metrics. Beyond performance improvements, AgenticSimLaw offers fine-grained control over reasoning steps, generates complete interaction transcripts for explainability, and enables systematic profiling of agent behaviors. While we instantiate this framework in the criminal justice domain to stress-test reasoning under ethical complexity, the approach generalizes to any deliberative, high-stakes decision task requiring transparency and human oversight. This work addresses key LLM-based multi-agent system challenges: organization through structured roles, observability through logged interactions, and responsibility through explicit non-deployment constraints for sensitive domains. Data, results, and code will be available on github.com under the MIT license.

</details>


### [176] [Retrieval-Infused Reasoning Sandbox: A Benchmark for Decoupling Retrieval and Reasoning Capabilities](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21937)
*Shuangshuang Ying,Zheyu Wang,Yunjian Peng,Jin Chen,Yuhao Wu,Hongbin Lin,Dingyu He,Siyi Liu,Gengchen Yu,YinZhu Piao,Yuchen Wu,Xin Gui,Zhongyuan Peng,Xin Li,Xeron Du,Libo Qin,YiXin Cao,Ge Zhang*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: DeR2 is a controlled sandbox that isolates document-grounded reasoning from retrieval to measure true reasoning on novel science; it uses four regimes, two-phase validation, and a fixed 2023–2025 paper library to enable interpretable error attribution and reveal headroom in foundation models.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Traditional end-to-end RAG benchmarks conflate retrieval, tool use, and memorization with reasoning, obscuring true multi-step scientific reasoning. A controlled, reproducible benchmark is needed to isolate reasoning difficulty and diagnose failures in LM-based research.

Method: Introduce four regimes (Instruction-only, Concepts, Related-only, Full-set) to separate access to evidence from reasoning. Use two-phase validation to prevent parametric leakage. Provide a frozen document library of recent theoretical papers with expert-annotated concepts and validated rationales. Evaluate diverse state-of-the-art foundation models on multi-step synthesis, denoising, and evidence-based conclusions, with regime gaps to attribute errors (retrieval loss vs. reasoning loss).

Result: Significant variation across models and substantial headroom remain. Some models exhibit mode-switch fragility (performing worse with Full-set than Instruction-only), while others show structural concept misuse (correct concept naming but failure to execute them as procedures).

Conclusion: DeR2 offers a principled, interpretable framework to diagnose and quantify retrieval versus reasoning limitations in LM-based science reasoning, highlighting both model fragility and opportunities for targeted improvements and more robust evaluation.

Abstract: Despite strong performance on existing benchmarks, it remains unclear whether large language models can reason over genuinely novel scientific information. Most evaluations score end-to-end RAG pipelines, where reasoning is confounded with retrieval and toolchain choices, and the signal is further contaminated by parametric memorization and open-web volatility. We introduce DeR2, a controlled deep-research sandbox that isolates document-grounded reasoning while preserving core difficulties of deep search: multi-step synthesis, denoising, and evidence-based conclusion making. DeR2 decouples evidence access from reasoning via four regimes--Instruction-only, Concepts (gold concepts without documents), Related-only (only relevant documents), and Full-set (relevant documents plus topically related distractors)--yielding interpretable regime gaps that operationalize retrieval loss vs. reasoning loss and enable fine-grained error attribution. To prevent parametric leakage, we apply a two-phase validation that requires parametric failure without evidence while ensuring oracle-concept solvability. To ensure reproducibility, each instance provides a frozen document library (drawn from 2023-2025 theoretical papers) with expert-annotated concepts and validated rationales. Experiments across a diverse set of state-of-the-art foundation models reveal substantial variation and significant headroom: some models exhibit mode-switch fragility, performing worse with the Full-set than with Instruction-only, while others show structural concept misuse, correctly naming concepts but failing to execute them as procedures.

</details>


### [177] [ToolWeaver: Weaving Collaborative Semantics for Scalable Tool Use in Large Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21947)
*Bowen Fang,Wen Ye,Yunyue Su,Jinghao Zhang,Qiang Liu,Yesheng Liu,Xin Sun,Shu Wu,Jiabing Yang,Baole Wei,Liang Wang*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: ToolWeaver encodes tools as hierarchical sequences to replace monolithic IDs, enabling logarithmic vocabulary growth, better generalization, and learning of collaborative tool relationships from dense shared codes.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current retrieval-based tool-use pipelines and LLMs suffer from limited semantic understanding of tools and poor scalability; mapping each tool to a unique token causes vocabulary explosion and semantic bottlenecks, hindering generalization across tools and their relationships.

Method: Introduce a hierarchical tool-tokenization scheme that weaves intrinsic tool semantics with extrinsic co-usage patterns to form structured codes. These codes are integrated into the LLM via a generative alignment stage, guiding the model to produce hierarchical code sequences when selecting tools.

Result: On a benchmark of ~47,000 tools, ToolWeaver significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods, demonstrating improved scalability, generalization, and semantic awareness for tool-augmented agents.

Conclusion: Hierarchical, semantically-informed tool codes enable scalable learning of tool relationships and improved tool usage by LLMs, providing a robust foundation for large-scale, tool-augmented AI systems.

Abstract: Prevalent retrieval-based tool-use pipelines struggle with a dual semantic challenge: their retrievers often employ encoders that fail to capture complex semantics, while the Large Language Model (LLM) itself lacks intrinsic tool knowledge from its natural language pretraining. Generative methods offer a powerful alternative by unifying selection and execution, tasking the LLM to directly learn and generate tool identifiers. However, the common practice of mapping each tool to a unique new token introduces substantial limitations: it creates a scalability and generalization crisis, as the vocabulary size explodes and each tool is assigned a semantically isolated token. This approach also creates a semantic bottleneck that hinders the learning of collaborative tool relationships, as the model must infer them from sparse co-occurrences of monolithic tool IDs within a vast library. To address these limitations, we propose ToolWeaver, a novel generative tool learning framework that encodes tools into hierarchical sequences. This approach makes vocabulary expansion logarithmic to the number of tools. Crucially, it enables the model to learn collaborative patterns from the dense co-occurrence of shared codes, rather than the sparse co-occurrence of monolithic tool IDs. We generate these structured codes through a novel tokenization process designed to weave together a tool's intrinsic semantics with its extrinsic co-usage patterns. These structured codes are then integrated into the LLM through a generative alignment stage, where the model is fine-tuned to produce the hierarchical code sequences. Evaluation results with nearly 47,000 tools show that ToolWeaver significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods, establishing a more scalable, generalizable, and semantically-aware foundation for advanced tool-augmented agents.

</details>


### [178] [How do Visual Attributes Influence Web Agents? A Comprehensive Evaluation of User Interface Design Factors](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21961)
*Kuai Yu,Naicheng Yu,Han Wang,Rui Yang,Huan Zhang*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: VAF is a controlled evaluation pipeline that quantifies how visual webpage attributes influence web-agent decision-making. It identifies background color contrast, item size, position, and card clarity as strong influencers, while font styling, text color, and image clarity have weaker effects.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: There is limited systematic understanding of how benign visual attributes affect web-agent behavior; prior work focuses on robustness to adversarial attacks or textual attributes. A controlled, semantic-preserving variant-generation approach is needed to isolate visual factors.

Method: A three-stage pipeline: (i) variant generation ensuring semantic equivalence while altering visual attributes; (ii) browsing interaction simulating human-like scrolling and clicking; (iii) validation using Target Click Rate and Target Mention Rate to measure impact, across 8 variant families (48 variants total), 5 real-world websites, and 4 representative web agents.

Result: From experiments, background color contrast, item size, position, and card clarity strongly influence agent actions; font styling, text color, and item image clarity show minor effects; the findings enable ranking of visual factors by their influence on decision-making.

Conclusion: VAF provides a quantitative, controlled methodology to study visual factors in web-agent decision-making, enabling more robust agent and page design in benign settings and guiding future research on perceptual biases and layout effects.

Abstract: Web agents have demonstrated strong performance on a wide range of web-based tasks. However, existing research on the effect of environmental variation has mostly focused on robustness to adversarial attacks, with less attention to agents' preferences in benign scenarios. Although early studies have examined how textual attributes influence agent behavior, a systematic understanding of how visual attributes shape agent decision-making remains limited. To address this, we introduce VAF, a controlled evaluation pipeline for quantifying how webpage Visual Attribute Factors influence web-agent decision-making. Specifically, VAF consists of three stages: (i) variant generation, which ensures the variants share identical semantics as the original item while only differ in visual attributes; (ii) browsing interaction, where agents navigate the page via scrolling and clicking the interested item, mirroring how human users browse online; (iii) validating through both click action and reasoning from agents, which we use the Target Click Rate and Target Mention Rate to jointly evaluate the effect of visual attributes. By quantitatively measuring the decision-making difference between the original and variant, we identify which visual attributes influence agents' behavior most. Extensive experiments, across 8 variant families (48 variants total), 5 real-world websites (including shopping, travel, and news browsing), and 4 representative web agents, show that background color contrast, item size, position, and card clarity have a strong influence on agents' actions, whereas font styling, text color, and item image clarity exhibit minor effects.

</details>


### [179] [The Energy Impact of Domain Model Design in Classical Planning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21967)
*Ilche Georgievski,Serhat Tekin,Marco Aiello*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Domain-model design affects energy use in classical planners; across 5 domains and 5 planners, 32 variants each show energy differences that do not always align with runtime, suggesting energy-aware domain design can improve Green AI in planning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the neglected energy efficiency dimension in automated planning (Green AI) by exploiting the modular separation of domain models and planners to study how domain features affect energy consumption.

Method: Introduce a domain model configuration framework to systematically vary features (element ordering, action arity, dead-end states). Evaluate 5 benchmark domains with 5 state‑of‑the‑art planners, analyzing energy and runtime across 32 variants per domain.

Result: Domain-level modifications produce measurable energy differences across planners; energy consumption does not always correlate with runtime, indicating distinct energy behavior and planner sensitivity to domain features.

Conclusion: Domain design is a viable lever to reduce energy use in automated planning; energy-aware domain modeling should be explored further, as energy and runtime can diverge and planners respond differently to domain features.

Abstract: AI research has traditionally prioritised algorithmic performance, such as optimising accuracy in machine learning or runtime in automated planning. The emerging paradigm of Green AI challenges this by recognising energy consumption as a critical performance dimension. Despite the high computational demands of automated planning, its energy efficiency has received little attention. This gap is particularly salient given the modular planning structure, in which domain models are specified independently of algorithms. On the other hand, this separation also enables systematic analysis of energy usage through domain model design. We empirically investigate how domain model characteristics affect the energy consumption of classical planners. We introduce a domain model configuration framework that enables controlled variation of features, such as element ordering, action arity, and dead-end states. Using five benchmark domains and five state-of-the-art planners, we analyse energy and runtime impacts across 32 domain variants per benchmark. Results demonstrate that domain-level modifications produce measurable energy differences across planners, with energy consumption not always correlating with runtime.

</details>


### [180] [Learning Decentralized LLM Collaboration with Multi-Agent Actor Critic](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21972)
*Shuo Liu,Tianle Chen,Ryan Amiri,Christopher Amato*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: MAAC-based CoLLM methods for decentralized LLM collaboration; compares centralized vs decentralized critics; performance depends on horizon and reward density; Decentralized critics offer parallelism but can struggle with convergence in long/horizon sparse tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reduce reliance on predefined centralized execution protocols; address high variance of Monte Carlo fines; enable decentralized, parallel LLM collaboration using actor-critic MARL.

Method: Introduce two MAAC approaches: CoLLM-CC with a centralized critic and CoLLM-DC with decentralized critics. Analyze when and why MAAC helps; evaluate across writing, coding, and game-playing domains; compare with Monte Carlo baselines.

Result: CoLLM-DC and Monte Carlo methods can match CoLLM-CC in short-horizon/dense-reward settings; both underperform CoLLM-CC on long-horizon or sparse-reward tasks; Monte Carlo requires more samples; CoLLM-DC struggles to converge in those tougher settings; code available at the provided repository.

Conclusion: Centralized critic (CoLLM-CC) offers stronger performance in challenging long-horizon or sparse-reward tasks, while decentralized critics (CoLLM-DC) enable decentralization and sample efficiency in favorable settings but may converge issues in hard tasks; results highlight trade-offs between decentralization, convergence, and sample efficiency in MAAC-based LLM collaboration.

Abstract: Recent work has explored optimizing LLM collaboration through Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL). However, most MARL fine-tuning approaches rely on predefined execution protocols, which often require centralized execution. Decentralized LLM collaboration is more appealing in practice, as agents can run inference in parallel with flexible deployments. Also, current approaches use Monte Carlo methods for fine-tuning, which suffer from high variance and thus require more samples to train effectively. Actor-critic methods are prevalent in MARL for dealing with these issues, so we developed Multi-Agent Actor-Critic (MAAC) methods to optimize decentralized LLM collaboration. In this paper, we analyze when and why these MAAC methods are beneficial. We propose 2 MAAC approaches, \textbf{CoLLM-CC} with a \textbf{C}entralized \textbf{C}ritic and \textbf{CoLLM-DC} with \textbf{D}ecentralized \textbf{C}ritics. Our experiments across writing, coding, and game-playing domains show that Monte Carlo methods and CoLLM-DC can achieve performance comparable to CoLLM-CC in short-horizon and dense-reward settings. However, they both underperform CoLLM-CC on long-horizon or sparse-reward tasks, where Monte Carlo methods require substantially more samples and CoLLM-DC struggles to converge. Our code is available at https://github.com/OpenMLRL/CoMLRL/releases/tag/v1.3.2.

</details>


### [181] [Mind the Gap: How Elicitation Protocols Shape the Stated-Revealed Preference Gap in Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21975)
*Pranav Mahajan,Ihor Kendiukhov,Syed Hussain,Lydia Nottingham*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: SvR (stated-revealed) preference correlation in LMs is highly sensitive to elicitation protocol; neutrality and abstention alter correlation, while abstention in revealed preferences can destroy it; system-prompt steering shows limited reliability.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand how elicitation design (allowing neutrality/abstention, abstention in revealed prefs, system prompt steering) impacts the alignment between what LMs say they value and what they actually choose in tasks, across many models.

Method: Systematic experimental study across 24 LMs comparing stated-preference elicitation with and without neutrality/abstention; compute Spearman correlations between volunteered stated preferences and forced-choice revealed preferences; explore abstention in revealed prefs; test system-prompt steering on AIRiskDilemmas.

Result: Allowing neutrality during stated elicitation substantially increases ρ by excluding weak signals; permitting abstention in stated prefs further improves or maintains ρ for some settings but abstention in revealed prefs drives ρ toward zero or negative due to high neutrality rates; system-prompt steering using stated prefs does not reliably improve SvR correlation on AIRiskDilemmas.

Conclusion: SvR correlation is highly protocol-dependent; methods must account for indeterminate preferences. Current forced-choice elicitation risks conflating genuine preferences with elicitation artifacts; robust assessment requires incorporating indeterminacy signals (neutrality/abstention) and careful design of revealed-preference tasks.

Abstract: Recent work identifies a stated-revealed (SvR) preference gap in language models (LMs): a mismatch between the values models endorse and the choices they make in context. Existing evaluations rely heavily on binary forced-choice prompting, which entangles genuine preferences with artifacts of the elicitation protocol. We systematically study how elicitation protocols affect SvR correlation across 24 LMs. Allowing neutrality and abstention during stated preference elicitation allows us to exclude weak signals, substantially improving Spearman's rank correlation ($ρ$) between volunteered stated preferences and forced-choice revealed preferences. However, further allowing abstention in revealed preferences drives $ρ$ to near-zero or negative values due to high neutrality rates. Finally, we find that system prompt steering using stated preferences during revealed preference elicitation does not reliably improve SvR correlation on AIRiskDilemmas. Together, our results show that SvR correlation is highly protocol-dependent and that preference elicitation requires methods that account for indeterminate preferences.

</details>


### [182] [VERSA: Verified Event Data Format for Reliable Soccer Analytics](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21981)
*Geonhee Jo,Mingu Kang,Kangmin Lee,Minho Lee,Pascal Bauer,Sang-Ki Ko*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: VERSA is a state-transition–based verification framework for soccer event streams that detects and corrects logical inconsistencies, improving data reliability and downstream VAEP performance; applied to Bepro K League 1 2024 data with 18.81% inconsistencies and improved cross-provider consistency.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Event-stream data quality issues cause logical inconsistencies (e.g., ordering, missing events), undermining analytics; a formal verification framework is needed to ensure data integrity for reliable downstream tasks.

Method: Propose VERSA, a verification framework built on a state-transition model that defines valid event sequences; automatically detects and corrects anomalous patterns in the event stream; evaluate on real-world data (K League 1 2024 from Bepro); quantify inconsistencies, cross-provider consistency, and downstream impact on VAEP.

Result: Found 18.81% of events with logical inconsistencies in Bepro-supplied K League 1 (2024); VERSA improves cross-provider consistency and yields more robust performance for the VAEP player-contribution task after data refinement.

Conclusion: Verification via a state-transition model significantly enhances the reliability of soccer event data and improves downstream analytics like VAEP; approach supports unified representation across heterogeneous data sources.

Abstract: Event stream data is a critical resource for fine-grained analysis across various domains, including financial transactions, system operations, and sports. In sports, it is actively used for fine-grained analyses such as quantifying player contributions and identifying tactical patterns. However, the reliability of these models is fundamentally limited by inherent data quality issues that cause logical inconsistencies (e.g., incorrect event ordering or missing events). To this end, this study proposes VERSA (Verified Event Data Format for Reliable Soccer Analytics), a systematic verification framework that ensures the integrity of event stream data within the soccer domain. VERSA is based on a state-transition model that defines valid event sequences, thereby enabling the automatic detection and correction of anomalous patterns within the event stream data. Notably, our examination of event data from the K League 1 (2024 season), provided by Bepro, detected that 18.81% of all recorded events exhibited logical inconsistencies. Addressing such integrity issues, our experiments demonstrate that VERSA significantly enhances cross-provider consistency, ensuring stable and unified data representation across heterogeneous sources. Furthermore, we demonstrate that data refined by VERSA significantly improves the robustness and performance of a downstream task called VAEP, which evaluates player contributions. These results highlight that the verification process is highly effective in increasing the reliability of data-driven analysis.

</details>


### [183] [Liquid Interfaces: A Dynamic Ontology for the Interoperability of Autonomous Systems](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21993)
*Dhiogo de Sá,Carlos Schmiedel,Carlos Pereira Lopes*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Liquid Interfaces propose ephemeral, intention-driven interfaces and the Liquid Interface Protocol (LIP) to enable adaptive, context-aware coordination among autonomous agents; the work provides a formal model, governance considerations, and a reference architecture to demonstrate feasibility.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Conventional software architectures rely on static interfaces and deterministic contracts, which impede adaptive, probabilistic, context-dependent agent reasoning. There is a need for runtime, semantic negotiation that yields ephemeral interfaces to support flexible coordination.

Method: Formalize the coordination model; develop the Liquid Interface Protocol (LIP) governing intention-driven interaction, negotiated execution, and ephemerality under semantic uncertainty; discuss governance implications; present a reference architecture to demonstrate practical feasibility.

Result: A formal model and protocol for ephemeral, intention-based interactions; governance considerations; and a reference architecture showing practical feasibility for adaptive coordination in agent-based systems.

Conclusion: Liquid Interfaces provide a principled foundation for adaptive coordination in contemporary agent-based software systems.

Abstract: Contemporary software architectures struggle to support autonomous agents whose reasoning is adaptive, probabilistic, and context-dependent, while system integration remains dominated by static interfaces and deterministic contracts. This paper introduces Liquid Interfaces, a coordination paradigm in which interfaces are not persistent technical artifacts, but ephemeral relational events that emerge through intention articulation and semantic negotiation at runtime.We formalize this model and present the Liquid Interface Protocol (LIP),which governs intention-driven interaction, negotiated execution, and enforce ephemerality under semantic uncertainty. We further discuss the governance implications of this approach and describe a reference architecture that demonstrates practical feasibility. Liquid Interfaces provide a principled foundation for adaptive coordination in agent-based systems

</details>


### [184] [Heterogeneous Computing: The Key to Powering the Future of AI Agent Inference](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22001)
*Yiren Zhao,Junyi Liu*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Proposes Operational Intensity (OI) and Capacity Footprint (CF) to explain memory-related bottlenecks in large-scale AI inference, revealing the memory capacity wall and motivating disaggregated, heterogeneous architectures and agent-hardware co-design.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Classic roofline analyses miss memory capacity constraints that become critical for agentic AI workloads with long-context caches. There is a need for metrics that capture the interplay of memory footprint and bandwidth across diverse workflows and model types.

Method: Define and apply two metrics, OI and CF, across agentic workflows (chat, coding, web use, computer use) and base model families (GQA/MLA, MoE, quantization). Analyze how long context KV caches influence memory-bound decoding and argue for disaggregated serving, specialized accelerators, and system-level heterogeneity; hypothesize agent-hardware co-design with multiple accelerators and memory disaggregation via high-bandwidth I/O.

Result: OI/CF explain regimes not captured by traditional roofline, showing that memory capacity and bandwidth dominate in many agentic workloads, especially with long-context KV caches. Observations support disaggregated serving and heterogeneous architectures, including prefill/decode accelerators, broader networking, and optical I/O, as foundations for scalable inference.

Conclusion: Encourage agent-hardware co-design with multiple accelerators per system and high-bandwidth, large-capacity memory disaggregation to adapt to evolving OI/CF, charting a path to sustain efficiency and capability for large-scale agentic AI inference.

Abstract: AI agent inference is driving an inference heavy datacenter future and exposes bottlenecks beyond compute - especially memory capacity, memory bandwidth and high-speed interconnect. We introduce two metrics - Operational Intensity (OI) and Capacity Footprint (CF) - that jointly explain regimes the classic roofline analysis misses, including the memory capacity wall. Across agentic workflows (chat, coding, web use, computer use) and base model choices (GQA/MLA, MoE, quantization), OI/CF can shift dramatically, with long context KV cache making decode highly memory bound. These observations motivate disaggregated serving and system level heterogeneity: specialized prefill and decode accelerators, broader scale up networking, and decoupled compute-memory enabled by optical I/O. We further hypothesize agent-hardware co design, multiple inference accelerators within one system, and high bandwidth, large capacity memory disaggregation as foundations for adaptation to evolving OI/CF. Together, these directions chart a path to sustain efficiency and capability for large scale agentic AI inference.

</details>


### [185] [CAR-bench: Evaluating the Consistency and Limit-Awareness of LLM Agents under Real-World Uncertainty](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22027)
*Johannes Kirmayr,Lukas Stappen,Elisabeth André*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: CAR-bench evaluates reliability of multi-turn, tool-using LLM agents in an in-car assistant; introduces Hallucination and Disambiguation tasks; baseline results reveal major reliability gaps in consistency, uncertainty handling, and policy adherence.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current benchmarks emphasize task completion under idealized conditions, but real-world, user-facing applications involve incomplete/ambiguous requests and intrinsic uncertainty. There is a need for self-aware, policy-compliant agents that can manage uncertainty in dialogue and tool use.

Method: An environment with an LLM-simulated user, domain policies, and 58 interconnected tools spanning navigation, productivity, charging, and vehicle control. Multi-turn interactions assess consistency, uncertainty handling, and capability awareness. Hallucination tasks test limit-awareness under missing tools/information; Disambiguation tasks require clarification or internal information gathering.

Result: Baseline results show sizable gaps between occasional and consistent success across tasks. Even frontier LLMs achieve <50% consistent pass rate on Disambiguation due to premature actions, and frequently violate policies or fabricate information in Hallucination tasks, highlighting reliability and self-awareness deficiencies.

Conclusion: CAR-bench reveals critical reliability and self-awareness gaps in current LLM agents operating in realistic, tool-using, multi-turn scenarios; findings point to directions for improving consistency, uncertainty handling, policy adherence, and tool-use governance.

Abstract: Existing benchmarks for Large Language Model (LLM) agents focus on task completion under idealistic settings but overlook reliability in real-world, user-facing applications. In domains, such as in-car voice assistants, users often issue incomplete or ambiguous requests, creating intrinsic uncertainty that agents must manage through dialogue, tool use, and policy adherence. We introduce CAR-bench, a benchmark for evaluating consistency, uncertainty handling, and capability awareness in multi-turn, tool-using LLM agents in an in-car assistant domain. The environment features an LLM-simulated user, domain policies, and 58 interconnected tools spanning navigation, productivity, charging, and vehicle control. Beyond standard task completion, CAR-bench introduces Hallucination tasks that test agents' limit-awareness under missing tools or information, and Disambiguation tasks that require resolving uncertainty through clarification or internal information gathering. Baseline results reveal large gaps between occasional and consistent success on all task types. Even frontier reasoning LLMs achieve less than 50% consistent pass rate on Disambiguation tasks due to premature actions, and frequently violate policies or fabricate information to satisfy user requests in Hallucination tasks, underscoring the need for more reliable and self-aware LLM agents in real-world settings.

</details>


### [186] [Routing the Lottery: Adaptive Subnetworks for Heterogeneous Data](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22141)
*Grzegorz Stefanski,Alberto Presta,Michal Byra*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: RTL proposes adaptive tickets—multiple specialized subnetworks for heterogeneous data, routing inputs to the appropriate subnetwork to improve performance with far fewer parameters; reveals subnetwork collapse and introduces a similarity score for diagnosing oversparsification.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Pruning's Lottery Ticket Hypothesis shows sparse winning tickets exist but typically assumes a single universal ticket, ignoring data heterogeneity. There is a need for modular, context-aware pruning that aligns subnetworks with different data contexts.

Method: Introduce Routing the Lottery (RTL); learn multiple adaptive tickets for distinct contexts (classes, semantic clusters, environments); incorporate a routing mechanism to select the suitable subnetwork; analyze subnetwork similarity; identify subnetwork collapse under aggressive pruning.

Result: RTL outperforms single- and multi-model baselines across tasks and datasets in balanced accuracy and recall; uses up to 10x fewer parameters than independent models; subnetworks are semantically aligned with their contexts; introduce a label-free diagnosis tool (subnetwork similarity score).

Conclusion: Pruning can be framed as structuring model capacity to match data heterogeneity, enabling modular, context-aware networks and more efficient deployment.

Abstract: In pruning, the Lottery Ticket Hypothesis posits that large networks contain sparse subnetworks, or winning tickets, that can be trained in isolation to match the performance of their dense counterparts. However, most existing approaches assume a single universal winning ticket shared across all inputs, ignoring the inherent heterogeneity of real-world data. In this work, we propose Routing the Lottery (RTL), an adaptive pruning framework that discovers multiple specialized subnetworks, called adaptive tickets, each tailored to a class, semantic cluster, or environmental condition. Across diverse datasets and tasks, RTL consistently outperforms single- and multi-model baselines in balanced accuracy and recall, while using up to 10 times fewer parameters than independent models and exhibiting semantically aligned. Furthermore, we identify subnetwork collapse, a performance drop under aggressive pruning, and introduce a subnetwork similarity score that enables label-free diagnosis of oversparsification. Overall, our results recast pruning as a mechanism for aligning model structure with data heterogeneity, paving the way toward more modular and context-aware deep learning.

</details>


### [187] [Optimizing Agentic Workflows using Meta-tools](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22037)
*Sami Abuzakuk,Anne-Marie Kermarrec,Rishi Sharma,Rasmus Moorits Veski,Martijn de Vos*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: AWO identifies and composes recurring tool-call patterns into meta-tools to optimize agentic AI workflows, reducing LLM usage and improving robustness.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Agentic AI workflows incur high latency, cost, and hallucination risk due to iterative reasoning and numerous tool invocations; there is a need to improve efficiency and reliability.

Method: Analyze workflow traces to discover recurring sequences of tool calls; transform these sequences into deterministic, composite meta-tools that bundle multiple agent actions into a single invocation, bypassing intermediate reasoning steps when possible.
