Result: Empirical evaluation on two agentic AI benchmarks shows up to 11.9% reduction in LLM calls and up to 4.2 percentage-point gains in task success rate.

Conclusion: Meta-tools reduce intermediate reasoning, lower operational cost, shorten execution paths, and improve robustness, without sacrificing—and possibly improving—task performance.

Abstract: Agentic AI enables LLM to dynamically reason, plan, and interact with tools to solve complex tasks. However, agentic workflows often require many iterative reasoning steps and tool invocations, leading to significant operational expense, end-to-end latency and failures due to hallucinations. This work introduces Agent Workflow Optimization (AWO), a framework that identifies and optimizes redundant tool execution patterns to improve the efficiency and robustness of agentic workflows. AWO analyzes existing workflow traces to discover recurring sequences of tool calls and transforms them into meta-tools, which are deterministic, composite tools that bundle multiple agent actions into a single invocation. Meta-tools bypass unnecessary intermediate LLM reasoning steps and reduce operational cost while also shortening execution paths, leading to fewer failures. Experiments on two agentic AI benchmarks show that AWO reduces the number of LLM calls up to 11.9% while also increasing the task success rate by up to 4.2 percent points.

</details>


### [188] [Defining Operational Conditions for Safety-Critical AI-Based Systems from Data](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22118)
*Johann Christensen,Elena Hoemann,Frank Köster,Sven Hallerbach*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: A data-driven, kernel-based method to define the Operational Design Domain (ODD) after data collection, enabling certification of AI systems in safety-critical contexts by equating the learned ODD with the original hidden ODD; validated via Monte Carlo simulations and an aviation use case.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: ODD descriptions are difficult to obtain for complex, real-world systems, yet certification requires a precise, verifiable ODD. A posteriori, data-driven ODDs can fill gaps when expert-based ODDs are incomplete.

Method: Proposes a multi-dimensional kernel-based representation to define the ODD from data post hoc. Validates with Monte Carlo methods and a real-world aviation collision-avoidance case. Establishes conditions under which two ODDs are equal, showing data-driven ODD can equal the underlying hidden ODD.

Result: Demonstrates that the data-driven ODD can be equal to the original ODD of the data. The approach supports certification of data-driven, safety-critical AI systems via Safe-by-Design kernel-based ODD.

Conclusion: A Safe-by-Design kernel-based ODD framework enables certification of data-driven safety-critical AI systems by deriving and validating a posteriori ODDs from data and proving conditions for ODD equivalence.

Abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) has been on the rise in many domains, including numerous safety-critical applications. However, for complex systems found in the real world, or when data already exist, defining the underlying environmental conditions is extremely challenging. This often results in an incomplete description of the environment in which the AI-based system must operate. Nevertheless, this description, called the Operational Design Domain (ODD), is required in many domains for the certification of AI-based systems. Traditionally, the ODD is created in the early stages of the development process, drawing on sophisticated expert knowledge and related standards. This paper presents a novel Safety-by-Design method to a posteriori define the ODD from previously collected data using a multi-dimensional kernel-based representation. This approach is validated through both Monte Carlo methods and a real-world aviation use case for a future safety-critical collision-avoidance system. Moreover, by defining under what conditions two ODDs are equal, the paper shows that the data-driven ODD can equal the original, underlying hidden ODD of the data. Utilizing the novel, Safe-by-Design kernel-based ODD enables future certification of data-driven, safety-critical AI-based systems.

</details>


### [189] [World of Workflows: a Benchmark for Bringing World Models to Enterprise Systems](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22130)
*Lakshya Gupta,Litao Li,Yizhe Liu,Sriram Ganapathi Subramanian,Kaheer Suleman,Zichen Zhang,Haoye Lu,Sumit Pasupalak*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: WoW introduces a realistic enterprise environment and benchmark revealing dynamics blindness in frontier LLMs; effective enterprise agents require grounded world modeling to infer hidden state transitions.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Enterprise systems exhibit hidden workflows, limited observability, and cascading side effects across large databases. Existing benchmarks assess surface-level task completion and fail to capture core enterprise dynamics.

Method: Develop World of Workflows (WoW), a ServiceNow-based, rule-rich environment with 4,000+ business rules and 55 active workflows; accompany with WoW-bench, a 234-task benchmark to evaluate constrained task completion and dynamics modeling in enterprise contexts.

Result: Two main findings: (1) Frontier LLMs struggle to predict invisible, cascading side effects, leading to silent constraint violations; (2) reliable performance in opaque systems requires grounded world modeling and mental simulation of hidden state transitions when feedback is scarce.

Conclusion: WoW advocates a new paradigm centered on explicit learning of system dynamics for reliable enterprise agents; authors provide a GitHub resource to set up and evaluate WoW.

Abstract: Frontier large language models (LLMs) excel as autonomous agents in many domains, yet they remain untested in complex enterprise systems where hidden workflows create cascading effects across interconnected databases. Existing enterprise benchmarks evaluate surface-level agentic task completion similar to general consumer benchmarks, ignoring true challenges in enterprises, such as limited observability, large database state, and hidden workflows with cascading side effects. We introduce World of Workflows (WoW), a realistic ServiceNow-based environment incorporating 4,000+ business rules and 55 active workflows embedded in the system, alongside WoW-bench, a benchmark of 234 tasks evaluating constrained agentic task completion and enterprise dynamics modeling capabilities. We reveal two major takeaways: (1) Frontier LLMs suffer from dynamics blindness, consistently failing to predict the invisible, cascading side effects of their actions, which leads to silent constraint violations, and (2) reliability in opaque systems requires grounded world modeling, where agents must mentally simulate hidden state transitions to bridge the observability gap when high-fidelity feedback is unavailable. For reliable and useful enterprise agents, WoW motivates a new paradigm to explicitly learn system dynamics. We release our GitHub for setting up and evaluating WoW.

</details>


### [190] [Exploring Reasoning Reward Model for Agents](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22154)
*Kaixuan Fan,Kaituo Feng,Manyuan Zhang,Tianshuo Peng,Zhixun Li,Yilei Jiang,Shuang Chen,Peng Pei,Xunliang Cai,Xiangyu Yue*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Agent-RRM introduces structured feedback signals for agentic reasoning and explores three integration strategies, with Reagent-U achieving notable gains on GAIA and WebWalkerQA across 12 benchmarks; resources released.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address sparsity and late feedback in reward signals that hinder intermediate reasoning quality in agentic RL.

Method: Proposes Agent Reasoning Reward Model with three components: explicit reasoning trace, focused critique, overall score. Evaluates three integration strategies: Reagent-C, Reagent-R, Reagent-U across 12 benchmarks.

Result: Reagent-U yields substantial performance gains; GAIA 43.7%, WebWalkerQA 46.2% (presumably accuracy). Code/models/datasets released.

Conclusion: Structured reasoning feedback improves agentic RL; unified feedback integration is most effective; releases enable reproducibility.

Abstract: Agentic Reinforcement Learning (Agentic RL) has achieved notable success in enabling agents to perform complex reasoning and tool use. However, most methods still relies on sparse outcome-based reward for training. Such feedback fails to differentiate intermediate reasoning quality, leading to suboptimal training results. In this paper, we introduce Agent Reasoning Reward Model (Agent-RRM), a multi-faceted reward model that produces structured feedback for agentic trajectories, including (1) an explicit reasoning trace , (2) a focused critique that provides refinement guidance by highlighting reasoning flaws, and (3) an overall score that evaluates process performance. Leveraging these signals, we systematically investigate three integration strategies: Reagent-C (text-augmented refinement), Reagent-R (reward-augmented guidance), and Reagent-U (unified feedback integration). Extensive evaluations across 12 diverse benchmarks demonstrate that Reagent-U yields substantial performance leaps, achieving 43.7% on GAIA and 46.2% on WebWalkerQA, validating the effectiveness of our reasoning reward model and training schemes. Code, models, and datasets are all released to facilitate future research.

</details>


<div id='cs.LG'></div>

# cs.LG [[Back]](#toc)

### [191] [Rethinking LLM-Driven Heuristic Design: Generating Efficient and Specialized Solvers via Dynamics-Aware Optimization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.20868)
*Rongzheng Wang,Yihong Huang,Muquan Li,Jiakai Li,Di Liang,Bob Simons,Pei Ke,Shuang Liang,Ke Qin*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: DASH introduces a dynamics-aware, convergence-guided LHD framework with Profiled Library Retrieval to improve efficiency and adaptation across heterogeneous distributions, achieving >3x runtime speedups and >90% reduction in adaptation costs while outperforming baselines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current LHD approaches rely on endpoint (final-quality) evaluation and require costly re-adaptation when instance distributions shift. There is a need to incorporate convergence dynamics and reusable solvers to improve efficiency and robustness.

Method: Co-optimizes solver search strategies and runtime schedules under a convergence-aware metric. It uses Profiled Library Retrieval to archive specialized solvers during evolutionary search, enabling warm starts for diverse/heterogeneous instances.

Result: Empirical results on four combinatorial optimization problems show runtime improvements exceeding 3x and superior solution quality compared to state-of-the-art baselines across problem scales. Profile-based warm starts preserve accuracy under distribution shifts and reduce LLM adaptation costs by more than 90%.

Conclusion: DASH provides a scalable, convergence-aware framework for LLM-driven heuristic design, combining dynamic solver/search optimization with reusable, profiled solvers to boost efficiency and robustness across problem distributions.

Abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have advanced the field of Combinatorial Optimization through automated heuristic generation. Instead of relying on manual design, this LLM-Driven Heuristic Design (LHD) process leverages LLMs to iteratively generate and refine solvers to achieve high performance. However, existing LHD frameworks face two critical limitations: (1) Endpoint-only evaluation, which ranks solvers solely by final quality, ignoring the convergence process and runtime efficiency; (2) High adaptation costs, where distribution shifts necessitate re-adaptation to generate specialized solvers for new instance groups. To address these issues, we propose Dynamics-Aware Solver Heuristics (DASH), a framework that co-optimizes solver search mechanisms and runtime schedules guided by a convergence-aware metric, thereby identifying efficient and high-performance solvers. Furthermore, to mitigate expensive re-adaptation, DASH incorporates Profiled Library Retrieval (PLR). PLR efficiently archives specialized solvers concurrently with the evolutionary process, enabling cost-effective warm-starts for heterogeneous distributions. Experiments on four combinatorial optimization problems demonstrate that DASH improves runtime efficiency by over 3 times, while surpassing the solution quality of state-of-the-art baselines across diverse problem scales. Furthermore, by enabling profile-based warm starts, DASH maintains superior accuracy under different distributions while cutting LLM adaptation costs by over 90%.

</details>


### [192] [Finetune-Informed Pretraining Boosts Downstream Performance](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.20884)
*Atik Faysal,Mohammad Rostami,Reihaneh Gh. Roshan,Nikhil Muralidhar,Huaxia Wang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Finetune-Informed Pretraining (FIP) biases multimodal pretraining toward a designated target modality at fine-tuning time by increasing masking difficulty, loss weighting, and decoder capacity for that modality, without changing the shared encoder or adding supervision, improving downstream performance in masked modeling on wireless signal constellation diagrams; model-agnostic and broadly applicable.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: In many deployments, a single modality dominates downstream tasks. Uniform multimodal pretraining may under-prepare representations for this important modality. FIP aims to align pretraining with downstream modality requirements.

Method: FIP increases three aspects for the target modality during masked modeling: (1) higher masking difficulty, (2) stronger loss weighting, and (3) increased decoder capacity for the target modality. These changes apply to the target modality only, without modifying the shared encoder or requiring additional supervision, making the approach model-agnostic.

Result: Applied to masked modeling on constellation diagrams for wireless signals, FIP consistently improves downstream fine-tuned performance without extra data or compute. It is simple to implement, architecture-compatible, and broadly applicable across multimodal masked modeling pipelines.

Conclusion: FIP offers a simple, effective, and generalizable strategy to bias multimodal pretraining toward the modality that matters at fine-tuning time, improving downstream performance while preserving training efficiency and compatibility.

Abstract: Multimodal pretraining is effective for building general-purpose representations, but in many practical deployments, only one modality is heavily used during downstream fine-tuning. Standard pretraining strategies treat all modalities uniformly, which can lead to under-optimized representations for the modality that actually matters. We propose Finetune-Informed Pretraining (FIP), a model-agnostic method that biases representation learning toward a designated target modality needed at fine-tuning time. FIP combines higher masking difficulty, stronger loss weighting, and increased decoder capacity for the target modality, without modifying the shared encoder or requiring additional supervision. When applied to masked modeling on constellation diagrams for wireless signals, FIP consistently improves downstream fine-tuned performance with no extra data or compute. FIP is simple to implement, architecture-compatible, and broadly applicable across multimodal masked modeling pipelines.

</details>


### [193] [A generative machine learning model for designing metal hydrides applied to hydrogen storage](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.20892)
*Xiyuan Liu,Christian Hacker,Shengnian Wang,Yuhua Duan*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A causal-discovery–driven, lightweight generative ML framework expands metal hydride candidates beyond existing databases, yielding six new formulas/structures (four DFT-validated) from 450 samples, accelerating hydrogen storage materials discovery.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current materials databases lack comprehensive hydride coverage, restricting discovery of optimal hydrogen storage materials; a scalable method to explore unexplored chemical space is needed.

Method: Combine causal discovery with a lightweight generative ML model; train on 450 samples (270/90/90), generate 1,000 candidates, rank/filter, identify novel formulas/structures, and validate via density functional theory (DFT) for four promising cases.

Result: Identified six previously unreported candidates; four pass DFT validation and show strong potential for experiments; demonstrates a scalable, time-efficient path for expanding hydrogen storage datasets.

Conclusion: The framework can accelerate discovery of metal hydrides and help overcome database limitations; further work includes experimental validation and exploration of generalizability to broader chemistries.

Abstract: Developing new metal hydrides is a critical step toward efficient hydrogen storage in carbon-neutral energy systems. However, existing materials databases, such as the Materials Project, contain a limited number of well-characterized hydrides, which constrains the discovery of optimal candidates. This work presents a framework that integrates causal discovery with a lightweight generative machine learning model to generate novel metal hydride candidates that may not exist in current databases. Using a dataset of 450 samples (270 training, 90 validation, and 90 testing), the model generates 1,000 candidates. After ranking and filtering, six previously unreported chemical formulas and crystal structures are identified, four of which are validated by density functional theory simulations and show strong potential for future experimental investigation. Overall, the proposed framework provides a scalable and time-efficient approach for expanding hydrogen storage datasets and accelerating materials discovery.

</details>


### [194] [Is Parameter Isolation Better for Prompt-Based Continual Learning?](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.20894)
*Jiangyang Li,Chenhao Ding,Songlin Dong,Qiang Wang,Jianchao Zhao,Yuhang He,Yihong Gong*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A prompt-sharing continual learning framework with a global prompt pool, task-aware gated routing, and a history-aware modulator; it dynamically decouples tasks and improves efficiency, outperforming static prompt allocation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Fixed, per-task prompt allocations waste parameters and isolate knowledge, hindering cross-task knowledge transfer and efficient utilization.

Method: Construct a global pool of prompts; employ a task-aware gated routing mechanism that sparsely activates a subset of prompts for each task to enable dynamic decoupling and collaborative feature optimization; introduce a history-aware modulator that uses cumulative prompt activation statistics to protect frequently used prompts from excessive updates, mitigating inefficient parameter usage and forgetting.

Result: The approach consistently outperforms existing static allocation strategies in both effectiveness and efficiency across continual learning scenarios.

Conclusion: Dynamic prompt sharing with gating routing and history-aware modulation provides better parameter utilization and resilience against forgetting compared to fixed, task-isolated prompt allocations.

Abstract: Prompt-based continual learning methods effectively mitigate catastrophic forgetting. However, most existing methods assign a fixed set of prompts to each task, completely isolating knowledge across tasks and resulting in suboptimal parameter utilization. To address this, we consider the practical needs of continual learning and propose a prompt-sharing framework. This framework constructs a global prompt pool and introduces a task-aware gated routing mechanism that sparsely activates a subset of prompts to achieve dynamic decoupling and collaborative optimization of task-specific feature representations. Furthermore, we introduce a history-aware modulator that leverages cumulative prompt activation statistics to protect frequently used prompts from excessive updates, thereby mitigating inefficient parameter usage and knowledge forgetting. Extensive analysis and empirical results demonstrate that our approach consistently outperforms existing static allocation strategies in effectiveness and efficiency.

</details>


### [195] [Faster Predictive Coding Networks via Better Initialization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.20895)
*Luca Pinchetti,Simon Frieder,Thomas Lukasiewicz,Tommaso Salvatori*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A new initialization strategy for predictive coding networks preserves iterative progress across samples, substantially speeding convergence and improving final performance in supervised and unsupervised tasks, addressing computational efficiency gaps with backprop.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Energy-based, predictive coding networks are promising but computationally heavy due to iterative inference. Initialization can influence convergence speed; bridging predictive coding with backprop requires efficiency gains.

Method: Introduce a novel initialization technique that preserves the iterative progress from previous training samples when starting inference for a new sample, effectively warm-starting the dynamics of predictive coding networks.

Result: Experiments show substantial improvements in convergence speed and final test loss in both supervised and unsupervised settings.

Conclusion: Initialization-aware training can reconcile predictive coding with backprop-like efficiency, offering a practical path to scalable energy-based learning and faster convergence.

Abstract: Research aimed at scaling up neuroscience inspired learning algorithms for neural networks is accelerating. Recently, a key research area has been the study of energy-based learning algorithms such as predictive coding, due to their versatility and mathematical grounding. However, the applicability of such methods is held back by the large computational requirements caused by their iterative nature. In this work, we address this problem by showing that the choice of initialization of the neurons in a predictive coding network matters significantly and can notably reduce the required training times. Consequently, we propose a new initialization technique for predictive coding networks that aims to preserve the iterative progress made on previous training samples. Our approach suggests a promising path toward reconciling the disparities between predictive coding and backpropagation in terms of computational efficiency and final performance. In fact, our experiments demonstrate substantial improvements in convergence speed and final test loss in both supervised and unsupervised settings.

</details>


### [196] [TwinWeaver: An LLM-Based Foundation Model Framework for Pan-Cancer Digital Twins](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.20906)
*Nikita Makarov,Maria Bordukova,Lena Voith von Voithenberg,Estrella Pivel-Villanueva,Sabrina Mielke,Jonathan Wickes,Hanchen Wang,Mingyu Derek Ma,Keunwoo Choi,Kyunghyun Cho,Stephen Ra,Raul Rodriguez-Esteban,Fabian Schmich,Michael Menden*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: TwinWeaver converts longitudinal patient histories into text to enable unified event prediction with LLMs; Genie Digital Twin (GDT) trained on 93k patients across 20 cancer types improves forecasting accuracy (lower MASE) and risk stratification (higher C-index), and generalizes to out-of-distribution trials, with an interpretable reasoning extension.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Forecasting clinical events from sparse, multi-modal clinical time series is difficult; a scalable framework is needed to leverage large language models for longitudinal oncology data.

Method: Serialize longitudinal clinical histories into text using TwinWeaver, then apply LLM-based prediction and forecasting on GDT across multiple tasks (event prediction, survival/progression/therapy-switching risk). Evaluate using MASE and C-index; test zero-shot/generalization to clinical trials; provide an interpretable clinical reasoning extension.

Result: GDT achieves median MASE of 0.87 vs 0.97 for strongest time-series baseline (p<0.001); average C-index 0.703 across tasks vs 0.662 baseline; zero-shot median MASE 0.75-0.88 and C-index 0.672 vs 0.648 baseline; demonstrates generalization to unseen trials and an interpretable framework.

Conclusion: TwinWeaver offers a scalable, transparent foundation for longitudinal clinical modeling with LLMs, enabling improved forecasting, risk stratification, and generalization across oncology tasks.

Abstract: Precision oncology requires forecasting clinical events and trajectories, yet modeling sparse, multi-modal clinical time series remains a critical challenge. We introduce TwinWeaver, an open-source framework that serializes longitudinal patient histories into text, enabling unified event prediction as well as forecasting with large language models, and use it to build Genie Digital Twin (GDT) on 93,054 patients across 20 cancer types. In benchmarks, GDT significantly reduces forecasting error, achieving a median Mean Absolute Scaled Error (MASE) of 0.87 compared to 0.97 for the strongest time-series baseline (p<0.001). Furthermore, GDT improves risk stratification, achieving an average concordance index (C-index) of 0.703 across survival, progression, and therapy switching tasks, surpassing the best baseline of 0.662. GDT also generalizes to out-of-distribution clinical trials, matching trained baselines at zero-shot and surpassing them with fine-tuning, achieving a median MASE of 0.75-0.88 and outperforming the strongest baseline in event prediction with an average C-index of 0.672 versus 0.648. Finally, TwinWeaver enables an interpretable clinical reasoning extension, providing a scalable and transparent foundation for longitudinal clinical modeling.

</details>


### [197] [Noisy but Valid: Robust Statistical Evaluation of LLMs with Imperfect Judges](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.20913)
*Chen Feng,Minghe Shen,Ananth Balashankar,Carsten Gerner-Beuerle,Miguel R. D. Rodrigues*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Noisy but Valid: a principled hypothesis-testing framework to certify LLM safety under imperfect judges by calibrating judge error rates and applying a variance-corrected threshold to large judge-labeled data, achieving finite-sample validity and improved power.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reliable certification of LLM safety is hindered by judge imperfections (noise, bias). Existing Prediction-Powered Inference (PPI) is black-box and lacks explicit modeling of judge behavior. A principled method that accounts for judge reliability is needed.

Method: Calibrate the judge using a small human-labeled set to estimate True Positive Rate (TPR) and False Positive Rate (FPR). Derive a variance-corrected critical threshold and apply it to a large judge-labeled dataset. Provide finite-sample Type-I error control despite calibration uncertainty. Frame as diagnostic that models judge behavior rather than a black-box estimator. Compare with PPI.

Result: Theoretical guarantees under finite-sample settings, showing conditions where noisy testing yields higher power than direct evaluation. Empirical validation on Jigsaw Comment, Hate Speech, and SafeRLHF corroborates theory. Introduces the Oracle Gap—the performance gap between practical methods and the hypothetical oracle with perfectly known judge parameters. Delivers interpretable diagnostics of judge reliability and clarifies how evaluation power depends on judge quality, dataset size, and certification level.

Conclusion: Presents the first systematic treatment of imperfect-judge evaluation, enabling interpretable assessment of judge reliability, quantifying the cost of estimation, and clarifying the trade-offs among evaluation tools for LLM safety certification.

Abstract: Reliable certification of Large Language Models (LLMs)-verifying that failure rates are below a safety threshold-is critical yet challenging. While "LLM-as-a-Judge" offers scalability, judge imperfections, noise, and bias can invalidate statistical guarantees. We introduce a "Noisy but Valid" hypothesis testing framework to address this. By leveraging a small human-labelled calibration set to estimate the judge's True Positive and False Positive Rates (TPR/FPR), we derive a variance-corrected critical threshold applied to a large judge-labelled dataset. Crucially, our framework theoretically guarantees finite-sample Type-I error control (validity) despite calibration uncertainty. This distinguishes our work from Prediction-Powered Inference (PPI), positioning our method as a diagnostic tool that explicitly models judge behavior rather than a black-box estimator. Our contributions include: (1) Theoretical Guarantees: We derive the exact conditions under which noisy testing yields higher statistical power than direct evaluation; (2) Empirical Validation: Experiments on Jigsaw Comment, Hate Speech and SafeRLHF confirm our theory; (3) The Oracle Gap: We reveal a significant performance gap between practical methods and the theoretical "Oracle" (perfectly known judge parameters), quantifying the cost of estimation. Specifically, we provide the first systematic treatment of the imperfect-judge setting, yielding interpretable diagnostics of judge reliability and clarifying how evaluation power depends on judge quality, dataset size, and certification levels. Together, these results sharpen understanding of statistical evaluation with LLM judges, and highlight trade-offs among competing inferential tools.

</details>


### [198] [Noninvasive Intracranial Pressure Estimation Using Subspace System Identification and Bespoke Machine Learning Algorithms: A Learning-to-Rank Approach](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.20916)
*Anni Zhao,Ayca Ermis,Jeffrey Robert Vitt,Sergio Brasil,Wellingson Paiva,Magdalena Kasprowicz,Malgorzata Burzynska,Robert Hamilton,Runze Yan,Ofer Sadan,J. Claude Hemphill,Lieven Vandenberghe,Xiao Hu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Noninvasive ICP estimation via a hybrid ML framework combining subspace system identification and ranking-constrained optimization; achieves ~32% within 2 mmHg and ~34% within 2–6 mmHg on test data, suggesting feasibility but requiring further validation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Enable accurate, noninvasive, bedside ICP monitoring to replace or supplement invasive methods in acute brain injury, addressing critical care needs and patient safety.

Method: Build cerebral hemodynamics models with subspace system identification using ABP, CBv, and R-R signals; learn a convex, ranking-constrained nonlinear mapping from signal features to ICP estimation errors; evaluate on randomly split training/testing cohorts.

Result: On testing data, 31.88% of entries have estimation error ≤ 2 mmHg; 34.07% have error between 2 and 6 mmHg; overall demonstration of feasibility, with a substantial portion of cases achieving clinically acceptable accuracy.

Conclusion: The approach shows feasibility for noninvasive mean ICP estimation; requires comprehensive external validation, comparison with existing methods, and refinement for clinical deployment.

Abstract: Objective: Accurate noninvasive estimation of intracranial pressure (ICP) remains a major challenge in critical care. We developed a bespoke machine learning algorithm that integrates system identification and ranking-constrained optimization to estimate mean ICP from noninvasive signals. Methods: A machine learning framework was proposed to obtain accurate mean ICP values using arbitrary noninvasive signals. The subspace system identification algorithm is employed to identify cerebral hemodynamics models for ICP simulation using arterial blood pressure (ABP), cerebral blood velocity (CBv), and R-wave to R-wave interval (R-R interval) signals in a comprehensive database. A mapping function to describe the relationship between the features of noninvasive signals and the estimation errors is learned using innovative ranking constraints through convex optimization. Patients across multiple clinical settings were randomly split into testing and training datasets for performance evaluation of the mapping function. Results: The results indicate that about 31.88% of testing entries achieved estimation errors within 2 mmHg and 34.07% of testing entries between 2 mmHg to 6 mmHg from the nonlinear mapping with constraints. Conclusion: Our results demonstrate the feasibility of the proposed noninvasive ICP estimation approach. Significance: Further validation and technical refinement are required before clinical deployment, but this work lays the foundation for safe and broadly accessible ICP monitoring in patients with acute brain injury and related conditions.

</details>


### [199] [A Theory of Universal Agnostic Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.20961)
*Steve Hanneke,Shay Moran*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Complete tetrachotomy for universal agnostic rates in binary classification; rates depend on simple combinatorial structures of the concept class; four regimes: e^{-n}, e^{-o(n)}, o(n^{-1/2}), or arbitrarily slow.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Extend the theory from the realizable setting to the agnostic setting with distribution-free optimal rates; identify the structural determinants of rate regimes.

Method: Theoretical analysis of excess error convergence under universal (distribution-free) settings; classify concept classes using combinatorial structures; derive the four-rate dichotomy/ tetrachotomy and map classes to regimes; generalize prior realizable-case results.

Result: Establishes a complete four-way classification (tetrachotomy) of optimal universal convergence rates for excess error in agnostic binary classification and identifies simple combinatorial structures that determine the regime for a given class.

Conclusion: Advances fundamental understanding of learnability limits in agnostic binary classification and provides a structural framework to predict the rate regime for a given concept class, guiding both theory and potential algorithm design.

Abstract: We provide a complete theory of optimal universal rates for binary classification in the agnostic setting. This extends the realizable-case theory of Bousquet, Hanneke, Moran, van Handel, and Yehudayoff (2021) by removing the realizability assumption on the distribution. We identify a fundamental tetrachotomy of optimal rates: for every concept class, the optimal universal rate of convergence of the excess error rate is one of $e^{-n}$, $e^{-o(n)}$, $o(n^{-1/2})$, or arbitrarily slow. We further identify simple combinatorial structures which determine which of these categories any given concept class falls into.

</details>


### [200] [Monotone Optimisation with Learned Projections](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.20983)
*Ahmed Rashwan,Keith Briggs,Chris Budd,Lisa Kreusser*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Learns the projection step of Polyblock Outer Approximation (POA) for monotone optimization via Homogeneous-Monotone Radial Inverse (HM-RI) networks, replacing costly bisection with a learned radial inverse predictor.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: POA-style global solvers require explicit objective/constraint functions, which may be data-driven. The work aims to enable data-driven, fast projection by integrating learned models that respect monotonicity and homogeneity, reducing compute while maintaining feasibility and quality.

Method: Develop HM-RI networks that enforce monotonicity and homogeneity to predict the radial inverse projection; provide a theoretical characterization showing HM-RI corresponds to the radial inverse of a valid monotone constraint set under mild conditions; introduce relaxed monotonicity to ease training; integrate the predictor into POA and evaluate on indefinite quadratic programming, multiplicative programming, and transmit power optimization.

Result: Significant speed-ups over direct function estimation while preserving solution quality; HM-RI-based predictions outperform baselines that do not exploit monotone structure; effective across multiple monotone optimization benchmarks.

Conclusion: Learning-augmented POA with structure-aware projection yields fast, reliable solutions for monotone optimization and illustrates the value of embedding problem structure into neural predictors for optimization subroutines.

Abstract: Monotone optimisation problems admit specialised global solvers such as the Polyblock Outer Approximation (POA) algorithm, but these methods typically require explicit objective and constraint functions. In many applications, these functions are only available through data, making POA difficult to apply directly. We introduce an algorithm-aware learning approach that integrates learned models into POA by directly predicting its projection primitive via the radial inverse, avoiding the costly bisection procedure used in standard POA. We propose Homogeneous-Monotone Radial Inverse (HM-RI) networks, structured neural architectures that enforce key monotonicity and homogeneity properties, enabling fast projection estimation. We provide a theoretical characterisation of radial inverse functions and show that, under mild structural conditions, a HM-RI predictor corresponds to the radial inverse of a valid set of monotone constraints. To reduce training overhead, we further develop relaxed monotonicity conditions that remain compatible with POA. Across multiple monotone optimisation benchmarks (indefinite quadratic programming, multiplicative programming, and transmit power optimisation), our approach yields substantial speed-ups in comparison to direct function estimation while maintaining strong solution quality, outperforming baselines that do not exploit monotonic structure.

</details>


### [201] [Distributional Active Inference](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.20985)
*Abdullah Akgül,Gulcin Baykal,Manuel Haußmann,Mustafa Mert Çelikok,Melih Kandemir*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A formal abstraction unifies model-based, distributional, and model-free RL with active inference, enabling AI to reap active inference's benefits within a distributional RL framework without modeling transition dynamics.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Robotic optimal control suffers from two intertwined challenges: efficient sensory-state organization and long-horizon action planning. RL addresses only planning and tends to be sample-inefficient; active inference explains how brains handle both, but AI usage has been limited to extensions of model-based approaches.

Method: Introduce a formal abstraction of reinforcement learning algorithms that spans model-based, distributional, and model-free paradigms and integrate active inference into the distributional RL framework without requiring explicit transition dynamics modeling.

Result: A theoretical unification that makes active inference advantages accessible within distributional RL, eliminating the need for explicit transition dynamics modeling while covering multiple RL paradigms.

Conclusion: The work provides a principled bridge between active inference and RL, offering a path toward more sample-efficient, long-horizon control in complex environments.

Abstract: Optimal control of complex environments with robotic systems faces two complementary and intertwined challenges: efficient organization of sensory state information and far-sighted action planning. Because the reinforcement learning framework addresses only the latter, it tends to deliver sample-inefficient solutions. Active inference is the state-of-the-art process theory that explains how biological brains handle this dual problem. However, its applications to artificial intelligence have thus far been limited to extensions of existing model-based approaches. We present a formal abstraction of reinforcement learning algorithms that spans model-based, distributional, and model-free approaches. This abstraction seamlessly integrates active inference into the distributional reinforcement learning framework, making its performance advantages accessible without transition dynamics modeling.

</details>


### [202] [Pre-trained Encoders for Global Child Development: Transfer Learning Enables Deployment in Data-Scarce Settings](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.20987)
*Md Muhtasim Munif Fahim,Md Rezaul Karim*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Globally pre-trained encoder for child development enabling few-shot ML in SDG 4.2.1 with diverse UNICEF data; strong cross-country generalization and zero-shot transfer.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the data bottleneck for ML in new countries by providing a general-purpose encoder trained on a large, diverse dataset to improve performance with limited local data.

Method: Train a pre-trained encoder on 357,709 children across 44 countries using UNICEF survey data. Use the encoder in a downstream classifier; evaluate AUC at small (N=50) and moderate (N=500) sample sizes, and in zero-shot deployment to unseen countries. Compare to cold-start gradient boosting and apply a transfer-learning bound to explain diversity-driven generalization.

Result: With N=50, AUC=0.65 (95% CI: 0.56–0.72); gradient boosting AUC=0.61 (8–12% advantage for the encoder). With N=500, AUC=0.73. Zero-shot AUCs up to 0.84 in unseen countries.

Conclusion: Pre-trained encoders enable feasible ML-based SDG 4.2.1 monitoring in resource-constrained settings; diverse training data underpins strong few-shot generalization, supported by a transfer-learning bound.

Abstract: A large number of children experience preventable developmental delays each year, yet the deployment of machine learning in new countries has been stymied by a data bottleneck: reliable models require thousands of samples, while new programs begin with fewer than 100. We introduce the first pre-trained encoder for global child development, trained on 357,709 children across 44 countries using UNICEF survey data. With only 50 training samples, the pre-trained encoder achieves an average AUC of 0.65 (95% CI: 0.56-0.72), outperforming cold-start gradient boosting at 0.61 by 8-12% across regions. At N=500, the encoder achieves an AUC of 0.73. Zero-shot deployment to unseen countries achieves AUCs up to 0.84. We apply a transfer learning bound to explain why pre-training diversity enables few-shot generalization. These results establish that pre-trained encoders can transform the feasibility of ML for SDG 4.2.1 monitoring in resource-constrained settings.

</details>


### [203] [Top-k on a Budget: Adaptive Ranking with Weak and Strong Oracles](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.20989)
*Lutz Oettershagen*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Two-oracle top-k identification framework leveraging a fast noisy weak oracle with confidence intervals and a costly strong oracle. Introduces ACE and ACE-W adaptive certification strategies that concentrate high-fidelity queries on boundary items, achieving near-optimal strong-query bounds tied to near-tie mass m(·) around the top-k threshold under weak uncertainty ε_max.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Exact valuations are expensive; reduce reliance on a costly strong oracle by exploiting a fast, noisy weak oracle with confidence intervals. Establish baseline STC bounds, derive lower bound, and develop adaptive algorithms (ACE, ACE-W) to minimize high-fidelity queries while preserving accuracy.

Method: 1) Screen-then-certify (STC) baseline analyzed under jointly valid weak confidence intervals with radius ε_max; bound on strong calls: ≤ m(4ε_max). 2) Prove a conditional Ω(m(ε_max)) lower bound for any algorithm with same weak uncertainty. 3) ACE: adaptive certification focusing strong queries on boundary items, attaining the same asymptotic bound with practical reductions in strong calls. 4) ACE-W: fully adaptive two-phase method allocating weak budget adaptively before ACE to further reduce strong costs.

Result: Upper bound: STC uses at most m(4ε_max) strong calls. Lower bound: any algorithm has Ω(m(ε_max)) strong calls under the same weak uncertainty. ACE achieves the same O(m(4ε_max)) bound but with fewer strong calls in practice. ACE-W further reduces strong costs by adaptively allocating the weak budget prior to ACE.

Conclusion: Adaptive certification strategies (ACE, ACE-W) nearly match the information-theoretic lower bound for strong-query complexity under a fixed weak uncertainty model, efficiently trading weak versus strong oracle usage by concentrating high-fidelity queries on boundary items and optimally allocating weak budget. This framework is practically beneficial for top-k identification when exact valuations are expensive.

Abstract: Identifying the top-$k$ items is fundamental but often prohibitive when exact valuations are expensive. We study a two-oracle setting with a fast, noisy weak oracle and a scarce, high-fidelity strong oracle (e.g., human expert verification or expensive simulation). We first analyze a simple screen-then-certify baseline (STC) and prove it makes at most $m(4\varepsilon_{\max})$ strong calls given jointly valid weak confidence intervals with maximum radius $\varepsilon_{\max}$, where $m(\cdot)$ denotes the near-tie mass around the top-$k$ threshold. We establish a conditional lower bound of $Ω(m(\varepsilon_{\max}))$ for any algorithm given the same weak uncertainty. Our main contribution is ACE, an adaptive certification algorithm that focuses strong queries on critical boundary items, achieving the same $O(m(4\varepsilon_{\max}))$ bound while reducing strong calls in practice. We then introduce ACE-W, a fully adaptive two-phase method that allocates weak budget adaptively before running ACE, further reducing strong costs.

</details>


### [204] [The Depth Delusion: Why Transformers Should Be Wider, Not Deeper](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.20994)
*Md Muhtasim Munif Fahim,Md Rezaul Karim*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Architecture-conditioned scaling laws reveal that optimal depth and width scale differently with compute: D* ~ C^0.12 and W* ~ C^0.34, meaning width grows ~2.8x faster than depth; a critical depth D_crit ~ W^0.44 exists beyond which deeper models can worsen loss (Depth Delusion). Empirically validated across 30 transformers (17M–7B params) with R^2 = 0.922; at 7B scale, a 64-layer model underperforms a 32-layer model by 0.12 nats, confirming nontrivial depth-width tradeoffs at production scale.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Neural scaling laws assume architecture is interchangeable; this work asks how depth and width interact with data and parameters to shape loss, and whether there exist architecture-aware scaling laws that predict optimal configurations.

Method: Propose architecture-conditioned scaling laws and fit them to empirical data. Derive optimal depth D* ~ C^0.12 and width W* ~ C^0.34; identify a critical depth D_crit ~ W^0.44 where additional layers increase loss; validate across 30 transformer architectures (17M–7B params) trained on representative high-compute samples; report fit quality (R^2).

Result: Width grows 2.8x faster than depth; existence of Depth Delusion where beyond D_crit adding layers raises loss; high predictive accuracy with R^2 = 0.922 across architectures; at 7B scale, 64-layer model (6.38B params) underperforms 32-layer model (6.86B params) by 0.12 nats, illustrating persistent depth-width tradeoffs at production scale.

Conclusion: Architecture-aware scaling laws are necessary; optimal depth-width configurations depend on compute and data; blindly stacking depth can harm performance beyond a critical point; results provide practical design guidance for scaling transformers.

Abstract: Neural scaling laws describe how language model loss decreases with parameters and data, but treat architecture as interchangeable--a billion parameters could arise from a shallow-wide model (10 layers & 8,192 hidden dimension) or a deep-narrow one (80 layers & 2,048 hidden dimension). We propose architecture-conditioned scaling laws decomposing this dependence, finding that optimal depth scales as D* ~ C^0.12 while optimal width scales as W* ~ C^0.34, meaning width should grow 2.8x faster than depth. We discover a critical depth phenomenon: beyond D_crit ~ W^0.44 (sublinear in W), adding layers increases loss despite adding parameters--the Depth Delusion. Empirically, we validate these findings across 30 transformer architectures spanning 17M to 7B parameters, each trained on representative high-compute samples, achieving R^2 = 0.922. Our central finding: at 7B scale, a 64-layer model (6.38B params) underperforms a 32-layer model (6.86B params) by 0.12 nats, despite being significantly deeper. This demonstrates that optimal depth-width tradeoffs persist at the production scale.

</details>


### [205] [MADE: Benchmark Environments for Closed-Loop Materials Discovery](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.20996)
*Shreshth A Malik,Tiarnan Doherty,Panagiotis Tigas,Muhammed Razzak,Stephen J. Roberts,Aron Walsh,Yarin Gal*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: MADE introduces end-to-end, budget-constrained benchmarking of autonomous materials discovery pipelines via closed-loop simulations, enabling ablations and scaling analyses.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing benchmarks focus on static predictive tasks and sub-tasks, neglecting the iterative, adaptive, resource-limited nature of real discovery workflows; there is a need for standardized, end-to-end evaluation of autonomous materials discovery pipelines.

Method: Define MAD E as a simulation framework where an agent proposes candidates, evaluates them via a constrained oracle, and refines decisions to search for thermodynamically stable compounds relative to a convex hull. The framework uses a modular architecture with interchangeable components (generative models, filters, planners), enabling workflows from fixed pipelines to fully agentic systems with tool use. Evaluation compares efficacy and efficiency against baselines, and supports ablations and scalability studies across families of systems.

Result: Feasibility demonstrated through systematic experiments across multiple system families. Ablation studies reveal the contributions of individual components, and scaling analyses illustrate how methods perform as system complexity grows, enabling comparative benchmarking.

Conclusion: MADE provides a flexible, reusable benchmark for end-to-end, adaptive materials discovery pipelines, supporting component-wise analysis, ablation studies, and scalability assessments, and promoting reproducible evaluation of autonomous discovery workflows.

Abstract: Existing benchmarks for computational materials discovery primarily evaluate static predictive tasks or isolated computational sub-tasks. While valuable, these evaluations neglect the inherently iterative and adaptive nature of scientific discovery. We introduce MAterials Discovery Environments (MADE), a novel framework for benchmarking end-to-end autonomous materials discovery pipelines. MADE simulates closed-loop discovery campaigns in which an agent or algorithm proposes, evaluates, and refines candidate materials under a constrained oracle budget, capturing the sequential and resource-limited nature of real discovery workflows. We formalize discovery as a search for thermodynamically stable compounds relative to a given convex hull, and evaluate efficacy and efficiency via comparison to baseline algorithms. The framework is flexible; users can compose discovery agents from interchangeable components such as generative models, filters, and planners, enabling the study of arbitrary workflows ranging from fixed pipelines to fully agentic systems with tool use and adaptive decision making. We demonstrate this by conducting systematic experiments across a family of systems, enabling ablation of components in discovery pipelines, and comparison of how methods scale with system complexity.

</details>


### [206] [Solver-in-the-Loop: MDP-Based Benchmarks for Self-Correction and Behavioral Rationality in Operations Research](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21008)
*Ruicheng Ao,David Simchi-Levi,Xinshang Wang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Benchmarks place the solver in the evaluation loop for IR/OR problems, enabling verifiable feedback and iterative repair; domain-specific RLVR training improves performance beyond frontier APIs; curriculum training reduces ID→OOD bias.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Traditional OR/LLM benchmarks treat problem solving as one-shot translation and ignore the diagnostic loop of debugging infeasible models. There is a need for process-aware evaluation with verifiable feedback to train models to perform iterative repair.

Method: Introduce ORDebug (5k+ problems, 9 error types; iterative repairs trigger solver re-run and IIS recomputation) and ORBias (2k newsvendor instances, 1k ID/1k OOD; measure deviation from closed-form policies). Evaluate 26 models on 12k+ samples; train with domain-specific RLVR; apply curriculum training for bias mitigation.

Result: Domain-specific RLVR improves an 8B model to 95.3% recovery vs 86.2% (gain 9.1%), 62.4% diagnostic accuracy vs 47.8% (gain 14.6%), and 2.25x fewer steps to resolution (1.7× faster). ORBias shows curriculum reduces ID→OOD bias drift by 9.6% and halves systematic bias from 20.0% to 10.4% (48% reduction).

Conclusion: Process-level evaluation with verifiable oracles enables targeted training that outperforms scaling alone, illustrating the value of iterative, feedback-driven benchmarks for OR-LMM collaboration.

Abstract: Operations Research practitioners routinely debug infeasible models through an iterative process: analyzing Irreducible Infeasible Subsystems (\IIS{}), identifying constraint conflicts, and systematically repairing formulations until feasibility is achieved. Yet existing LLM benchmarks evaluate OR as one-shot translation -- given a problem description, generate solver code -- ignoring this diagnostic loop entirely. We introduce two benchmarks that place the \textbf{solver in the evaluation loop}. \textbf{\ORDebug{}} evaluates iterative self-correction through 5,000+ problems spanning 9 error types; each repair action triggers solver re-execution and \IIS{} recomputation, providing deterministic, verifiable feedback. \textbf{\ORBias{}} evaluates behavioral rationality through 2,000 newsvendor instances (1,000 ID + 1,000 OOD), measuring systematic deviations from closed-form optimal policies. Across 26 models and 12,000+ samples, we find that domain-specific RLVR training enables an 8B model to surpass frontier APIs: 95.3\% vs 86.2\% recovery rate (+9.1\%), 62.4\% vs 47.8\% diagnostic accuracy (+14.6\%), and 2.25 vs 3.78 steps to resolution (1.7$\times$ faster). On \ORBias{}, curriculum training achieves the only negative ID$\rightarrow$OOD bias drift among models evaluated (-9.6\%), reducing systematic bias by 48\% (from 20.0\% to 10.4\%). These results demonstrate that process-level evaluation with verifiable oracles enables targeted training that outperforms scale.

</details>


### [207] [Order-Aware Test-Time Adaptation: Leveraging Temporal Dynamics for Robust Streaming Inference](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21012)
*Young Kyung Kim,Oded Schlesinger,Qiangqiang Wu,J. Matías Di Martino,Guillermo Sapiro*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: OATTA introduces a gradient-free recursive Bayesian test-time adaptation using a learned temporal transition prior and a likelihood-ratio gate to exploit temporal dynamics in streaming inputs, yielding consistent accuracy gains (up to 6.35%) across diverse modalities while remaining lightweight and model-agnostic.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current TTA methods treat test-time streams as independent samples, neglecting supervisory signals from temporal structure. Exploiting temporal dynamics can provide complementary information for adaptation under distribution shift.

Method: Formulate TTA as a gradient-free recursive Bayesian estimation task. Use a learned dynamic transition matrix as a temporal prior to refine predictions. Introduce a likelihood-ratio gate (LLR) to revert to the base predictor when temporal evidence is weak or absent, ensuring safety in weakly structured streams. The module is lightweight and model-agnostic.

Result: Empirical evaluation across image classification, wearable/physiological signals, and language sentiment analysis shows universal applicability and consistent improvement over baselines, with accuracy gains up to 6.35%.

Conclusion: Modeling temporal dynamics provides a distinct, orthogonal signal to traditional order-agnostic TTA, and OATTA offers a low-overhead, plug-in module that enhances pre-trained models without significant computational cost.

Abstract: Test-Time Adaptation (TTA) enables pre-trained models to adjust to distribution shift by learning from unlabeled test-time streams. However, existing methods typically treat these streams as independent samples, overlooking the supervisory signal inherent in temporal dynamics. To address this, we introduce Order-Aware Test-Time Adaptation (OATTA). We formulate test-time adaptation as a gradient-free recursive Bayesian estimation task, using a learned dynamic transition matrix as a temporal prior to refine the base model's predictions. To ensure safety in weakly structured streams, we introduce a likelihood-ratio gate (LLR) that reverts to the base predictor when temporal evidence is absent. OATTA is a lightweight, model-agnostic module that incurs negligible computational overhead. Extensive experiments across image classification, wearable and physiological signal analysis, and language sentiment analysis demonstrate its universality; OATTA consistently boosts established baselines, improving accuracy by up to 6.35%. Our findings establish that modeling temporal dynamics provides a critical, orthogonal signal beyond standard order-agnostic TTA approaches.

</details>


### [208] [Conditional Denoising Model as a Physical Surrogate Model](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21021)
*José Afonso,Pedro Viegas,Rodrigo Ventura,Vasco Guerra*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces the Conditional Denoising Model (CDM) to learn the geometry of the physical solution manifold via denoising; uses a time-independent fixed-point inference to project noisy states onto the equilibrium manifold; achieves higher data and parameter efficiency than physics-consistent baselines and acts as a strong implicit regularizer without using governing equations during training.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Surrogate modeling often trades data-fitting accuracy against physical consistency. Soft physics losses may fail to strictly enforce governing equations, and post-hoc corrections do not learn the underlying geometry. There is a need for a method that intrinsically learns the solution manifold and projects estimations onto it.

Method: CDM trains a conditional denoising network that restores clean states from noisy ones, thereby learning a vector field pointing toward the valid solution subspace. A time-independent formulation converts inference into a deterministic fixed-point iteration, effectively projecting noisy approximations onto the equilibrium manifold. The model is trained with a denoising objective and does not rely on explicit governing equations during training.

Result: Validated on a low-temperature plasma physics and chemistry benchmark, CDM achieves higher parameter and data efficiency than physics-consistent baselines.

Conclusion: The denoising objective acts as a powerful implicit regularizer. Even without exposure to the governing equations during training, the model adheres to physical constraints more strictly than baselines trained with explicit physics losses, offering a robust geometry-learning approach for physics-consistent surrogate modeling.

Abstract: Surrogate modeling for complex physical systems typically faces a trade-off between data-fitting accuracy and physical consistency. Physics-consistent approaches typically treat physical laws as soft constraints within the loss function, a strategy that frequently fails to guarantee strict adherence to the governing equations, or rely on post-processing corrections that do not intrinsically learn the underlying solution geometry. To address these limitations, we introduce the {Conditional Denoising Model (CDM)}, a generative model designed to learn the geometry of the physical manifold itself. By training the network to restore clean states from noisy ones, the model learns a vector field that points continuously towards the valid solution subspace. We introduce a time-independent formulation that transforms inference into a deterministic fixed-point iteration, effectively projecting noisy approximations onto the equilibrium manifold. Validated on a low-temperature plasma physics and chemistry benchmark, the CDM achieves higher parameter and data efficiency than physics-consistent baselines. Crucially, we demonstrate that the denoising objective acts as a powerful implicit regularizer: despite never seeing the governing equations during training, the model adheres to physical constraints more strictly than baselines trained with explicit physics losses.

</details>


### [209] [SIGMA-PPG: Statistical-prior Informed Generative Masking Architecture for PPG Foundation Model](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21031)
*Zongheng Guo,Tao Chen,Yang Jiao,Yi Pan,Xiao Hu,Manuela Ferrario*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A generative, priors-informed masked model for PPG (SIGMA-PPG) that uses prior-guided adversarial masking and vector-quantized semantic consistency to improve robustness and downstream performance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: PPG signals are inherently redundant and noisy; standard masked models yield trivial solutions; contrastive methods lack morphological precision. A model that incorporates statistical priors and preserves physiologic waveform structure is needed.

Method: SIGMA-PPG introduces a Prior-Guided Adversarial Masking mechanism driven by a reinforcement-learning-based teacher that uses statistical priors to craft challenging learning paths and avoid overfitting to noise. It also enforces semantic consistency via vector quantization so physiologically identical waveforms map to shared codebook indices, increasing semantic density and reducing redundant features.

Result: Pre-trained on over 120,000 hours of data; achieves superior average performance relative to five state-of-the-art baselines across 12 diverse downstream tasks.

Conclusion: SIGMA-PPG demonstrates stronger, more robust representations for PPG across diverse tasks, due to priors-informed masking and semantic codebook constraints; code is available on GitHub.

Abstract: Current foundation model for photoplethysmography (PPG) signals is challenged by the intrinsic redundancy and noise of the signal. Standard masked modeling often yields trivial solutions while contrastive methods lack morphological precision. To address these limitations, we propose a Statistical-prior Informed Generative Masking Architecture (SIGMA-PPG), a generative foundation model featuring a Prior-Guided Adversarial Masking mechanism, where a reinforcement learning-driven teacher leverages statistical priors to create challenging learning paths that prevent overfitting to noise. We also incorporate a semantic consistency constraint via vector quantization to ensure that physiologically identical waveforms (even those altered by recording artifacts or minor perturbations) map to shared indices. This enhances codebook semantic density and eliminates redundant feature structures. Pre-trained on over 120,000 hours of data, SIGMA-PPG achieves superior average performance compared to five state-of-the-art baselines across 12 diverse downstream tasks. The code is available at https://github.com/ZonghengGuo/SigmaPPG.

</details>


### [210] [Predict-Project-Renoise: Sampling Diffusion Models under Hard Constraints](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21033)
*Omer Rochman-Sharabi,Gilles Louppe*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Constrained diffusion sampling with Predict-Project-Renoise (PPR) enforces hard constraints during generation, improving physical fidelity.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Diffusion-based neural emulators may violate physical laws or observational constraints; a sampling-time mechanism to guarantee constraint satisfaction is needed for scientific applications.

Method: Define a constrained forward diffusion that only diffuses within the feasible constraint set, producing constrained marginals. Introduce Predict-Project-Renoise (PPR): an iterative sampler that denoises, projects onto the feasible set, and renois es to sample from constrained marginals.

Result: PPR reduces constraint violations by >10x across 2D distributions, PDEs, and global weather forecasting, improves sample consistency, and better matches the true constrained distribution versus baselines.

Conclusion: A principled framework for hard-constraint enforcement in diffusion-based emulators, with PPR showing strong cross-domain effectiveness.

Abstract: Neural emulators based on diffusion models show promise for scientific applications, but vanilla models cannot guarantee physical accuracy or constraint satisfaction. We address this by introducing a constrained sampling framework that enforces hard constraints, such as physical laws or observational consistency, at generation time. Our approach defines a constrained forward process that diffuses only over the feasible set of constraint-satisfying samples, inducing constrained marginal distributions. To reverse this, we propose Predict-Project-Renoise (PPR), an iterative algorithm that samples from the constrained marginals by alternating between denoising predictions, projecting onto the feasible set, and renoising. Experiments on 2D distributions, PDEs, and global weather forecasting demonstrate that PPR reduces constraint violations by over an order of magnitude while improving sample consistency and better matching the true constrained distribution compared to baselines.

</details>


### [211] [Thinking in Frames: How Visual Context and Test-Time Scaling Empower Video Reasoning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21037)
*Chengzu Li,Zanyi Wang,Jiaang Li,Yi Xu,Han Zhou,Huanyu Zhang,Ruichuan An,Dengyang Jiang,Zhaochong An,Ivan Vulić,Serge Belongie,Anna Korhonen*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Video-generation-based visual reasoning uses intermediate frames as reasoning steps, enabling strong zero-shot generalization in Maze Navigation and Tangram puzzles; visual context acts as explicit control, and longer generated videos at test time improve spatial-temporal planning in unseen scenarios.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address limitations of vision-language models in fine-grained spatial understanding and planning by introducing an intermediate, controllable visual representation (video frames) that can bridge initial and solved states.

Method: Formulate visual reasoning as a video-generation process that outputs intermediate frames between the initial state and the solution. Evaluate in two regimes: (i) Maze Navigation (sequential discrete planning with low visual change) and (ii) Tangram Puzzle (continuous manipulation with high visual change). Assess zero-shot generalization, use of visual context for control, and test-time video-length scaling.

Result: Three key findings: (1) Robust zero-shot generalization across unseen data without task-specific fine-tuning; (2) Visual context (icons/shapes) provides explicit control, maintaining visual consistency and robust planning; (3) Visual test-time scaling; longer generated videos improve zero-shot generalization to complex spatial-temporal paths.

Conclusion: Video generation is a scalable, generalizable paradigm for visual reasoning, not merely a media tool, capable of supporting planning in spatial-temporal tasks through intermediate reasoning frames.

Abstract: Vision-Language Models have excelled at textual reasoning, but they often struggle with fine-grained spatial understanding and continuous action planning, failing to simulate the dynamics required for complex visual reasoning. In this work, we formulate visual reasoning by means of video generation models, positing that generated frames can act as intermediate reasoning steps between initial states and solutions. We evaluate their capacity in two distinct regimes: Maze Navigation for sequential discrete planning with low visual change and Tangram Puzzle for continuous manipulation with high visual change. Our experiments reveal three critical insights: (1) Robust Zero-Shot Generalization: In both tasks, the model demonstrates strong performance on unseen data distributions without specific finetuning. (2) Visual Context: The model effectively uses visual context as explicit control, such as agent icons and tangram shapes, enabling it to maintain high visual consistency and adapt its planning capability robustly to unseen patterns. (3) Visual Test-Time Scaling: We observe a test-time scaling law in sequential planning; increasing the generated video length (visual inference budget) empowers better zero-shot generalization to spatially and temporally complex paths. These findings suggest that video generation is not merely a media tool, but a scalable, generalizable paradigm for visual reasoning.

</details>


### [212] [Test-Time Adaptation for Unsupervised Combinatorial Optimization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21048)
*Yiqiao Liao,Farinaz Koushanfar,Parinaz Naghizadeh*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes TACO, a model-agnostic test-time adaptation framework for unsupervised NCO that warm-starts partially relaxed trained parameters to blend generalization and instance-specific optimization, achieving better solutions with minimal cost on MVC and Max Clique.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Bridge the gap between generalization-based solvers and instance-specific optimization in unsupervised neural combinatorial optimization (NCO); generalization models offer inductive bias but poor warm starts, while instance-specific models adapt well but miss learned structure and risk poor optima.

Method: TACO applies strategic warm-starting by partially relaxing trained parameters while preserving inductive bias, enabling rapid and effective unsupervised adaptation at test time. It is model-agnostic and can be applied to existing generalizable NCO solvers.

Result: Outperforms naïve fine-tuning of a trained generalizable model and from-scratch instance-specific optimization; achieves better solution quality with negligible additional computational cost. Demonstrated on canonical CO problems (Minimum Vertex Cover and Maximum Clique) with robustness across static, distribution-shifted, and dynamic CO scenarios.

Conclusion: TACO provides a practical bridge between generalizable and instance-specific unsupervised NCO, delivering effective adaptation with low overhead and strong empirical performance across varied problem settings.

Abstract: Unsupervised neural combinatorial optimization (NCO) enables learning powerful solvers without access to ground-truth solutions. Existing approaches fall into two disjoint paradigms: models trained for generalization across instances, and instance-specific models optimized independently at test time. While the former are efficient during inference, they lack effective instance-wise adaptability; the latter are flexible but fail to exploit learned inductive structure and are prone to poor local optima. This motivates the central question of our work: how can we leverage the inductive bias learned through generalization while unlocking the flexibility required for effective instance-wise adaptation? We first identify a challenge in bridging these two paradigms: generalization-focused models often constitute poor warm starts for instance-wise optimization, potentially underperforming even randomly initialized models when fine-tuned at test time. To resolve this incompatibility, we propose TACO, a model-agnostic test-time adaptation framework that unifies and extends the two existing paradigms for unsupervised NCO. TACO applies strategic warm-starting to partially relax trained parameters while preserving inductive bias, enabling rapid and effective unsupervised adaptation. Crucially, compared to naively fine-tuning a trained generalizable model or optimizing an instance-specific model from scratch, TACO achieves better solution quality while incurring negligible additional computational cost. Experiments on canonical CO problems, Minimum Vertex Cover and Maximum Clique, demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of TACO across static, distribution-shifted, and dynamic combinatorial optimization problems, establishing it as a practical bridge between generalizable and instance-specific unsupervised NCO.

</details>


### [213] [Snowball: A Scalable All-to-All Ising Machine with Dual-Mode Markov Chain Monte Carlo Spin Selection and Asynchronous Spin Updates for Fast Combinatorial Optimization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21058)
*Seungki Hong,Kyeongwon Jeong,Taekwang Jang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Snowball is a digital, scalable Ising machine with all-to-all couplings that uses dual-mode MCMC spin selection and asynchronous updates to speed up convergence; achieves 8x time-to-solution improvement on FPGA-based benchmark relative to a state-of-the-art Ising machine.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To overcome three practical bottlenecks in Ising machines: restrictive hardware topologies requiring embedding, destabilizing naive parallel spin updates, and limited coupling precision that hinders mappings and solution quality.

Method: Design and implement Snowball: a fully digital, all-to-all coupled Ising machine with dual-mode MCMC spin selection (two probabilistic update modes) and asynchronous spin updates. Supports wide, configurable coupling precision. Implemented on an AMD Alveo U250 accelerator card for acceleration.

Result: Prototype demonstrates an 8× reduction in time-to-solution compared to a state-of-the-art Ising machine on the same benchmark instance.

Conclusion: Digital, scalable, all-to-all Ising machines with advanced spin-selection and asynchronous updates can achieve substantial time-to-solution improvements, thanks to greater precision and better convergence. The approach shows promise for practical deployment in combinatorial optimization tasks.

Abstract: Ising machines have emerged as accelerators for combinatorial optimization. To enable practical deployment, this work aims to reduce time-to-solution by addressing three challenges: (1) hardware topology, (2) spin selection and update algorithms, and (3) scalable coupling-coefficient precision. Restricted topologies require minor embedding; naive parallel updates can oscillate or stall; and limited precision can preclude feasible mappings or degrade solution quality.
  This work presents Snowball, a digital, scalable, all-to-all coupled Ising machine that integrates dual-mode Markov chain Monte Carlo spin selection with asynchronous spin updates to promote convergence and reduce time-to-solution. The digital architecture supports wide, configurable coupling precision, unlike many analog realizations at high bit widths. A prototype on an AMD Alveo U250 accelerator card achieves an 8$\times$ reduction in time-to-solution relative to a state-of-the-art Ising machine on the same benchmark instance.

</details>


### [214] [Human-LLM Collaborative Feature Engineering for Tabular Data](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21060)
*Zhuoyan Li,Aditya Bansal,Jinzhao Li,Shishuang He,Zhuoran Lu,Mutian Zhang,Qin Liu,Yiwei Yang,Swati Jain,Ming Yin,Yunyao Li*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Decoupled, human-in-the-loop framework where LLMs propose feature transformations and an explicit utility/uncertainty model guides selection, augmented by selective human feedback; improves performance and reduces cognitive load in tabular feature engineering.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: LLMs have been used as black-box optimizers for feature engineering, but their operation-utility estimates are poorly calibrated, causing wasted exploration. Introducing a principled selection mechanism and human-in-the-loop feedback aims to improve efficiency and effectiveness.

Method: Two-stage process: (1) LLMs generate a diverse set of candidate feature transformation operations; (2) a utility/uncertainty model evaluates and selects among candidates for implementation; (3) selectively incorporate human expert preferences to refine selection, especially in early rounds; experimental evaluation on synthetic and real user studies across tabular datasets.

Result: Demonstrates improved feature engineering performance across various tabular datasets and reduces users’ cognitive load during the feature engineering process.

Conclusion: Decoupling proposal from selection and incorporating human preferences within a calibrated utility framework yields more effective feature transformations and more efficient human-LLM collaboration in tabular learning.

Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly used to automate feature engineering in tabular learning. Given task-specific information, LLMs can propose diverse feature transformation operations to enhance downstream model performance. However, current approaches typically assign the LLM as a black-box optimizer, responsible for both proposing and selecting operations based solely on its internal heuristics, which often lack calibrated estimations of operation utility and consequently lead to repeated exploration of low-yield operations without a principled strategy for prioritizing promising directions. In this paper, we propose a human-LLM collaborative feature engineering framework for tabular learning. We begin by decoupling the transformation operation proposal and selection processes, where LLMs are used solely to generate operation candidates, while the selection is guided by explicitly modeling the utility and uncertainty of each proposed operation. Since accurate utility estimation can be difficult especially in the early rounds of feature engineering, we design a mechanism within the framework that selectively elicits and incorporates human expert preference feedback, comparing which operations are more promising, into the selection process to help identify more effective operations. Our evaluations on both the synthetic study and the real user study demonstrate that the proposed framework improves feature engineering performance across a variety of tabular datasets and reduces users' cognitive load during the feature engineering process.

</details>


### [215] [Signal from Structure: Exploiting Submodular Upper Bounds in Generative Flow Networks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21061)
*Alexandre Larouche,Audrey Durand*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: SUBo-GFN introduces submodular upper bounds to train Generative Flow Networks (GFlowNets), enabling much higher data efficiency by generating training samples for unseen compositional objects. It leverages optimism in uncertainty to bound rewards and demonstrates improved distribution matching and high-quality candidate generation on synthetic and real submodular tasks.


<details>
