  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To improve data efficiency and coverage of the reward landscape in GFlowNets when rewards exhibit submodular structure, enabling better exploration of the compositional space.

Method: Derive submodular upper bounds on unseen compositions and use them within an Optimism in the Face of Uncertainty framework to train a GFlowNet (SUBo-GFN). Analyze bounds’ probability and coverage, and empirically validate on synthetic and real submodular tasks, comparing data efficiency and sample quality against classical GFNs.

Result: SUBo-GFN achieves orders of magnitude more training data than classical GFNs for the same reward-query budget, with strong distribution matching and high-quality candidate generation on both synthetic and real submodular tasks.

Conclusion: Exploiting submodular structure via upper bounds and optimistic learning substantially improves GFlowNet data efficiency and performance for submodular objectives.

Abstract: Generative Flow Networks (GFlowNets; GFNs) are a class of generative models that learn to sample compositional objects proportionally to their a priori unknown value, their reward. We focus on the case where the reward has a specified, actionable structure, namely that it is submodular. We show submodularity can be harnessed to retrieve upper bounds on the reward of compositional objects that have not yet been observed. We provide in-depth analyses of the probability of such bounds occurring, as well as how many unobserved compositional objects can be covered by a bound. Following the Optimism in the Face of Uncertainty principle, we then introduce SUBo-GFN, which uses the submodular upper bounds to train a GFN. We show that SUBo-GFN generates orders of magnitude more training data than classical GFNs for the same number of queries to the reward function. We demonstrate the effectiveness of SUBo-GFN in terms of distribution matching and high-quality candidate generation on synthetic and real-world submodular tasks.

</details>


### [216] [Textual Equilibrium Propagation for Deep Compound AI Systems](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21064)
*Minghui Chen,Wenlong Deng,James Zou,Han Yu,Xiaoxiao Li*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: TEP (Textual Equilibrium Propagation) introduces a local learning paradigm for long-horizon LLM-based pipelines to avoid exploding/vanishing gradients from global text feedback. It uses a two-phase process (free phase with local critics reaching equilibrium, and nudged phase with bounded prompt edits) to align local prompt optimization with global goals, improving accuracy and efficiency as system depth increases.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Global textual backpropagation methods suffer depth-scaling issues: textual gradients explode or vanish as the pipeline depth grows, making optimization inefficient and error-prone.

Method: TEP employs a two-phase local learning scheme. In the free phase, local LLM critics iteratively refine prompts to equilibrium. In the nudged phase, proximal prompt edits are applied with bounded intensity, using forward signaling of task-level objectives rather than backward gradient chains. This enables local optimization followed by controlled adaptation toward global goals without backpropagation through the entire pipeline.

Result: Empirically, TEP improves accuracy and efficiency over global propagation methods (e.g., TextGrad) on long-horizon QA benchmarks and multi-agent tool-use datasets, with gains that grow with depth while preserving black-box LLM practicality.

Conclusion: TEP provides a scalable, depth-friendly alternative to global textual backpropagation, mitigating gradient-related issues and reducing computation, thereby enabling deeper, more capable compound AI systems.

Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly deployed as part of compound AI systems that coordinate multiple modules (e.g., retrievers, tools, verifiers) over long-horizon workflows. Recent approaches that propagate textual feedback globally (e.g., TextGrad) make it feasible to optimize such pipelines, but we find that performance degrades as system depth grows. In particular, long-horizon agentic workflows exhibit two depth-scaling failure modes: 1) exploding textual gradient, where textual feedback grows exponentially with depth, leading to prohibitively long message and amplifies evaluation biases; and 2) vanishing textual gradient, where limited long-context ability causes models overemphasize partial feedback and compression of lengthy feedback causes downstream messages to lose specificity gradually as they propagate many hops upstream. To mitigate these issues, we introduce Textual Equilibrium Propagation (TEP), a local learning principle inspired by Equilibrium Propagation in energy-based models. TEP includes two phases: 1) a free phase where a local LLM critics iteratively refine prompts until reaching equilibrium (no further improvements are suggested); and 2) a nudged phase which applies proximal prompt edits with bounded modification intensity, using task-level objectives that propagate via forward signaling rather than backward feedback chains. This design supports local prompt optimization followed by controlled adaptation toward global goals without the computational burden and signal degradation of global textual backpropagation. Across long-horizon QA benchmarks and multi-agent tool-use dataset, TEP consistently improves accuracy and efficiency over global propagation methods such as TextGrad. The gains grows with depth, while preserving the practicality of black-box LLM components in deep compound AI system.

</details>


### [217] [Out-of-Distribution Generalization in Graph Foundation Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21067)
*Haoyang Li,Haibo Chen,Xin Wang,Wenwu Zhu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A survey on OOD generalization in Graph Foundation Models (GFMs), organizing approaches by fixed-task vs heterogeneous-task generalization, and outlining evaluation protocols and future directions.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Graphs are central to many domains, but graph learning models struggle to generalize under distribution shifts caused by changes in structure, semantics, modalities, or task formulations. GFMs trained on diverse graphs aim to provide robust, general representations.

Method: Review and synthesize recent GFMs literature with a unified OOD problem setting, categorize methods by their support for fixed-task and cross-task generalization, summarize OOD handling strategies and pretraining objectives, and discuss evaluation protocols and future directions.

Result: The paper claims to be the first survey specifically addressing OOD generalization in GFMs, consolidating current approaches and their OOD handling strategies and pretraining objectives.

Conclusion: Provides a structured overview of challenges, taxonomies of methods, evaluation practices, and open research directions for fostering OOD robustness in GFMs.

Abstract: Graphs are a fundamental data structure for representing relational information in domains such as social networks, molecular systems, and knowledge graphs. However, graph learning models often suffer from limited generalization when applied beyond their training distributions. In practice, distribution shifts may arise from changes in graph structure, domain semantics, available modalities, or task formulations. To address these challenges, graph foundation models (GFMs) have recently emerged, aiming to learn general-purpose representations through large-scale pretraining across diverse graphs and tasks. In this survey, we review recent progress on GFMs from the perspective of out-of-distribution (OOD) generalization. We first discuss the main challenges posed by distribution shifts in graph learning and outline a unified problem setting. We then organize existing approaches based on whether they are designed to operate under a fixed task specification or to support generalization across heterogeneous task formulations, and summarize the corresponding OOD handling strategies and pretraining objectives. Finally, we review common evaluation protocols and discuss open directions for future research. To the best of our knowledge, this paper is the first survey for OOD generalization in GFMs.

</details>


### [218] [LOCUS: Low-Dimensional Model Embeddings for Efficient Model Exploration, Comparison, and Selection](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21082)
*Shivam Patel,William Cocke,Gauri Joshi*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: LOCUS creates low-dimensional, geometry-aware embeddings of LLMs by an attention-based forward pass over query encodings and evaluation scores, enabling new model onboarding and robust routing without retraining.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Manage and harness a large, dynamic pool of LLMs by compactly representing each model’s capabilities so that routing, comparison, and selection can occur efficiently and without retraining.

Method: An attention-based encoder generates deterministic embeddings from query encodings and per-model evaluation scores; a correctness predictor uses embeddings plus query encodings to improve routing on unseen queries; no retraining of models is required when adding new models to the pool.

Result:  LOCUS achieves up to 4.8x fewer query evaluations to produce informative embeddings; the embedding space is geometrically meaningful with proximity reflecting model similarity, enabling clustering, model comparison, portfolio selection, and proxies for unavailable models.

Conclusion: LOCUS provides an efficient, model-agnostic embedding framework for large model pools that supports scalable onboarding, accurate routing for unseen queries, and versatile downstream tasks without retraining existing models.

Abstract: The rapidly growing ecosystem of Large Language Models (LLMs) makes it increasingly challenging to manage and utilize the vast and dynamic pool of models effectively. We propose LOCUS, a method that produces low-dimensional vector embeddings that compactly represent a language model's capabilities across queries. LOCUS is an attention-based approach that generates embeddings by a deterministic forward pass over query encodings and evaluation scores via an encoder model, enabling seamless incorporation of new models to the pool and refinement of existing model embeddings without having to perform any retraining. We additionally train a correctness predictor that uses model embeddings and query encodings to achieve state-of-the-art routing accuracy on unseen queries. Experiments show that LOCUS needs up to 4.8x fewer query evaluation samples than baselines to produce informative and robust embeddings. Moreover, the learned embedding space is geometrically meaningful: proximity reflects model similarity, enabling a range of downstream applications including model comparison and clustering, model portfolio selection, and resilient proxies of unavailable models.

</details>


### [219] [MapPFN: Learning Causal Perturbation Maps in Context](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21092)
*Marvin Sextro,Weronika Kłos,Gabriel Dernbach*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: MapPFN is a prior-data fitted network pretrained on synthetic, causal perturbation data and used with in-context learning to predict perturbation effects in unseen biological contexts without gradient updates, matching performance of models trained on real data.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To create treatment-effect estimators that adapt to unseen biological contexts by leveraging interventional evidence at inference time, addressing the limitation that current methods cannot generalize beyond their training data.

Method: Pretrain a PFN on synthetic perturbation data generated from a prior over causal perturbations (in silico gene knockouts). At inference, given a set of experiments, use in-context learning to map observed experiments to post-perturbation distributions without gradient-based optimization.

Result: MapPFN can identify differentially expressed genes and achieves performance comparable to models trained on real single-cell data, despite being trained only on simulated knockouts.

Conclusion: Pretraining on synthetic causal perturbations enables a context-adaptive perturbation estimator that leverages in-context learning at inference time, reducing the need for retraining with real data while remaining competitive with models trained on real data.

Abstract: Planning effective interventions in biological systems requires treatment-effect models that adapt to unseen biological contexts by identifying their specific underlying mechanisms. Yet single-cell perturbation datasets span only a handful of biological contexts, and existing methods cannot leverage new interventional evidence at inference time to adapt beyond their training data. To meta-learn a perturbation effect estimator, we present MapPFN, a prior-data fitted network (PFN) pretrained on synthetic data generated from a prior over causal perturbations. Given a set of experiments, MapPFN uses in-context learning to predict post-perturbation distributions, without gradient-based optimization. Despite being pretrained on in silico gene knockouts alone, MapPFN identifies differentially expressed genes, matching the performance of models trained on real single-cell data. Our code and data are available at https://github.com/marvinsxtr/MapPFN.

</details>


### [220] [Safety Generalization Under Distribution Shift in Safe Reinforcement Learning: A Diabetes Testbed](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21094)
*Minjae Kwon,Josephine Lamp,Lu Feng*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Safe RL policies often fail under distribution shift in a diabetes management setting; test-time shielding with learned dynamics models restores safety and yields 13–14% Time-in-Range gains for strong baselines, across eight algorithms and multiple patient groups. Provides GlucoSim benchmark and code for studying safety under shift.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the mismatch between training-time safety guarantees and deployment under distribution shift in safety-critical control. Diabetes management is a safety-critical testbed for RL; need mechanisms to preserve safety across diverse patients.

Method: Evaluate eight safe RL algorithms on a unified clinical simulator (GlucoSim) to identify a safety generalization gap. Propose test-time shielding that filters unsafe actions using learned dynamics models. Assess across three diabetes types and three age groups. Metrics include Time-in-Range, clinical risk index, and glucose variability.

Result: Found a safety generalization gap: training-time constraints are often violated on unseen patients. Test-time shielding recovers safety across algorithms and populations. Time-in-Range gains of 13–14% achieved for PPO-Lag and CPO; reductions in clinical risk index and glucose variability. Benchmarked across eight algorithms, three diabetes types, and three age groups.

Conclusion: The proposed shielding approach is effective across diverse safe-RL methods and patient populations, suggesting a robust path to safe deployment under distribution shift. The GlucoSim platform provides a public benchmark to study safety under shift in safety-critical control; code is publicly available.

Abstract: Safe Reinforcement Learning (RL) algorithms are typically evaluated under fixed training conditions. We investigate whether training-time safety guarantees transfer to deployment under distribution shift, using diabetes management as a safety-critical testbed. We benchmark safe RL algorithms on a unified clinical simulator and reveal a safety generalization gap: policies satisfying constraints during training frequently violate safety requirements on unseen patients. We demonstrate that test-time shielding, which filters unsafe actions using learned dynamics models, effectively restores safety across algorithms and patient populations. Across eight safe RL algorithms, three diabetes types, and three age groups, shielding achieves Time-in-Range gains of 13--14\% for strong baselines such as PPO-Lag and CPO while reducing clinical risk index and glucose variability. Our simulator and benchmark provide a platform for studying safety under distribution shift in safety-critical control domains. Code is available at https://github.com/safe-autonomy-lab/GlucoSim and https://github.com/safe-autonomy-lab/GlucoAlg.

</details>


### [221] [TRACE: Trajectory Recovery for Continuous Mechanism Evolution in Causal Representation Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21135)
*Shicheng Fan,Kun Zhang,Lu Cheng*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes TRACE for continuous transitions between causal mechanisms, modeling transitions as convex mixtures of atomic mechanisms; demonstrates identifiability and superior trajectory recovery (up to 0.99 correlation) over discrete-switching baselines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Real-world systems often evolve smoothly rather than switching abruptly between discrete causal regimes; existing methods fail to capture gradual transitions and jointly identifying latent variables and their mixing trajectory.

Method: Formulates transitional mechanisms as convex combinations of finitely many atomic mechanisms with time-varying mixing coefficients. Introduces TRACE, a Mixture-of-Experts where each expert learns an atomic mechanism; during training, and at test time, it recovers the continuous mechanism trajectory, including intermediate states unseen during training.

Result: Theoretically, latent causal variables and the continuous mixing trajectory are identifiable. Empirically, TRACE recovers mechanism trajectories with high fidelity (up to 0.99 correlation) on synthetic and real data, outperforming discrete-switching baselines.

Conclusion: The approach enables joint identifiability and practical recovery of continuous mechanism transitions in temporal causal representations, generalizing to intermediate states and improving robustness beyond discrete-switching models.

Abstract: Temporal causal representation learning methods assume that causal mechanisms switch instantaneously between discrete domains, yet real-world systems often exhibit continuous mechanism transitions. For example, a vehicle's dynamics evolve gradually through a turning maneuver, and human gait shifts smoothly from walking to running. We formalize this setting by modeling transitional mechanisms as convex combinations of finitely many atomic mechanisms, governed by time-varying mixing coefficients. Our theoretical contributions establish that both the latent causal variables and the continuous mixing trajectory are jointly identifiable. We further propose TRACE, a Mixture-of-Experts framework where each expert learns one atomic mechanism during training, enabling recovery of mechanism trajectories at test time. This formulation generalizes to intermediate mechanism states never observed during training. Experiments on synthetic and real-world data demonstrate that TRACE recovers mixing trajectories with up to 0.99 correlation, substantially outperforming discrete-switching baselines.

</details>


### [222] [Smooth Dynamic Cutoffs for Machine Learning Interatomic Potentials](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21147)
*Kevin Han,Haolin Cong,Bowen Deng,Amir Barati Farimani*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Dynamic cutoff for MLIPs induces sparsity by limiting per-atom neighbors, enabling substantial memory and speed gains with minimal accuracy loss across 4 architectures.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Overcome the bottlenecks of MLIP inference time and memory consumption by relaxing the fixed cutoff, enabling scalable molecular dynamics with accurate potentials.

Method: Introduce a dynamic cutoff per atom to enforce a target number of neighbors, producing a sparser atom graph. Apply this approach to four state-of-the-art MLIPs (MACE, Nequip, OrbV3, TensorNet) and evaluate on materials and molecular datasets.

Result: Achieves ~2.26x reduction in memory and ~2.04x faster inference, with minimal accuracy drop compared to fixed-cutoff models across tested systems.

Conclusion: Dynamic cutoff is a viable route for scalable MLIP-based MD, preserving accuracy while delivering significant efficiency gains; open-source implementations included.

Abstract: Machine learning interatomic potentials (MLIPs) have proven to be wildly useful for molecular dynamics simulations, powering countless drug and materials discovery applications. However, MLIPs face two primary bottlenecks preventing them from reaching realistic simulation scales: inference time and memory consumption. In this work, we address both issues by challenging the long-held belief that the cutoff radius for the MLIP must be held to a fixed, constant value. For the first time, we introduce a dynamic cutoff formulation that still leads to stable, long timescale molecular dynamics simulation. In introducing the dynamic cutoff, we are able to induce sparsity onto the underlying atom graph by targeting a specific number of neighbors per atom, significantly reducing both memory consumption and inference time. We show the effectiveness of a dynamic cutoff by implementing it onto 4 state of the art MLIPs: MACE, Nequip, Orbv3, and TensorNet, leading to 2.26x less memory consumption and 2.04x faster inference time, depending on the model and atomic system. We also perform an extensive error analysis and find that the dynamic cutoff models exhibit minimal accuracy dropoff compared to their fixed cutoff counterparts on both materials and molecular datasets. All model implementations and training code will be fully open sourced.

</details>


### [223] [Mobility-Embedded POIs: Learning What A Place Is and How It Is Used from Human Movement](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21149)
*Maria Despoina Siampou,Shushman Choudhury,Shang-Ling Hsu,Neha Arora,Cyrus Shahabi*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: ME-POIs fuse mobility-derived usage signals with text-based POI embeddings via temporally contextualized visits and contrastive alignment, plus a cross-scale propagation to alleviate long-tail sparsity; yields superior POI representations across five map-enrichment tasks, showing POI function is crucial for generalization.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current POI representations rely on static textual metadata (identity) or trajectory context (movement patterns) but largely ignore function—how places are actually used. Function is a missing, essential signal for robust, general representations of POIs in real-world contexts.

Method: 1) Start from language-model-derived POI embeddings (identity). 2) Integrate large-scale human mobility data. 3) Encode each visit as temporally contextualized embeddings. 4) Use contrastive learning to align visit embeddings with learnable POI representations, capturing cross-user and temporal usage patterns. 5) Address long-tail sparsity by propagating temporal visit patterns from nearby frequently visited POIs across multiple spatial scales.

Result: ME-POIs augmented embeddings consistently outperform text-only and mobility-only baselines across five proposed map enrichment tasks. Notably, mobility data alone can surpass text-only models on some tasks, highlighting the importance of POI function in representations.

Conclusion: Incorporating POI function through mobility-augmented, temporally contextualized embeddings yields more accurate and generalizable POI representations, suggesting future work should integrate usage signals with identity signals for richer map understanding.

Abstract: Recent progress in geospatial foundation models highlights the importance of learning general-purpose representations for real-world locations, particularly points-of-interest (POIs) where human activity concentrates. Existing approaches, however, focus primarily on place identity derived from static textual metadata, or learn representations tied to trajectory context, which capture movement regularities rather than how places are actually used (i.e., POI's function). We argue that POI function is a missing but essential signal for general POI representations. We introduce Mobility-Embedded POIs (ME-POIs), a framework that augments POI embeddings derived, from language models with large-scale human mobility data to learn POI-centric, context-independent representations grounded in real-world usage. ME-POIs encodes individual visits as temporally contextualized embeddings and aligns them with learnable POI representations via contrastive learning to capture usage patterns across users and time. To address long-tail sparsity, we propose a novel mechanism that propagates temporal visit patterns from nearby, frequently visited POIs across multiple spatial scales. We evaluate ME-POIs on five newly proposed map enrichment tasks, testing its ability to capture both the identity and function of POIs. Across all tasks, augmenting text-based embeddings with ME-POIs consistently outperforms both text-only and mobility-only baselines. Notably, ME-POIs trained on mobility data alone can surpass text-only models on certain tasks, highlighting that POI function is a critical component of accurate and generalizable POI representations.

</details>


### [224] [Can Neural Networks Learn Small Algebraic Worlds? An Investigation Into the Group-theoretic Structures Learned By Narrow Models Trained To Predict Group Operations](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21150)
*Henry Kvinge,Andrew Aguilar,Nayda Farnsworth,Grace O'Brien,Robert Jasper,Sarah Scullen,Helen Jenne*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Neural networks trained to perform a fixed group operation can learn latent, reusable algebraic structure; some properties emerge in representations, enabling simple classifiers to detect subgroups, but fundamental notions like the identity element may remain elusive.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To move beyond AI-era answer-extraction in mathematics and assess whether narrow ML models trained on a specific algebraic task acquire broader mathematical structure that a researcher or another AI could extract.

Method: Train neural networks to predict group operations (e.g., modular arithmetic, composition of permutations) and evaluate their internal representations. Use a suite of tests targeting group-theoretic concepts (identity, commutativity, subgroups). Attempt to extract abstract properties via linear probes/classifiers without explicit labels for the abstract concepts.

Result: Models develop representations that encode some algebraic properties, including hints of commutativity in modular arithmetic. Linear classifiers can reliably distinguish elements of certain subgroups despite no subgroup labels in the data. However, the concept of the identity element is not extractable from the representations in these experiments.

Conclusion: Even small neural networks can distill nontrivial abstract structure from new mathematical objects, suggesting a pathway to using ML to assist mathematical discovery, though some fundamental notions may remain inaccessible to current linear probing approaches.

Abstract: While a real-world research program in mathematics may be guided by a motivating question, the process of mathematical discovery is typically open-ended. Ideally, exploration needed to answer the original question will reveal new structures, patterns, and insights that are valuable in their own right. This contrasts with the exam-style paradigm in which the machine learning community typically applies AI to math. To maximize progress in mathematics using AI, we will need to go beyond simple question answering. With this in mind, we explore the extent to which narrow models trained to solve a fixed mathematical task learn broader mathematical structure that can be extracted by a researcher or other AI system. As a basic test case for this, we use the task of training a neural network to predict a group operation (for example, performing modular arithmetic or composition of permutations). We describe a suite of tests designed to assess whether the model captures significant group-theoretic notions such as the identity element, commutativity, or subgroups. Through extensive experimentation we find evidence that models learn representations capable of capturing abstract algebraic properties. For example, we find hints that models capture the commutativity of modular arithmetic. We are also able to train linear classifiers that reliably distinguish between elements of certain subgroups (even though no labels for these subgroups are included in the data). On the other hand, we are unable to extract notions such as the concept of the identity element. Together, our results suggest that in some cases the representations of even small neural networks can be used to distill interesting abstract structure from new mathematical objects.

</details>


### [225] [Learning to Advect: A Neural Semi-Lagrangian Architecture for Weather Forecasting](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21151)
*Carlos A. Pereira,Stéphane Gaudreault,Valentin Dallerit,Christopher Subich,Shoyon Panday,Siqi Wei,Sasa Zhang,Siddharth Rout,Eldad Haber,Raymond J. Spiteri,David Millard,Emilia Diaconescu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: PARADIS introduces a physics-inspired decomposition of weather dynamics into advection, diffusion, and reaction blocks operating on latent variables. Advection is implemented via Neural Semi-Lagrangian transport on the sphere with differentiable interpolation; diffusion is modeled by depthwise-separable spatial mixing; local sources and vertical interactions are captured by pointwise channel interactions. The architecture achieves state-of-the-art forecast skill at a fraction of the training cost on ERA5 benchmarks, matching or exceeding 0.25-degree baselines such as ECMWF HRES and GraphCast with a 1-degree model trained in under a GPU month.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the limitations of monolithic neural weather models in handling long-range advection and other physical processes by introducing inductive biases through a modular, physics-inspired decomposition into advection, diffusion, and reaction components to improve efficiency and accuracy.

Method: Decompose latent state into three blocks: (1) advection via Neural Semi-Lagrangian operator on the sphere with differentiable trajectory interpolation; (2) diffusion-like processes via depthwise-separable spatial mixing; (3) local source terms and vertical interactions via pointwise channel interactions. End-to-end training on ERA5-based benchmarks using a 1-degree grid; compare against traditional and ML baselines including ECMWF HRES and GraphCast; training cost reported as under one GPU-month.

Result: The PARADIS model delivers state-of-the-art forecast skill at a fraction of the training cost, achieving performance that meets or exceeds 0.25-degree baselines such as ECMWF HRES and GraphCast on ERA5 benchmarks with a 1-degree configuration.

Conclusion: A modular, physics-inspired architecture with explicit advection, diffusion, and reaction components can deliver competitive weather forecasting performance at lower training costs, validating the value of embedding physical inductive biases in neural weather models.

Abstract: Recent machine-learning approaches to weather forecasting often employ a monolithic architecture, where distinct physical mechanisms (advection, transport), diffusion-like mixing, thermodynamic processes, and forcing are represented implicitly within a single large network. This representation is particularly problematic for advection, where long-range transport must be treated with expensive global interaction mechanisms or through deep, stacked convolutional layers. To mitigate this, we present PARADIS, a physics-inspired global weather prediction model that imposes inductive biases on network behavior through a functional decomposition into advection, diffusion, and reaction blocks acting on latent variables. We implement advection through a Neural Semi-Lagrangian operator that performs trajectory-based transport via differentiable interpolation on the sphere, enabling end-to-end learning of both the latent modes to be transported and their characteristic trajectories. Diffusion-like processes are modeled through depthwise-separable spatial mixing, while local source terms and vertical interactions are modeled via pointwise channel interactions, enabling operator-level physical structure. PARADIS provides state-of-the-art forecast skill at a fraction of the training cost. On ERA5-based benchmarks, the 1 degree PARADIS model, with a total training cost of less than a GPU month, meets or exceeds the performance of 0.25 degree traditional and machine-learning baselines, including the ECMWF HRES forecast and DeepMind's GraphCast.

</details>


### [226] [A Federated Generalized Expectation-Maximization Algorithm for Mixture Models with an Unknown Number of Components](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21160)
*Michael Ibrahim,Nagi Gebraeel,Weijun Xie*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: FedGEM introduces a federated EM-based clustering method for unknown K across clients with heterogeneous local cluster sets; it uses uncertainty sets around local component maximizers to infer overlaps and the global number of clusters, with convergence guarantees and isotropic-GMM specialization for efficiency; empirically competitive with centralized EM and superior to existing federated clustering baselines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Clustering under a federated setting where the global number of clusters K is unknown and local data exhibit heterogeneous, potentially overlapping cluster structures. The goal is a privacy-preserving, distributed algorithm with principled inference of global components.

Method: Each client runs local EM to estimate local components, constructs an uncertainty set around each local maximizer, and the server aggregates these to learn overlaps between clients and infer the global number of clusters via closed-form computations. The isotropic GMM setting is analyzed to derive tractable per-iteration computations.

Result: The approach comes with probabilistic convergence guarantees under standard assumptions. For isotropic GMMs, the method yields low-complexity, scalable updates. Numerical experiments show FedGEM achieves performance comparable to centralized EM and outperforms existing federated clustering methods.

Conclusion: FedGEM provides a principled framework for federated clustering with an unknown global K, enabling convergence guarantees and practical efficiency, particularly under isotropic GMMs, while showing competitive empirical performance against both centralized and federated baselines.

Abstract: We study the problem of federated clustering when the total number of clusters $K$ across clients is unknown, and the clients have heterogeneous but potentially overlapping cluster sets in their local data. To that end, we develop FedGEM: a federated generalized expectation-maximization algorithm for the training of mixture models with an unknown number of components. Our proposed algorithm relies on each of the clients performing EM steps locally, and constructing an uncertainty set around the maximizer associated with each local component. The central server utilizes the uncertainty sets to learn potential cluster overlaps between clients, and infer the global number of clusters via closed-form computations. We perform a thorough theoretical study of our algorithm, presenting probabilistic convergence guarantees under common assumptions. Subsequently, we study the specific setting of isotropic GMMs, providing tractable, low-complexity computations to be performed by each client during each iteration of the algorithm, as well as rigorously verifying assumptions required for algorithm convergence. We perform various numerical experiments, where we empirically demonstrate that our proposed method achieves comparable performance to centralized EM, and that it outperforms various existing federated clustering methods.

</details>


### [227] [Efficient Simple Regret Algorithms for Stochastic Contextual Bandits](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21167)
*Shuai Liu,Alireza Bakhtiari,Alex Ayoub,Botao Hao,Csaba Szepesvári*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: First simple-regret guarantees for stochastic contextual logistic bandits; achieves near-optimal rates in dimension d and horizon T with leading term independent of κ; introduces tractable deterministic and randomized algorithms (Thompson Sampling variants) and validates empirically.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Extend simple-regret guarantees from linear to logistic contextual bandits, remove dependence on a condition-number-like κ, and provide practical, tractable algorithms with empirical validation.

Method: Leverage ideas from contextual linear bandits and self-concordant analysis to design algorithms for logistic bandits; derive simple-regret bounds tilde O(d/√T); introduce a Thompson Sampling variant achieving tilde O(d^{3/2}/√T); extend to logistic setting with same rates; analyze tractability for finite action sets; provide randomized vs deterministic variants.

Result: Simple regret bounds tilde O(d/√T) with leading term independent of κ; randomized Thompson Sampling achieves tilde O(d^{3/2}/√T); extension to logistic case preserves rates and κ-independence; finite-action tractable; experiments corroborate theory.

Conclusion: Presents the first simple-regret guarantees for stochastic contextual logistic bandits, with practical, lower-cost randomized algorithms, and empirical validation; results bridge the gap between linear models and logistic contexts in the simple-regret regime.

Abstract: We study stochastic contextual logistic bandits under the simple regret objective. While simple regret guarantees have been established for the linear case, no such results were previously known for the logistic setting. Building on ideas from contextual linear bandits and self-concordant analysis, we propose the first algorithm that achieves simple regret $\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(d/\sqrt{T})$. Notably, the leading term of our regret bound is free of the constant $κ= \mathcal O(\exp(S))$, where $S$ is a bound on the magnitude of the unknown parameter vector. The algorithm is shown to be fully tractable when the action set is finite. We also introduce a new variant of Thompson Sampling tailored to the simple-regret setting. This yields the first simple regret guarantee for randomized algorithms in stochastic contextual linear bandits, with regret $\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(d^{3/2}/\sqrt{T})$. Extending this method to the logistic case, we obtain a similarly structured Thompson Sampling algorithm that achieves the same regret bound -- $\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(d^{3/2}/\sqrt{T})$ -- again with no dependence on $κ$ in the leading term. The randomized algorithms, as expected, are cheaper to run than their deterministic counterparts. Finally, we conducted a series of experiments to empirically validate these theoretical guarantees.

</details>


### [228] [Generalized Information Gathering Under Dynamics Uncertainty](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21988)
*Fernando Palafox,Jingqi Li,Jesse Milzman,David Fridovich-Keil*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A unifying, model-agnostic framework for information-gathering costs in active learning of unknown dynamical systems, based on Massey’s directed information; shows mutual information is a special case and links it to linearized Bayesian information gain; validated on linear, nonlinear, and multi-agent scenarios.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Active information gathering aims to accelerate learning of system dynamics, but existing approaches embed bespoke costs tied to specific models and planners. A general, decoupled cost is desirable to compare methods fairly and understand fundamental information requirements.

Method: Develop a general information-gathering cost using Massey’s directed information that relies only on Markov dynamics with additive noise. Explicitly expose causal dependencies among parameters, beliefs, and controls to decouple design choices (dynamics model, belief update, observation model, planner). Demonstrate that mutual information costs from prior work are a special case within this framework and derive a connection to information gain in linearized Bayesian estimation.

Result: The framework subsumes existing mutual-information-based costs as a special case, provides theoretical justification for MI-based active learning through a link to Bayesian information gain, and demonstrates practical utility with experiments across linear, nonlinear, and multi-agent dynamical systems.

Conclusion: A universal, model-agnostic cost for information gathering is established, enabling principled comparisons of active learning strategies. It clarifies when MI-based criteria align with true information gain and supports broader applicability across diverse dynamical settings.

Abstract: An agent operating in an unknown dynamical system must learn its dynamics from observations. Active information gathering accelerates this learning, but existing methods derive bespoke costs for specific modeling choices: dynamics models, belief update procedures, observation models, and planners. We present a unifying framework that decouples these choices from the information-gathering cost by explicitly exposing the causal dependencies between parameters, beliefs, and controls. Using this framework, we derive a general information-gathering cost based on Massey's directed information that assumes only Markov dynamics with additive noise and is otherwise agnostic to modeling choices. We prove that the mutual information cost used in existing literature is a special case of our cost. Then, we leverage our framework to establish an explicit connection between the mutual information cost and information gain in linearized Bayesian estimation, thereby providing theoretical justification for mutual information-based active learning approaches. Finally, we illustrate the practical utility of our framework through experiments spanning linear, nonlinear, and multi-agent systems.

</details>


### [229] [The Powers of Precision: Structure-Informed Detection in Complex Systems -- From Customer Churn to Seizure Onset](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21170)
*Augusto Santos,Teresa Santos,Catarina Rodrigues,José M. F. Moura*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes a representation-learning pipeline for early detection of emergent phenomena by tuning a one-parameter family of estimators (powers of covariance/precision) and classifying the learned features, with theoretical guarantees and empirical validation on seizures and churn.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Emergent phenomena in complex systems stem from hidden causal interactions. Detecting them early requires uncovering latent structure when the data-generating process is unknown and partially observed, enabling interpretable and predictive insights.

Method: Learn an optimal feature representation from a one-parameter family of estimators based on powers of the empirical covariance or precision matrix, then use a supervised classifier on this representation. The authors establish structural consistency for the estimator family.

Result: Empirical validation shows competitive performance on seizure detection and churn prediction. The optimal covariance power also exhibits identifiability and captures structural signatures, aligning predictive accuracy with interpretable structure.

Conclusion: The framework integrates prediction and explainability, revealing how to tune into underlying causal structure driving critical events and providing a principled, interpretable approach suitable for early-warning tasks.

Abstract: Emergent phenomena -- onset of epileptic seizures, sudden customer churn, or pandemic outbreaks -- often arise from hidden causal interactions in complex systems. We propose a machine learning method for their early detection that addresses a core challenge: unveiling and harnessing a system's latent causal structure despite the data-generating process being unknown and partially observed. The method learns an optimal feature representation from a one-parameter family of estimators -- powers of the empirical covariance or precision matrix -- offering a principled way to tune in to the underlying structure driving the emergence of critical events. A supervised learning module then classifies the learned representation. We prove structural consistency of the family and demonstrate the empirical soundness of our approach on seizure detection and churn prediction, attaining competitive results in both. Beyond prediction, and toward explainability, we ascertain that the optimal covariance power exhibits evidence of good identifiability while capturing structural signatures, thus reconciling predictive performance with interpretable statistical structure.

</details>


### [230] [AC2L-GAD: Active Counterfactual Contrastive Learning for Graph Anomaly Detection](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21171)
*Kamal Berahmand,Saman Forouzandeh,Mehrnoush Mohammadi,Parham Moradi,Mahdi Jalili*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: AC2L-GAD: Active Counterfactual Contrastive Learning for graph anomaly detection; combines information-theoretic active selection with counterfactual augmentation to produce anomaly-preserving positives and hard negatives; reduces computation ~65% while maintaining detection quality; strong results on nine benchmarks including GADBench.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address label scarcity and severe class imbalance in graph anomaly detection; fix two limitations of graph contrastive learning: semantic inconsistency from random augmentations and trivial negatives from naive sampling; leverage counterfactual reasoning to generate informative positives/negatives.

Method: Use active information-theoretic node selection to identify structurally complex nodes; generate counterfactual augmentations that preserve anomalies; create anomaly-preserving positives and hard normals; limit counterfactual generation to a strategically chosen subset to save cost.

Result: Cost reduced ~65% compared to full-graph counterfactual generation; detection quality preserved; competitive or superior to SOTA baselines on nine datasets; notable gains on anomalies with complex attribute-structure interactions (e.g., GADBench real-world financial graphs).

Conclusion: AC2L-GAD demonstrates effective, scalable graph anomaly detection via principled counterfactual reasoning, offering a practical solution for label-scarce, imbalanced graph settings.

Abstract: Graph anomaly detection aims to identify abnormal patterns in networks, but faces significant challenges from label scarcity and extreme class imbalance. While graph contrastive learning offers a promising unsupervised solution, existing methods suffer from two critical limitations: random augmentations break semantic consistency in positive pairs, while naive negative sampling produces trivial, uninformative contrasts. We propose AC2L-GAD, an Active Counterfactual Contrastive Learning framework that addresses both limitations through principled counterfactual reasoning. By combining information-theoretic active selection with counterfactual generation, our approach identifies structurally complex nodes and generates anomaly-preserving positive augmentations alongside normal negative counterparts that provide hard contrasts, while restricting expensive counterfactual generation to a strategically selected subset. This design reduces computational overhead by approximately 65% compared to full-graph counterfactual generation while maintaining detection quality. Experiments on nine benchmark datasets, including real-world financial transaction graphs from GADBench, show that AC2L-GAD achieves competitive or superior performance compared to state-of-the-art baselines, with notable gains in datasets where anomalies exhibit complex attribute-structure interactions.

</details>


### [231] [Breaking the Reasoning Horizon in Entity Alignment Foundation Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21174)
*Yuanning Cui,Zequn Sun,Wei Hu,Kexuan Xin,Zhangjie Fu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A novel EA foundation model with parallel encoding guided by seed pairs, combining local anchor-aware propagation and a merged relation graph with a learnable matcher to boost cross-graph alignment and unseen KG generalization.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current EA models suffer from limited transferability; adapting GFMs to EA is impeded by a reasoning horizon gap due to long-range dependencies in sparse, heterogeneous KGs; the approach seeks to leverage local anchors and global structure to enable scalable, zero-shot alignment.

Method: Two parallel encoding streams initialized from seed EA pairs; anchor-conditioned message passing; merged relation graph to capture global dependencies; learnable interaction module for matching; inference is shortened by local proximity guidance; evaluated on unseen KGs.

Result: Experiments show strong generalizability to unseen KGs and superior performance over baselines, validating the proposed EA foundation model.

Conclusion: The parallel-encoding EA foundation model effectively mitigates the reasoning horizon gap, achieving transferable alignment across unseen KGs and offering a scalable framework for EA in conjunction with graph foundation models.

Abstract: Entity alignment (EA) is critical for knowledge graph (KG) fusion. Existing EA models lack transferability and are incapable of aligning unseen KGs without retraining. While using graph foundation models (GFMs) offer a solution, we find that directly adapting GFMs to EA remains largely ineffective. This stems from a critical "reasoning horizon gap": unlike link prediction in GFMs, EA necessitates capturing long-range dependencies across sparse and heterogeneous KG structuresTo address this challenge, we propose a EA foundation model driven by a parallel encoding strategy. We utilize seed EA pairs as local anchors to guide the information flow, initializing and encoding two parallel streams simultaneously. This facilitates anchor-conditioned message passing and significantly shortens the inference trajectory by leveraging local structural proximity instead of global search. Additionally, we incorporate a merged relation graph to model global dependencies and a learnable interaction module for precise matching. Extensive experiments verify the effectiveness of our framework, highlighting its strong generalizability to unseen KGs.

</details>


### [232] [Rethinking Refinement: Correcting Generative Bias without Noise Injection](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21182)
*Xin Peng,Ang Gao*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Bi-stage Flow Refinement (BFR) provides post-hoc, deterministic bias correction for diffusion/flow models, preserving sampling trajectories while improving fidelity and coverage; achieves state-of-the-art MNIST FID with 1-NFE.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Generative models exhibit systematic biases that degrade sample quality in high dimensions; want effective bias correction without noise injection or multi-step resampling, via post-hoc refinements.

Method: Two refinement stages: (1) latent-space alignment for approximately invertible generators, (2) data-space refinement with lightweight augmentations; corrections are deterministic and keep the original ODE trajectory, avoiding perturbations to sampling dynamics; no additional noise or resampling required.

Result: Consistent improvements in fidelity and coverage on MNIST, CIFAR-10, FFHQ-256; MNIST FID improves from 3.95 to 1.46 with 1-NFE; maintains sample diversity.

Conclusion: BFR offers an efficient, effective bias correction framework compatible with flow/diffusion models, enabling strong performance with minimal extra computation; potential broader applicability; (limitations not detailed in abstract).

Abstract: Generative models, including diffusion and flow-based models, often exhibit systematic biases that degrade sample quality, particularly in high-dimensional settings. We revisit refinement methods and show that effective bias correction can be achieved as a post-hoc procedure, without noise injection or multi-step resampling of the sampling process. We propose a flow-matching-based \textbf{Bi-stage Flow Refinement (BFR)} framework with two refinement strategies operating at different stages: latent space alignment for approximately invertible generators and data space refinement trained with lightweight augmentations. Unlike previous refiners that perturb sampling dynamics, BFR preserves the original ODE trajectory and applies deterministic corrections to generated samples. Experiments on MNIST, CIFAR-10, and FFHQ at 256x256 resolution demonstrate consistent improvements in fidelity and coverage; notably, starting from base samples with FID 3.95, latent space refinement achieves a \textbf{state-of-the-art} FID of \textbf{1.46} on MNIST using only a single additional function evaluation (1-NFE), while maintaining sample diversity.

</details>


### [233] [Rethinking Self-Training Based Cross-Subject Domain Adaptation for SSVEP Classification](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21203)
*Weiguang Wang,Yong Liu,Yingjie Gao,Guangyuan Xu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A cross-subject SSVEP-BCI framework that combines Filter-Bank Euclidean Alignment (FBEA), Cross-Subject Self-Training (CSST) with adversarial pre-training and dual-ensemble pseudo-label refinement, plus Time-Frequency Augmented Contrastive Learning (TFA-CL); achieves state-of-the-art results across Benchmark and BETA datasets, robust to varying signal lengths.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: SSVEP-based BCIs suffer from strong inter-subject variability and high annotation costs, limiting generalization. Cross-subject domain adaptation with self-training and contrastive learning can improve transferability with fewer labels.

Method: FBEA exploits frequency information from SSVEP filter banks. CSST comprises PTAL (adversarial alignment of source and target distributions) and DEST (refined pseudo-labels via dual ensembles). TFA-CL enhances feature discriminability across multiple augmented time–frequency views.

Result: Extensive experiments on Benchmark and BETA datasets show state-of-the-art performance across varying signal lengths, demonstrating strong generalization and robustness.

Conclusion: The integration of FBEA, CSST, and TFA-CL effectively mitigates cross-subject variability and labeling demands in SSVEP-BCIs, achieving superior generalization and potential applicability to related EEG-based BCIs.

Abstract: Steady-state visually evoked potentials (SSVEP)-based brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) are widely used due to their high signal-to-noise ratio and user-friendliness. Accurate decoding of SSVEP signals is crucial for interpreting user intentions in BCI applications. However, signal variability across subjects and the costly user-specific annotation limit recognition performance. Therefore, we propose a novel cross-subject domain adaptation method built upon the self-training paradigm. Specifically, a Filter-Bank Euclidean Alignment (FBEA) strategy is designed to exploit frequency information from SSVEP filter banks. Then, we propose a Cross-Subject Self-Training (CSST) framework consisting of two stages: Pre-Training with Adversarial Learning (PTAL), which aligns the source and target distributions, and Dual-Ensemble Self-Training (DEST), which refines pseudo-label quality. Moreover, we introduce a Time-Frequency Augmented Contrastive Learning (TFA-CL) module to enhance feature discriminability across multiple augmented views. Extensive experiments on the Benchmark and BETA datasets demonstrate that our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance across varying signal lengths, highlighting its superiority.

</details>


### [234] [A Sheaf-Theoretic and Topological Perspective on Complex Network Modeling and Attention Mechanisms in Graph Neural Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21207)
*Chuan-Shen Hu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A cellular sheaf framework to analyze local consistency and diffusion of features in graph-based geometric/topological DL; adds a multiscale TDA-inspired extension to capture hierarchical interactions, enabling topological insights into node classification.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Addresses the underexplored issue of how GDL/TDL features diffuse and align during training on graphs, proposing a formal topological framework to model local feature agreements via cellular sheaves.

Method: Develops a cellular sheaf theoretic model on graphs (nodes/edges) to encode feature data and edge weights; defines measures of local alignment/harmonicity; tracks feature diffusion and aggregation; introduces a multiscale extension inspired by TDA to capture hierarchical interactions across scales.

Result: Provides a topological characterization of GDL/TDL architectures and their learned signals; yields qualitative insights for tasks such as node classification, substructure detection, and community detection; sets up a framework for future empirical and theoretical studies on training dynamics.

Conclusion: A topological data analysis-inspired, sheaf-theoretic framework to study feature diffusion in graph-based deep learning, enabling joint geometric/topological analyses of architectures and learned signals and guiding future research.

Abstract: Combinatorial and topological structures, such as graphs, simplicial complexes, and cell complexes, form the foundation of geometric and topological deep learning (GDL and TDL) architectures. These models aggregate signals over such domains, integrate local features, and generate representations for diverse real-world applications. However, the distribution and diffusion behavior of GDL and TDL features during training remains an open and underexplored problem. Motivated by this gap, we introduce a cellular sheaf theoretic framework for modeling and analyzing the local consistency and harmonicity of node features and edge weights in graph-based architectures. By tracking local feature alignments and agreements through sheaf structures, the framework offers a topological perspective on feature diffusion and aggregation. Furthermore, a multiscale extension inspired by topological data analysis (TDA) is proposed to capture hierarchical feature interactions in graph models. This approach enables a joint characterization of GDL and TDL architectures based on their underlying geometric and topological structures and the learned signals defined on them, providing insights for future studies on conventional tasks such as node classification, substructure detection, and community detection.

</details>


### [235] [Temporal Context and Architecture: A Benchmark for Naturalistic EEG Decoding](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21215)
*Mehmet Ergezer*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Long-context EEG decoding yields higher accuracy across architectures; S5 achieves peak accuracy with ~20x fewer parameters than CNN, but trade-offs in robustness (over-confident OOD errors) versus EEGXF's conservative uncertainty.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Understand how model architecture and temporal context interact in naturalistic EEG decoding and how different architectures fare under robustness challenges (OOD inputs, cross-frequency shifts, cross-subject generalization).

Method: Benchmark five architectures (CNN, LSTM, stabilized EEG Transformer EEGXF, S4, S5) on a 4-class decoding task using the HBN movie-watching dataset. Vary segment lengths from 8s to 128s. Evaluate zero-shot cross-frequency shifts, cross-task OOD inputs, and leave-one-subject-out generalization.

Result: Longer context improves accuracy; at 64s, S5 ≈ 98.7%±0.6, CNN ≈ 98.3%±0.3. S5 uses ~20x fewer parameters than CNN. S5 shows stronger cross-subject accuracy but more over-confident errors on OOD tasks; EEGXF is more conservative and stable under frequency shifts but less calibrated in-distribution.

Conclusion: There is a practical efficiency-robustness trade-off: S5 is attractive for parameter-efficient peak accuracy, while EEGXF is preferable when robustness and conservative uncertainty are critical.

Abstract: We study how model architecture and temporal context interact in naturalistic EEG decoding. Using the HBN movie-watching dataset, we benchmark five architectures, CNN, LSTM, a stabilized Transformer (EEGXF), S4, and S5, on a 4-class task across segment lengths from 8s to 128s. Accuracy improves with longer context: at 64s, S5 reaches 98.7%+/-0.6 and CNN 98.3%+/-0.3, while S5 uses ~20x fewer parameters than CNN. To probe real-world robustness, we evaluate zero-shot cross-frequency shifts, cross-task OOD inputs, and leave-one-subject-out generalization. S5 achieves stronger cross-subject accuracy but makes over-confident errors on OOD tasks; EEGXF is more conservative and stable under frequency shifts, though less calibrated in-distribution. These results reveal a practical efficiency-robustness trade-off: S5 for parameter-efficient peak accuracy; EEGXF when robustness and conservative uncertainty are critical.

</details>


### [236] [Soft Quantization: Model Compression Via Weight Coupling](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21219)
*Daniel T. Bernstein,Luca Di Carlo,David Schwab*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introducing short-range attractive couplings during training yields a soft, mixed-precision weight quantization that outperforms histogram-equalized post-training quantization on ResNet-20 trained on CIFAR-10, using only two extra hyperparameters.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Enable efficient model compression by inducing fast discretization of weight distributions through training-time couplings; provide a tool to study the compression-generalization trade-off in high-dimensional loss landscapes.

Method: Add short-range attractive couplings between weights during training to rapidly discretize the weight distribution and define a soft quantization objective with two new hyperparameters; compare against histogram-equalized PTQ on ResNet-20/CIFAR-10.

Result: Soft quantization achieves favorable accuracy/compression trade-offs compared to histogram-equalized PTQ and supports a mixed-precision compression regime with only two additional hyperparameters.

Conclusion: Training-time weight couplings offer a viable path to soft, mixed-precision quantization and enable a new framework for examining the compression-generalization trade-off in deep networks.

Abstract: We show that introducing short-range attractive couplings between the weights of a neural network during training provides a novel avenue for model quantization. These couplings rapidly induce the discretization of a model's weight distribution, and they do so in a mixed-precision manner despite only relying on two additional hyperparameters. We demonstrate that, within an appropriate range of hyperparameters, our "soft quantization'' scheme outperforms histogram-equalized post-training quantization on ResNet-20/CIFAR-10. Soft quantization provides both a new pipeline for the flexible compression of machine learning models and a new tool for investigating the trade-off between compression and generalization in high-dimensional loss landscapes.

</details>


### [237] [PHDME: Physics-Informed Diffusion Models without Explicit Governing Equations](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21234)
*Kaiyuan Tan,Kendra Givens,Peilun Li,Thomas Beckers*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A diffusion-based trajectory forecaster (PHDME) that uses a GP-dPHS prior to enable physics-informed learning under sparse observations and incomplete physics, culminating in an amortized sampler with split conformal uncertainty.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Forecast dynamical systems under data scarcity and partial physical knowledge; enforce physical structure without full governing equations.

Method: 1) Learn energy-based port-Hamiltonian system via Gaussian process distributed PHS (GP-dPHS) from limited data. 2) Use GP-dPHS to generate a physically consistent artificial dataset for diffusion training. 3) Include a physics residual loss guided by the PHS. 4) Train diffusion model as amortized sampler/forecaster. 5) Apply split conformal calibration to quantify uncertainty.

Result: Improved accuracy and physical consistency under data scarcity on PDE benchmarks and a real-world spring system; provides uncertainty statements.

Conclusion: PHDME integrates port-Hamiltonian priors with diffusion models in a data-scarce regime, enabling reliable forecasting with calibrated uncertainty; particularly suited for complex, nonlinear dynamics with incomplete equations.

Abstract: Diffusion models provide expressive priors for forecasting trajectories of dynamical systems, but are typically unreliable in the sparse data regime. Physics-informed machine learning (PIML) improves reliability in such settings; however, most methods require \emph{explicit governing equations} during training, which are often only partially known due to complex and nonlinear dynamics. We introduce \textbf{PHDME}, a port-Hamiltonian diffusion framework designed for \emph{sparse observations} and \emph{incomplete physics}. PHDME leverages port-Hamiltonian structural prior but does not require full knowledge of the closed-form governing equations. Our approach first trains a Gaussian process distributed Port-Hamiltonian system (GP-dPHS) on limited observations to capture an energy-based representation of the dynamics. The GP-dPHS is then used to generate a physically consistent artificial dataset for diffusion training, and to inform the diffusion model with a structured physics residual loss. After training, the diffusion model acts as an amortized sampler and forecaster for fast trajectory generation. Finally, we apply split conformal calibration to provide uncertainty statements for the generated predictions. Experiments on PDE benchmarks and a real-world spring system show improved accuracy and physical consistency under data scarcity.

</details>


### [238] [Understanding Diffusion Models via Ratio-Based Function Approximation with SignReLU Networks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21242)
*Luwei Sun,Dongrui Shen,Jianfe Li,Yulong Zhao,Han Feng*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: The paper provides a theory to approximate ratio-type density functionals f1/f2, where f1 and f2 are kernel-based marginals, within diffusion-based generative models, using SignReLU neural networks to derive L^p approximation bounds and rates; specialized to DDPMs to bound excess KL risk and decompose it into approximation and estimation errors, yielding finite-sample generalization guarantees.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Conditional generative modeling often requires modeling a conditional density as a ratio f1/f2. This ratio-structured objective in a diffusion-model context lacks rigorous approximation theory and finite-sample guarantees. The work aims to establish a neural-approximation framework with SignReLU activations to handle the piecewise-linear structure of the ratio functionals and provide generalization bounds.

Method: Develop a theoretical framework for approximating ratio-type functionals with deep nets using SignReLU activations that exploit piecewise structure; prove L^p(Omega) approximation bounds and convergence rates under standard regularity assumptions. Specialize to Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models (DDPMs) by constructing a SignReLU-based estimator for the reverse process and deriving upper bounds on the excess KL risk between generated and true distributions, decomposed into approximation and estimation errors.

Result: Establishes L^p approximation bounds and convergence rates for ratio-type functionals with SignReLU nets; provides a SignReLU-based neural estimator for the DDPM reverse process; derives excess KL risk bounds and decomposes them into approximation and estimation errors, yielding finite-sample generalization guarantees for diffusion-based generative models.

Conclusion: The work links ratio-type density functionals to neural estimation in diffusion models, delivering concrete approximation guarantees and finite-sample generalization results via SignReLU networks, thereby informing theory and practice of diffusion-based generative modeling.

Abstract: Motivated by challenges in conditional generative modeling, where the target conditional density takes the form of a ratio f1 over f2, this paper develops a theoretical framework for approximating such ratio-type functionals. Here, f1 and f2 are kernel-based marginal densities that capture structured interactions, a setting central to diffusion-based generative models. We provide a concise proof for approximating these ratio-type functionals using deep neural networks with the SignReLU activation function, leveraging the activation's piecewise structure. Under standard regularity assumptions, we establish L^p(Omega) approximation bounds and convergence rates. Specializing to Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models (DDPMs), we construct a SignReLU-based neural estimator for the reverse process and derive bounds on the excess Kullback-Leibler (KL) risk between the generated and true data distributions. Our analysis decomposes this excess risk into approximation and estimation error components. These results provide generalization guarantees for finite-sample training of diffusion-based generative models.

</details>


### [239] [Less Noise, More Voice: Reinforcement Learning for Reasoning via Instruction Purification](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21244)
*Yiju Guo,Tianyi Hu,Zexu Sun,Yankai Lin*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: LENS introduces token-level interference removal to RLVR, purifying prompts to improve rollout efficiency and then transferring successes to train on noisy prompts; achieves faster convergence and higher performance than GRPO.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address exploration inefficiency in RLVR under limited rollout budgets by identifying non-difficulty-related failures caused by interference tokens in prompts.

Method: Purify prompts by identifying and removing interference tokens, then use successful rollouts from this purification to supervise policy optimization on the original noisy prompts, enabling learning to ignore interference in realistic prompting settings.

Result: LENS outperforms GRPO with a 3.88% average gain and over 1.6x speedup in experiments.

Conclusion: Pruning interference tokens is a critical driver of rollout efficiency in RLVR and suggests a new research direction focusing on prompt-level interference mitigation.

Abstract: Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards (RLVR) has advanced LLM reasoning, but remains constrained by inefficient exploration under limited rollout budgets, leading to low sampling success and unstable training in complex tasks. We find that many exploration failures arise not from problem difficulty, but from a small number of prompt tokens that introduce interference. Building on this insight, we propose the Less Noise Sampling Framework (LENS), which first prompts by identifying and removing interference tokens. then transfers successful rollouts from the purification process to supervise policy optimization on the original noisy prompts, enabling the model to learn to ignore interference in the real-world, noisy prompting settings. Experimental results show that LENS significantly outperforms GRPO, delivering higher performance and faster convergence, with a 3.88% average gain and over 1.6$\times$ speedup. Our work highlights the critical role of pruning interference tokens in improving rollout efficiency, offering a new perspective for RLVR research.

</details>


### [240] [Conditional Generative Framework with Peak-Aware Attention for Robust Chemical Detection under Interferences](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21246)
*Namkyung Yoon,Sanghong Kim,Hwangnam Kim*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Peak-aware CGAN generates conditioned GC-MS signals to augment data for AI-based discrimination under interference, achieving high similarity to real spectra and fewer false alarms.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: GC-MS reliability degrades with interfering substances causing nonspecific peaks, drift, and noise. Limited experimental data hampers robust AI discrimination.

Method: Introduce a peak-aware mechanism to emphasize characteristic GC-MS peaks; encode chemical/solvent information into a latent vector; train a conditional GAN to generate spectra matching experimental conditions and simulated indirect substance scenarios; evaluate with synthetic and real-like datasets.

Result: Generated spectra achieve cosine similarity and Pearson correlation >0.9 with target signals, preserve peak diversity, and reduce discrimination false alarms.

Conclusion: The peak-aware CGAN framework can improve GC-MS reliability under interference by producing realistic conditioned spectra for AI discrimination, potentially reducing the need for extensive real experiments.

Abstract: Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) is a widely used analytical method for chemical substance detection, but measurement reliability tends to deteriorate in the presence of interfering substances. In particular, interfering substances cause nonspecific peaks, residence time shifts, and increased background noise, resulting in reduced sensitivity and false alarms. To overcome these challenges, in this paper, we propose an artificial intelligence discrimination framework based on a peak-aware conditional generative model to improve the reliability of GC-MS measurements under interference conditions. The framework is learned with a novel peak-aware mechanism that highlights the characteristic peaks of GC-MS data, allowing it to generate important spectral features more faithfully. In addition, chemical and solvent information is encoded in a latent vector embedded with it, allowing a conditional generative adversarial neural network (CGAN) to generate a synthetic GC-MS signal consistent with the experimental conditions. This generates an experimental dataset that assumes indirect substance situations in chemical substance data, where acquisition is limited without conducting real experiments. These data are used for the learning of AI-based GC-MS discrimination models to help in accurate chemical substance discrimination. We conduct various quantitative and qualitative evaluations of the generated simulated data to verify the validity of the proposed framework. We also verify how the generative model improves the performance of the AI discrimination framework. Representatively, the proposed method is shown to consistently achieve cosine similarity and Pearson correlation coefficient values above 0.9 while preserving peak number diversity and reducing false alarms in the discrimination model.

</details>


### [241] [EGAM: Extended Graph Attention Model for Solving Routing Problems](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21281)
*Licheng Wang,Yuzi Yan,Mingtao Huang,Yuan Shen*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: EGAM extends GAM by updating both node and edge embeddings via multi-head dot-product attention, using an autoregressive encoder–decoder trained with policy-gradient RL and a designed baseline; it matches or surpasses existing NCO methods on routing tasks, with strong performance on highly constrained problems.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: GAM only aggregates node features, potentially underutilizing edge information and struggling with highly constrained routing graphs. A more expressive attention mechanism and edge-aware representations could improve performance without labeled data.

Method: Propose Extended Graph Attention Model (EGAM) that updates node and edge embeddings with multi-head dot-product attention; uses autoregressive encoder–decoder architecture; trained with policy-gradient reinforcement learning using a specially designed baseline.

Result: EGAM matches or outperforms existing methods across various routing problems; shows exceptional performance on highly constrained problems, demonstrating robustness on complex graph structures.

Conclusion: EGAM effectively extends GAM to edge-aware, more expressive routing solvers, offering strong performance without labeled data and handling difficult constraint regimes better than prior GAM-based approaches.

Abstract: Neural combinatorial optimization (NCO) solvers, implemented with graph neural networks (GNNs), have introduced new approaches for solving routing problems. Trained with reinforcement learning (RL), the state-of-the-art graph attention model (GAM) achieves near-optimal solutions without requiring expert knowledge or labeled data. In this work, we generalize the existing graph attention mechanism and propose the extended graph attention model (EGAM). Our model utilizes multi-head dot-product attention to update both node and edge embeddings, addressing the limitations of the conventional GAM, which considers only node features. We employ an autoregressive encoder-decoder architecture and train it with policy gradient algorithms that incorporate a specially designed baseline. Experiments show that EGAM matches or outperforms existing methods across various routing problems. Notably, the proposed model demonstrates exceptional performance on highly constrained problems, highlighting its efficiency in handling complex graph structures.

</details>


### [242] [DUET: Distilled LLM Unlearning from an Efficiently Contextualized Teacher](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21283)
*Yisheng Zhong,Zhengbang Yang,Zhuangdi Zhu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: DUET uses distillation from a prompt-steered teacher to train a student that forgets undesirable knowledge while preserving general knowledge, yielding strong forgetting with high utility and far better data-efficiency than prior unlearning methods.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Remove undesirable knowledge from LLMs without retraining from scratch, addressing computational cost and catastrophic forgetting of tuning-based methods, and vulnerability of in-context unlearning to prompt manipulation.

Method: Train a student model to imitate a prompt-steered teacher that refuses undesirable knowledge, via distillation, to preserve general knowledge while erasing undesired content.

Result: On benchmarks with enriched evaluation protocols, DUET achieves better forgetting and utility preservation and is orders of magnitude more data-efficient than state-of-the-art unlearning methods.

Conclusion: DUET presents a practical, data-efficient distillation-based unlearning paradigm that blends the strengths of tuning-free and in-context approaches, improving trustworthy AI by removing unwanted knowledge while preserving general capabilities.

Abstract: LLM unlearning is a technique to remove the impacts of undesirable knowledge from the model without retraining from scratch, which is indispensable towards trustworthy AI. Existing unlearning methods face significant limitations: conventional tuning-based unlearning is computationally heavy and prone to catastrophic forgetting.
