In contrast, in-contextualized unlearning is lightweight for precise unlearning but vulnerable to prompt removal or reverse engineering attacks. In response, we propose Distilled Unlearning from an Efficient Teacher (DUET), a novel distillation-based unlearning method that combines the merits of these two lines of work. It learns a student model to imitate the behavior of a prompt-steered teacher that effectively refuses undesirable knowledge generation while preserving general domain knowledge. Extensive evaluations on existing benchmarks with our enriched evaluation protocols demonstrate that DUET achieves higher performance in both forgetting and utility preservation, while being orders of magnitude more data-efficient than state-of-the-art unlearning methods.

</details>


### [243] [PILD: Physics-Informed Learning via Diffusion](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21284)
*Tianyi Zeng,Tianyi Wang,Jiaru Zhang,Zimo Zeng,Feiyang Zhang,Yiming Xu,Sikai Chen,Yajie Zou,Yangyang Wang,Junfeng Jiao,Christian Claudel,Xinbo Chen*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Physics-Informed Learning via Diffusion (PILD) fuses diffusion models with first-principles constraints by adding Laplace-based residual supervision and multi-layer physical conditioning, yielding physics-consistent generation with improved accuracy and generalization across ODEs, PDEs, and algebraic constraints.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To enable physics-compliant generative modeling by integrating explicit physical constraints into diffusion-based learning, addressing the purely data-driven limitation in engineering and scientific problems.

Method: Use a virtual residual observation sampled from a Laplace distribution to supervise training; a conditional embedding module injects physical information into the denoising network at multiple diffusion steps, making guidance consistent throughout the process.

Result: Extensive experiments on vehicle trajectories, tire forces, Darcy flow, and plasma dynamics show PILD improves accuracy, stability, and generalization versus existing physics-informed and diffusion baselines.

Conclusion: PILD offers a concise, modular framework broadly applicable to problems governed by ODEs, PDEs, and algebraic/inequality constraints, effectively enforcing physics during diffusion-based generation.

Abstract: Diffusion models have emerged as powerful generative tools for modeling complex data distributions, yet their purely data-driven nature limits applicability in practical engineering and scientific problems where physical laws need to be followed. This paper proposes Physics-Informed Learning via Diffusion (PILD), a framework that unifies diffusion modeling and first-principles physical constraints by introducing a virtual residual observation sampled from a Laplace distribution to supervise generation during training. To further integrate physical laws, a conditional embedding module is incorporated to inject physical information into the denoising network at multiple layers, ensuring consistent guidance throughout the diffusion process. The proposed PILD framework is concise, modular, and broadly applicable to problems governed by ordinary differential equations, partial differential equations, as well as algebraic equations or inequality constraints. Extensive experiments across engineering and scientific tasks including estimating vehicle trajectories, tire forces, Darcy flow and plasma dynamics, demonstrate that our PILD substantially improves accuracy, stability, and generalization over existing physics-informed and diffusion-based baselines.

</details>


### [244] [Zenith: Scaling up Ranking Models for Billion-scale Livestreaming Recommendation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21285)
*Ruifeng Zhang,Zexi Huang,Zikai Wang,Ke Sun,Bohang Zheng,Zhen Ouyang,Huimin Xie,Phil Shen,Junlin Zhang,Wentao Guo,Qinglei Wang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Zenith is a scalable, efficient ranking architecture for recommender systems that captures multi-granularity feature interactions with minimal runtime overhead, leveraging Token Fusion and Token Boost to scale high-dimensional Prime Tokens; deployed to TikTok Live and yields modest CTR AUC gains and notable engagement improvements.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Need to model complex feature interactions while scaling model capacity without incurring high inference latency; prior work underexplored efficient token-level handling.

Method: Zenith uses few high-dimensional Prime Tokens and introduces Token Fusion and Token Boost modules to increase token heterogeneity and balance computational efficiency; designed for scalability in live recommender scenarios.

Result: In an online A/B test on TikTok Live, Zenith achieved +1.05% CTR AUC and -1.10% Logloss; and approximately +9.93% improvements in Quality Watch Session per user and +8.11% in Quality Watch duration per user.

Conclusion: Zenith demonstrates a practical, scalable approach to feature interaction modeling that improves ranking performance and user-engagement metrics with low runtime overhead.

Abstract: Accurately capturing feature interactions is essential in recommender systems, and recent trends show that scaling up model capacity could be a key driver for next-level predictive performance. While prior work has explored various model architectures to capture multi-granularity feature interactions, relatively little attention has been paid to efficient feature handling and scaling model capacity without incurring excessive inference latency. In this paper, we address this by presenting Zenith, a scalable and efficient ranking architecture that learns complex feature interactions with minimal runtime overhead. Zenith is designed to handle a few high-dimensional Prime Tokens with Token Fusion and Token Boost modules, which exhibits superior scaling laws compared to other state-of-the-art ranking methods, thanks to its improved token heterogeneity. Its real-world effectiveness is demonstrated by deploying the architecture to TikTok Live, a leading online livestreaming platform that attracts billions of users globally. Our A/B test shows that Zenith achieves +1.05%/-1.10% in online CTR AUC and Logloss, and realizes +9.93% gains in Quality Watch Session / User and +8.11% in Quality Watch Duration / User.

</details>


### [245] [TimeSliver : Symbolic-Linear Decomposition for Explainable Time Series Classification](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21289)
*Akash Pandey,Payal Mohapatra,Wei Chen,Qi Zhu,Sinan Keten*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: TimeSliver combines raw time-series data with a symbolic abstraction to create a representation where each temporal segment linearly contributes to the final prediction, enabling faithful, segment-level attribution. It outperforms gradient/attention-based attribution methods and maintains predictive accuracy close to state-of-the-art across benchmarks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Motivate the need for faithful, comprehensive temporal attribution in time-series classification by addressing limitations of post-hoc gradient/feature-based attributions (reference-state sensitivity, poor cross-dataset generalization) and the questionable faithfulness of attention-based temporal attribution.

Method: Introduce TimeSliver, a deep learning framework that jointly encodes raw time-series data and its symbolic abstraction into a representation where each element linearly encodes a temporal segment's contribution to the prediction, yielding per-time-point importance scores; evaluate on 7 synthetic/real-world multivariate datasets for attribution performance and on 26 UEA benchmarks for predictive performance.

Result: TimeSliver achieves an 11% improvement over other temporal attribution methods on 7 datasets and attains predictive performance within 2% of state-of-the-art baselines across 26 UEA benchmarks.

Conclusion: TimeSliver provides a strong, explainable framework for general time-series classification that preserves temporal structure and delivers faithful, segment-level attribution without sacrificing predictive accuracy.

Abstract: Identifying the extent to which every temporal segment influences a model's predictions is essential for explaining model decisions and increasing transparency. While post-hoc explainable methods based on gradients and feature-based attributions have been popular, they suffer from reference state sensitivity and struggle to generalize across time-series datasets, as they treat time points independently and ignore sequential dependencies. Another perspective on explainable time-series classification is through interpretable components of the model, for instance, leveraging self-attention mechanisms to estimate temporal attribution; however, recent findings indicate that these attention weights often fail to provide faithful measures of temporal importance. In this work, we advance this perspective and present a novel explainability-driven deep learning framework, TimeSliver, which jointly utilizes raw time-series data and its symbolic abstraction to construct a representation that maintains the original temporal structure. Each element in this representation linearly encodes the contribution of each temporal segment to the final prediction, allowing us to assign a meaningful importance score to every time point. For time-series classification, TimeSliver outperforms other temporal attribution methods by 11% on 7 distinct synthetic and real-world multivariate time-series datasets. TimeSliver also achieves predictive performance within 2% of state-of-the-art baselines across 26 UEA benchmark datasets, positioning it as a strong and explainable framework for general time-series classification.

</details>


### [246] [Physics-Guided Tiny-Mamba Transformer for Reliability-Aware Early Fault Warning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21293)
*Changyu Li,Dingcheng Huang,Kexuan Yao,Xiaoya Ni,Lijuan Shen,Fei Luo*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: PG-TMT: a physics-guided tri-branch transformer for reliable prognostics in rotating machinery; combines physics-aligned representations, EVT-calibrated decision rules, and hysteresis for calibrated, interpretable early warnings; shows improvements in precision-recall under imbalance and cross-domain transfer with leakage-free streaming.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Need reliable early warning signals under nonstationary operation, domain shifts, and severe class imbalance while keeping false alarms low; existing methods often lack physics grounding or calibrated decision rules for deployment.

Method: Tri-branch encoder: (1) depthwise-separable conv stem for micro-transients, (2) Tiny-Mamba state-space branch for near-linear long-range dynamics, (3) lightweight local Transformer for cross-channel resonances; analytic temporal-to-spectral mapping tying attention to fault-order bands with a band-alignment score; EVT-based healthy-score exceedances with on-threshold false-alarm control and dual-threshold hysteresis; leakage-free streaming with right-censoring for datasets (CWRU, Paderborn, XJTU-SY) and an industrial pilot; evaluation on precision-recall AUC, ROC AUC, mean time-to-detect, cross-domain transfer.

Result: PG-TMT attains higher precision-recall AUC under imbalance, competitive or better ROC AUC, shorter mean time-to-detect at matched false-alarm intensity, and strong cross-domain transfer; provides calibrated, interpretable early warnings.

Conclusion: Physics-aligned representations combined with EVT-calibrated decision rules yield deployment-ready, interpretable PHM warnings with calibrated false-alarm control and robust cross-domain performance.

Abstract: Reliability-centered prognostics for rotating machinery requires early warning signals that remain accurate under nonstationary operating conditions, domain shifts across speed/load/sensors, and severe class imbalance, while keeping the false-alarm rate small and predictable. We propose the Physics-Guided Tiny-Mamba Transformer (PG-TMT), a compact tri-branch encoder tailored for online condition monitoring. A depthwise-separable convolutional stem captures micro-transients, a Tiny-Mamba state-space branch models near-linear long-range dynamics, and a lightweight local Transformer encodes cross-channel resonances. We derive an analytic temporal-to-spectral mapping that ties the model's attention spectrum to classical bearing fault-order bands, yielding a band-alignment score that quantifies physical plausibility and provides physics-grounded explanations. To ensure decision reliability, healthy-score exceedances are modeled with extreme-value theory (EVT), which yields an on-threshold achieving a target false-alarm intensity (events/hour); a dual-threshold hysteresis with a minimum hold time further suppresses chatter. Under a leakage-free streaming protocol with right-censoring of missed detections on CWRU, Paderborn, XJTU-SY, and an industrial pilot, PG-TMT attains higher precision-recall AUC (primary under imbalance), competitive or better ROC AUC, and shorter mean time-to-detect at matched false-alarm intensity, together with strong cross-domain transfer. By coupling physics-aligned representations with EVT-calibrated decision rules, PG-TMT delivers calibrated, interpretable, and deployment-ready early warnings for reliability-centric prognostics and health management.

</details>


### [247] [Missing-Data-Induced Phase Transitions in Spectral PLS for Multimodal Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21294)
*Anders Gjølbye,Ida Kargaard,Emma Kargaard,Lars Kai Hansen*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: PLS-SVD under random entrywise missing data in a high-dimensional spiked setting: masked cross-covariance behaves like a spiked rectangular random matrix with signal attenuated by sqrt(rho); a BBP-type phase transition dictates when the top singular vectors recover latent directions, with closed-form asymptotic overlaps; validation via simulations and semi-synthetic experiments across aspect ratios, signal strength, and missingness.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Quantify the recoverability and theoretical limits of PLS-SVD when data are incomplete, providing a precise phase diagram and overlap formulas.

Method: Model as a proportional high-dimensional spiked model with independent, entrywise missing-at-random masking. Normalize the masked cross-covariance and treat it as a spiked rectangular random matrix with effective signal scaled by sqrt(rho). Derive BBP-type phase transition and closed-form asymptotic overlaps; validate with simulations and semi-synthetic experiments across aspect ratios and missingness levels.

Result: Masked signal strength is attenuated by sqrt(rho); a sharp BBP-type phase transition governs recoverability: below threshold, leading singular vectors are asymptotically uninformative; above threshold, they align with latent directions with computable asymptotic overlaps. Simulations and semi-synthetic experiments corroborate the phase diagram and recovery curves across aspect ratios, signal strengths, and missingness.

Conclusion: The work characterizes PLS-SVD performance under missing data, linking detectability to rho and aspect ratio, and providing theoretical benchmarks and practical guidance for incomplete multimodal data; it also prompts extensions to non-MCAR missingness and finite-sample analyses.

Abstract: Partial Least Squares (PLS) learns shared structure from paired data via the top singular vectors of the empirical cross-covariance (PLS-SVD), but multimodal datasets often have missing entries in both views. We study PLS-SVD under independent entry-wise missing-completely-at-random masking in a proportional high-dimensional spiked model. After appropriate normalization, the masked cross-covariance behaves like a spiked rectangular random matrix whose effective signal strength is attenuated by $\sqrtρ$, where $ρ$ is the joint entry retention probability. As a result, PLS-SVD exhibits a sharp BBP-type phase transition: below a critical signal-to-noise threshold the leading singular vectors are asymptotically uninformative, while above it they achieve nontrivial alignment with the latent shared directions, with closed-form asymptotic overlap formulas. Simulations and semi-synthetic multimodal experiments corroborate the predicted phase diagram and recovery curves across aspect ratios, signal strengths, and missingness levels.

</details>


### [248] [Grounding and Enhancing Informativeness and Utility in Dataset Distillation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21296)
*Shaobo Wang,Yantai Yang,Guo Chen,Peiru Li,Kaixin Li,Yufa Zhou,Zhaorun Chen,Linfeng Zhang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: InfoUtil reframes dataset distillation via informativeness and utility; combines Shapley-based informativeness with gradient-norm-based utility; achieves 6.1% ImageNet-1K improvement with ResNet-18.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the theoretical gap in dataset distillation by formalizing optimal distillation around information capture (informativeness) and sample effectiveness (utility).

Method: Two components: (1) game-theoretic informativeness maximization using Shapley Value attribution to extract key information from samples; (2) utility maximization by selecting globally influential samples based on Gradient Norm; integrated into a distillation framework to balance informativeness and utility.

Result: Empirical results show a 6.1 percentage point improvement over state-of-the-art on ImageNet-1K with ResNet-18, indicating strong performance gains. 

Conclusion: Presents a principled framework that connects information-theoretic notions with practical sample selection for dataset distillation, offering improved performance and a path toward architecture-aware distillation; scalability and approximation of Shapley Values may be practical considerations.

Abstract: Dataset Distillation (DD) seeks to create a compact dataset from a large, real-world dataset. While recent methods often rely on heuristic approaches to balance efficiency and quality, the fundamental relationship between original and synthetic data remains underexplored. This paper revisits knowledge distillation-based dataset distillation within a solid theoretical framework. We introduce the concepts of Informativeness and Utility, capturing crucial information within a sample and essential samples in the training set, respectively. Building on these principles, we define optimal dataset distillation mathematically. We then present InfoUtil, a framework that balances informativeness and utility in synthesizing the distilled dataset. InfoUtil incorporates two key components: (1) game-theoretic informativeness maximization using Shapley Value attribution to extract key information from samples, and (2) principled utility maximization by selecting globally influential samples based on Gradient Norm. These components ensure that the distilled dataset is both informative and utility-optimized. Experiments demonstrate that our method achieves a 6.1\% performance improvement over the previous state-of-the-art approach on ImageNet-1K dataset using ResNet-18.

</details>


### [249] [Achieving $\varepsilon^{-2}$ Dependence for Average-Reward Q-Learning with a New Contraction Principle](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21301)
*Zijun Chen,Zaiwei Chen,Nian Si,Shengbo Wang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Optimal sample complexity tilde-O(epsilon^-2) for synchronous and asynchronous Q-learning in average-reward MDPs via lazy dynamics and an instance-dependent seminorm that induces one-step contraction.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the lack of contraction in average-reward MDPs and limitations of existing analyses that rely on strong contraction or discounting/episodic reductions; obtain non-asymptotic, near-optimal learning guarantees under practical assumptions.

Method: Introduce lazified dynamics (state-stay probability) and construct an instance-dependent seminorm. Prove that the lazified Bellman operator is a one-step contraction under this seminorm and analyze both synchronous and asynchronous Q-learning.

Result: Establishes optimal tilde-O(epsilon^-2) sample complexity (up to log factors) for learning under the lazy dynamics, matching lower bounds up to logarithmic factors.

Conclusion: The approach shows that contractivity can be recovered via a data-dependent seminorm under lazy dynamics, enabling optimal non-asymptotic learning rates for average-reward MDPs without requiring strong prior assumptions or discounting/episodic reductions.

Abstract: We present the convergence rates of synchronous and asynchronous Q-learning for average-reward Markov decision processes, where the absence of contraction poses a fundamental challenge. Existing non-asymptotic results overcome this challenge by either imposing strong assumptions to enforce seminorm contraction or relying on discounted or episodic Markov decision processes as successive approximations, which either require unknown parameters or result in suboptimal sample complexity. In this work, under a reachability assumption, we establish optimal $\widetilde{O}(\varepsilon^{-2})$ sample complexity guarantees (up to logarithmic factors) for a simple variant of synchronous and asynchronous Q-learning that samples from the lazified dynamics, where the system remains in the current state with some fixed probability. At the core of our analysis is the construction of an instance-dependent seminorm and showing that, after a lazy transformation of the Markov decision process, the Bellman operator becomes one-step contractive under this seminorm.

</details>


### [250] [The Surprising Difficulty of Search in Model-Based Reinforcement Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21306)
*Wei-Di Chang,Mikael Henaff,Brandon Amos,Gregory Dudek,Scott Fujimoto*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Search in model-based RL is not a plug-and-play substitute for learned policies; mitigating distribution shift during planning is more crucial than model or value accuracy, enabling state-of-the-art performance across benchmarks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Challenge the standard view that long-horizon predictions and compounding errors are the main obstacles to model-based RL; investigate the actual bottleneck and the conditions under which search helps or hurts.

Method: Empirical analysis of search-based planning in model-based RL across multiple benchmarks, with ablations to identify techniques that mitigate distribution shift and enable effective search.

Result: Contrary to common belief, search can harm performance even with highly accurate models; improving distribution shift mitigation yields state-of-the-art results; the authors also identify key techniques for enabling effective search.

Conclusion: Mitigating distribution shift is more important than maximizing model or value function accuracy; leveraging proper techniques to control shift allows search to be beneficial, redefining the role of planning in model-based RL.

Abstract: This paper investigates search in model-based reinforcement learning (RL). Conventional wisdom holds that long-term predictions and compounding errors are the primary obstacles for model-based RL. We challenge this view, showing that search is not a plug-and-play replacement for a learned policy. Surprisingly, we find that search can harm performance even when the model is highly accurate. Instead, we show that mitigating distribution shift matters more than improving model or value function accuracy. Building on this insight, we identify key techniques for enabling effective search, achieving state-of-the-art performance across multiple popular benchmark domains.

</details>


### [251] [Transferable Graph Condensation from the Causal Perspective](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21309)
*Huaming Du,Yijie Huang,Su Yao,Yiying Wang,Yueyang Zhou,Jingwen Yang,Jinshi Zhang,Han Ji,Yu Zhao,Guisong Liu,Hegui Zhang,Carl Yang,Gang Kou*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: TGCC is a transferable graph dataset condensation method that uses causal-invariant features to enable cross-task and cross-domain transfer, via spatial-domain causal interventions, enhanced condensation, and spectral-domain contrastive learning; it reports up to 13.41% gains in cross-task/domain scenarios and state-of-the-art on most single-task datasets.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing graph dataset condensation methods assume downstream tasks align with the original dataset and task, which limits cross-task/cross-domain transfer. Preserving domain-invariant, causally relevant knowledge could enable condensed datasets to generalize across tasks and domains.

Method: 1) Extract domain causal-invariant features from the graph's spatial domain via causal interventions. 2) Perform enhanced condensation to capture both structural and feature information. 3) Use spectral-domain enhanced contrastive learning to inject causal-invariant features into the condensed graph, preserving original causal information.

Result: Experimental evaluation on five public datasets and a novel FinReport dataset shows TGCC achieving up to 13.41% improvement in cross-task and cross-domain scenarios, and attaining state-of-the-art performance on 5 of 6 datasets in the single-dataset, single-task setting.

Conclusion: TGCC provides effective and transferable condensed graphs that retain causal information, enabling robust cross-task and cross-domain transfer while remaining competitive in standard single-task scenarios.

Abstract: The increasing scale of graph datasets has significantly improved the performance of graph representation learning methods, but it has also introduced substantial training challenges. Graph dataset condensation techniques have emerged to compress large datasets into smaller yet information-rich datasets, while maintaining similar test performance. However, these methods strictly require downstream applications to match the original dataset and task, which often fails in cross-task and cross-domain scenarios. To address these challenges, we propose a novel causal-invariance-based and transferable graph dataset condensation method, named \textbf{TGCC}, providing effective and transferable condensed datasets. Specifically, to preserve domain-invariant knowledge, we first extract domain causal-invariant features from the spatial domain of the graph using causal interventions. Then, to fully capture the structural and feature information of the original graph, we perform enhanced condensation operations. Finally, through spectral-domain enhanced contrastive learning, we inject the causal-invariant features into the condensed graph, ensuring that the compressed graph retains the causal information of the original graph. Experimental results on five public datasets and our novel \textbf{FinReport} dataset demonstrate that TGCC achieves up to a 13.41\% improvement in cross-task and cross-domain complex scenarios compared to existing methods, and achieves state-of-the-art performance on 5 out of 6 datasets in the single dataset and task scenario.

</details>


### [252] [Few-Shot Learning for Dynamic Operations of Automated Electric Taxi Fleets under Evolving Charging Infrastructure: A Meta-Deep Reinforcement Learning Approach](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21312)
*Xiaozhuang Li,Xindi Tang,Fang He*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A meta-reinforcement learning framework called GAT-PEARL combines a graph attention network (GAT) with PEARL to enable rapid adaptation of autonomous electric taxi fleet policies to dynamic charging network layouts, improving generalization and efficiency in Chengdu data.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Addresses the mismatch between static charging-network assumptions in many RL studies and the real-world dynamic, uncertain charging availability. Seeks rapid adaptation to changing infrastructure without retraining.

Method: Integrates GAT for robust spatial representations of infrastructure layouts, capturing spatiotemporal relations; uses PEARL-like probabilistic embeddings to enable quick inferrence-based adaptation in actor-critic RL, forming a meta-RL framework that adapts to different charging network layouts without retraining.

Result: In simulations with real Chengdu data, GAT-PEARL outperforms conventional RL baselines, generalizes to unseen infrastructure layouts, and achieves higher overall operational efficiency under dynamic charging conditions.

Conclusion: GAT-PEARL provides a practical, adaptable policy for AET fleet management in dynamic charging environments, demonstrating strong generalization and sample-efficient adaptation without retraining.

Abstract: With the rapid expansion of electric vehicles (EVs) and charging infrastructure, the effective management of Autonomous Electric Taxi (AET) fleets faces a critical challenge in environments with dynamic and uncertain charging availability. While most existing research assumes a static charging network, this simplification creates a significant gap between theoretical models and real-world operations. To bridge this gap, we propose GAT-PEARL, a novel meta-reinforcement learning framework that learns an adaptive operational policy. Our approach integrates a graph attention network (GAT) to effectively extract robust spatial representations under infrastructure layouts and model the complex spatiotemporal relationships of the urban environment, and employs probabilistic embeddings for actor-critic reinforcement learning (PEARL) to enable rapid, inference-based adaptation to changes in charging network layouts without retraining. Through extensive simulations on real-world data in Chengdu, China, we demonstrate that GAT-PEARL significantly outperforms conventional reinforcement learning baselines, showing superior generalization to unseen infrastructure layouts and achieving higher overall operational efficiency in dynamic settings.

</details>


### [253] [Distributionally Robust Classification for Multi-source Unsupervised Domain Adaptation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21315)
*Seonghwi Kim,Sung Ho Jo,Wooseok Ha,Minwoo Chae*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A distributionally robust unsupervised domain adaptation (UDA) framework that accounts for uncertainty in both covariate and conditional label distributions. It yields a practical, scalable algorithm applicable to multi-source and single-source UDA, with strong gains when target unlabeled data are scarce.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: UDA assumes some alignment between source and target distributions, but real-world shifts include changes in feature distribution and label-conditional behavior. When target data are scarce and source correlations are spurious, standard UDA can fail. A framework that explicitly models uncertainty in both the covariate and conditional distributions aims to improve generalization under such shifts.

Method: Define ambiguity sets over the source-target covariate distribution and over the conditional label distribution. Formulate a distributionally robust objective that seeks good performance under worst-case plausible shifts. Develop an efficient optimization algorithm that can be integrated with existing UDA methods, and adapt the framework to both multi-source and single-source settings.

Result: Empirical evaluations across diverse distribution shift scenarios show consistent improvements over strong baselines, with the largest gains when target unlabeled data are extremely scarce. Ablation studies illustrate the contribution of robustness to both covariate and conditional distribution uncertainty.

Conclusion: The proposed distributionally robust framework provides a versatile and practical advancement for UDA, bridging multi-source and single-source settings. It improves resilience to scarce target data and distribution shifts while remaining compatible with existing UDA approaches. Future work could explore alternative ambiguity sets and scalability to larger datasets.

Abstract: Unsupervised domain adaptation (UDA) is a statistical learning problem when the distribution of training (source) data is different from that of test (target) data. In this setting, one has access to labeled data only from the source domain and unlabeled data from the target domain. The central objective is to leverage the source data and the unlabeled target data to build models that generalize to the target domain. Despite its potential, existing UDA approaches often struggle in practice, particularly in scenarios where the target domain offers only limited unlabeled data or spurious correlations dominate the source domain. To address these challenges, we propose a novel distributionally robust learning framework that models uncertainty in both the covariate distribution and the conditional label distribution. Our approach is motivated by the multi-source domain adaptation setting but is also directly applicable to the single-source scenario, making it versatile in practice. We develop an efficient learning algorithm that can be seamlessly integrated with existing UDA methods. Extensive experiments under various distribution shift scenarios show that our method consistently outperforms strong baselines, especially when target data are extremely scarce.

</details>


### [254] [Heterogeneous Vertiport Selection Optimization for On-Demand Air Taxi Services: A Deep Reinforcement Learning Approach](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21316)
*Aoyu Pang,Maonan Wang,Zifan Sha,Wenwei Yue,Changle Li,Chung Shue Chen,Man-On Pun*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Unified Air-Ground Mobility Coordination (UAGMC) uses a unified optimization model and deep RL with V2X to coordinate vertiport selection and air-taxi routing with ground transport, improving door-to-door efficiency. Code is available.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Addresses the gap in systematic, integrated routing for air-ground mobility; current literature lacks a unified framework considering real-time traffic and passenger decision-making.

Method: Develop a unified optimization model for simultaneous air and ground strategy selection, capturing dynamic multimodal networks and real-time traffic; implement a UAGMC framework leveraging deep reinforcement learning and V2X for vertiport selection and dynamic air taxi routing.

Result: Demonstrates a 34% reduction in average travel time over proportional allocation methods; improves overall travel efficiency; provides insights into multimodal integration; code released at the provided repository.

Conclusion: Foundational contribution toward intelligent urban mobility through coordinated air and ground modes, with potential for extension to more realistic scenarios and broader uptake.

Abstract: Urban Air Mobility (UAM) has emerged as a transformative solution to alleviate urban congestion by utilizing low-altitude airspace, thereby reducing pressure on ground transportation networks. To enable truly efficient and seamless door-to-door travel experiences, UAM requires close integration with existing ground transportation infrastructure. However, current research on optimal integrated routing strategies for passengers in air-ground mobility systems remains limited, with a lack of systematic exploration.To address this gap, we first propose a unified optimization model that integrates strategy selection for both air and ground transportation. This model captures the dynamic characteristics of multimodal transport networks and incorporates real-time traffic conditions alongside passenger decision-making behavior. Building on this model, we propose a Unified Air-Ground Mobility Coordination (UAGMC) framework, which leverages deep reinforcement learning (RL) and Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) communication to optimize vertiport selection and dynamically plan air taxi routes. Experimental results demonstrate that UAGMC achieves a 34\% reduction in average travel time compared to conventional proportional allocation methods, enhancing overall travel efficiency and providing novel insights into the integration and optimization of multimodal transportation systems. This work lays a solid foundation for advancing intelligent urban mobility solutions through the coordination of air and ground transportation modes. The related code can be found at https://github.com/Traffic-Alpha/UAGMC.

</details>


### [255] [An introductory Generalization of the standard SVMs loss and its applications to Shallow and Deep Neural Networks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21331)
*Filippo Portera*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces a new convex loss for SVMs applicable to classification and regression, with dual formulations and empirical tests on small datasets. Claims potential generalization gains by leveraging pattern correlations within the loss and demonstrates some improvements, including experiments with shallow and deep neural networks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To improve generalization of SVM-like losses by incorporating pattern correlations into the loss function, and to provide dual formulations to study optimization properties; extend exploration to neural network applications.

Method: Formulates a new convex loss for SVMs, derives the corresponding dual problems for binary classification and regression, and conducts experiments on several small datasets to evaluate generalization compared to standard losses. Also reports some results when integrating the loss with shallow and deep neural networks.

Result: The loss yields generalization performance that is at least as good as standard losses, with several instances showing improvements. The study is limited by small dataset sizes due to scalability challenges of SVMs.

Conclusion: Pattern-correlated convex loss for SVMs appears promising for improving generalization and can be extended to neural networks; however, larger-scale validation is needed to confirm scalability and robustness beyond small data regimes.

Abstract: We propose a new convex loss for SVMs, both for the binary classification and for the regression models. Therefore, we show the mathematical derivation of the dual problems and we experiment them with several small data-sets. The minimal dimension of those data-sets is due to the difficult scalability of the SVM method to bigger instances. This preliminary study should prove that using pattern correlations inside the loss function could enhance the generalisation performances. Coherently, results show that generalisation measures are never worse than the standard losses and several times they are better. In our opinion, it should be considered a careful study of this loss, coupled with shallow and deep neural networks. In fact, we present some novel results obtained with those architectures.

</details>


### [256] [Memorization Control in Diffusion Models from Denoising-centric Perspective](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21348)
*Thuy Phuong Vu,Mai Viet Hoang Do,Minhhuy Le,Dinh-Cuong Hoang,Phan Xuan Tan*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A diffusion model memorization can be mitigated by a denoising-centric timestep sampling strategy that shifts learning toward later denoising steps, controlling memorization via the width of a confidence interval to balance memorization and distributional alignment.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Memorization remains a risk in diffusion models; traditional fixes are data- or model-centric and treat the model as a standalone predictor. A denoising-centric view can reveal how learning dynamics across denoising steps contribute to memorization and generalization.

Method: Analyse how uniform timestep sampling yields unequal learning contributions due to differing signal-to-noise ratios across denoising steps, leading to memorization bias. Propose a configurable timestep sampling strategy that controls where learning occurs along the denoising trajectory. Introduce a tunable confidence-interval width to directly trade off memorization and generalization.

Result: Empirical results on image and 1D signal generation show that shifting learning emphasis toward later denoising steps reduces memorization and improves alignment with the training data distribution, validating the method's generality and effectiveness.

Conclusion: Denoising-trajectory-aware timestep sampling provides a general and effective mechanism to regulate memorization in diffusion models, applicable across modalities and capable of achieving tunable generalization via confidence-interval width adjustments.

Abstract: Controlling memorization in diffusion models is critical for applications that require generated data to closely match the training distribution. Existing approaches mainly focus on data centric or model centric modifications, treating the diffusion model as an isolated predictor. In this paper, we study memorization in diffusion models from a denoising centric perspective. We show that uniform timestep sampling leads to unequal learning contributions across denoising steps due to differences in signal to noise ratio, which biases training toward memorization. To address this, we propose a timestep sampling strategy that explicitly controls where learning occurs along the denoising trajectory. By adjusting the width of the confidence interval, our method provides direct control over the memorization generalization trade off. Experiments on image and 1D signal generation tasks demonstrate that shifting learning emphasis toward later denoising steps consistently reduces memorization and improves distributional alignment with training data, validating the generality and effectiveness of our approach.

</details>


### [257] [L2R: Low-Rank and Lipschitz-Controlled Routing for Mixture-of-Experts](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21349)
*Minghao Yang,Ren Togo,Guang Li,Takahiro Ogawa,Miki Haseyama*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Low-rank & Lipschitz-controlled Routing (L2R) for mixture-of-experts; reshapes routing space to low-rank, uses Saturated Inner-Product Scoring (SIPS) to bound Lipschitz and stabilize routing, plus multi-anchor routing; shows improved routing stability, expert specialization, and performance in language and vision MoEs.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address representation mismatch, angular concentration, and scale-sensitive scoring in traditional linear routers which impair routing discriminability and stable expert specialization.

Method: Propose L2R: 1) expert assignment in a shared low-rank latent routing space; 2) SIPS to bound Lipschitz behavior of routing functions; 3) parameter-efficient multi-anchor routing to enhance expressiveness. Empirical validation on large-scale language MoE and ImageNet vision MoE.

Result: L2R consistently improves routing stability, expert specialization, and overall model performance in both language and vision MoE settings.

Conclusion: L2R provides a unified routing framework that reshapes routing space and scoring geometry, improving MoE routing quality and suggesting broad applicability.

Abstract: Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) models scale neural networks by conditionally activating a small subset of experts, where the router plays a central role in determining expert specialization and overall model performance. However, many modern MoE systems still adopt linear routers in raw high-dimensional representation spaces, where representation mismatch, angular concentration, and scale-sensitive scoring can jointly undermine routing discriminability and stable expert specialization. In this work, we propose Low-rank \& Lipschitz-controlled Routing (L2R), a unified routing framework that reshapes both the routing space and scoring geometry. L2R performs expert assignment in a shared low-rank latent routing space and introduces Saturated Inner-Product Scoring (SIPS) to explicitly control the Lipschitz behavior of routing functions, yielding smoother and more stable routing geometry. In addition, L2R incorporates a parameter-efficient multi-anchor routing mechanism to enhance expert expressiveness. Extensive experiments on a large-scale language MoE model and a vision MoE setting on ImageNet demonstrate that L2R consistently improves routing stability, expert specialization, and overall model performance.

</details>


### [258] [Factored Causal Representation Learning for Robust Reward Modeling in RLHF](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21350)
*Yupei Yang,Lin Yang,Wanxi Deng,Lin Qu,Fan Feng,Biwei Huang,Shikui Tu,Lei Xu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes a causal, factored reward model for RLHF that separates embedding into causal and non-causal factors; constrains the reward head to the causal component and uses an adversarial head (with gradient reversal) to discourage non-causal encoding of reward, leading to more robust reward models and better RLHF performance, with reduced reward hacking (e.g., length, sycophancy).


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reward models often latch onto spurious, non-causal features that correlate with human labels, enabling reward hacking and misalignment. A causal, factored representation aims to ensure reward prediction relies only on factors causally related to human preferences.

Method: Decompose the model's contextual embedding into two components: causal factors sufficient for reward prediction and non-causal factors capturing reward-irrelevant attributes. Constrain the reward head to depend only on the causal component. Train an adversarial head to predict reward from non-causal factors and apply gradient reversal to discourage non-causal factors from encoding reward-relevant information.

Result: Empirical evaluation on mathematical and dialogue tasks shows more robust reward models and consistent improvements in downstream RLHF performance over state-of-the-art baselines. Analyses indicate reduced reward hacking related to length and sycophantic bias.

Conclusion: A causally aware, factored reward model with an adversarial mechanism against non-causal information improves robustness and RLHF effectiveness, mitigating reward hacking and aligning model behavior more closely with human preferences.

Abstract: A reliable reward model is essential for aligning large language models with human preferences through reinforcement learning from human feedback. However, standard reward models are susceptible to spurious features that are not causally related to human labels. This can lead to reward hacking, where high predicted reward does not translate into better behavior. In this work, we address this problem from a causal perspective by proposing a factored representation learning framework that decomposes the model's contextual embedding into (1) causal factors that are sufficient for reward prediction and (2) non-causal factors that capture reward-irrelevant attributes such as length or sycophantic bias. The reward head is then constrained to depend only on the causal component. In addition, we introduce an adversarial head trained to predict reward from the non-causal factors, while applying gradient reversal to discourage them from encoding reward-relevant information. Experiments on both mathematical and dialogue tasks demonstrate that our method learns more robust reward models and consistently improves downstream RLHF performance over state-of-the-art baselines. Analyses on length and sycophantic bias further validate the effectiveness of our method in mitigating reward hacking behaviors.

</details>


### [259] [Theoretically Optimal Attention/FFN Ratios in Disaggregated LLM Serving](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21351)
*Chendong Song,Meixuan Wang,Hang Zhou,Hong Liang,Yuan Lyu,Zixi Chen,Yuwei Fan,Zijie Zhou*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Analytical framework for sizing Attention/FFN bundles in rA-1F LLM decoding. Derives closed-form optimal A/F ratio under probabilistic workload with nonstationary Attention and stable FFN work; validated by trace-calibrated simulator; yields near-optimal throughput and reduced idle time.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address performance sensitivity of Attention-FFN disaggregation (AFD) to provisioning; enable independent scaling of memory (Attention) and compute (FFN) resources for efficient LLM decoding.

Method: Develop a tractable analytical model of AFD in an rA-1F topology with nonstationary Attention workload (growing context tokens, random-length requests) and stable FFN workload; derive closed-form rules for the optimal Attention/FFN (A/F) ratio using probabilistic workload assumptions; validate the theory with a trace-calibrated AFD simulator.

Result: Derived closed-form rules for the optimal A/F ratio that maximize average throughput per instance. Simulation shows theory matches optimum within 10% across workloads and consistently reduces idle time.

Conclusion: Sizing AFD bundles using the derived A/F ratio rules enables near-optimal throughput and improved resource utilization; the framework provides practical guidance for scalable AFD deployments.

Abstract: Attention-FFN disaggregation (AFD) is an emerging architecture for LLM decoding that separates state-heavy, KV-cache-dominated Attention computation from stateless, compute-intensive FFN computation, connected by per-step communication. While AFD enables independent scaling of memory and compute resources, its performance is highly sensitive to the Attention/FFN provisioning ratio: mis-sizing induces step-level blocking and costly device idle time. We develop a tractable analytical framework for sizing AFD bundles in an $r$A-$1$F topology, where the key difficulty is that Attention-side work is nonstationary-token context grows and requests are continuously replenished with random lengths-while FFN work is stable given the aggregated batch. Using a probabilistic workload model, we derive closed-form rules for the optimal A/F ratio that maximize average throughput per instance across the system. A trace-calibrated AFD simulator validates the theory: across workloads, the theoretical optimal A/F ratio matches the simulation-optimal within 10%, and consistently reduces idle time.

</details>


### [260] [Expected Improvement via Gradient Norms](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21357)
*Joshua Hang Sai Ip,Georgios Makrygiorgos,Ali Mesbah*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: EI-GN extends Expected Improvement by optimizing a gradient-aware auxiliary objective to probe regions near high performance and approaching first-order stationarity; shows improved performance on BO benchmarks and in control policy learning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: EI tends to be overly exploitative and can miss regions near stationary points. Incorporating gradient information via gradient-enhanced surrogates enables principled gradient inference and guides sampling toward regions with high potential and near-stationarity.

Method: Introduce EI-GN, an acquisition that applies the improvement principle to a gradient-norm objective. Utilize gradient observations to learn gradient-enhanced surrogate models, derive a tractable closed-form EI-GN, and ensure consistency with the improvement-based framework; optimize efficiently.

Result: Empirical evaluations on standard BO benchmarks show consistent improvements over standard baselines. Demonstrates applicability to control policy learning problems via gradient-informed sampling.

Conclusion: EI-GN is a principled extension of EI that leverages gradient information to balance exploration and exploitation, steering samples toward high-performing, near-stationarity regions within the improvement framework; suitable for gradient-enhanced BO and policy learning tasks.

Abstract: Bayesian Optimization (BO) is a principled approach for optimizing expensive black-box functions, with Expected Improvement (EI) being one of the most widely used acquisition functions. Despite its empirical success, EI is known to be overly exploitative and can converge to suboptimal stationary points. We propose Expected Improvement via Gradient Norms (EI-GN), a novel acquisition function that applies the improvement principle to a gradient-aware auxiliary objective, thereby promoting sampling in regions that are both high-performing and approaching first-order stationarity. EI-GN relies on gradient observations used to learn gradient-enhanced surrogate models that enable principled gradient inference from function evaluations. We derive a tractable closed-form expression for EI-GN that allows efficient optimization and show that the proposed acquisition is consistent with the improvement-based acquisition framework. Empirical evaluations on standard BO benchmarks demonstrate that EI-GN yields consistent improvements against standard baselines. We further demonstrate applicability of EI-GN to control policy learning problems.

</details>


### [261] [Perceptrons and localization of attention's mean-field landscape](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21366)
*Antonio Álvarez-López,Borjan Geshkovski,Domènec Ruiz-Balet*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Mean-field interpretation of Transformer forward pass shows the perceptron block induces atomic, localized critical points on the unit sphere under Wasserstein gradient-flow dynamics.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Provide a theoretical framework to understand Transformer dynamics by mapping the forward pass to an interacting-particle system on the unit sphere; investigate how the perceptron block shapes the energy landscape and critical points in a mean-field setting.

Method: Model the forward pass as a system of interacting particles on the unit sphere; interpret depth as time; relate to gradient flows of an explicit energy in certain weight regimes; establish a mean-field (infinite context) limit via Wasserstein gradient flows; analyze the impact of the perceptron block on the energy landscape.

Result: In certain weight settings, the dynamics coincide with gradient flow of an explicit energy; critical points are generically atomic and localized on subsets of the sphere.

Conclusion: The perceptron block leads to sparse, localized critical points in the mean-field, Wasserstein-gradient-flow framework, offering geometric insight into Transformer representations and the role of normalization.

Abstract: The forward pass of a Transformer can be seen as an interacting particle system on the unit sphere: time plays the role of layers, particles that of token embeddings, and the unit sphere idealizes layer normalization. In some weight settings the system can even be seen as a gradient flow for an explicit energy, and one can make sense of the infinite context length (mean-field) limit thanks to Wasserstein gradient flows. In this paper we study the effect of the perceptron block in this setting, and show that critical points are generically atomic and localized on subsets of the sphere.

</details>


### [262] [Rethinking Federated Graph Foundation Models: A Graph-Language Alignment-based Approach](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21369)
*Yinlin Zhu,Di Wu,Xianzhi Zhang,Yuming Ai,Xunkai Li,Miao Hu,Guocong Quan*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: FedGALA aligns pre-trained language models (PLMs) and graph neural networks (GNNs) in a federated setting to overcome semantic-structural orthogonality and knowledge loss from quantization, using unsupervised contrastive learning in a continuous embedding space and prompt-tuning for efficient adaptation; it achieves strong, multi-domain performance gains without full fine-tuning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing FedGFM approaches rely on vector-quantized backbones that introduce irreversible knowledge loss and struggle with data heterogeneity and communication constraints across distributed, privacy-restricted data silos. A principled alignment between PLMs and GNNs in a continuous space is needed to preserve semantic-structural integrity and enable robust knowledge transfer.

Method: FedGALA employs unsupervised contrastive learning to align GNN encoders with frozen PLMs in a shared continuous embedding space, reducing orthogonality between graph semantics and language semantics. It then uses a communication-efficient prompt-tuning mechanism to steer these aligned encoders and PLMs for downstream tasks, avoiding full-parameter fine-tuning.

Result: Empirical evaluation across multi-domain datasets and multiple tasks shows FedGALA outperforms competitive baselines, with up to 14.37% performance improvement.

Conclusion: FedGALA effectively reconciles semantic-structural orthogonality in federated graph foundation models, mitigates data heterogeneity and communication constraints, and demonstrates robust transfer of general knowledge through alignment and prompt-based adaptation.

Abstract: Recent studies of federated graph foundational models (FedGFMs) break the idealized and untenable assumption of having centralized data storage to train graph foundation models, and accommodate the reality of distributed, privacy-restricted data silos. Despite their simplicity and intuition, existing studies that project aligned generalizable knowledge onto a discrete token space via vector-quantized backbones suffer from irreversible knowledge loss during the quantization process. In this context, we argue that reconciling the semantic-structural orthogonality and integrity between pre-trained language models (PLMs) and graph neural networks (GNNs) is paramount for developing effective FedGFMs while simultaneously mitigating the severe data heterogeneity and communication constraints inherent in distributed, resource-limited environments.
  To address these issues, we propose FedGALA (Federated Graph And Language Alignment), a framework that resolves graph-based semantic-structural orthogonality and integrity in federated settings by employing unsupervised contrastive learning to align GNNs and frozen PLMs within a continuous embedding space, thereby capturing robust, transferable general knowledge. Subsequently, FedGALA leverages a communication-efficient prompt tuning mechanism to steer these pre-aligned encoders and frozen PLMs, facilitating effective adaptation to diverse downstream tasks while circumventing the prohibitive overhead of full-parameter fine-tuning. The comprehensive experiments validate that FedGALA outperforms all competitive baselines across multi-domain datasets on multiple tasks with up to 14.37% performance improvement.

</details>


### [263] [DA-SPS: A Dual-stage Network based on Singular Spectrum Analysis, Patching-strategy and Spearman-correlation for Multivariate Time-series Prediction](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21381)
*Tianhao Zhang,Shusen Ma,Yu Kang,Yun-Bo Zhao*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: DA-SPS is a two-stage multivariate time-series forecasting model that separately processes the target variable and extraneous variables. It uses SSA to decompose the target, LSTM and P-Conv-LSTM to capture trend/seasonality, and a correlation-based filter plus L-Attention to process extraneous variables, with final fusion yielding state-of-the-art performance on four public datasets and a private real-world dataset.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing multivariate time-series models often ignore the impact of extraneous variables on the target and underutilize diverse temporal patterns. There is a need to selectively filter relevant extraneous variables and extract complex sequence information across time patterns to improve forecast accuracy.

Method: Two-stage architecture: TVPS (target variable processing) applies Singular Spectrum Analysis to the target sequence, then LSTM and P-Conv-LSTM with a patching strategy to extract trend- and seasonality-related features. EVPS (extraneous variables processing) filters extraneous variables via Spearman correlation with the target and processes them with an L-Attention module combining LSTM and attention mechanism. Final prediction is obtained by weighted summation and linear mapping of TVPS and EVPS outputs.

Result: On four public datasets, the proposed DA-SPS outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods. Its effectiveness is further validated on a private real-world dataset containing laptop motherboard test-item information.

Conclusion: DA-SPS effectively handles extraneous variables and leverages diverse time-pattern information to improve forecasting accuracy, demonstrating strong generalization across datasets and real-world applicability.

Abstract: Multivariate time-series forecasting, as a typical problem in the field of time series prediction, has a wide range of applications in weather forecasting, traffic flow prediction, and other scenarios. However, existing works do not effectively consider the impact of extraneous variables on the prediction of the target variable. On the other hand, they fail to fully extract complex sequence information based on various time patterns of the sequences. To address these drawbacks, we propose a DA-SPS model, which adopts different modules for feature extraction based on the information characteristics of different variables. DA-SPS mainly consists of two stages: the target variable processing stage (TVPS) and the extraneous variables processing stage (EVPS). In TVPS, the model first uses Singular Spectrum Analysis (SSA) to process the target variable sequence and then uses Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and P-Conv-LSTM which deploys a patching strategy to extract features from trend and seasonality components, respectively. In EVPS, the model filters extraneous variables that have a strong correlation with the target variate by using Spearman correlation analysis and further analyses them using the L-Attention module which consists of LSTM and attention mechanism. Finally, the results obtained by TVPS and EVPS are combined through weighted summation and linear mapping to produce the final prediction. The results on four public datasets demonstrate that the DA-SPS model outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods. Additionally, its performance in real-world scenarios is further validated using a private dataset collected by ourselves, which contains the test items' information on laptop motherboards.

</details>


### [264] [Sim-MSTNet: sim2real based Multi-task SpatioTemporal Network Traffic Forecasting](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21384)
*Hui Ma,Qingzhong Li,Jin Wang,Jie Wu,Shaoyu Dou,Li Feng,Xinjun Pei*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Sim-MSTNet uses sim2real with synthetic data and bi-level optimization to address data scarcity and task imbalance in multi-task spatiotemporal network traffic forecasting, employing attention-based cross-task sharing and dynamic loss weighting, achieving SOTA results on two datasets.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Improve generalization in multi-task network traffic forecasting under limited real data and task imbalance/negative transfer across service types.

Method: 1) Use a simulator to generate synthetic traffic data (sim2real pipeline). 2) Apply domain randomization and bi-level optimization to align synthetic and real distributions via sample weighting and model training. 3) Incorporate attention-based mechanisms to selectively share knowledge across tasks. 4) Employ dynamic loss weighting to balance task objectives. 5) Evaluate on two open-source datasets against state-of-the-art baselines.

Result: Extensive experiments on two open-source datasets show that Sim-MSTNet outperforms baselines, with improved accuracy and generalization across tasks/services.

Conclusion: The proposed framework effectively tackles data scarcity and negative transfer in multi-task traffic forecasting, demonstrating enhanced performance and generalization; potential applicability to broader multi-task spatiotemporal forecasting domains.

Abstract: Network traffic forecasting plays a crucial role in intelligent network operations, but existing techniques often perform poorly when faced with limited data. Additionally, multi-task learning methods struggle with task imbalance and negative transfer, especially when modeling various service types. To overcome these challenges, we propose Sim-MSTNet, a multi-task spatiotemporal network traffic forecasting model based on the sim2real approach. Our method leverages a simulator to generate synthetic data, effectively addressing the issue of poor generalization caused by data scarcity. By employing a domain randomization technique, we reduce the distributional gap between synthetic and real data through bi-level optimization of both sample weighting and model training. Moreover, Sim-MSTNet incorporates attention-based mechanisms to selectively share knowledge between tasks and applies dynamic loss weighting to balance task objectives. Extensive experiments on two open-source datasets show that Sim-MSTNet consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, achieving enhanced accuracy and generalization.

</details>


### [265] [Intrinsic Reward Policy Optimization for Sparse-Reward Environments](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21391)
*Minjae Cho,Huy Trong Tran*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes IRPO: a policy optimization method using multiple intrinsic rewards to directly optimize extrinsic return without pretraining subpolicies; uses a surrogate policy gradient for sparse rewards; shows improved performance and sample efficiency; code at GitHub.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: In sparse-reward RL, exploration is difficult. Intrinsic rewards can guide exploration but prior approaches either miscredit intrinsic signals or require costly subpolicies. A method that directly optimizes extrinsic performance via intrinsic rewards without subpolicy pretraining is desirable.

Method: IRPO forms a surrogate policy gradient combining multiple intrinsic rewards to yield a richer learning signal than the true gradient. It avoids pretraining subpolicies and provides theoretical analysis of the optimization problem. Evaluated in discrete and continuous domains; code released.

Result: IRPO improves performance and sample efficiency relative to baselines in both discrete and continuous tasks; formal analysis of the optimization problem; code available.

Conclusion: IRPO provides a principled framework to leverage intrinsic rewards for direct extrinsic optimization, addressing credit assignment and sample efficiency issues without subpolicy pretraining; supported by theory and experiments.

Abstract: Exploration is essential in reinforcement learning as an agent relies on trial and error to learn an optimal policy. However, when rewards are sparse, naive exploration strategies, like noise injection, are often insufficient. Intrinsic rewards can also provide principled guidance for exploration by, for example, combining them with extrinsic rewards to optimize a policy or using them to train subpolicies for hierarchical learning. However, the former approach suffers from unstable credit assignment, while the latter exhibits sample inefficiency and sub-optimality. We propose a policy optimization framework that leverages multiple intrinsic rewards to directly optimize a policy for an extrinsic reward without pretraining subpolicies. Our algorithm -- intrinsic reward policy optimization (IRPO) -- achieves this by using a surrogate policy gradient that provides a more informative learning signal than the true gradient in sparse-reward environments. We demonstrate that IRPO improves performance and sample efficiency relative to baselines in discrete and continuous environments, and formally analyze the optimization problem solved by IRPO. Our code is available at https://github.com/Mgineer117/IRPO.

</details>


### [266] [Mitigating Overthinking in Large Reasoning Models via Difficulty-aware Reinforcement Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21418)
*Qian Wan,Ziao Xu,Luona Wei,Xiaoxuan Shen,Jianwen Sun*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: DiPO is a reinforcement-learning-based framework for large reasoning models that learns to model task difficulty and integrate it into policy optimization, reducing overthinking and unnecessary tokens while preserving performance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: LRMs often overthink due to reward-driven preferences after post-training and lack of task-difficulty awareness, leading to inefficient reasoning; existing fixes focus on prompts or training but ignore difficulty-aware resource allocation.

Method: Proposes a difficulty modeling module based on the model’s own reasoning (self-reasoning), integrated into a reinforcement learning loop to modulate generation preferences. Introduces a difficulty-signal-enhanced reward that penalizes lengthy reasoning while accounting for reasoning quality and output format. The approach requires less manual annotation and formalizes task complexity.

Result: The model learns to spontaneously reflect task difficulty, achieving substantial reductions in redundant tokens (overthinking) with no loss (or minimal loss) in task performance due to thought compression.

Conclusion: Incorporating task difficulty signals into RL-based training enables LRMs to adapt inference effort to problem complexity, improving efficiency without sacrificing effectiveness.

Abstract: Large Reasoning Models (LRMs) achieve explicit chain-of-thought expansion by imitating deep thinking behaviors of humans, demonstrating excellent performance in complex task scenarios. However, the deep-thinking mode often leads to unnecessarily lengthy reasoning and resource inefficiency when handling simple tasks. This overthinking phenomenon may arise from the generation preference triggered by the reward function during post-training. Existing research attempts to mitigate overthinking from the perspective of prompt design or model training, but generally underestimates the importance of task difficulty awareness, which makes it difficult for LRMs to effectively allocate reasoning resources. In this paper, we propose Difficulty-aware Policy Optimization (DiPO), a reinforcement learning-based LRM training framework. DiPO encourages LRM to spontaneously model task complexity, and integrates them into reinforcement learning framework to adjust the generation preferences introduced by post-training. A difficulty modeling method based on model self-reasoning is proposed, which significantly reduces the dependence on manual annotation and formalize task complexity. We further develop a difficulty-signal-enhanced reward function that incorporates a penalty for lengthy reasoning while considering reasoning performance and output format. Experimental results indicate that DiPO enables the model to spontaneously adjust inference overhead, significantly reducing redundant tokens without losing performance due to thought compression.

</details>


### [267] [Revisiting Diffusion Model Predictions Through Dimensionality](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21419)
*Qing Jin,Chaoyang Wang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A theoretical framework for diffusion/flow matching with arbitrary prediction targets, showing when x-prediction is optimal based on data geometry; introduces k-Diff to learn the optimal target k from data; empirically improves image generation across latent and pixel spaces.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Recent work shifts from predicting noise or velocity to direct data (x) in high-dimensional settings. A formal explanation for when and why the optimal target depends on data properties is lacking, hindering principled target selection.

Method: Propose a generalized prediction formulation that encompasses ε-, v-, and x-prediction as special cases. Derive an analytical link between data geometry (ambient vs intrinsic dimension) and the optimal target. Introduce k-Diff, a data-driven framework to learn the optimal prediction parameter k without estimating intrinsic dimension. Validate via extensive experiments in latent-space and pixel-space image generation across architectures and scales.

Result: The theory identifies ambient dimensionality as the key factor governing the optimal target. k-Diff consistently outperforms fixed-target baselines, demonstrating improved generative performance across diverse architectures and data scales.

Conclusion: A principled, automated approach to target selection in diffusion/flow models is established. The generalized framework explains when x-prediction is superior and provides a practical method (k-Diff) to learn the optimal target from data, enhancing generation quality without explicit dimension estimation.

Abstract: Recent advances in diffusion and flow matching models have highlighted a shift in the preferred prediction target -- moving from noise ($\varepsilon$) and velocity (v) to direct data (x) prediction -- particularly in high-dimensional settings. However, a formal explanation of why the optimal target depends on the specific properties of the data remains elusive. In this work, we provide a theoretical framework based on a generalized prediction formulation that accommodates arbitrary output targets, of which $\varepsilon$-, v-, and x-prediction are special cases. We derive the analytical relationship between data's geometry and the optimal prediction target, offering a rigorous justification for why x-prediction becomes superior when the ambient dimension significantly exceeds the data's intrinsic dimension. Furthermore, while our theory identifies dimensionality as the governing factor for the optimal prediction target, the intrinsic dimension of manifold-bound data is typically intractable to estimate in practice. To bridge this gap, we propose k-Diff, a framework that employs a data-driven approach to learn the optimal prediction parameter k directly from data, bypassing the need for explicit dimension estimation. Extensive experiments in both latent-space and pixel-space image generation demonstrate that k-Diff consistently outperforms fixed-target baselines across varying architectures and data scales, providing a principled and automated approach to enhancing generative performance.

</details>


### [268] [ConceptMoE: Adaptive Token-to-Concept Compression for Implicit Compute Allocation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21420)
*Zihao Huang,Jundong Zhou,Xingwei Qu,Qiyang Min,Ge Zhang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: ConceptMoE introduces dynamic concept-level token merging to allocate compute adaptively, achieving efficiency and accuracy gains over standard MoE on language and vision-language tasks, including continual training.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Large language models allocate uniform compute across tokens; some sequences are trivially predictable while others require deep reasoning. Adaptive compute allocation at the token/concept level could improve efficiency and performance.

Method: A learnable chunk module partitions token sequences by inter-token similarity into concept representations, compressing sequences to a target ratio R before processing in a concept model. The architecture remains MoE-based, enabling controlled evaluation by reallocate saved computation to match baseline activated FLOPs and total parameters to isolate architectural benefits. Evaluations span language pretraining, long-context understanding, and multimodal benchmarks; continual training with layer looping is also considered.

Result: Across tasks, ConceptMoE yields consistent gains over standard MoE: +0.9 points in language pretraining, +2.3 points in long-context understanding, and +0.6 points in multimodal benchmarks. During continual training with layer looping, gains reach +5.5 points. Efficiency gains include reductions in attention computation up to R^2 and KV cache up to R; at R=2, prefill speedups reach 175% and decoding speedups up to 117% on long sequences.

Conclusion: The approach requires minimal architectural changes and can be integrated into existing MoE frameworks. Adaptive concept-level processing improves both effectiveness and efficiency, with practical applicability demonstrated in continual training and notable runtime improvements.

Abstract: Large language models allocate uniform computation across all tokens, ignoring that some sequences are trivially predictable while others require deep reasoning. We introduce ConceptMoE, which dynamically merges semantically similar tokens into concept representations, performing implicit token-level compute allocation. A learnable chunk module identifies optimal boundaries by measuring inter-token similarity, compressing sequences by a target ratio $R$ before they enter the compute-intensive concept model. Crucially, the MoE architecture enables controlled evaluation: we reallocate saved computation to match baseline activated FLOPs (excluding attention map computation) and total parameters, isolating genuine architectural benefits. Under these conditions, ConceptMoE consistently outperforms standard MoE across language and vision-language tasks, achieving +0.9 points on language pretraining, +2.3 points on long context understanding, and +0.6 points on multimodal benchmarks. When converting pretrained MoE during continual training with layer looping, gains reach +5.5 points, demonstrating practical applicability. Beyond performance, ConceptMoE reduces attention computation by up to $R^2\times$ and KV cache by $R\times$. At $R=2$, empirical measurements show prefill speedups reaching 175\% and decoding speedups up to 117\% on long sequences. The minimal architectural modifications enable straightforward integration into existing MoE, demonstrating that adaptive concept-level processing fundamentally improves both effectiveness and efficiency of large language models.

</details>


### [269] [Lossy Common Information in a Learnable Gray-Wyner Network](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21424)
*Anderson de Andrade,Alon Harell,Ivan V. Bajić*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A three-channel, learnable codec that splits shared (common) and task-specific information across two vision tasks, guided by Gray-Wyner theory; introduces lossy common information and an objective balancing tradeoffs; empirical results show reduced redundancy and improved performance across six benchmarks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Overlapping information across tasks leads to redundancy; conventional codecs ignore shared content. A principled framework (Gray-Wyner) motivates separating common and task-specific signals to improve efficiency in multi-task vision representations.

Method: Develop a learnable three-channel codec that disentangles shared information from task-specific details across tasks. Define and optimize for lossy common information to balance tradeoffs. Compare three codec architectures in two-task scenarios spanning six vision benchmarks.

Result: Redundancy is substantially reduced and independent coding is consistently outperformed across the evaluated tasks and benchmarks.

Conclusion: Bringing Gray-Wyner theory into modern ML enables practical gains in multi-task representation learning by explicitly modeling and exploiting shared information across tasks.

Abstract: Many computer vision tasks share substantial overlapping information, yet conventional codecs tend to ignore this, leading to redundant and inefficient representations. The Gray-Wyner network, a classical concept from information theory, offers a principled framework for separating common and task-specific information. Inspired by this idea, we develop a learnable three-channel codec that disentangles shared information from task-specific details across multiple vision tasks.
