We characterize the limits of this approach through the notion of lossy common information, and propose an optimization objective that balances inherent tradeoffs in learning such representations. Through comparisons of three codec architectures on two-task scenarios spanning six vision benchmarks, we demonstrate that our approach substantially reduces redundancy and consistently outperforms independent coding. These results highlight the practical value of revisiting Gray-Wyner theory in modern machine learning contexts, bridging classic information theory with task-driven representation learning.

</details>


### [270] [From Consistency to Complementarity: Aligned and Disentangled Multi-modal Learning for Time Series Understanding and Reasoning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21436)
*Hang Ni,Weijia Zhang,Fei Wang,Zezhi Shao,Hao Liu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: MADI advances multi-modal LLMs for time-series understanding by enforcing patch-level cross-modal alignment, disentangled interaction of modality-common and modality-unique semantics, and critical-token highlighting, achieving robust and superior reasoning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Cross-modal integration in time-series MLLMs is hampered by fine-grained temporal misalignment across modalities and entanglement between shared and modality-specific semantics, hindering localized interpretation and reasoning.

Method: (1) Patch-level Alignment: enforce fine-grained, physically grounded correspondence across modalities; (2) Discrete Disentangled Interaction: decompose modality-common semantics into compact discrete latent codes and synergize purified modality-unique information; (3) Critical-token Highlighting: emphasize informative, query-relevant signals for robust reasoning.

Result: Empirical results on synthetic and real-world benchmarks show MADI consistently outperforms general-purpose LLMs and time-series-specialized MLLMs.

Conclusion: MADI effectively enables fine-grained cross-modal alignment and disentangled interaction to improve temporal reasoning in multi-modal LLMs.

Abstract: Advances in multi-modal large language models (MLLMs) have inspired time series understanding and reasoning tasks, that enable natural language querying over time series, producing textual analyses of complex temporal dynamics. Recent attempts hybridize numerical time series with their visualized plots, facilitating precise value reasoning and visual structure comprehension for comprehensive time series understanding of MLLMs. However, effective cross-modal integration remains challenging due to fine-grained temporal misalignment across modalities and severe entanglement between shared and modality-specific semantics, which hinder localized interpretation and complementary reasoning. To address these issues, we propose MADI, a multi-modal LLM enhanced with fine-grained alignment and disentangled interaction, featuring (1) Patch-level Alignment, which enforces physically grounded fine-grained correspondence across heterogeneous modalities, (2) Discrete Disentangled Interaction, which separates modality-common semantics into compact discrete latents and adaptively synergizes the purified modality-unique information, and (3) Critical-token Highlighting, which emphasizes informative, query-relevant signals for robust reasoning. Experiments on synthetic and real-world benchmarks show that MADI consistently outperforms general-purpose LLMs and time-series-specialized MLLMs.

</details>


### [271] [Accurate Network Traffic Matrix Prediction via LEAD: an LLM-Enhanced Adapter-Based Conditional Diffusion Model](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21437)
*Yu Sun,Yaqiong Liu,Nan Cheng,Jiayuan Li,Zihan Jia,Xialin Du,Mugen Peng*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A diffusion-basedTM forecasting framework (LEAD) that converts traffic matrices to images, uses a frozen LLM with adapters and dual-conditioning to guide prediction, achieving state-of-the-art RMSE on Abilene and GEANT datasets.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Accurate TM forecasting under stochastic, non-linear, bursty network dynamics is essential for proactive traffic engineering and edge AI, but discriminative models suffer from over-smoothing and limited uncertainty, especially under bursts; existing methods struggle with computation and latency constraints in 6G contexts.

Method: Traffic-to-Image: convert TM to RGB images for global dependencies; Frozen LLM with Trainable Adapter to capture temporal semantics efficiently; Dual-Conditioning Strategy to steer diffusion for dynamic TM; evaluation on Abilene and GEANT.

Result: On Abilene: RMSE reduced by 45.2% vs best baseline; one-step RMSE 0.1098, 20-step 0.1134. On GEANT: RMSE 0.0258 at 20 steps, 27.3% below best baseline.

Conclusion: LEAD demonstrates strong performance gains by combining vision-based TM representation with LLM-guided diffusion, suggesting a viable path for accurate, uncertainty-aware TM forecasting under stringent latency.

Abstract: Driven by the evolution toward 6G and AI-native edge intelligence, network operations increasingly require predictive and risk-aware adaptation under stringent computation and latency constraints. Network Traffic Matrix (TM), which characterizes flow volumes between nodes, is a fundamental signal for proactive traffic engineering. However, accurate TM forecasting remains challenging due to the stochastic, non-linear, and bursty nature of network dynamics. Existing discriminative models often suffer from over-smoothing and provide limited uncertainty awareness, leading to poor fidelity under extreme bursts. To address these limitations, we propose LEAD, a Large Language Model (LLM)-Enhanced Adapter-based conditional Diffusion model. First, LEAD adopts a "Traffic-to-Image" paradigm to transform traffic matrices into RGB images, enabling global dependency modeling via vision backbones. Then, we design a "Frozen LLM with Trainable Adapter" model, which efficiently captures temporal semantics with limited computational cost. Moreover, we propose a Dual-Conditioning Strategy to precisely guide a diffusion model to generate complex, dynamic network traffic matrices. Experiments on the Abilene and GEANT datasets demonstrate that LEAD outperforms all baselines. On the Abilene dataset, LEAD attains a remarkable 45.2% reduction in RMSE against the best baseline, with the error margin rising only marginally from 0.1098 at one-step to 0.1134 at 20-step predictions. Meanwhile, on the GEANT dataset, LEAD achieves a 0.0258 RMSE at 20-step prediction horizon which is 27.3% lower than the best baseline.

</details>


### [272] [Synthetic Pattern Generation and Detection of Financial Activities using Graph Autoencoders](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21446)
*Francesco Zola,Lucia Muñoz,Andrea Venturi,Amaia Gil*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: GAEs trained on synthetic graphs of money-laundering-like patterns; GAE-GCN most robust across patterns; GAEs trained unsupervised via reconstruction error; synthetic data mitigates real-data scarcity.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Overcome scarcity and privacy constraints of labeled illicit-finance graphs by using parametrized synthetic data to study whether GAEs can learn and distinguish topological patterns associated with illicit activity.

Method: Generate seven illicit-pattern synthetic graphs with parametrized generators preserving structural realism. Train three GAEs (GCN, SAGE, GAT) without labels, using reconstruction error as the learning signal. Compare reconstruction performance across patterns.

Result: GAE-GCN provides the most consistent reconstruction across patterns; GAE-SAGE and GAE-GAT are competitive only on a subset of patterns.

Conclusion: Graph-based representation learning on synthetic data is a viable path toward AI-assisted detection of illicit behaviors, helping to mitigate data access limitations.

Abstract: Illicit financial activities such as money laundering often manifest through recurrent topological patterns in transaction networks. Detecting these patterns automatically remains challenging due to the scarcity of labeled real-world data and strict privacy constraints. To address this, we investigate whether Graph Autoencoders (GAEs) can effectively learn and distinguish topological patterns that mimic money laundering operations when trained on synthetic data. The analysis consists of two phases: (i) data generation, where synthetic samples are created for seven well-known illicit activity patterns using parametrized generators that preserve structural consistency while introducing realistic variability; and (ii) model training and validation, where separate GAEs are trained on each pattern without explicit labels, relying solely on reconstruction error as an indicator of learned structure. We compare three GAE implementations based on three distinct convolutional layers: Graph Convolutional (GAE-GCN), GraphSAGE (GAE-SAGE), and Graph Attention Network (GAE-GAT). Experimental results show that GAE-GCN achieves the most consistent reconstruction performance across patterns, while GAE-SAGE and GAE-GAT exhibit competitive results only in few specific patterns. These findings suggest that graph-based representation learning on synthetic data provides a viable path toward developing AI-driven tools for detecting illicit behaviors, overcoming the limitations of financial datasets.

</details>


### [273] [SAGE: Sequence-level Adaptive Gradient Evolution for Generative Recommendation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21452)
*Yu Xie,Xing Kai Ren,Ying Qi,Hu Yao*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: SAGE is proposed to overcome tokenization constraints and gradient issues in OneRec-like LLM-recommender systems by (i) decoupling sequence-level signals to avoid token-level variance and reward collapse, and (ii) introducing asymmetric adaptive dynamics with a Boost Factor for cold-start items and an entropy-aware penalty to maintain diversity, achieving cold-start unblock and stable performance without sacrificing GBPO stability.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To enable efficient reuse of open-source LLM architectures in recommender systems without building a separate token vocabulary, and to address the Symmetric Conservatism in OneRec's GBPO that inhibits updates for cold-start items and risks diversity collapse in high-noise settings.

Method: Introduce SAGE (Sequence-level Adaptive Gradient Evolution) with two core components: (1) Sequence-level Signal Decoupling that uses a geometric mean importance ratio combined with decoupled multi-objective advantages to remove token-level variance and mitigate Reward Collapse; (2) Asymmetric Adaptive Dynamics that defines a dynamic gradient manifold with a Boost Factor to amplify updates for high-potential cold-start items and an Entropy Aware Penalty to prevent information cocoons and encourage exploration.

Result: Theoretical analyses and empirical experiments show that SAGE effectively unlocks cold-start traffic, preserves recommendation diversity, and maintains numerical stability comparable to GBPO, while improving overall performance.

Conclusion: SAGE provides a unified optimization framework for list-wise generative recommendations that simultaneously improves cold-start dynamics and diversity without sacrificing stability, addressing key weaknesses in OneRec/GBPO and enabling easier reuse of open-source LLM architectures.

Abstract: While works such as OneRec have validated the scaling laws of Large Language Models (LLMs) in recommender systems, they rely on a cumbersome separate vocabulary. This dependency prevents the model architecture from reusing native LLM vocabularies, resulting in high maintenance costs and poor scalability. In response, we aim to efficiently reuse open-source LLM architectures without constructing a separate tokenization vocabulary. Furthermore, we identify that the optimization strategy of OneRec Gradient Bounded Policy Optimization (GBPO),suffers from a "Symmetric Conservatism" problem: its static gradient boundaries structurally suppress the update momentum required for cold-start items and fail to prevent diversity collapse in high-noise environments.To address this issue, we propose SAGE (Sequence-level Adaptive Gradient Evolution), a unified optimization framework tailored for list-wise generative recommendation. SAGE introduces two key innovations:(1) Sequence-level Signal Decoupling: By combining a geometric mean importance ratio with decoupled multi-objective advantages, we eliminate token-level variance and resolve the "Reward Collapse" problem. (2) Asymmetric Adaptive Dynamics: We construct a dynamic gradient manifold that applies a "Boost Factor" to high-potential cold start items to achieve super-linear updates and employs an "Entropy Aware Penalty" to break information cocoons. Theoretical analysis and empirical results demonstrate that SAGE effectively unblocks cold-start traffic and sustains recommendation diversity, all while retaining the numerical stability of GBPO.

</details>


### [274] [HER: Human-like Reasoning and Reinforcement Learning for LLM Role-playing](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21459)
*Chengyu Du,Xintao Wang,Aili Chen,Weiyuan Li,Rui Xu,Junteng Liu,Zishan Huang,Rong Tian,Zijun Sun,Yuhao Li,Liheng Feng,Deming Ding,Pengyu Zhao,Yanghua Xiao*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: HER: a dual-layer cognitive framework for persona-based LLM role-play that outperforms a strong baseline on CoSER and Minimax Role-Play, with released datasets and models.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To enable cognitive-level simulation in LLM role-play by addressing lack of high-quality reasoning traces and aligned reward signals, enabling inner-thought-like reasoning while maintaining safety and alignment.

Method: Propose dual-layer thinking; curate reasoning-augmented data via reverse engineering; define human-aligned principles and reward models; train HER models based on Qwen3-32B with supervised learning and RL.

Result: Significant performance gains: +30.26 on CoSER, +14.97 on Minimax Role-Play Bench over Qwen3-32B baseline; robust validation across experiments.

Conclusion: Release datasets, principles, and models; demonstrate feasibility of cognitive simulation in LLM role-play and set resources for future research.

Abstract: LLM role-playing, i.e., using LLMs to simulate specific personas, has emerged as a key capability in various applications, such as companionship, content creation, and digital games. While current models effectively capture character tones and knowledge, simulating the inner thoughts behind their behaviors remains a challenge. Towards cognitive simulation in LLM role-play, previous efforts mainly suffer from two deficiencies: data with high-quality reasoning traces, and reliable reward signals aligned with human preferences. In this paper, we propose HER, a unified framework for cognitive-level persona simulation. HER introduces dual-layer thinking, which distinguishes characters' first-person thinking from LLMs' third-person thinking. To bridge these gaps, we curate reasoning-augmented role-playing data via reverse engineering and construct human-aligned principles and reward models. Leveraging these resources, we train \method models based on Qwen3-32B via supervised and reinforcement learning. Extensive experiments validate the effectiveness of our approach. Notably, our models significantly outperform the Qwen3-32B baseline, achieving a 30.26 improvement on the CoSER benchmark and a 14.97 gain on the Minimax Role-Play Bench. Our datasets, principles, and models will be released to facilitate future research.

</details>


### [275] [L$^3$: Large Lookup Layers](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21461)
*Albert Tseng,Christopher De Sa*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Large Lookup Layer (L^3) generalizes embedding tables to decoder layers, enabling static token-based routing to aggregate multiple embeddings per token, achieving sparse, context-dependent representations with efficient training/inference; outperforms dense and iso-sparse MoEs on language modeling and downstream tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address inefficiencies of Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) dynamic routing (hardware inefficiency, auxiliary losses) and the lack of contextual information in pure tokenizer embeddings by introducing a new, scalable sparsity axis in decoder layers.

Method: Introduce L^3 with static token-based routing that aggregates a set of learned embeddings per token in a context-dependent way; two main components: (1) systems-friendly architecture for fast training and CPU-offloaded inference with no overhead, (2) information-theoretic embedding allocation algorithm to balance speed and quality.

Result: Trained transformers with up to 2.6B active parameters; L^3 substantially outperforms both dense models and iso-sparse MoEs in language modeling and downstream tasks.

Conclusion: L^3 opens a new sparsity axis for decoder layers by leveraging token-based embeddings with context-aware aggregation, enabling efficient memory–compute trade-offs and practical scalability.

Abstract: Modern sparse language models typically achieve sparsity through Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) layers, which dynamically route tokens to dense MLP "experts." However, dynamic hard routing has a number of drawbacks, such as potentially poor hardware efficiency and needing auxiliary losses for stable training. In contrast, the tokenizer embedding table, which is natively sparse, largely avoids these issues by selecting a single embedding per token at the cost of not having contextual information. In this work, we introduce the Large Lookup Layer (L$^3$), which unlocks a new axis of sparsity by generalizing embedding tables to model decoder layers. L$^3$ layers use static token-based routing to aggregate a set of learned embeddings per token in a context-dependent way, allowing the model to efficiently balance memory and compute by caching information in embeddings. L$^3$ has two main components: (1) a systems-friendly architecture that allows for fast training and CPU-offloaded inference with no overhead, and (2) an information-theoretic embedding allocation algorithm that effectively balances speed and quality. We empirically test L$^3$ by training transformers with up to 2.6B active parameters and find that L$^3$ strongly outperforms both dense models and iso-sparse MoEs in both language modeling and downstream tasks.

</details>


### [276] [Partial Feedback Online Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21462)
*Shihao Shao,Cong Fang,Zhouchen Lin,Dacheng Tao*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Near-complete minimax regret characterization for partial-feedback online learning under set realizability; introduces PFLdim and PMSdim; shows deterministic vs randomized separations, and intractability outside realizability; extends to set-valued learning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Because language generation and similar tasks have multiple valid outputs but only a single reference, there is partial feedback; we need new complexity notions beyond standard Littlestone dimension to understand learnability.

Method: Define Partial-Feedback Littlestone dimension (PFLdim) via a collection version space and an auxiliary dimension; develop Partial-Feedback Measure Shattering dimension (PMSdim) for randomized learners; derive tight minimax regret bounds; establish inseparability results under conditions (finite Helly number, nested-inclusion label structure); extend to set-valued online learning; compare to realistic/agnostic variants.

Result: PFLdim exactly characterizes deterministic learnability and minimax regret; PMSdim gives tight bounds for randomized learners; proves broad conditions for deterministic vs randomized inseparability; resolves Raman et al. open question for set-valued learning; shows potential linear regret outside set realizability even for |H|=2, indicating information-theoretic intractability without realizability.

Conclusion: Pushes beyond traditional realizability with new complexity measures; clarifies when partial-feedback learning is feasible; highlights necessity of noise-sensitive measures; implications for language generation and related domains; suggests future work on extending these measures and exploring more general feedback models.

Abstract: We study partial-feedback online learning, where each instance admits a set of correct labels, but the learner only observes one correct label per round; any prediction within the correct set is counted as correct. This model captures settings such as language generation, where multiple responses may be valid but data provide only a single reference. We give a near-complete characterization of minimax regret for both deterministic and randomized learners in the set-realizable regime, i.e., in the regime where sublinear regret is generally attainable. For deterministic learners, we introduce the Partial-Feedback Littlestone dimension (PFLdim) and show it precisely governs learnability and minimax regret; technically, PFLdim cannot be defined via the standard version space, requiring a new collection version space viewpoint and an auxiliary dimension used only in the proof. We further develop the Partial-Feedback Measure Shattering dimension (PMSdim) to obtain tight bounds for randomized learners. We identify broad conditions ensuring inseparability between deterministic and randomized learnability (e.g., finite Helly number or nested-inclusion label structure), and extend the argument to set-valued online learning, resolving an open question of Raman et al. [2024b]. Finally, we show a sharp separation from weaker realistic and agnostic variants: outside set realizability, the problem can become information-theoretically intractable, with linear regret possible even for $|H|=2$. This highlights the need for fundamentally new, noise-sensitive complexity measures to meaningfully characterize learnability beyond set realizability.

</details>


### [277] [A block-coordinate descent framework for non-convex composite optimization. Application to sparse precision matrix estimation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21467)
*Guillaume Lauga*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A general block-coordinate descent (BCD) framework for non-convex composite optimization with convergence guarantees, unifying Graphical Lasso solvers and delivering large iteration-efficiency gains.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the limited theoretical understanding of non-convex optimization and provide a unifying, convergent framework for BCD methods applicable to large-scale problems, notably sparse precision matrix estimation.

Method: Introduce a flexible BCD framework that supports variable-metric proximal gradient updates, proximal Newton updates, and alternating minimization; show that the framework encompasses graphical ISTA, Primal GLasso, and QUIC solvers.

Result: Prove convergence guarantees for the non-convex setting and demonstrate substantial practical efficiency, achieving up to 100-fold reductions in iterations to reach high-quality estimates in sparse precision matrix estimation.

Conclusion: A broadly applicable, convergent BCD framework for non-convex composite optimization that not only unifies major Graphical Lasso solvers but also delivers significant computational speedups in practice.

Abstract: Block-coordinate descent (BCD) is the method of choice to solve numerous large scale optimization problems, however their theoretical study for non-convex optimization, has received less attention. In this paper, we present a new block-coordinate descent (BCD) framework to tackle non-convex composite optimization problems, ensuring decrease of the objective function and convergence to a solution. This framework is general enough to include variable metric proximal gradient updates, proximal Newton updates, and alternated minimization updates. This generality allows to encompass three versions of the most used solvers in the sparse precision matrix estimation problem, deemed Graphical Lasso: graphical ISTA, Primal GLasso, and QUIC. We demonstrate the value of this new framework on non-convex sparse precision matrix estimation problems, providing convergence guarantees and up to a $100$-fold reduction in the number of iterations required to reach state-of-the-art estimation quality.

</details>


### [278] [PPI-SVRG: Unifying Prediction-Powered Inference and Variance Reduction for Semi-Supervised Optimization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21470)
*Ruicheng Ao,Hongyu Chen,Haoyang Liu,David Simchi-Levi,Will Wei Sun*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: PPI and SVRG are two variance-reduction techniques that are shown to be equivalent; the paper unifies them into PPI-SVRG, yielding a convergence bound with the SVRG rate plus an error term from prediction uncertainty. Predictions influence the neighborhood size rather than the rate; perfect predictions recover SVRG, while noisy predictions set an error floor. Empirically, PPI-SVRG yields substantial gains under label scarcity.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To enable efficient stochastic optimization when annotations are scarce but access to pre-trained predictions exists, by unifying prediction-based and gradient-based variance reduction.

Method: Prove mathematical equivalence between Prediction-Perturbed Iterates (PPI) and SVRG; derive PPI-SVRG that combines both approaches; derive decomposition of convergence bound into standard SVRG rate and prediction-induced error floor; analyze dependence on loss geometry and prediction quality; validate on mean estimation benchmarks and MNIST with limited labels.

Result: Convergence bound decomposes into SVRG rate plus a prediction-uncertainty error floor; with perfect predictions, it reduces to SVRG; with degraded predictions, convergence stabilizes within a larger neighborhood; empirical results show 43–52% MSE reduction under label scarcity and 2.7–2.9 percentage point accuracy gain on MNIST with 10% labeled data.

Conclusion: PPI-SVRG is a robust variance-reduction strategy for semi-supervised stochastic optimization: it preserves the SVRG rate in ideal conditions and gracefully degrades with prediction noise, delivering substantial empirical gains under scarce labeling.

Abstract: We study semi-supervised stochastic optimization when labeled data is scarce but predictions from pre-trained models are available. PPI and SVRG both reduce variance through control variates -- PPI uses predictions, SVRG uses reference gradients. We show they are mathematically equivalent and develop PPI-SVRG, which combines both. Our convergence bound decomposes into the standard SVRG rate plus an error floor from prediction uncertainty. The rate depends only on loss geometry; predictions affect only the neighborhood size. When predictions are perfect, we recover SVRG exactly. When predictions degrade, convergence remains stable but reaches a larger neighborhood. Experiments confirm the theory: PPI-SVRG reduces MSE by 43--52\% under label scarcity on mean estimation benchmarks and improves test accuracy by 2.7--2.9 percentage points on MNIST with only 10\% labeled data.

</details>


### [279] [Best Arm Identification with LLM Judges and Limited Human](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21471)
*Ruicheng Ao,Hongyu Chen,Siyang Gao,Hanwei Li,David Simchi-Levi*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A fixed-confidence best-arm identification problem with a biased, context-dependent proxy and selective ground-truth auditing is tackled. The authors show bias leads to persistent mis-selection, and they propose an estimator that fuses proxy scores with inverse-propensity-weighted residuals, plus anytime-valid confidence sequences, to guide an adaptive auditing algorithm achieving near-oracle efficiency.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: In many practical settings (e.g., LLM judges) cheap proxies provide biased cues for arm quality. Unlike standard multi-fidelity BAI, the proxy is biased and ground truth can only be obtained sparingly via auditing. This necessitates bias-aware estimation and selective auditing to avoid waste and mis-selection.

Method: 1) Develop a mean estimator that combines proxy information with inverse-propensity-weighted residuals. 2) Construct anytime-valid confidence sequences for this estimator. 3) Propose an adaptive algorithm that concentrates audits on uncertain contexts and close arms, using a plug-in Neyman rule for near-oracle audit efficiency.

Result: Demonstrate that without bias correction and propensity adjustment, mis-selection probability may not vanish even with unlimited proxy data. The proposed estimator + confidence sequences enable effective adaptive auditing, achieving near-oracle efficiency, with theoretical guarantees and favorable empirical performance in simulations.

Conclusion: Accounting for bias and selective auditing is crucial in fixed-confidence BAI with proxies. The proposed framework provides bias-corrected estimation, valid uncertainty quantification, and an efficient audit strategy, improving accuracy and resource use. The results suggest strong performance and potential applicability to real-world auditing scenarios with biased proxies.

Abstract: We study fixed-confidence best-arm identification (BAI) where a cheap but potentially biased proxy (e.g., LLM judge) is available for every sample, while an expensive ground-truth label can only be acquired selectively when using a human for auditing. Unlike classical multi-fidelity BAI, the proxy is biased (arm- and context-dependent) and ground truth is selectively observed. Consequently, standard multi-fidelity methods can mis-select the best arm, and uniform auditing, though accurate, wastes scarce resources and is inefficient. We prove that without bias correction and propensity adjustment, mis-selection probability may not vanish (even with unlimited proxy data). We then develop an estimator for the mean of each arm that combines proxy scores with inverse-propensity-weighted residuals and form anytime-valid confidence sequences for that estimator. Based on the estimator and confidence sequence, we propose an algorithm that adaptively selects and audits arms. The algorithm concentrates audits on unreliable contexts and close arms and we prove that a plug-in Neyman rule achieves near-oracle audit efficiency. Numerical experiments confirm the theoretical guarantees and demonstrate the superior empirical performance of the proposed algorithm.

</details>


### [280] [ETS: Energy-Guided Test-Time Scaling for Training-Free RL Alignment](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21484)
*Xiuyu Li,Jinkai Zhang,Mingyang Yi,Yu Li,Longqiang Wang,Yue Wang,Ju Fan*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Training-free inference method that samples from an optimal RL policy for language models by combining a reference policy with an energy term; Energy-Guided Test-Time Scaling (ETS) estimates the energy online via Monte Carlo with convergence guarantees, enabling efficient, high-quality generation across MLM and diffusion-based LMs.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To bypass costly and unstable RL post-training alignment by enabling direct sampling from an optimal policy at test time, reducing training complexity and latency.

Method: Define transition probability as a product of a reference policy and an energy term; estimate the energy term online using Monte Carlo with convergence guarantees; accelerate inference with modern frameworks and tailored importance sampling to maintain sampling quality while reducing latency.

Result: Empirical results show ETS improves generation quality across MLMs (autoregressive and diffusion language models) on reasoning, coding, and science benchmarks, with substantial latency reductions and preserved sampling fidelity.

Conclusion: ETS provides a training-free, provably convergent, efficient approach for sampling from the optimal RL policy in language models, enabling practical deployment without costly RL post-training.

Abstract: Reinforcement Learning (RL) post-training alignment for language models is effective, but also costly and unstable in practice, owing to its complicated training process. To address this, we propose a training-free inference method to sample directly from the optimal RL policy. The transition probability applied to Masked Language Modeling (MLM) consists of a reference policy model and an energy term. Based on this, our algorithm, Energy-Guided Test-Time Scaling (ETS), estimates the key energy term via online Monte Carlo, with a provable convergence rate. Moreover, to ensure practical efficiency, ETS leverages modern acceleration frameworks alongside tailored importance sampling estimators, substantially reducing inference latency while provably preserving sampling quality. Experiments on MLM (including autoregressive models and diffusion language models) across reasoning, coding, and science benchmarks show that our ETS consistently improves generation quality, validating its effectiveness and design.

</details>


### [281] [Task-Awareness Improves LLM Generations and Uncertainty](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21500)
*Tim Tomov,Dominik Fuchsgruber,Stephan Günnemann*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A latent-structure Bayesian decoding framework for LLMs that computes Bayes-optimal outputs in a task-specific latent space, surpassing standard decoding and enabling uncertainty via Bayesian risk.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current decoding and uncertainty estimation operate in language space and ignore latent structural information (labels, numbers, graphs). Incorporating latent structure can improve accuracy, reliability, and task alignment.

Method: Model LLM outputs directly in a task-dependent latent structure; define a dissimilarity measure on the latent space; compute Bayes-optimal responses by combining individual latent outputs; quantify uncertainty via Bayesian risk.

Result: Bayes-optimal responses consistently outperform beam search across tasks; Bayesian risk-based uncertainty correlates with output quality/correctness and improves alignment.

Conclusion: The decision-theoretic latent-structure framework is broadly applicable to any problem with latent response structure, enabling more reliable task-aware LLM predictions.

Abstract: In many applications of LLMs, natural language responses often have an underlying structure such as representing discrete labels, numerical values, or graphs. Yet, existing decoding and uncertainty estimation methods operate only in language space and largely disregard structural information. We address this by modeling LLM outputs directly in a task-dependent latent structure. By equipping this structure with a dissimilarity measure, we can compute Bayes-optimal responses. These are not selected from sampled generations but are newly synthesized by combining individual responses in the latent space. Across different tasks, Bayes-optimal responses consistently outperform standard decoding methods like beam search. Moreover, quantifying uncertainty via the induced Bayesian risk captures variations in terms of the latent structure and improves alignment with output quality and correctness. Our decision-theoretic framework is applicable to any problem that admits a latent response structure and enables reliable task-aware LLM predictions.

</details>


### [282] [Cascaded Transfer: Learning Many Tasks under Budget Constraints](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21513)
*Eloi Campagne,Yvenn Amara-Ouali,Yannig Goude,Mathilde Mougeot,Argyris Kalogeratos*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces Cascaded Transfer Learning for many-task problems with unknown task relationships; builds a rooted tree of tasks and transfers knowledge cascaded along its edges, guided by a minimum spanning tree budget allocation to improve accuracy under cost constraints.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: In many-task learning, relating a large set of tasks when their interdependencies are unknown is difficult; effective knowledge transfer must be budget-aware to ensure scalable performance.

Method: Proposes a cascaded transfer mechanism arranged over a minimum spanning tree that connects tasks by a distance measure; uses a rooted tree to define the learning order and allocates the training budget along branches, enabling hierarchical parameter transfer among same-class models.

Result: Empirical studies on synthetic and real-world many-task settings show the method achieves higher accuracy and more cost-effective adaptation across large task collections than alternative approaches.

Conclusion: Cascaded Transfer Learning offers a scalable, budget-aware framework for cross-task knowledge transfer in many-task learning, improving accuracy while respecting resource constraints.

Abstract: Many-Task Learning refers to the setting where a large number of related tasks need to be learned, the exact relationships between tasks are not known. We introduce the Cascaded Transfer Learning, a novel many-task transfer learning paradigm where information (e.g. model parameters) cascades hierarchically through tasks that are learned by individual models of the same class, while respecting given budget constraints. The cascade is organized as a rooted tree that specifies the order in which tasks are learned and refined. We design a cascaded transfer mechanism deployed over a minimum spanning tree structure that connects the tasks according to a suitable distance measure, and allocates the available training budget along its branches. Experiments on synthetic and real many-task settings show that the resulting method enables more accurate and cost effective adaptation across large task collections compared to alternative approaches.

</details>


### [283] [A Unified SPD Token Transformer Framework for EEG Classification: Systematic Comparison of Geometric Embeddings](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21521)
*Chi-Sheng Chen,En-Jui Kuo,Guan-Ying Chen,Xinyu Zhang,Fan Zhang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: The paper links SPD embedding geometry to optimization dynamics, deriving gradient-conditioning, normalization, and distance-preservation results; and shows a Log-Euclidean Transformer achieves state-of-the-art across EEG tasks, with BWSPD offering competitive performance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address how embedding choices for SPD matrices (EEG covariance on SPD manifold) affect training stability, gradient conditioning, and empirical performance, bridging geometry with optimization dynamics.

Method: Theoretical analysis using Daleckii–Krein matrices to compare gradient conditioning of BWSPD vs Log-Euclidean; derivation of Embedding-Space Batch Normalization (BN-Embed) error; proof of bi-Lipschitz distance preservation for BWSPD; large-scale empirical evaluation (≈1,500 runs, 3 EEG paradigms, 36 subjects) comparing BWSPD, Log-Euclidean, and Euclidean embeddings within a unified Transformer framework.

Result: (1) BWSPD achieves sqrt(κ) gradient conditioning vs κ for Log-Euclidean in high dimensions (d≥22); advantage diminishes for low dimensions (d≤8) due to eigendecomposition overhead. (2) BN-Embed approximates Riemannian normalization to O(ε^2); yields +26% accuracy on 56-channel ERP data, negligible effect on 8-channel SSVEP data, in line with channel-count predictions. (3) bi-Lipschitz bounds show BWSPD preserves manifold distances with distortion governed solely by κ.; (4) Log-Euclidean Transformer attains state-of-the-art across motor imagery, ERP, SSVEP datasets; BWSPD competitive with similar training time.

Conclusion: Embedding geometry matters for optimization on SPD manifolds; Log-Euclidean embedding with a Transformer provides best overall performance across EEG tasks, while BWSPD offers competitive accuracy with favorable conditioning in certain regimes; theory aligns with empirical findings across channel counts and paradigms.

Abstract: Spatial covariance matrices of EEG signals are Symmetric Positive Definite (SPD) and lie on a Riemannian manifold, yet the theoretical connection between embedding geometry and optimization dynamics remains unexplored. We provide a formal analysis linking embedding choice to gradient conditioning and numerical stability for SPD manifolds, establishing three theoretical results: (1) BWSPD's $\sqrtκ$ gradient conditioning (vs $κ$ for Log-Euclidean) via Daleckii-Kreĭn matrices provides better gradient conditioning on high-dimensional inputs ($d \geq 22$), with this advantage reducing on low-dimensional inputs ($d \leq 8$) where eigendecomposition overhead dominates; (2) Embedding-Space Batch Normalization (BN-Embed) approximates Riemannian normalization up to $O(\varepsilon^2)$ error, yielding $+26\%$ accuracy on 56-channel ERP data but negligible effect on 8-channel SSVEP data, matching the channel-count-dependent prediction; (3) bi-Lipschitz bounds prove BWSPD tokens preserve manifold distances with distortion governed solely by the condition ratio $κ$. We validate these predictions via a unified Transformer framework comparing BWSPD, Log-Euclidean, and Euclidean embeddings within identical architecture across 1,500+ runs on three EEG paradigms (motor imagery, ERP, SSVEP; 36 subjects). Our Log-Euclidean Transformer achieves state-of-the-art performance on all datasets, substantially outperforming classical Riemannian classifiers and recent SPD baselines, while BWSPD offers competitive accuracy with similar training time.

</details>


### [284] [More Bang for the Buck: Improving the Inference of Large Language Models at a Fixed Budget using Reset and Discard (ReD)](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21522)
*Sagi Meir,Tommer D. Keidar,Noam Levi,Shlomi Reuveni,Barak Hirshberg*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes Reset-and-Discard (ReD) to improve coverage@cost for evaluating LLMs by exploiting the observed power-law behavior of pass@k. ReD increases unique question coverage under a fixed budget, allows predicting savings and inferring the power-law exponent, and demonstrates cost-efficient evaluation on HumanEval across three models.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Evaluation of LLMs under budget constraints often uses pass@k, but at fixed budgets this yields diminishing returns. A metric like coverage@cost captures how many unique questions are answered as a function of attempts. The work connects these metrics and offers a method to optimize coverage and to infer or predict power-law exponents.

Method: Introduce Reset-and-Discard (ReD), a query strategy that, given a fixed budget, increases coverage@cost by resetting the model and discarding unproductive attempts to maximize the number of unique questions answered. The method provides a way to predict, from a given pass@k, the expected saving in total attempts, and can infer the power-law exponent if pass@k is not available.

Result: Empirical results on three LLMs using HumanEval show that ReD substantially reduces the number of attempts, tokens, and USD cost needed to reach a target coverage, while also enabling efficient measurement of inference power-laws.

Conclusion: ReD offers a universal, budget-aware querying strategy to boost coverage@cost, enabling more cost-effective evaluation of LLMs and providing mechanisms to predict savings and infer power-law exponents, with demonstrated gains on standard benchmarks.

Abstract: The performance of large language models (LLMs) on verifiable tasks is usually measured by pass@k, the probability of answering a question correctly at least once in k trials. At a fixed budget, a more suitable metric is coverage@cost, the average number of unique questions answered as a function of the total number of attempts. We connect the two metrics and show that the empirically-observed power-law behavior in pass@k leads to a sublinear growth of the coverage@cost (diminishing returns). To solve this problem, we propose Reset-and-Discard (ReD), a query method of LLMs that increases coverage@cost for any given budget, regardless of the pass@k form. Moreover, given a pass@k, we can quantitatively predict the savings in the total number of attempts using ReD. If pass@k is not available for the model, ReD can infer its power-law exponent. Experiments on three LLMs using HumanEval demonstrate that ReD substantially reduces the required attempts, tokens, and USD cost to reach a desired coverage, while also offering an efficient way to measure inference power-laws.

</details>


### [285] [Explicit Credit Assignment through Local Rewards and Dependence Graphs in Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21523)
*Bang Giang Le,Viet Cuong Ta*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A graph-based credit assignment method for cooperative MARL that blends global and local rewards by using an approximated interaction graph to attribute contributions more finely than a global reward while maintaining faster learning from local rewards; empirically improves over standard reward settings.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Fully cooperative MARL suffers from noisy global rewards and credit assignment challenges; local rewards speed learning but can be suboptimal for global coordination. A method that combines both aims to retain cooperation benefits while enabling effective credit attribution.

Method: Constructs an interaction graph among agents to capture fine-grained contributions. Uses this graph to derive agent-specific credit signals that lie between the global reward and pure local rewards. Proposes a practical approach to approximate the interaction graph for scalability and applicability.

Result: Experimental results show the proposed graph-based credit assignment yields improvements over traditional local and global reward baselines, demonstrating flexibility across scenarios.

Conclusion: A graph-informed credit assignment framework bridges the gap between local and global rewards, offering a practical, scalable approach to improve cooperation and learning efficiency in MARL.

Abstract: To promote cooperation in Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning, the reward signals of all agents can be aggregated together, forming global rewards that are commonly known as the fully cooperative setting. However, global rewards are usually noisy because they contain the contributions of all agents, which have to be resolved in the credit assignment process. On the other hand, using local reward benefits from faster learning due to the separation of agents' contributions, but can be suboptimal as agents myopically optimize their own reward while disregarding the global optimality. In this work, we propose a method that combines the merits of both approaches. By using a graph of interaction between agents, our method discerns the individual agent contribution in a more fine-grained manner than a global reward, while alleviating the cooperation problem with agents' local reward. We also introduce a practical approach for approximating such a graph. Our experiments demonstrate the flexibility of the approach, enabling improvements over the traditional local and global reward settings.

</details>


### [286] [Visual-Guided Key-Token Regularization for Multimodal Large Language Model Unlearning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22020)
*Chengyi Cai,Zesheng Ye,Peike Li,Bo Han,Jianzhong Qi,Feng Liu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: ViKeR introduces visual-guided key-token regularization for unlearning in multimodal LLMs, using irrelevant visuals to shape token-level post-unlearning distributions and entropy-based key-token weighting with gradient reweighting; shows improved unlearning with reduced forgetting on MLLMU and CLEAR.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Unlearning in multimodal LLMs is needed to prevent leakage of private image information; existing approaches treat output tokens uniformly and ignore visual cues, leading to suboptimal unlearning and potential leakage.

Method: Propose Visual-Guided Key-Token Regularization (ViKeR): identify key tokens via information entropy; use irrelevant visual inputs to predict ideal post-unlearning token distributions; regularize the model to align outputs with these distributions; apply token-level gradient reweighting to amplify updates on key tokens.

Result: Experiments on MLLMU and CLEAR benchmarks show effective unlearning while mitigating forgetting and maintaining response coherence.

Conclusion: ViKeR demonstrates that leveraging visual context and information-theoretic token importance improves unlearning in multimodal LLMs and provides a practical framework for privacy-preserving AI in multimodal settings.

Abstract: Unlearning in Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) prevents the model from revealing private information when queried about target images. Existing MLLM unlearning methods largely adopt approaches developed for LLMs. They treat all answer tokens uniformly, disregarding their varying importance in the unlearning process. Moreover, these methods focus exclusively on the language modality, disregarding visual cues that indicate key tokens in answers. In this paper, after formulating the problem of unlearning in multimodal question answering for MLLMs, we propose Visual-Guided Key-Token Regularization (ViKeR). We leverage irrelevant visual inputs to predict ideal post-unlearning token-level distributions and use these distributions to regularize the unlearning process, thereby prioritizing key tokens. Further, we define key tokens in unlearning via information entropy and discuss ViKeR's effectiveness through token-level gradient reweighting, which amplifies updates on key tokens. Experiments on MLLMU and CLEAR benchmarks demonstrate that our method effectively performs unlearning while mitigating forgetting and maintaining response coherence.

</details>


### [287] [Fast and Geometrically Grounded Lorentz Neural Networks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21529)
*Robert van der Klis,Ricardo Chávez Torres,Max van Spengler,Yuhui Ding,Thomas Hofmann,Pascal Mettes*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes a distance-to-hyperplane-based Lorentz linear layer to fix scaling issues in hyperbolic neural networks, achieving linear growth of hyperbolic output norms with gradient steps and offering efficiency gains via activation functions and caching.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Hyperbolic geometry provides compact, hierarchical representations. However, existing Lorentz linear layers cause the hyperbolic norms of outputs to scale logarithmically with gradient steps, eroding the benefits. A formulation that preserves hyperbolic geometry while being computationally efficient is needed.

Method: Introduce a Lorentz linear layer based on the distance-to-hyperplane formulation. Provide theoretical proofs that output hyperbolic norms scale linearly with the number of gradient descent steps. Enhance efficiency with Lorentzian activation functions and a new caching strategy, enabling practical hyperbolic networks.

Result: Theoretically established linear scaling of output hyperbolic norms with respect to gradient steps. Demonstrated efficiency gains through activations and caching. Codebase released for replication and further development.

Conclusion: The proposed formulation preserves hyperbolic geometry in neural networks, reducing the computation gap to Euclidean networks and enabling more practical, scalable hyperbolic models.

Abstract: Hyperbolic space is quickly gaining traction as a promising geometry for hierarchical and robust representation learning. A core open challenge is the development of a mathematical formulation of hyperbolic neural networks that is both efficient and captures the key properties of hyperbolic space. The Lorentz model of hyperbolic space has been shown to enable both fast forward and backward propagation. However, we prove that, with the current formulation of Lorentz linear layers, the hyperbolic norms of the outputs scale logarithmically with the number of gradient descent steps, nullifying the key advantage of hyperbolic geometry. We propose a new Lorentz linear layer grounded in the well-known ``distance-to-hyperplane" formulation. We prove that our formulation results in the usual linear scaling of output hyperbolic norms with respect to the number of gradient descent steps. Our new formulation, together with further algorithmic efficiencies through Lorentzian activation functions and a new caching strategy results in neural networks fully abiding by hyperbolic geometry while simultaneously bridging the computation gap to Euclidean neural networks. Code available at: https://github.com/robertdvdk/hyperbolic-fully-connected.

</details>


### [288] [Multi-Modal Time Series Prediction via Mixture of Modulated Experts](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21547)
*Lige Zhang,Ali Maatouk,Jialin Chen,Leandros Tassiulas,Rex Ying*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A novel Expert Modulation framework (MoME) for multi-modal time series forecasting that uses textual signals to condition both routing and expert computation in a Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architecture, addressing token-level fusion limitations and improving prediction accuracy; code available on GitHub.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Real-world time series are dynamic and challenging to forecast. Multi-modal methods using text (e.g., news) often rely on token-level fusion, which underperforms when time-text pairs are scarce and when time-series scales vary, hindering cross-modal alignment.

Method: Introduce Expert Modulation (MoME), a cross-modal paradigm that conditions MoE routing and expert computations on textual signals, enabling direct cross-modal control over expert behavior. This leverages a Mixture-of-Experts framework with text-informed gating and expert modulation.

Result: Theoretical analysis accompanied by comprehensive experiments show substantial improvements in multi-modal time series prediction compared to baselines.

Conclusion: MoME provides efficient cross-modal control of expert behavior in MoE for time series forecasting and demonstrates strong empirical gains; the approach addresses alignment issues in token-level fusion and is complemented by publicly available code.

Abstract: Real-world time series exhibit complex and evolving dynamics, making accurate forecasting extremely challenging. Recent multi-modal forecasting methods leverage textual information such as news reports to improve prediction, but most rely on token-level fusion that mixes temporal patches with language tokens in a shared embedding space. However, such fusion can be ill-suited when high-quality time-text pairs are scarce and when time series exhibit substantial variation in scale and characteristics, thus complicating cross-modal alignment. In parallel, Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architectures have proven effective for both time series modeling and multi-modal learning, yet many existing MoE-based modality integration methods still depend on token-level fusion. To address this, we propose Expert Modulation, a new paradigm for multi-modal time series prediction that conditions both routing and expert computation on textual signals, enabling direct and efficient cross-modal control over expert behavior. Through comprehensive theoretical analysis and experiments, our proposed method demonstrates substantial improvements in multi-modal time series prediction. The current code is available at https://github.com/BruceZhangReve/MoME

</details>


### [289] [HistoPrism: Unlocking Functional Pathway Analysis from Pan-Cancer Histology via Gene Expression Prediction](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21560)
*Susu Hu,Qinghe Zeng,Nithya Bhasker,Jakob Nicolas Kather,Stefanie Speidel*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Transformer-based pan-cancer model (HistoPrism) predicts spatial gene expression from H&E histology, with pathway-level evaluation showing improved biological coherence and cross-cancer generalization.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Need generalizable models across cancer types and biologically meaningful signals; prior work focused on per-cancer, variance-based metrics with limited functional interpretation.

Method: Efficient transformer-based architecture (HistoPrism) for pan-cancer gene expression prediction from histology; introduces a pathway-level benchmark to assess coherent functional pathways rather than individual gene variance.

Result: Outperforms previous state-of-the-art on highly variable genes and achieves substantial gains at pathway level; demonstrates recovery of coherent transcriptomic patterns; benefits from pan-cancer generalization and improved efficiency.

Conclusion: HistoPrism sets a new standard for clinically relevant transcriptomic modeling from histology by delivering biologically coherent, generalizable, and efficient predictions.

Abstract: Predicting spatial gene expression from H&E histology offers a scalable and clinically accessible alternative to sequencing, but realizing clinical impact requires models that generalize across cancer types and capture biologically coherent signals. Prior work is often limited to per-cancer settings and variance-based evaluation, leaving functional relevance underexplored. We introduce HistoPrism, an efficient transformer-based architecture for pan-cancer prediction of gene expression from histology. To evaluate biological meaning, we introduce a pathway-level benchmark, shifting assessment from isolated gene-level variance to coherent functional pathways. HistoPrism not only surpasses prior state-of-the-art models on highly variable genes , but also more importantly, achieves substantial gains on pathway-level prediction, demonstrating its ability to recover biologically coherent transcriptomic patterns. With strong pan-cancer generalization and improved efficiency, HistoPrism establishes a new standard for clinically relevant transcriptomic modeling from routinely available histology.

</details>


### [290] [SAL: Selective Adaptive Learning for Backpropagation-Free Training with Sparsification](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21561)
*Fanping Liu,Hua Yang,Jiasi Zou*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: SAL proposes selective adaptive learning that partitions parameters into sample-dependent regions to reduce gradient interference and relax weight symmetry, achieving competitive convergence and scalability up to 1B parameters and 128-layer networks across 10 benchmarks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address intrinsic limitations of Backpropagation: biologically implausible weight symmetry, gradient interference in dense representations, and scalability concerns in deep/large models; seek a plausible, scalable alternative.

Method: Selective parameter activation with adaptive area partitioning; decomposes the parameter space into mutually exclusive, sample-dependent regions; decouples gradient flows to mitigate interference across divergent semantic patterns; uses refined feedback alignment to address weight symmetry.

Result: Empirical results show competitive convergence rates and improved classification accuracy across 10 benchmarks; SAL exhibits numerical consistency and competitive performance in deep regimes (up to 128 layers) and large-scale models (up to 1B parameters).

Conclusion: SAL offers a biologically inspired, scalable alternative to Backpropagation, contributing to the study of training large neural networks and enabling plausible, efficient learning with reduced gradient interference.

Abstract: Standard deep learning relies on Backpropagation (BP), which is constrained by biologically implausible weight symmetry and suffers from significant gradient interference within dense representations. To mitigate these bottlenecks, we propose Selective Adaptive Learning (SAL), a training method that combines selective parameter activation with adaptive area partitioning. Specifically, SAL decomposes the parameter space into mutually exclusive, sample-dependent regions. This decoupling mitigates gradient interference across divergent semantic patterns and addresses explicit weight symmetry requirements through our refined feedback alignment. Empirically, SAL demonstrates competitive convergence rates, leading to improved classification performance across 10 standard benchmarks. Additionally, SAL achieves numerical consistency and competitive accuracy even in deep regimes (up to 128 layers) and large-scale models (up to 1B parameters). Our approach is loosely inspired by biological learning mechanisms, offering a plausible alternative that contributes to the study of scalable neural network training.

</details>


### [291] [Representation Unlearning: Forgetting through Information Compression](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21564)
*Antonio Almudévar,Alfonso Ortega*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Represents unlearning in the model's representation space via an information bottleneck, using variational surrogates; supports both full data and zero-shot forgetting, yielding better forgetting, utility, and efficiency than parameter-based baselines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Privacy regulations and robustness concerns motivate removing the influence of specific training data. Parameter-centric unlearning can be unstable, costly, and rely on local approximations; a representation-space approach aims for global, efficient forgetting.

Method: Propose Representation Unlearning: learn a transformation on representations that enforces an information bottleneck by maximizing mutual information with retained data and minimizing information about forgotten data. Derive tractable variational surrogates and instantiate them in two regimes: (1) retain+forget data available; (2) zero-shot where only forget data is accessible.

Result: Empirical evaluation across several benchmarks shows more reliable forgetting, better utility retention, and lower computational cost than parameter-centric baselines.

Conclusion: Representation Unlearning offers a practical, efficient alternative to updating model parameters for forgetting. It demonstrates robustness and efficiency gains, with potential for broader applicability; future work could explore scalability, integration with diverse architectures, and detailed privacy guarantees.

Abstract: Machine unlearning seeks to remove the influence of specific training data from a model, a need driven by privacy regulations and robustness concerns. Existing approaches typically modify model parameters, but such updates can be unstable, computationally costly, and limited by local approximations. We introduce Representation Unlearning, a framework that performs unlearning directly in the model's representation space. Instead of modifying model parameters, we learn a transformation over representations that imposes an information bottleneck: maximizing mutual information with retained data while suppressing information about data to be forgotten. We derive variational surrogates that make this objective tractable and show how they can be instantiated in two practical regimes: when both retain and forget data are available, and in a zero-shot setting where only forget data can be accessed. Experiments across several benchmarks demonstrate that Representation Unlearning achieves more reliable forgetting, better utility retention, and greater computational efficiency than parameter-centric baselines.

</details>


### [292] [FlexCausal: Flexible Causal Disentanglement via Structural Flow Priors and Manifold-Aware Interventions](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21567)
*Yutao Jin,Yuang Tao,Junyong Zhai*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: FlexCausal introduces a block-diagonal covariance VAE with a Factorized Flow-based Prior to model non-Gaussian exogenous noise and disentangle causal factors, guided by supervised alignment, counterfactual constraints, and a manifold-aware intervention strategy, achieving state-of-the-art results on synthetic and real data.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Standard mean-field diagonally-parameterized posteriors and isotropic Gaussian priors conflate latent factors and hinder accurate causal disentanglement; real-world exogenous noise exhibits non-Gaussian statistics requiring richer priors.

Method: Use a block-diagonal covariance VAE to allow latent subspaces; Factorized Flow-based Prior to model exogenous noise; supervised alignment with ground-truth causal structure; counterfactual consistency constraints; manifold-aware relative intervention for high-fidelity generation.

Result: Experimental results on synthetic and real-world datasets show FlexCausal significantly outperforms competing methods.

Conclusion: FlexCausal provides precise structural correspondence between latent subspaces and causal relations and decouples learning of causal mechanisms from distributional statistics via richer priors and interventions.

Abstract: Causal Disentangled Representation Learning(CDRL) aims to learn and disentangle low dimensional representations and their underlying causal structure from observations. However, existing disentanglement methods rely on a standard mean-field approximation with a diagonal posterior covariance, which decorrelates all latent dimensions. Additionally, these methods often assume isotropic Gaussian priors for exogenous noise, failing to capture the complex, non-Gaussian statistical properties prevalent in real-world causal factors. Therefore, we propose FlexCausal, a novel CDRL framework based on a block-diagonal covariance VAE. FlexCausal utilizes a Factorized Flow-based Prior to realistically model the complex densities of exogenous noise, effectively decoupling the learning of causal mechanisms from distributional statistics. By integrating supervised alignment objectives with counterfactual consistency constraints, our framework ensures a precise structural correspondence between the learned latent subspaces and the ground-truth causal relations. Finally, we introduce a manifold-aware relative intervention strategy to ensure high-fidelity generation. Experimental results on both synthetic and real-world datasets demonstrate that FlexCausal significantly outperforms other methods.

</details>


### [293] [Bridging Functional and Representational Similarity via Usable Information](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21568)
*Antonio Almudévar,Alfonso Ortega*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Unified usable-information framework linking functional and representational similarity, revealing symmetry/asymmetry of stitching, estimator relationships for reconstruction-based metrics, and a task-granularity hierarchy culminating in input reconstruction as the most granular representation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Bridge disparate similarity notions (functional and representational) using a single information-theoretic quantity (usable information) and clarify how observer capacity affects perceived similarity.

Method: Theoretical derivations and proofs: (i) link between stitching performance and conditional mutual information; (ii) proof of asymmetry in stitching requiring bidirectional analysis; (iii) demonstration that reconstruction-based metrics and tools (CKA, RSA) estimate usable information under constraints; (iv) argument that similarity depends on predictive family capacity; (v) establish task-granularity hierarchy showing that similarity on fine-grained tasks implies similarity on coarser tasks; (vi) position input reconstruction as the limit of granularity.

Result: Proved: stitching performance is tied to conditional mutual information and is asymmetric; reconstruction-based metrics and common representational similarity tools estimate usable information under certain constraints; similarity is contingent on observer/predictive capacity; representational similarity is sufficient but not necessary for functional similarity; a hierarchy where complex-task similarity implies coarser similarity; input reconstruction represents maximal granularity.

Conclusion: The framework unifies functional and representational similarity through usable information, clarifies when these notions align, and highlights the role of task granularity and observer capacity. It also legitimizes common metrics as estimators and sets constraints for interpreting their results.

Abstract: We present a unified framework for quantifying the similarity between representations through the lens of \textit{usable information}, offering a rigorous theoretical and empirical synthesis across three key dimensions. First, addressing functional similarity, we establish a formal link between stitching performance and conditional mutual information. We further reveal that stitching is inherently asymmetric, demonstrating that robust functional comparison necessitates a bidirectional analysis rather than a unidirectional mapping. Second, concerning representational similarity, we prove that reconstruction-based metrics and standard tools (e.g., CKA, RSA) act as estimators of usable information under specific constraints. Crucially, we show that similarity is relative to the capacity of the predictive family: representations that appear distinct to a rigid observer may be identical to a more expressive one. Third, we demonstrate that representational similarity is sufficient but not necessary for functional similarity. We unify these concepts through a task-granularity hierarchy: similarity on a complex task guarantees similarity on any coarser derivative, establishing representational similarity as the limit of maximum granularity: input reconstruction.

</details>


### [294] [Shaping capabilities with token-level data filtering](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21571)
*Neil Rathi,Alec Radford*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Token-level filtering during pretraining can effectively reduce undesired capabilities in language models, outperforming document-level filtering, and scales well with model size while preserving alignment on targeted domains; it introduces a token-labeling pipeline using sparse autoencoders and cheap classifiers and is robust to noisy labels under sufficient compute.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Post hoc safety measures are often bypassed by adversaries. Shaping capabilities at pretraining time offers a more robust defense. The abstract uses a medical capability removal proxy to demonstrate the viability of data filtering as a scalable safety intervention.

Method: Compare token-level versus document-level data filtering during pretraining. Develop a token-labeling pipeline: use sparse autoencoders to label tokens, distill cheap classifiers to filter tokens, and apply this filtering to pretraining data. Evaluate across model scales, analyze compute implications, and assess whether models maintain alignment on a forget-domain task.

Result: Token filtering achieves the same reduction in undesired capabilities as document filtering but at lower cost to benign performance. Scaling improves effectiveness with model size; the largest models exhibit a substantial (reported as 7000x) compute slowdown on the forget domain. Models trained with token filtering can still be aligned on the forget domain. They also introduce a token-labeling technique based on sparse autoencoders and cheap classifiers, and show robustness to noisy labels given sufficient pretraining compute.

Conclusion: Token-level data filtering is a scalable and effective pretraining intervention to mitigate undesired capabilities, outperforming document-level filtering while preserving benign behavior and alignment on target domains. The work provides a practical labeling methodology and demonstrates robustness to label noise; future work should clarify metrics and extend to more domains and capability types.

Abstract: Current approaches to reducing undesired capabilities in language models are largely post hoc, and can thus be easily bypassed by adversaries. A natural alternative is to shape capabilities during pretraining itself. On the proxy task of removing medical capabilities, we show that the simple intervention of filtering pretraining data is highly effective, robust, and inexpensive at scale. Inspired by work on data attribution, we show that filtering tokens is more effective than filtering documents, achieving the same hit to undesired capabilities at a lower cost to benign ones. Training models spanning two orders of magnitude, we then demonstrate that filtering gets more effective with scale: for our largest models, token filtering leads to a 7000x compute slowdown on the forget domain. We also show that models trained with token filtering can still be aligned on the forget domain. Along the way, we introduce a methodology for labeling tokens with sparse autoencoders and distilling cheap, high-quality classifiers. We also demonstrate that filtering can be robust to noisy labels with sufficient pretraining compute.

</details>


### [295] [Signal-Adaptive Trust Regions for Gradient-Free Optimization of Recurrent Spiking Neural Networks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21572)
*Jinhao Li,Yuhao Sun,Zhiyuan Ma,Hao He,Xinche Zhang,Xing Chen,Jin Li,Sen Song*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces Signal-Adaptive Trust Regions (SATR) for gradient-free optimization of recurrent spiking neural networks (RSNNs), stabilizing high-variance updates by bounding KL divergence with signal-energy normalization; instantiated for Bernoulli connectivity; paired with a bitset implementation to accelerate training.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Population-based, gradient-free methods coolly sidestep non-differentiable spike dynamics but suffer high-variance, unstable updates in high-dimensional, long-horizon RL. A trust-region in distribution space—adaptively scaled by signal energy—can stabilize updates and improve data efficiency and performance.

Method: Define SATR as a distributional update rule that constrains relative policy change by KL divergence normalized by estimated signal energy. The trust region expands with strong signals and contracts when updates are noise-dominated. Implement SATR for Bernoulli connectivity distributions in RSNNs. Introduce a bitset-based implementation for binary spiking and binary weights to reduce computation and enable scalable RSNN policy search.

Result: Empirically, SATR improves stability under limited populations and yields competitive returns on high-dimensional continuous-control benchmarks, matching or exceeding strong baselines including PPO-LSTM.

Conclusion: SATR provides a scalable, robust gradient-free optimization framework for RSNN policy learning, leveraging adaptive distributional trust regions and efficient bitset acceleration to enable effective, high-dimensional RSNN control.

Abstract: Recurrent spiking neural networks (RSNNs) are a promising substrate for energy-efficient control policies, but training them for high-dimensional, long-horizon reinforcement learning remains challenging. Population-based, gradient-free optimization circumvents backpropagation through non-differentiable spike dynamics by estimating gradients. However, with finite populations, high variance of these estimates can induce harmful and overly aggressive update steps. Inspired by trust-region methods in reinforcement learning that constrain policy updates in distribution space, we propose \textbf{Signal-Adaptive Trust Regions (SATR)}, a distributional update rule that constrains relative change by bounding KL divergence normalized by an estimated signal energy. SATR automatically expands the trust region under strong signals and contracts it when updates are noise-dominated. We instantiate SATR for Bernoulli connectivity distributions, which have shown strong empirical performance for RSNN optimization. Across a suite of high-dimensional continuous-control benchmarks, SATR improves stability under limited populations and reaches competitive returns against strong baselines including PPO-LSTM. In addition, to make SATR practical at scale, we introduce a bitset implementation for binary spiking and binary weights, substantially reducing wall-clock training time and enabling fast RSNN policy search.

</details>


### [296] [Learning the Mechanism of Catastrophic Forgetting: A Perspective from Gradient Similarity](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21577)
*Mutian Yang,Zisen Zhan,Yutong Chen,Haolin Li,Kaiwen Wang,Kaili Zheng,Yuguang Wang,Qi Wang,Jiandong Gao,Ji Wu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A gradient-based theory explains catastrophic forgetting in knowledge injection; identifies conflicting vs collaborative neurons via gradient similarity and introduces Collaborative Neural Learning (CNL) that freezes conflicting neurons. It achieves near-zero forgetting in ideal conditions and substantial forgetting reductions across diverse models and settings.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Catastrophic forgetting during knowledge injection undermines continual learning in LLMs. Existing methods lack a foundational theoretical explanation. A gradient-centric framework is proposed to explain forgetting and guide mitigation.

Method: Develop a gradient-based theoretical framework; prove that strongly negative gradient similarity causes forgetting. Use gradient similarity to classify neurons as conflicting (50%-75%) and collaborative (25%-50%). Propose CNL: freeze conflicting neurons and update collaborative neurons; provide theoretical guarantee of zero forgetting under infinitesimal learning rate and exact mastered set.

Result: Experiments across five LLMs, four datasets, and four optimizers show CNL achieves zero forgetting in in-set settings and reduces forgetting by 59.1%-81.7% in out-of-set settings.

Conclusion: Gradient similarity offers a causal explanation for forgetting and guides neuron-level interventions. CNL can theoretically eliminate forgetting under ideal conditions and yields substantial empirical improvements across diverse tasks, suggesting strong potential for robust continual learning in LLMs.

Abstract: Catastrophic forgetting during knowledge injection severely undermines the continual learning capability of large language models (LLMs). Although existing methods attempt to mitigate this issue, they often lack a foundational theoretical explanation. We establish a gradient-based theoretical framework to explain catastrophic forgetting. We first prove that strongly negative gradient similarity is a fundamental cause of forgetting. We then use gradient similarity to identify two types of neurons: conflicting neurons that induce forgetting and account for 50%-75% of neurons, and collaborative neurons that mitigate forgetting and account for 25%-50%. Based on this analysis, we propose a knowledge injection method, Collaborative Neural Learning (CNL). By freezing conflicting neurons and updating only collaborative neurons, CNL theoretically eliminates catastrophic forgetting under an infinitesimal learning rate eta and an exactly known mastered set. Experiments on five LLMs, four datasets, and four optimizers show that CNL achieves zero forgetting in in-set settings and reduces forgetting by 59.1%-81.7% in out-of-set settings.

</details>


### [297] [Evaluating Prediction Uncertainty Estimates from BatchEnsemble](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21581)
*Morten Blørstad,Herman Jangsett Mostein,Nello Blaser,Pekka Parviainen*

Main category: cs.LG
