Method: Theoretical bias-variance analysis of PIDM; derive conditions on state predictor bias for lower error and higher sample efficiency; empirical validation in 2D navigation and 3D visual environment.

Result: PIDM reduces variance by conditioning IDM on predicted future state, with bias from the predictor; under sufficient bias balance, PIDM achieves lower error and higher sample efficiency than BC; additional data sources amplify the advantage; empirical results show BC needs up to 5x more demonstrations in 2D (3x average) and >66% more samples in 3D game.

Conclusion: PIDM's bias-variance tradeoff explains empirical gains and offers guidance on predictor bias levels; leveraging data sources can further widen the gap; supports PIDM as a theoretically grounded improvement over BC.

Abstract: Behavior cloning (BC) is a practical offline imitation learning method, but it often fails when expert demonstrations are limited. Recent works have introduced a class of architectures named predictive inverse dynamics models (PIDM) that combine a future state predictor with an inverse dynamics model (IDM). While PIDM often outperforms BC, the reasons behind its benefits remain unclear. In this paper, we provide a theoretical explanation: PIDM introduces a bias-variance tradeoff. While predicting the future state introduces bias, conditioning the IDM on the prediction can significantly reduce variance. We establish conditions on the state predictor bias for PIDM to achieve lower prediction error and higher sample efficiency than BC, with the gap widening when additional data sources are available. We validate the theoretical insights empirically in 2D navigation tasks, where BC requires up to five times (three times on average) more demonstrations than PIDM to reach comparable performance; and in a complex 3D environment in a modern video game with high-dimensional visual inputs and stochastic transitions, where BC requires over 66\% more samples than PIDM.

</details>


### [325] [LoRA and Privacy: When Random Projections Help (and When They Don't)](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21719)
*Yaxi Hu,Johanna Düngler,Bernhard Schölkopf,Amartya Sanyal*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Wishart-based projection can ensure non-additive DP for vector-valued queries without extra noise, but not for matrix-valued queries in the noise-free setting. Adding noise yields privacy amplification via randomness and low-rank projections; LoRA updates map to this mechanism yet are not inherently private, though low-rank fine-tuning can be more privacy-preserving than full fine-tuning at the same noise level. Preliminary experiments show tighter accounting improves accuracy with DP.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Investigate a randomized Wishart projection mechanism as a potentially noise-efficient DP tool, evaluating its privacy guarantees for vector- versus matrix-valued queries and its relation to popular parameter-efficient fine-tuning methods (LoRA).

Method: Define the mechanism S ↦ M f(S) with M drawn from a Wishart distribution W_d(1/r I_d, r). Derive non-asymptotic DP guarantees for vector-valued queries without additive noise. Show a sharp negative result for matrix-valued queries in the noise-free setting via a near-perfect membership inference attack. Introduce a noisy variant and prove privacy amplification due to randomness and low-rank projection, in both large- and small-rank regimes. Connect LoRA-style updates to this mechanism and discuss privacy implications. Present preliminary experiments suggesting improved accuracy with tighter DP accounting at fixed noise.

Result: Vector-valued queries can be differentially private without extra noise under the Wishart projection mechanism. Matrix-valued queries are not DP in the noise-free setting, evidenced by a near-perfect membership inference attack. Introducing noise yields privacy amplification through the randomness of the Wishart draw and low-rank structure, with stronger guarantees in both high- and low-rank regimes. LoRA updates can be viewed as instances of the matrix-valued mechanism; however, LoRA is not inherently private, though low-rank fine-tuning may offer privacy advantages over full fine-tuning at the same noise level. Preliminary experiments indicate that tighter DP accounting can enable lower noise and better accuracy in practice.

Conclusion: Wishart-based projections offer a promising DP tool for vector-valued workloads without additive noise but face limitations for matrix-valued queries unless noise is deployed. The framework highlights the role of randomness and rank in privacy amplification and connects to practical parameter-efficient fine-tuning methods (LoRA), suggesting that low-rank strategies can enhance privacy-utility trade-offs under differential privacy constraints.

Abstract: We introduce the (Wishart) projection mechanism, a randomized map of the form $S \mapsto M f(S)$ with $M \sim W_d(1/r I_d, r)$ and study its differential privacy properties. For vector-valued queries $f$, we prove non-asymptotic DP guarantees without any additive noise, showing that Wishart randomness alone can suffice. For matrix-valued queries, however, we establish a sharp negative result: in the noise-free setting, the mechanism is not DP, and we demonstrate its vulnerability by implementing a near perfect membership inference attack (AUC $> 0.99$). We then analyze a noisy variant and prove privacy amplification due to randomness and low rank projection, in both large- and small-rank regimes, yielding stronger privacy guarantees than additive noise alone. Finally, we show that LoRA-style updates are an instance of the matrix-valued mechanism, implying that LoRA is not inherently private despite its built-in randomness, but that low-rank fine-tuning can be more private than full fine-tuning at the same noise level. Preliminary experiments suggest that tighter accounting enables lower noise and improved accuracy in practice.

</details>


### [326] [Amortized Spectral Kernel Discovery via Prior-Data Fitted Network](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21731)
*Kaustubh Sharma,Srijan Tiwari,Ojasva Nema,Parikshit Pareek*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Interpretable spectral discovery for Prior-Data Fitted Networks (PFNs) by decoding attention latents into explicit spectral densities and stationary kernels via Bochner's theorem, enabling fast GP-compatible inference.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: PFNs provide amortized inference but hide priors/kernels, limiting downstream tasks that require explicit covariance models; transparent, identifiable priors are desired.

Method: Mechanistic analysis shows attention latent outputs as the key intermediary; design decoders that map PFN latents to spectral densities and kernels using Bochner's theorem; study single- and multi-realization regimes; establish identifiability limits and consistency with multiple samples.

Result: Decoders recover complex multi-peak spectral mixtures and produce explicit kernels. GP regression with these kernels achieves accuracy comparable to PFNs and baselines, with substantially faster inference (single forward pass) than optimization-based approaches.

Conclusion: An interpretable, efficient path from PFN latents to explicit spectral models enables transparent priors/kernels for downstream GP-based tasks, maintaining performance while dramatically reducing inference time.

Abstract: Prior-Data Fitted Networks (PFNs) enable efficient amortized inference but lack transparent access to their learned priors and kernels. This opacity hinders their use in downstream tasks, such as surrogate-based optimization, that require explicit covariance models. We introduce an interpretability-driven framework for amortized spectral discovery from pre-trained PFNs with decoupled attention. We perform a mechanistic analysis on a trained PFN that identifies attention latent output as the key intermediary, linking observed function data to spectral structure. Building on this insight, we propose decoder architectures that map PFN latents to explicit spectral density estimates and corresponding stationary kernels via Bochner's theorem. We study this pipeline in both single-realization and multi-realization regimes, contextualizing theoretical limits on spectral identifiability and proving consistency when multiple function samples are available. Empirically, the proposed decoders recover complex multi-peak spectral mixtures and produce explicit kernels that support Gaussian process regression with accuracy comparable to PFNs and optimization-based baselines, while requiring only a single forward pass. This yields orders-of-magnitude reductions in inference time compared to optimization-based baselines.

</details>


### [327] [Mixed-Precision Training and Compilation for RRAM-based Computing-in-Memory Accelerators](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21737)
*Rebecca Pelke,Joel Klein,Jose Cubero-Cascante,Nils Bosbach,Jan Moritz Joseph,Rainer Leupers*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A mixed-precision training/compilation framework for CIM accelerators using reinforcement learning to search quantization settings, reducing MVM latency. Best case yields up to 2.48x speedup with 0.086% accuracy loss.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: CIM accelerators operate on crossbar arrays with very limited bit-width for inputs and cells; many CIM compilers do not support quantization below 8-bit, leading to many compute cycles and inefficient weight storage. A flexible, sub-8-bit quantization strategy is needed to improve latency without sacrificing accuracy.

Method: Proposes a mixed-precision training and compilation framework augmented with a reinforcement learning-based strategy to explore the massive quantization search space and optimize configurations that trade off latency and accuracy.

Result: The approach achieves up to 2.48x speedup over state-of-the-art solutions with an accuracy loss of 0.086%.

Conclusion: An RL-guided mixed-precision approach effectively reduces CIM latency while preserving accuracy, enabling more efficient CIM compiler design and expanding viable sub-8-bit quantization for MVM on crossbar arrays.

Abstract: Computing-in-Memory (CIM) accelerators are a promising solution for accelerating Machine Learning (ML) workloads, as they perform Matrix-Vector Multiplications (MVMs) on crossbar arrays directly in memory. Although the bit widths of the crossbar inputs and cells are very limited, most CIM compilers do not support quantization below 8 bit. As a result, a single MVM requires many compute cycles, and weights cannot be efficiently stored in a single crossbar cell. To address this problem, we propose a mixed-precision training and compilation framework for CIM architectures. The biggest challenge is the massive search space, that makes it difficult to find good quantization parameters. This is why we introduce a reinforcement learning-based strategy to find suitable quantization configurations that balance latency and accuracy. In the best case, our approach achieves up to a 2.48x speedup over existing state-of-the-art solutions, with an accuracy loss of only 0.086 %.

</details>


### [328] [Why Adam Works Better with $β_1 = β_2$: The Missing Gradient Scale Invariance Principle](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21739)
*Alberto Fernández-Hernández,Cristian Pérez-Corral,Jose I. Mestre,Manuel F. Dolz,Enrique S. Quintana-Ortí*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Adam is first-order gradient scale invariant if and only if β1=β2, explaining empirical gains and guiding future optimizer design.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Empirically, validating scores and training dynamics improve when β1=β2; there is no established explanation for this pattern. The work identifies gradient scale invariance as a unifying principle underlying robust updates.

Method: Formalize gradient scale invariance and prove that Adam achieves first-order gradient scale invariance precisely when β1=β2. Support theory with experiments across vision and language tasks and diverse architectures, showing smoother behavior under gradient rescaling when β1=β2 and alignment with other scale-robust optimizers.

Result: Theoretical claim: first-order gradient scale invariance holds iff β1=β2. Empirical results across multiple domains corroborate that rescaling gradients has a smoother effect on Adam updates under β1=β2, and that this regime aligns with recent scale-robust optimizers.

Conclusion: The work provides a coherent explanation for Adam’s behavior and presents a simple design principle for future optimizers based on gradient-scale invariance.

Abstract: Adam has been at the core of large-scale training for almost a decade, yet a simple empirical fact remains unaccounted for: both validation scores and the qualitative behaviour of the training runs improve when the momentum parameters satisfy $β_{1}=β_{2}$. Some recent studies have reported this pattern, but there is still no explanation for why this choice helps. We show that this choice is closely tied to a structural property that we refer to as \textit{gradient scale invariance}. We formalize this notion and prove that Adam becomes gradient scale invariant of first order if and only if $β_{1}=β_{2}$. This perspective places the balanced regime of Adam in direct alignment with the design principles underlying several recent optimizers that explicitly enforce scale-robust updates. The theory is supported by experiments across vision and language tasks, and across different architectural families, in which rescaling the gradient has a markedly smoother effect on the update when $β_{1}=β_{2}$. Overall, our results offer a coherent explanation for an open question in the behavior of Adam and provide a simple principle that helps guide the design of future optimizers.

</details>


### [329] [Temporal Sepsis Modeling: a Fully Interpretable Relational Way](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21747)
*Vincent Lemaire,Nédra Meloulli,Pierre Jaquet*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A relational, propositionalised approach to sepsis prediction from temporal EMR data, yielding highly interpretable features and a fourfold interpretation (univariate, global, local, counterfactual) via a selective Naive Bayes classifier.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Tackling the lack of interpretability and neglected latent sub-phenotypes in deep learning approaches for sepsis prediction by converting longitudinal EMR data into an interpretable relational representation and using propositionalisation to produce flat, meaningful features.

Method: Model EMR time-series as multivariate relational data; apply propositionalisation with classic aggregation/selection functions to construct flat, interpretable features; classify with a selective Naive Bayes classifier; provide fourfold interpretability (univariate, global, local, counterfactual).

Result: Experimental validation indicates that the approach is relevant and offers extreme interpretability, enabling fourfold explanations; performance is competitive with baseline methods while prioritizing interpretability.

Conclusion: A relational, propositionalisation-based framework can enhance interpretability in sepsis prediction and reveal latent sub-phenotypes through structured, flat features, with fourfold interpretability and efficient probabilistic classification.

Abstract: Sepsis remains one of the most complex and heterogeneous syndromes in intensive care, characterized by diverse physiological trajectories and variable responses to treatment. While deep learning models perform well in the early prediction of sepsis, they often lack interpretability and ignore latent patient sub-phenotypes. In this work, we propose a machine learning framework by opening up a new avenue for addressing this issue: a relational approach. Temporal data from electronic medical records (EMRs) are viewed as multivariate patient logs and represented in a relational data schema. Then, a propositionalisation technique (based on classic aggregation/selection functions from the field of relational data) is applied to construct interpretable features to "flatten" the data. Finally, the flattened data is classified using a selective naive Bayesian classifier. Experimental validation demonstrates the relevance of the suggested approach as well as its extreme interpretability. The interpretation is fourfold: univariate, global, local, and counterfactual.

</details>


### [330] [Differentiable Knapsack and Top-k Operators via Dynamic Programming](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21775)
*Germain Vivier-Ardisson,Michaël E. Sander,Axel Parmentier,Mathieu Blondel*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A unified differentiable framework for knapsack/top-k operators via dynamic programming, with differentiable relaxations, efficient parallel forward/backward passes, and theoretical characterizations of regularizers; validated on decision-focused learning, dynamic assortment RL, and discrete VAEs.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Knapsack and top-k are powerful for discrete subset selection but are non-differentiable and piecewise constant, hindering gradient-based learning; need differentiable approximations and scalable algorithms with theoretical guarantees.

Method: Cast the operators as dynamic programs; derive differentiable relaxations by smoothing recursions; develop parallel algorithms for deterministic and stochastic forward passes; provide vector-Jacobian products for backpropagation; prove entropy is the unique permutation-equivariant regularizer and characterize sparse-inducing regularizers.

Result: Empirical demonstration on decision-focused learning benchmarks, constrained dynamic assortment RL, and extensions of discrete VAEs, showing effective integration of these operators with neural models and the benefits of the theoretical findings.

Conclusion: Presents a unified DP-based differentiable framework for knapsack/top-k operators, with novel algorithmic and theoretical contributions and broad empirical validation across tasks.

Abstract: Knapsack and Top-k operators are useful for selecting discrete subsets of variables. However, their integration into neural networks is challenging as they are piecewise constant, yielding gradients that are zero almost everywhere. In this paper, we propose a unified framework casting these operators as dynamic programs, and derive differentiable relaxations by smoothing the underlying recursions. On the algorithmic side, we develop efficient parallel algorithms supporting both deterministic and stochastic forward passes, and vector-Jacobian products for the backward pass. On the theoretical side, we prove that Shannon entropy is the unique regularization choice yielding permutation-equivariant operators, and characterize regularizers inducing sparse selections. Finally, on the experimental side, we demonstrate our framework on a decision-focused learning benchmark, a constrained dynamic assortment RL problem, and an extension of discrete VAEs.

</details>


### [331] [Quantum LEGO Learning: A Modular Design Principle for Hybrid Artificial Intelligence](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21780)
*Jun Qi,Chao-Han Huck Yang,Pin-Yu Chen,Min-Hsiu Hsieh,Hector Zenil,Jesper Tegner*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A modular, architecture-agnostic framework (Quantum LEGO Learning) for hybrid quantum-classical models using frozen classical feature blocks and trainable quantum heads, with block-wise generalization theory and empirical validation on quantum dot classification.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address limited generality and transferability in existing tightly coupled hybrid models by decoupling classical and quantum components into reusable building blocks, enabling efficient learning with constrained quantum resources and enabling principled analysis.

Method: Treat components as reusable blocks: a pre-trained classical neural network as a frozen feature extractor and a variational quantum circuit as the trainable adaptive head operating on structured representations. Develop block-wise generalization theory decomposing error into approximation and estimation terms, generalizing tensor-network results. Conduct block-swap experiments across different feature extractors and heads, and validate on quantum dot classification with attention to optimization stability and noise robustness.

Result: Demonstrated stable optimization and reduced sensitivity to qubit count; observed robustness to realistic noise; identified conditions where quantum modules offer representational advantages over similarly sized classical heads; block-swap experiments validate modular framework.

Conclusion: A modular, architecture-agnostic hybrid learning framework enabling principled analysis and transferability of quantum-classical models, with theoretical decomposition of errors and empirical evidence of practical benefits under resource constraints.

Abstract: Hybrid quantum-classical learning models increasingly integrate neural networks with variational quantum circuits (VQCs) to exploit complementary inductive biases. However, many existing approaches rely on tightly coupled architectures or task-specific encoders, limiting conceptual clarity, generality, and transferability across learning settings. In this work, we introduce Quantum LEGO Learning, a modular and architecture-agnostic learning framework that treats classical and quantum components as reusable, composable learning blocks with well-defined roles. Within this framework, a pre-trained classical neural network serves as a frozen feature block, while a VQC acts as a trainable adaptive module that operates on structured representations rather than raw inputs. This separation enables efficient learning under constrained quantum resources and provides a principled abstraction for analyzing hybrid models. We develop a block-wise generalization theory that decomposes learning error into approximation and estimation components, explicitly characterizing how the complexity and training status of each block influence overall performance. Our analysis generalizes prior tensor-network-specific results and identifies conditions under which quantum modules provide representational advantages over comparably sized classical heads. Empirically, we validate the framework through systematic block-swap experiments across frozen feature extractors and both quantum and classical adaptive heads. Experiments on quantum dot classification demonstrate stable optimization, reduced sensitivity to qubit count, and robustness to realistic noise.

</details>


### [332] [ECSEL: Explainable Classification via Signomial Equation Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21789)
*Adia Lumadjeng,Ilker Birbil,Erman Acar*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: ECSEL learns compact signomial expressions as interpretable classifiers, achieving competitive accuracy with efficient computation and providing explanations via closed-form, global/local explanations and bias/counterfactual insights.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Symbolic regression benchmarks indicate many problems admit compact signomial structure; there is a need for models that are interpretable, globally well-behaved, and able to expose biases and counterfactuals, while maintaining accuracy.

Method: ECSEL directly constructs a closed-form signomial expression that serves as both classifier and explanation; emphasizes structure discovery and interpretability; demonstrates efficiency by recovering target equations with less computation; evaluates on benchmarks and real-world datasets.

Result: Outperforms competing symbolic regression methods in recovering target equations; achieves classification accuracy competitive with standard ML models; exhibits desirable properties for global feature behavior, decision-boundary analysis, and local attributions; real-world case studies reveal dataset biases and support counterfactual reasoning.

Conclusion: ECSEL provides an interpretable, efficient classifier that matches or surpasses baselines in accuracy while offering explainability and bias/causality insights; suitable for applications requiring transparent decision-making.

Abstract: We introduce ECSEL, an explainable classification method that learns formal expressions in the form of signomial equations, motivated by the observation that many symbolic regression benchmarks admit compact signomial structure. ECSEL directly constructs a structural, closed-form expression that serves as both a classifier and an explanation. On standard symbolic regression benchmarks, our method recovers a larger fraction of target equations than competing state-of-the-art approaches while requiring substantially less computation. Leveraging this efficiency, ECSEL achieves classification accuracy competitive with established machine learning models without sacrificing interpretability. Further, we show that ECSEL satisfies some desirable properties regarding global feature behavior, decision-boundary analysis, and local feature attributions. Experiments on benchmark datasets and two real-world case studies i.e., e-commerce and fraud detection, demonstrate that the learned equations expose dataset biases, support counterfactual reasoning, and yield actionable insights.

</details>


### [333] [NetMamba+: A Framework of Pre-trained Models for Efficient and Accurate Network Traffic Classification](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21792)
*Tongze Wang,Xiaohui Xie,Wenduo Wang,Chuyi Wang,Jinzhou Liu,Boyan Huang,Yannan Hu,Youjian Zhao,Yong Cui*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: NetMamba+ offers an efficient Transformer-inspired framework (Mamba/Flash Attention) for traffic classification, with a multimodal, byte-preserving representation and a label-distribution-aware fine-tuning strategy, yielding higher accuracy, throughput, and few-shot capability.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address three core issues in encrypted traffic classification: (1) computational inefficiency of Transformer-based models, (2) loss of crucial byte-level features and introduction of biases in representations, and (3) poor handling of long-tail distributions in real-world data.

Method: Propose NetMamba+ consisting of (1) an efficient architecture leveraging Mamba and Flash Attention, (2) a multimodal traffic representation that preserves essential information while mitigating biases, and (3) a label-distribution-aware fine-tuning strategy. An online traffic classification system is also implemented to demonstrate real-world performance.

Result: NetMamba+ achieves up to 6.44% absolute improvement in F1 over state-of-the-art baselines, 1.7x higher inference throughput with similar memory usage, and superior few-shot performance. The online system attains a throughput of 261.87 Mb/s.

Conclusion: As the first framework to adapt Mamba architecture for network traffic classification, NetMamba+ enables efficient and accurate traffic analysis in complex network environments.

Abstract: With the rapid growth of encrypted network traffic, effective traffic classification has become essential for network security and quality of service management. Current machine learning and deep learning approaches for traffic classification face three critical challenges: computational inefficiency of Transformer architectures, inadequate traffic representations with loss of crucial byte-level features while retaining detrimental biases, and poor handling of long-tail distributions in real-world data. We propose NetMamba+, a framework that addresses these challenges through three key innovations: (1) an efficient architecture considering Mamba and Flash Attention mechanisms, (2) a multimodal traffic representation scheme that preserves essential traffic information while eliminating biases, and (3) a label distribution-aware fine-tuning strategy. Evaluation experiments on massive datasets encompassing four main classification tasks showcase NetMamba+'s superior classification performance compared to state-of-the-art baselines, with improvements of up to 6.44\% in F1 score. Moreover, NetMamba+ demonstrates excellent efficiency, achieving 1.7x higher inference throughput than the best baseline while maintaining comparably low memory usage. Furthermore, NetMamba+ exhibits superior few-shot learning abilities, achieving better classification performance with fewer labeled data. Additionally, we implement an online traffic classification system that demonstrates robust real-world performance with a throughput of 261.87 Mb/s. As the first framework to adapt Mamba architecture for network traffic classification, NetMamba+ opens new possibilities for efficient and accurate traffic analysis in complex network environments.

</details>


### [334] [Knowledge Vector Weakening: Efficient Training-free Unlearning for Large Vision-Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21794)
*Yejin Kim,Dongjun Hwang,Sungmin Cha,Junsuk Choe*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: KVW is a training-free unlearning method for LVLMs that weakens knowledge vectors activated during the forget set, enabling efficient removal of undesirable knowledge without gradient updates and achieving a stable forget-retain trade-off.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address privacy leakage and harmful content risks in large vision-language models while avoiding the high computational cost of gradient-based unlearning.

Method: Identify activations of knowledge vectors during output generation on the forget set and progressively weaken their contributions without performing gradient-based optimization.

Result: KVW delivers a stable forget-retain balance and substantially reduces computation compared to gradient-based and LoRA-based unlearning on MLLMU and CLEAR benchmarks.

Conclusion: Training-free KVW offers an effective and scalable alternative for data unlearning in LVLMs, enabling practical removal of undesirable knowledge with lower computational overhead.

Abstract: Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) are widely adopted for their strong multimodal capabilities, yet they raise serious concerns such as privacy leakage and harmful content generation. Machine unlearning has emerged as a promising solution for removing the influence of specific data from trained models. However, existing approaches largely rely on gradient-based optimization, incurring substantial computational costs for large-scale LVLMs. To address this limitation, we propose Knowledge Vector Weakening (KVW), a training-free unlearning method that directly intervenes in the full model without gradient computation. KVW identifies knowledge vectors that are activated during the model's output generation on the forget set and progressively weakens their contributions, thereby preventing the model from exploiting undesirable knowledge. Experiments on the MLLMU and CLEAR benchmarks demonstrate that KVW achieves a stable forget-retain trade-off while significantly improving computational efficiency over gradient-based and LoRA-based unlearning methods.

</details>


### [335] [Effective LoRA Adapter Routing using Task Representations](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21795)
*Akash Dhasade,Anne-Marie Kermarrec,Igor Pavlovic,Diana Petrescu,Rafael Pires,Mathis Randl,Martijn de Vos*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: LORAUTER uses task-level representations to route and compose LoRA adapters for LLMs, enabling scalable, data-efficient adapter selection with strong performance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: With large public LoRA adapter pools, routing becomes a bottleneck. Existing query-to-adapter mappings scale poorly with the number of adapters and often require adapter-specific data. A task-centric routing approach promises scalability with the number of tasks and data efficiency.

Method: The framework derives task embeddings from small validation sets and routes queries via these task representations to select and compose LoRA adapters. It operates at the task level, does not require adapter training data, and scales with the number of tasks rather than adapters, handling very large adapter pools.

Result: LORAUTER consistently outperforms baseline routing methods, matches Oracle performance when task-aligned adapters exist, achieves state-of-the-art results on unseen tasks (+5.2 points), and remains robust when scaling to over 1500 adapters.

Conclusion: Task-level routing with task embeddings is effective for modular LoRA adapter pools, offering scalable, data-efficient, and robust adapter routing that generalizes to unseen tasks and large, noisy pools.

Abstract: Low-rank adaptation (LoRA) enables parameter efficient specialization of large language models (LLMs) through modular adapters, resulting in rapidly growing public adapter pools spanning diverse tasks. Effectively using these adapters requires routing: selecting and composing the appropriate adapters for a query. We introduce LORAUTER, a novel routing framework that selects and composes LoRA adapters using task representations rather than adapter characteristics. Unlike existing approaches that map queries directly to adapters, LORAUTER routes queries via task embeddings derived from small validation sets and does not require adapter training data. By operating at the task level, LORAUTER achieves efficient routing that scales with the number of tasks rather than the number of adapters. Experiments across multiple tasks show that LORAUTER consistently outperforms baseline routing approaches, matching Oracle performance (101.2%) when task-aligned adapters exist and achieving state-of-the-art results on unseen tasks (+5.2 points). We further demonstrate the robustness of LORAUTER to very large, noisy adapter pools by scaling it to over 1500 adapters.

</details>


### [336] [Nonparametric LLM Evaluation from Preference Data](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21816)
*Dennis Frauen,Athiya Deviyani,Mihaela van der Schaar,Stefan Feuerriegel*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Nonparametric DMLEval framework for ranking LLMs from preference data using debiased ML, introducing GARS to handle complex human responses (including ties) with efficient estimation and compatibility with black-box estimators and LLM evaluators.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Limitations of parametric models and lack of valid uncertainty quantification in LLM ranking from human preferences; need flexible, data-efficient methods.

Method: Debiased machine learning (DML) framework; generalized average ranking scores (GARS) that extend Bradley–Terry and centrality models; accommodates ties; integrates black-box estimators and LLM-based evaluators; provides data collection policies under budget.

Result: Theoretical guarantees and empirical validation on synthetic and real-world preference data showing efficiency and robustness; practical guidance for practitioners.

Conclusion: DMLEval offers a principled, scalable, nonparametric toolkit for comparing or ranking LLMs from preference data with valid uncertainty quantification and flexible estimation options.

Abstract: Evaluating the performance of large language models (LLMs) from human preference data is crucial for obtaining LLM leaderboards. However, many existing approaches either rely on restrictive parametric assumptions or lack valid uncertainty quantification when flexible machine learning methods are used. In this paper, we propose a nonparametric statistical framework, DMLEval, for comparing and ranking LLMs from preference data using debiased machine learning (DML). For this, we introduce generalized average ranking scores (GARS), which generalize commonly used ranking models, including the Bradley-Terry model or PageRank/ Rank centrality, with complex human responses such as ties. DMLEval comes with the following advantages: (i) It produces statistically efficient estimates of GARS ranking scores. (ii) It naturally allows the incorporation of black-box machine learning methods for estimation. (iii) It can be combined with pre-trained LLM evaluators (e.g., using LLM-as-a-judge). (iv) It suggests optimal policies for collecting preference data under budget constraints. We demonstrate these advantages both theoretically and empirically using both synthetic and real-world preference datasets. In summary, our framework provides practitioners with powerful, state-of-the-art methods for comparing or ranking LLMs.

</details>


### [337] [DASH: Deterministic Attention Scheduling for High-throughput Reproducible LLM Training](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21824)
*Xinwei Qiang,Hongmin Chen,Shixuan Sun,Jingwen Leng,Xin Liu,Minyi Guo*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Deterministic attention in LLM training incurs substantial throughput cost; we model the deterministic backward pass as a DAG scheduling problem and introduce DASH (Descending Q-Tile Iteration and Shift Scheduling) to minimize the critical path, reducing pipeline stalls.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Ensure reproducibility in LLM training via deterministic backward passes, which currently cause significant slowdowns (up to ~38% in deterministic backward pass for attention).

Method: Model the deterministic attention backward pass as a DAG scheduling problem and derive two scheduling strategies: (i) Descending Q-Tile Iteration (reversed query-block traversal to cut pipeline stalls in causal attention), and (ii) Shift Scheduling (theoretically optimal within the DAG model for both full and causal masks). Implement DASH and evaluate on NVIDIA H800 GPUs.

Result: DASH improves throughput of the deterministic attention backward pass by up to 1.28x over the baseline, narrowing the gap between deterministic and non-deterministic attention; code is open-sourced.

Conclusion: DASH effectively reduces deterministic backward-pass stalls in attention, advancing reproducible LLM training by delivering higher throughput and providing practical scheduling strategies.

Abstract: Determinism is indispensable for reproducibility in large language model (LLM) training, yet it often exacts a steep performance cost. In widely used attention implementations such as FlashAttention-3, the deterministic backward pass can incur up to a 37.9% throughput reduction relative to its non-deterministic counterpart, primarily because gradient accumulation operations must be serialized to guarantee numerical consistency. This performance loss stems from suboptimal scheduling of compute and gradient-reduction phases, leading to significant hardware underutilization.
  To address this challenge, we formulate the backward pass of deterministic attention as a scheduling problem on a Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) and derive schedules that minimize the critical path length. Building on this formulation, we present DASH (Deterministic Attention Scheduling for High-Throughput), which encapsulates two complementary scheduling strategies: (i) Descending Q-Tile Iteration, a reversed query-block traversal that shrinks pipeline stalls in causal attention, and (ii) Shift Scheduling, a theoretically optimal schedule within our DAG model that reduces pipeline stalls for both full and causal masks.
  Our empirical evaluations on NVIDIA H800 GPUs demonstrate that DASH narrows the performance gap of deterministic attention. The proposed strategies improve the throughput of the attention backward pass by up to 1.28$\times$ compared to the baseline, significantly advancing the efficiency of reproducible LLM training.
  Our code is open-sourced at https://github.com/SJTU-Liquid/deterministic-FA3.

</details>


### [338] [Goal-Driven Adaptive Sampling Strategies for Machine Learning Models Predicting Fields](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21832)
*Jigar Parekh,Philipp Bekemeyer*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: An active-learning framework for field-predicting ML models using a scalar GP reference; reduces epistemic error and scalar-field discrepancy; demonstrates efficiency on NASA CR model.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Extend active learning from scalar outputs to field predictions; reduce costly CFD simulations by selecting informative samples; architecture-agnostic approach.

Method: Hybrid strategy: use Gaussian process for scalar reference; jointly minimize scalar infill uncertainty and field-pidelity error; introduce variants; compare to scalar-only infill; apply to NASA CR model for uncertainty propagation.

Result: Achieves high accuracy with significantly lower sample count and computational cost than non-active-learning baseline; robust across variants in NASA CR model task.

Conclusion: Feasible and effective approach for active learning in field predictions; can generalize across architectures; promising for CFD-related uncertainty quantification.

Abstract: Machine learning models are widely regarded as a way forward to tackle multi-query challenges that arise once expensive black-box simulations such as computational fluid dynamics are investigated. However, ensuring the desired level of accuracy for a certain task at minimal computational cost, e.g. as few black-box samples as possible, remains a challenges. Active learning strategies are used for scalar quantities to overcome this challenges and different so-called infill criteria exists and are commonly employed in several scenarios. Even though needed in various field an extension of active learning strategies towards field predictions is still lacking or limited to very specific scenarios and/or model types. In this paper we propose an active learning strategy for machine learning models that are capable if predicting field which is agnostic to the model architecture itself. For doing so, we combine a well-established Gaussian process model for a scalar reference value and simultaneously aim at reducing the epistemic model error and the difference between scalar and field predictions. Different specific forms of the above-mentioned approach are introduced and compared to each other as well as only scalar-valued based infill. Results are presented for the NASA common research model for an uncertainty propagation task showcasing high level of accuracy at significantly smaller cost compared to an approach without active learning.

</details>


### [339] [Scalable Linearized Laplace Approximation via Surrogate Neural Kernel](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21835)
*Luis A. Ortega,Simón Rodríguez-Santana,Daniel Hernández-Lobato*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Scalable surrogate DNN to learn a kernel that emulates the NTK for the Linearized Laplace Approximation (LLA), enabling efficient predictive uncertainty for large pre-trained DNNs; achieves comparable or better calibration and improves out-of-distribution detection when the kernel is biased.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reduce the computational burden of LLA by avoiding large Jacobian computations while maintaining or improving uncertainty estimates; explore kernel learning beyond the standard NTK within the LLA framework.

Method: Train a compact surrogate DNN to learn a feature representation whose inner product replicates the Neural Tangent Kernel (NTK). Training uses efficient Jacobian-vector products (JVPs) rather than explicit large Jacobians, enabling uncertainty estimation on large-scale pre-trained networks.

Result: Experiments show similar or improved uncertainty estimation and calibration compared with existing LLA approximations. Biasing the learned kernel enhances out-of-distribution detection, highlighting the potential of kernel learning to produce kernels superior to NTK in the LLA context for uncertainty quantification.

Conclusion: Demonstrates that learning task-specific kernels can surpass NTK in the LLA setting, offering scalable, accurate uncertainty estimation for large pre-trained DNNs.

Abstract: We introduce a scalable method to approximate the kernel of the Linearized Laplace Approximation (LLA). For this, we use a surrogate deep neural network (DNN) that learns a compact feature representation whose inner product replicates the Neural Tangent Kernel (NTK). This avoids the need to compute large Jacobians. Training relies solely on efficient Jacobian-vector products, allowing to compute predictive uncertainty on large-scale pre-trained DNNs. Experimental results show similar or improved uncertainty estimation and calibration compared to existing LLA approximations. Notwithstanding, biasing the learned kernel significantly enhances out-of-distribution detection. This remarks the benefits of the proposed method for finding better kernels than the NTK in the context of LLA to compute prediction uncertainty given a pre-trained DNN.

</details>


### [340] [Constrained Meta Reinforcement Learning with Provable Test-Time Safety](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21845)
*Tingting Ni,Maryam Kamgarpour*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes a policy-refinement algorithm for constrained meta-RL with provable safety and near-optimal sample complexity guarantees on test tasks, plus a matching lower bound that proves tightness of the rate.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Safety-constrained learning in meta-RL, particularly for real-world tasks (robotics, healthcare), where ensuring safe behavior on test tasks while maintaining fast learning is crucial.

Method: Introduce a policy-refinement algorithm that builds on policies learned during training and provides provable safety guarantees and sample-complexity bounds for obtaining a near-optimal policy on test tasks; also derive a matching lower bound to show tightness of the bound.

Result: Demonstrates provable safety and sample complexity guarantees for learning a near-optimal policy on test tasks; upper bounds are matched by a lower bound, indicating tightness of the sample complexity.

Conclusion: Advances constrained meta-RL by delivering a Safety-certified refinement procedure with tight sample complexity guarantees, clarifying fundamental limits and ensuring practical applicability to safety-critical tasks.

Abstract: Meta reinforcement learning (RL) allows agents to leverage experience across a distribution of tasks on which the agent can train at will, enabling faster learning of optimal policies on new test tasks. Despite its success in improving sample complexity on test tasks, many real-world applications, such as robotics and healthcare, impose safety constraints during testing. Constrained meta RL provides a promising framework for integrating safety into meta RL. An open question in constrained meta RL is how to ensure the safety of the policy on the real-world test task, while reducing the sample complexity and thus, enabling faster learning of optimal policies. To address this gap, we propose an algorithm that refines policies learned during training, with provable safety and sample complexity guarantees for learning a near optimal policy on the test tasks. We further derive a matching lower bound, showing that this sample complexity is tight.

</details>


### [341] [READY: Reward Discovery for Meta-Black-Box Optimization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21847)
*Zechuan Huang,Zhiguang Cao,Hongshu Guo,Yue-Jiao Gong,Zeyuan Ma*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: LLM-driven automated reward discovery for MetaBBO using evolutionary iterative search and a multi-task parallel architecture to design effective rewards and speed up convergence.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reward design bias and potential reward hacking in MetaBBO; automated, scalable reward discovery via LLM to improve robustness and performance.

Method: Introduce an evolution-based LLM program search loop to iteratively refine reward functions; implement a multi-task evolution framework enabling parallel reward discovery and cross-task knowledge sharing.

Result: Discovered reward functions improve the performance of existing MetaBBO methods; empirical evaluations demonstrate their usefulness; parallelisation accelerates reward discovery through knowledge sharing.

Conclusion: Automated reward design via LLMs is a promising direction for MetaBBO, addressing bias and efficiency; the paper highlights the value of reward design and provides a reusable READY resource.

Abstract: Meta-Black-Box Optimization (MetaBBO) is an emerging avenue within Optimization community, where algorithm design policy could be meta-learned by reinforcement learning to enhance optimization performance. So far, the reward functions in existing MetaBBO works are designed by human experts, introducing certain design bias and risks of reward hacking. In this paper, we use Large Language Model~(LLM) as an automated reward discovery tool for MetaBBO. Specifically, we consider both effectiveness and efficiency sides. On effectiveness side, we borrow the idea of evolution of heuristics, introducing tailored evolution paradigm in the iterative LLM-based program search process, which ensures continuous improvement. On efficiency side, we additionally introduce multi-task evolution architecture to support parallel reward discovery for diverse MetaBBO approaches. Such parallel process also benefits from knowledge sharing across tasks to accelerate convergence. Empirical results demonstrate that the reward functions discovered by our approach could be helpful for boosting existing MetaBBO works, underscoring the importance of reward design in MetaBBO. We provide READY's project at https://anonymous.4open.science/r/ICML_READY-747F.

</details>


### [342] [Visual Disentangled Diffusion Autoencoders: Scalable Counterfactual Generation for Foundation Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21851)
*Sidney Bender,Marco Morik*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: DiDAE integrates frozen foundation models with a disentangled dictionary learning approach to generate multiple, diverse, disentangled counterfactuals via a diffusion autoencoder, enabling gradient-free, efficient mitigation of spurious correlations. When paired with Counterfactual Knowledge Distillation (DiDAE-CFKD), it achieves state-of-the-art mitigation of shortcut learning on unbalanced data.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Foundation models exhibit strong zero-shot performance but are vulnerable to spurious correlations and Clever Hans strategies. Existing mitigation methods often require unavailable group labels or expensive gradient-based adversarial optimization. A gradient-free, interpretable method tailored to foundation models is needed.

Method: Construct and edit embeddings of a frozen foundation model along interpretable directions from a disentangled dictionary; decode edited embeddings through a diffusion autoencoder to generate multiple diverse, disentangled counterfactuals for each factual input; optionally combine with Counterfactual Knowledge Distillation (CFKD) for improved robustness.

Result: The framework enables faster generation of multiple counterfactuals compared to baselines that produce single entangled counterfactuals; when paired with CFKD, DiDAE achieves state-of-the-art mitigation of shortcut learning and improves downstream performance on unbalanced datasets.

Conclusion: DiDAE offers a gradient-free, efficient approach for producing diverse counterfactuals by leveraging disentangled representations and diffusion decoding within frozen foundation models, with CFKD further enhancing robustness against shortcut learning.

Abstract: Foundation models, despite their robust zero-shot capabilities, remain vulnerable to spurious correlations and 'Clever Hans' strategies. Existing mitigation methods often rely on unavailable group labels or computationally expensive gradient-based adversarial optimization. To address these limitations, we propose Visual Disentangled Diffusion Autoencoders (DiDAE), a novel framework integrating frozen foundation models with disentangled dictionary learning for efficient, gradient-free counterfactual generation directly for the foundation model. DiDAE first edits foundation model embeddings in interpretable disentangled directions of the disentangled dictionary and then decodes them via a diffusion autoencoder. This allows the generation of multiple diverse, disentangled counterfactuals for each factual, much faster than existing baselines, which generate single entangled counterfactuals. When paired with Counterfactual Knowledge Distillation, DiDAE-CFKD achieves state-of-the-art performance in mitigating shortcut learning, improving downstream performance on unbalanced datasets.

</details>


### [343] [MoHETS: Long-term Time Series Forecasting with Mixture-of-Heterogeneous-Experts](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21866)
*Evandro S. Ortigossa,Guy Lutsker,Eran Segal*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes MoHETS, a sparse mixture-of-heterogeneous-experts encoder for long-horizon multivariate time-series forecasting, achieving state-of-the-art with ~12% MSE improvement by leveraging heterogeneous experts, cross-attention for exogenous covariates, and a convolutional patch decoder.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Real-world MTS have multi-scale structure (global trends, local periodicities, non-stationary regimes) and require scalable, horizon-generalizable models. Homogeneous MLP MoEs struggle to capture diverse dynamics and long-horizon dependencies.

Method: Encoder-only Transformer with MoHE layers routing patches to a small subset of heterogeneous experts: a shared depthwise-convolution expert for sequence-level continuity; routed Fourier-based experts for patch-level periodic structures; cross-attention over covariate patch embeddings for exogenous info; convolutional patch decoder in place of heavy linear heads for efficiency and horizon-generalization.

Result: Evaluated on seven multivariate benchmarks across multiple horizons; MoHETS achieves state-of-the-art results, reducing average MSE by 12% vs strong baselines.

Conclusion: Heterogeneous expert specialization within MoHE layers enables robust long-term forecasting, improved parameter efficiency, training stability, and horizon-generalization, establishing a new strong baseline for long-horizon MTS.

Abstract: Real-world multivariate time series can exhibit intricate multi-scale structures, including global trends, local periodicities, and non-stationary regimes, which makes long-horizon forecasting challenging. Although sparse Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) approaches improve scalability and specialization, they typically rely on homogeneous MLP experts that poorly capture the diverse temporal dynamics of time series data. We address these limitations with MoHETS, an encoder-only Transformer that integrates sparse Mixture-of-Heterogeneous-Experts (MoHE) layers. MoHE routes temporal patches to a small subset of expert networks, combining a shared depthwise-convolution expert for sequence-level continuity with routed Fourier-based experts for patch-level periodic structures. MoHETS further improves robustness to non-stationary dynamics by incorporating exogenous information via cross-attention over covariate patch embeddings. Finally, we replace parameter-heavy linear projection heads with a lightweight convolutional patch decoder, improving parameter efficiency, reducing training instability, and allowing a single model to generalize across arbitrary forecast horizons. We validate across seven multivariate benchmarks and multiple horizons, with MoHETS consistently achieving state-of-the-art performance, reducing the average MSE by $12\%$ compared to strong recent baselines, demonstrating effective heterogeneous specialization for long-term forecasting.

</details>


### [344] [Low-Rank Plus Sparse Matrix Transfer Learning under Growing Representations and Ambient Dimensions](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21873)
*Jinhang Chai,Xuyuan Liu,Elynn Chen,Yujun Yan*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Transfers subspace knowledge from a source task to a growing target task, decomposing the target into an embedded source component, low-rank innovations, and sparse edits. An anchored alternating projection estimator preserves the transferred subspace while estimating limited low-dimensional changes. Theoretical error bounds separate target noise, representation growth, and source estimation error, with improved rates for small rank/sparsity growth. Demonstrated on Markov transition matrices with dependent noise and on structured covariance under enlarged dimensions, with empirical transfer gains.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Enable transfer learning in settings where ambient dimensionality and intrinsic representation both grow, by leveraging a well-estimated source task embedded as a subspace to improve target estimation.

Method: An anchored alternating projection estimator that preserves the transferred subspace and estimates only low-dimensional innovations (low-rank) and sparse edits; the target parameter is decomposed into an embedded source component, low-rank innovations, and sparse modifications.

Result: Deterministic error bounds that decouple target noise, representation growth, and source estimation error; strictly improved rates when rank and sparsity increments are small. For Markov transition matrices, end-to-end guarantees under dependent noise. For structured covariance with enlarged dimensions, complementary analysis in the appendix and empirical validation of transfer gains.

Conclusion: A general transfer learning framework for structured matrix estimation under simultaneous growth, showing that preserving transferred subspaces while adapting only compact innovations yields provable gains; validated on two canonical problems demonstrating broad applicability.

Abstract: Learning systems often expand their ambient features or latent representations over time, embedding earlier representations into larger spaces with limited new latent structure. We study transfer learning for structured matrix estimation under simultaneous growth of the ambient dimension and the intrinsic representation, where a well-estimated source task is embedded as a subspace of a higher-dimensional target task.
  We propose a general transfer framework in which the target parameter decomposes into an embedded source component, low-dimensional low-rank innovations, and sparse edits, and develop an anchored alternating projection estimator that preserves transferred subspaces while estimating only low-dimensional innovations and sparse modifications. We establish deterministic error bounds that separate target noise, representation growth, and source estimation error, yielding strictly improved rates when rank and sparsity increments are small.
  We demonstrate the generality of the framework by applying it to two canonical problems. For Markov transition matrix estimation from a single trajectory, we derive end-to-end theoretical guarantees under dependent noise. For structured covariance estimation under enlarged dimensions, we provide complementary theoretical analysis in the appendix and empirically validate consistent transfer gains.

</details>


### [345] [Managing Solution Stability in Decision-Focused Learning with Cost Regularization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21883)
*Victor Spitzer,Francois Sanson*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Estimates objective coefficients via perturbation-based learning; shows instability from varying perturbation intensity; introduces regularization on cost vectors to stabilize learning; validated by numerical experiments.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Bridging prediction and combinatorial optimization requires differentiating through optimization; perturbation-based methods provide gradient signals but are sensitive to perturbation magnitude, hurting training stability and decision quality.

Method: Theoretically connect perturbation intensity fluctuations to solution stability; propose a regularization term on the estimated cost vector; integrate into the learning objective; evaluate on numerical experiments.

Result: Regularizing the estimated cost vectors improves robustness and reliability of the learning process; empirical results show better decision performance under perturbations.

Conclusion: Regularization of cost vectors is an effective remedy for instability in perturbation-based decision-focused learning; supports more robust integration of predictive modeling and optimization.

Abstract: Decision-focused learning integrates predictive modeling and combinatorial optimization by training models to directly improve decision quality rather than prediction accuracy alone. Differentiating through combinatorial optimization problems represents a central challenge, and recent approaches tackle this difficulty by introducing perturbation-based approximations. In this work, we focus on estimating the objective function coefficients of a combinatorial optimization problem. Our study demonstrates that fluctuations in perturbation intensity occurring during the learning phase can lead to ineffective training, by establishing a theoretical link to the notion of solution stability in combinatorial optimization. We propose addressing this issue by introducing a regularization of the estimated cost vectors which improves the robustness and reliability of the learning process, as demonstrated by extensive numerical experiments.

</details>


### [346] [Not All Code Is Equal: A Data-Centric Study of Code Complexity and LLM Reasoning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21894)
*Lukas Twist,Shu Yang,Hanqi Yan,Jingzhi Gong,Di Wang,Helen Yannakoudakis,Jie M. Zhang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Fine-tuning LLMs with code that has controlled structural complexity boosts reasoning more than training on arbitrary code; in most experiments, constraining to a target complexity range outperforms diverse-code training.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Identify which code properties, specifically structural complexity (control flow and composition), contribute to improved multi-step reasoning in LLMs, beyond simple scaling and generic code exposure.

Method: Create datasets by measuring cyclomatic complexity and logical lines of code; implement two regimes: solution-driven complexity (varying complexity across multiple solutions) and problem-driven complexity (varying complexity by task). Train/open-weight LLMs, evaluate on diverse reasoning benchmarks; compare complexity-controlled data vs structurally diverse data.

Result: Structural complexity strongly influences the usefulness of code; in 83% of experiments, restricting fine-tuning data to a limited complexity range outperforms training on diverse code; demonstrates data-centric improvement path for reasoning.

Conclusion: Targeting code structure during fine-tuning offers a promising route to enhance reasoning beyond scaling; structural-aware data selection can be more effective than merely increasing data volume or diversity.

Abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) increasingly exhibit strong reasoning abilities, often attributed to their capacity to generate chain-of-thought-style intermediate reasoning. Recent work suggests that exposure to code can further enhance these skills, but existing studies largely treat code as a generic training signal, leaving open the question of which properties of code actually contribute to improved reasoning. To address this gap, we study the structural complexity of code, which captures control flow and compositional structure that may shape how models internalise multi-step reasoning during fine-tuning. We examine two complementary settings: solution-driven complexity, where complexity varies across multiple solutions to the same problem, and problem-driven complexity, where complexity reflects variation in the underlying tasks. Using cyclomatic complexity and logical lines of code to construct controlled fine-tuning datasets, we evaluate a range of open-weight LLMs on diverse reasoning benchmarks. Our findings show that although code can improve reasoning, structural properties strongly determine its usefulness. In 83% of experiments, restricting fine-tuning data to a specific structural complexity range outperforms training on structurally diverse code, pointing to a data-centric path for improving reasoning beyond scaling.

</details>


### [347] [A Low-Complexity Plug-and-Play Deep Learning Model for Generalizable Massive MIMO Precoding](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21897)
*Ali Hasanzadeh Karkan,Ahmed Ibrahim,Jean-François Frigon,François Leduc-Primeau*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: PaPP is a transferable, energy-efficient DL-based precoder for mMIMO that uses a teacher-student framework with meta-learning to generalize across sites, power levels, and channel estimation errors, achieving >21x energy savings and robust performance after light fine-tuning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Overcome computational cost and poor robustness of WMMSE and DL-based precoders; enable a single model to be deployed across multiple sites, power regimes, and varying channel estimation quality without retraining from scratch.

Method: Introduce PaPP, a plug-and-play DL framework with a high-capacity teacher and a compact student, trained with a self-supervised loss that balances teacher imitation and normalized sum-rate. Employ meta-learning for domain-generalization and transmit-power-aware input normalization. Supports both fully digital and hybrid beamforming, and is evaluated on ray-tracing data from unseen sites with fine-tuning on small unlabeled local data.

Result: PaPP FDP and HBF models outperform conventional and DL baselines after fine-tuning, with more than 21× reduction in modeled computation energy. Demonstrates robustness to channel-estimation errors and transferability across sites.

Conclusion: PaPP provides a practical, energy-efficient, transferable DL-based precoding solution for mMIMO, reducing retraining needs and maintaining performance across deployment variations.

Abstract: Massive multiple-input multiple-output (mMIMO) downlink precoding offers high spectral efficiency but remains challenging to deploy in practice because near-optimal algorithms such as the weighted minimum mean squared error (WMMSE) are computationally expensive, and sensitive to SNR and channel-estimation quality, while existing deep learning (DL)-based solutions often lack robustness and require retraining for each deployment site. This paper proposes a plug-and-play precoder (PaPP), a DL framework with a backbone that can be trained for either fully digital (FDP) or hybrid beamforming (HBF) precoding and reused across sites, transmit-power levels, and with varying amounts of channel estimation error, avoiding the need to train a new model from scratch at each deployment. PaPP combines a high-capacity teacher and a compact student with a self-supervised loss that balances teacher imitation and normalized sum-rate, trained using meta-learning domain-generalization and transmit-power-aware input normalization. Numerical results on ray-tracing data from three unseen sites show that the PaPP FDP and HBF models both outperform conventional and deep learning baselines, after fine-tuning with a small set of local unlabeled samples. Across both architectures, PaPP achieves more than 21$\times$ reduction in modeled computation energy and maintains good performance under channel-estimation errors, making it a practical solution for energy-efficient mMIMO precoding.

</details>


### [348] [Breaking the Regional Barrier: Inductive Semantic Topology Learning for Worldwide Air Quality Forecasting](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21899)
*Zhiqing Cui,Siru Zhong,Ming Jin,Shirui Pan,Qingsong Wen,Yuxuan Liang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: OmniAir learns a semantic, adaptive topology for global station-level air quality forecasting and introduces WorldAir dataset; achieves state-of-the-art accuracy with scalable speed.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Global air quality forecasting suffers from spatial heterogeneity and poor generalization to unseen regions under existing transductive models.

Method: Encode invariant physical attributes into station identities and dynamically construct adaptive sparse topologies to capture long-range non-Euclidean correlations and physical diffusion across uneven global networks; introduce WorldAir dataset with 7,800+ stations.

Result: State-of-the-art performance against 18 baselines; about 10x faster than existing models; improves monitoring in data-sparse regions.

Conclusion: Semantic topology learning effectively enables scalable, generalizable global air quality forecasting; the WorldAir dataset provides a comprehensive benchmark and enables robust evaluation.

Abstract: Global air quality forecasting grapples with extreme spatial heterogeneity and the poor generalization of existing transductive models to unseen regions. To tackle this, we propose OmniAir, a semantic topology learning framework tailored for global station-level prediction. By encoding invariant physical environmental attributes into generalizable station identities and dynamically constructing adaptive sparse topologies, our approach effectively captures long-range non-Euclidean correlations and physical diffusion patterns across unevenly distributed global networks. We further curate WorldAir, a massive dataset covering over 7,800 stations worldwide. Extensive experiments show that OmniAir achieves state-of-the-art performance against 18 baselines, maintaining high efficiency and scalability with speeds nearly 10 times faster than existing models, while effectively bridging the monitoring gap in data-sparse regions.

</details>


### [349] [Hardware-Triggered Backdoors](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21902)
*Jonas Möller,Erik Imgrund,Thorsten Eisenhofer,Konrad Rieck*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Hardware-induced numerical variations can be exploited to create hardware-triggered backdoors in ML models, enabling different predictions on different GPUs; demonstrated reliably and discussed defenses.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Identify security risks when ML models are deployed across heterogeneous hardware where tiny numerical differences can be amplified to flip predictions, especially for third-party models.

Method: Shape the model's decision boundary near a target input; locally refine numerical deviations to flip predictions on selected hardware; validate the attack empirically across common GPU accelerators; explore defenses.

Result: Demonstrates reliable hardware-triggered backdoors across GPUs; establishes feasibility of this attack vector in real deployments; discusses countermeasures.

Conclusion: Hardware variability represents a credible backdoor risk in ML deployment; necessitates defenses such as cross-hardware validation and robust detection for third-party models.

Abstract: Machine learning models are routinely deployed on a wide range of computing hardware. Although such hardware is typically expected to produce identical results, differences in its design can lead to small numerical variations during inference. In this work, we show that these variations can be exploited to create backdoors in machine learning models. The core idea is to shape the model's decision function such that it yields different predictions for the same input when executed on different hardware. This effect is achieved by locally moving the decision boundary close to a target input and then refining numerical deviations to flip the prediction on selected hardware. We empirically demonstrate that these hardware-triggered backdoors can be created reliably across common GPU accelerators. Our findings reveal a novel attack vector affecting the use of third-party models, and we investigate different defenses to counter this threat.

</details>


### [350] [Optimistic Transfer under Task Shift via Bellman Alignment](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21924)
*Jinhang Chai,Enpei Zhang,Elynn Chen,Yujun Yan*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: One-step Bellman alignment with re-weighted targeting (RWT) enables transfer in online RL by correcting source Bellman updates via a change of measure; yields a two-stage Q-learning framework with regret guarantees under RKHS and empirical gains in tabular and neural setups, establishing Bellman alignment as a model-agnostic transfer principle.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Transferring knowledge between related tasks in online, episodic RL is hindered because task similarity is often defined on rewards/transitions, while learning targets are Bellman-based; naive reuse causes bias and breaks regret guarantees.

Method: Introduce one-step Bellman alignment; develop RWT operator-level correction that retargets continuation values and compensates transition mismatch via change of measure; a two-stage RWT Q-learning framework; theoretical regret bounds under RKHS; empirical tests in tabular and NN settings.

Result: RWT reduces task mismatch to a fixed one-step correction; regret bounds scale with task-shift complexity rather than target MDP; empirical results show consistent improvements over single-task learning and naive pooling.

Conclusion: Bellman alignment provides a model-agnostic transfer principle for online RL, enabling statistically sound reuse of source data and improved performance across settings.

Abstract: We study online transfer reinforcement learning (RL) in episodic Markov decision processes, where experience from related source tasks is available during learning on a target task. A fundamental difficulty is that task similarity is typically defined in terms of rewards or transitions, whereas online RL algorithms operate on Bellman regression targets. As a result, naively reusing source Bellman updates introduces systematic bias and invalidates regret guarantees.
  We identify one-step Bellman alignment as the correct abstraction for transfer in online RL and propose re-weighted targeting (RWT), an operator-level correction that retargets continuation values and compensates for transition mismatch via a change of measure. RWT reduces task mismatch to a fixed one-step correction and enables statistically sound reuse of source data.
  This alignment yields a two-stage RWT $Q$-learning framework that separates variance reduction from bias correction. Under RKHS function approximation, we establish regret bounds that scale with the complexity of the task shift rather than the target MDP. Empirical results in both tabular and neural network settings demonstrate consistent improvements over single-task learning and naïve pooling, highlighting Bellman alignment as a model-agnostic transfer principle for online RL.

</details>


### [351] [LoRIF: Low-Rank Influence Functions for Scalable Training Data Attribution](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21929)
*Shuangqi Li,Hieu Le,Jingyi Xu,Mathieu Salzmann*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: LoRIF enables scalable gradient-based training data attribution by leveraging low-rank structures, reducing storage and memory while maintaining or improving attribution quality.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To overcome two bottlenecks in gradient-based TDA: (i) I/O/storage of per-example projected gradients at scale; (ii) memory cost of D×D inverse Hessian; both scale with projection dimension D, hindering quality-scalability.

Method: Store rank-c factors of projected per-example gradients rather than full matrices; apply truncated SVD with Woodbury identity to approximate the Hessian term in an r-dimensional subspace; reductions in storage I/O to O(c sqrt(D)) per layer per sample and memory to O(Dr).

Result: LoRIF achieves up to 20× storage reduction and faster query time versus LoGRA; matches or exceeds attribution quality; scalable from 0.1B to 70B parameter models on million-scale datasets.

Conclusion: LoRIF makes gradient-based TDA practical at frontier scale by exploiting gradient low-rank structure, enabling efficient, high-quality attribution for large models and datasets.

Abstract: Training data attribution (TDA) identifies which training examples most influenced a model's prediction. The best-performing TDA methods exploits gradients to define an influence function. To overcome the scalability challenge arising from gradient computation, the most popular strategy is random projection (e.g., TRAK, LoGRA). However, this still faces two bottlenecks when scaling to large training sets and high-quality attribution: \emph{(i)} storing and loading projected per-example gradients for all $N$ training examples, where query latency is dominated by I/O; and \emph{(ii)} forming the $D \times D$ inverse Hessian approximation, which costs $O(D^2)$ memory. Both bottlenecks scale with the projection dimension $D$, yet increasing $D$ is necessary for attribution quality -- creating a quality-scalability tradeoff. We introduce \textbf{LoRIF (Low-Rank Influence Functions)}, which exploits low-rank structures of gradient to address both bottlenecks. First, we store rank-$c$ factors of the projected per-example gradients rather than full matrices, reducing storage and query-time I/O from $O(D)$ to $O(c\sqrt{D})$ per layer per sample. Second, we use truncated SVD with the Woodbury identity to approximate the Hessian term in an $r$-dimensional subspace, reducing memory from $O(D^2)$ to $O(Dr)$. On models from 0.1B to 70B parameters trained on datasets with millions of examples, LoRIF achieves up to 20$\times$ storage reduction and query-time speedup compared to LoGRA, while matching or exceeding its attribution quality. LoRIF makes gradient-based TDA practical at frontier scale.

</details>


### [352] [Robust Multimodal Representation Learning in Healthcare](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21941)
*Xiaoguang Zhu,Linxiao Gong,Lianlong Sun,Yang Liu,Haoyu Wang,Jing Liu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A dual-stream, causally-informed decorrelation framework for medical multimodal learning that disentangles causal features from biases, improving generalization across MIMIC-IV, eICU, and ADNI.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Medical multimodal data contain systemic biases from multiple sources that induce spurious correlations; existing fusion-focused methods fail to address these biases, hurting generalization. A method to separate causal features from biased correlations is needed.

Method: Introduce a model-agnostic dual-stream neural architecture that performs causal-bias decorrelation via structural causal analysis with latent confounders. The approach uses generalized cross-entropy loss and mutual information minimization to disentangle causal features from spurious correlations, and can be integrated into existing medical multimodal learning pipelines.

Result: Empirical evaluations on MIMIC-IV, eICU, and ADNI show consistent performance improvements over baselines, validating effective decorrelation of biases and better generalization.

Conclusion: The framework offers a practical plug-in solution for robust medical multimodal learning under bias by leveraging latent confounder–driven causal decorrelation, with broad applicability across datasets and modalities.

Abstract: Medical multimodal representation learning aims to integrate heterogeneous data into unified patient representations to support clinical outcome prediction. However, real-world medical datasets commonly contain systematic biases from multiple sources, which poses significant challenges for medical multimodal representation learning. Existing approaches typically focus on effective multimodal fusion, neglecting inherent biased features that affect the generalization ability.
