To address these challenges, we propose a Dual-Stream Feature Decorrelation Framework that identifies and handles the biases through structural causal analysis introduced by latent confounders. Our method employs a causal-biased decorrelation framework with dual-stream neural networks to disentangle causal features from spurious correlations, utilizing generalized cross-entropy loss and mutual information minimization for effective decorrelation. The framework is model-agnostic and can be integrated into existing medical multimodal learning methods. Comprehensive experiments on MIMIC-IV, eICU, and ADNI datasets demonstrate consistent performance improvements.

</details>


### [353] [Entropy-Based Dimension-Free Convergence and Loss-Adaptive Schedules for Diffusion Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21943)
*Ahmad Aghapour,Erhan Bayraktar,Ziqing Zhang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Presents a dimension-free convergence analysis for diffusion models via an information-theoretic KL bound, and introduces a Loss-Adaptive Schedule (LAS) for discretizing reverse SDE based on training loss, which improves sampling quality.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing analyses typically depend on ambient dimension or geometric assumptions about the target; the work seeks a dimension-free, assumption-light convergence framework.

Method: Develop an information-theoretic approach to bound KL(target || generated) by O(H^2/K) (H = Shannon entropy, K = sampling steps). Recast KL to derive LAS for discretizing reverse SDE, where LAS is lightweight and relies only on training loss.

Result: KL divergence bound of order O(H^2/K) (up to endpoint factors). LAS achieves improved sampling quality over common heuristic schedules in experiments.

Conclusion: Provides a dimension-free convergence perspective under mild conditions and a practical, loss-informed discretization scheme (LAS) that enhances sampling efficiency without heavy post-training computation.

Abstract: Diffusion generative models synthesize samples by discretizing reverse-time dynamics driven by a learned score (or denoiser). Existing convergence analyses of diffusion models typically scale at least linearly with the ambient dimension, and sharper rates often depend on intrinsic-dimension assumptions or other geometric restrictions on the target distribution. We develop an alternative, information-theoretic approach to dimension-free convergence that avoids any geometric assumptions. Under mild assumptions on the target distribution, we bound KL divergence between the target and generated distributions by $O(H^2/K)$ (up to endpoint factors), where $H$ is the Shannon entropy and $K$ is the number of sampling steps. Moreover, using a reformulation of the KL divergence, we propose a Loss-Adaptive Schedule (LAS) for efficient discretization of reverse SDE which is lightweight and relies only on the training loss, requiring no post-training heavy computation. Empirically, LAS improves sampling quality over common heuristic schedules.

</details>


### [354] [Clarity: The Flexibility-Interpretability Trade-Off in Sparsity-aware Concept Bottleneck Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21944)
*Konstantinos P. Panousis,Diego Marcos*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Analyzes how design choices in Concept Bottleneck Models (CBMs) for Vision-Language Models affect interpretability. Introduces a 'clarity' metric that combines downstream performance with sparsity and precision of concept representations; compares VLM-based and attribute-predictor CBMs under three sparsity strategies (per-example L1, L0, Bernoulli); finds a trade-off between interpretability and flexibility; provides an interpretability evaluation framework using ground-truth concept annotations; code to be released.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Interpreting Vision-Language Models remains challenging as they are often treated as black boxes. CBMs, especially sparsity-aware variants, promise interpretability, but objective, systematic evaluation of their learned representations is scarce. This work seeks to quantify how modeling decisions impact emergent concept representations and their interpretability.

Method: Define 'clarity' as a metric balancing downstream accuracy with the sparsity and precision of concept representations. Compare two CBM families (VLM-based CBMs and attribute-predictor CBMs) under three sparsity-inducing schemes: per-example L1, L0, and Bernoulli-based. Use datasets with ground-truth concept annotations and an interpretability assessment framework to evaluate representations.

Result: Reveal a critical trade-off between flexibility and interpretability: methods with similar downstream performance can exhibit markedly different interpretability. The choice of sparsity mechanism significantly affects the sparsity-precision-interpretability profile. No universal best approach; results highlight the need to align modeling decisions with interpretability goals.

Conclusion: Introduces the clarity measure and an interpretability evaluation framework for CBMs in VLMs. The work provides guidance on how to design CBMs with explicit interpretability considerations and will release code to support reproducibility and benchmarking.

Abstract: The widespread adoption of Vision-Language Models (VLMs) across fields has amplified concerns about model interpretability. Distressingly, these models are often treated as black-boxes, with limited or non-existent investigation of their decision making process. Despite numerous post- and ante-hoc interepretability methods, systematic and objective evaluation of the learned representations remains limited, particularly for sparsity-aware methods that are increasingly considered to "induce interpretability". In this work, we focus on Concept Bottleneck Models and investigate how different modeling decisions affect the emerging representations. We introduce the notion of clarity, a measure, capturing the interplay between the downstream performance and the sparsity and precision of the concept representation, while proposing an interpretability assessment framework using datasets with ground truth concept annotations. We consider both VLM- and attribute predictor-based CBMs, and three different sparsity-inducing strategies: per example $\ell_1, \ell_0$ and Bernoulli-based formulations. Our experiments reveal a critical trade-off between flexibility and interpretability, under which a given method can exhibit markedly different behaviors even at comparable performance levels. The code will be made publicly available upon publication.

</details>


### [355] [Dependence of Equilibrium Propagation Training Success on Network Architecture](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21945)
*Qingshan Wang,Clara C. Wanjura,Florian Marquardt*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Sparse, locally connected networks trained with equilibrium propagation can match dense networks on XY-model benchmarks, suggesting scalable, energy-efficient architectures for physics-based learning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the energy consumption of AI and explore hardware-friendly, realistic architectures for physics-based training beyond ideal densely connected models.

Method: Evaluate equilibrium propagation on locally connected lattice architectures by training an XY model, monitoring spatially distributed responses and couplings during training, and comparing performance to dense networks across benchmark tasks.

Result: Sparse networks with only local connections achieve performance comparable to dense networks.

Conclusion: Local connectivity suffices for competitive performance with equilibrium propagation in realistic settings; findings offer guidelines for scaling equilibrium-propagation-based architectures.

Abstract: The rapid rise of artificial intelligence has led to an unsustainable growth in energy consumption. This has motivated progress in neuromorphic computing and physics-based training of learning machines as alternatives to digital neural networks. Many theoretical studies focus on simple architectures like all-to-all or densely connected layered networks. However, these may be challenging to realize experimentally, e.g. due to connectivity constraints. In this work, we investigate the performance of the widespread physics-based training method of equilibrium propagation for more realistic architectural choices, specifically, locally connected lattices. We train an XY model and explore the influence of architecture on various benchmark tasks, tracking the evolution of spatially distributed responses and couplings during training. Our results show that sparse networks with only local connections can achieve performance comparable to dense networks. Our findings provide guidelines for further scaling up architectures based on equilibrium propagation in realistic settings.

</details>


### [356] [Embracing Aleatoric Uncertainty in Medical Multimodal Learning with Missing Modalities](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21950)
*Linxiao Gong,Yang Liu,Lianlong Sun,Yulai Bi,Jing Liu,Xiaoguang Zhu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes Aleatoric Uncertainty Modeling (AUM) for medical multimodal learning by representing each unimodal feature as a multivariate Gaussian and using an uncertainty-aware dynamic message-passing fusion on a bipartite patient-modality graph, enabling robust handling of missing modalities; demonstrates performance gains on MIMIC-IV and eICU mortality prediction.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Medical multimodal data frequently suffer from missing modalities and inherent data noise. Existing methods often assume equal modality contribution and random missingness, failing to capture uncertainty in data acquisition. There is a need for explicit unimodal aleatoric uncertainty modeling to guide reliable fusion.

Method: Model unimodal representations as multivariate Gaussian distributions (mean and covariance) to capture aleatoric uncertainty. Employ a dynamic message-passing mechanism on a bipartite patient-modality graph with uncertainty-aware aggregation to adaptively weight information from available modalities and accommodate missing ones. End-to-end training with a likelihood-based objective that leverages modality reliability during fusion.

Result: Reported improvements of 2.26% in AUC-ROC for MIMIC-IV mortality prediction and 2.17% for eICU mortality prediction, surpassing existing state-of-the-art approaches.

Conclusion: AUM offers principled unimodal uncertainty quantification and adaptive, uncertainty-aware fusion via dynamic message passing, improving performance in clinical multimodal tasks with missing modalities and suggesting broad applicability to other multimodal settings; prompts further work on calibration, ablations, and external validation.

Abstract: Medical multimodal learning faces significant challenges with missing modalities prevalent in clinical practice. Existing approaches assume equal contribution of modality and random missing patterns, neglecting inherent uncertainty in medical data acquisition. In this regard, we propose the Aleatoric Uncertainty Modeling (AUM) that explicitly quantifies unimodal aleatoric uncertainty to address missing modalities. Specifically, AUM models each unimodal representation as a multivariate Gaussian distribution to capture aleatoric uncertainty and enable principled modality reliability quantification. To adaptively aggregate captured information, we develop a dynamic message-passing mechanism within a bipartite patient-modality graph using uncertainty-aware aggregation mechanism. Through this process, missing modalities are naturally accommodated, while more reliable information from available modalities is dynamically emphasized to guide representation generation. Our AUM framework achieves an improvement of 2.26% AUC-ROC on MIMIC-IV mortality prediction and 2.17% gain on eICU, outperforming existing state-of-the-art approaches.

</details>


### [357] [Uncertainty-Aware Data-Based Method for Fast and Reliable Shape Optimization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21956)
*Yunjia Yang,Runze Li,Yufei Zhang,Haixin Chen*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: UA-DBO: uncertainty-aware data-based optimization using a probabilistic encoder-decoder surrogate to quantify and penalize high-uncertainty samples during optimization; improves accuracy and robustness in airfoil multipoint optimization, with speedups relative to full simulations.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: DBO performance hinges on training data; out-of-distribution samples during optimization can cause large surrogate errors, risking misleading updates; uncertainty quantification is needed to detect outliers and improve robustness.

Method: Introduce a probabilistic encoder-decoder surrogate that predicts both outputs and their uncertainties; integrate uncertainty into a model-confidence-aware objective to penalize uncertain samples during data-based optimization; applied to two multipoint airfoil optimization problems focused on drag divergence and buffet.

Result: UA-DBO reduces surrogate prediction errors in optimized samples; achieves superior performance compared to vanilla DBO; offers comparable optimization effectiveness to full-simulation multipoint optimization while significantly accelerating the optimization process.

Conclusion: Uncertainty-aware DBO enhances robustness and efficiency in data-driven aerodynamic optimization by incorporating a probabilistic surrogate and uncertainty-aware objective to mitigate distribution drift and accelerate convergence.

Abstract: Data-based optimization (DBO) offers a promising approach for efficiently optimizing shape for better aerodynamic performance by leveraging a pretrained surrogate model for offline evaluations during iterations. However, DBO heavily relies on the quality of the training database. Samples outside the training distribution encountered during optimization can lead to significant prediction errors, potentially misleading the optimization process. Therefore, incorporating uncertainty quantification into optimization is critical for detecting outliers and enhancing robustness. This study proposes an uncertainty-aware data-based optimization (UA-DBO) framework to monitor and minimize surrogate model uncertainty during DBO. A probabilistic encoder-decoder surrogate model is developed to predict uncertainties associated with its outputs, and these uncertainties are integrated into a model-confidence-aware objective function to penalize samples with large prediction errors during data-based optimization process. The UA-DBO framework is evaluated on two multipoint optimization problems aimed at improving airfoil drag divergence and buffet performance. Results demonstrate that UA-DBO consistently reduces prediction errors in optimized samples and achieves superior performance gains compared to original DBO. Moreover, compared to multipoint optimization based on full computational simulations, UA-DBO offers comparable optimization effectiveness while significantly accelerating optimization speed.

</details>


### [358] [Bridging Graph Structure and Knowledge-Guided Editing for Interpretable Temporal Knowledge Graph Reasoning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21978)
*Shiqi Fan,Quanming Yao,Hongyi Nie,Wentao Ma,Zhen Wang,Wen Hua*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: IGETR fuses graph-based temporal modeling with LLM-guided editing to robustly infer future events in temporal knowledge graphs, achieving state-of-the-art performance on ICEWS with notable gains and ablation-supported component effectiveness.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current LLM-centric TKGR approaches underutilize structural-temporal cues, leading to unreliable subgraph extraction and hallucination under temporal inconsistencies. A hybrid framework that grounds reasoning in data while leveraging external knowledge is needed.

Method: A three-stage pipeline: (1) ground reasoning via a temporal GNN to identify coherent candidate paths; (2) LLM-guided path editing to fix logical/semantic issues and integrate external knowledge; (3) integrate refined paths to generate accurate, interpretable predictions.

Result: State-of-the-art on standard TKG benchmarks; relative gains up to 5.6% on Hits@1 and 8.1% on Hits@3 on ICEWS; ablation studies confirm contributions of each component.

Conclusion: Hybrid integration of GNN-based temporal reasoning with LLM-guided editing yields accurate, interpretable TKGR predictions and improved robustness against temporal inconsistencies.

Abstract: Temporal knowledge graph reasoning (TKGR) aims to predict future events by inferring missing entities with dynamic knowledge structures. Existing LLM-based reasoning methods prioritize contextual over structural relations, struggling to extract relevant subgraphs from dynamic graphs. This limits structural information understanding, leading to unstructured, hallucination-prone inferences especially with temporal inconsistencies. To address this problem, we propose IGETR (Integration of Graph and Editing-enhanced Temporal Reasoning), a hybrid reasoning framework that combines the structured temporal modeling capabilities of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) with the contextual understanding of LLMs. IGETR operates through a three-stage pipeline. The first stage aims to ground the reasoning process in the actual data by identifying structurally and temporally coherent candidate paths through a temporal GNN, ensuring that inference starts from reliable graph-based evidence. The second stage introduces LLM-guided path editing to address logical and semantic inconsistencies, leveraging external knowledge to refine and enhance the initial paths. The final stage focuses on integrating the refined reasoning paths to produce predictions that are both accurate and interpretable. Experiments on standard TKG benchmarks show that IGETR achieves state-of-the-art performance, outperforming strong baselines with relative improvements of up to 5.6% on Hits@1 and 8.1% on Hits@3 on the challenging ICEWS datasets. Additionally, we execute ablation studies and additional analyses confirm the effectiveness of each component.

</details>


### [359] [Investigation into using stochastic embedding representations for evaluating the trustworthiness of the Fréchet Inception Distance](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21979)
*Ciaran Bench,Vivek Desai,Carlijn Roozemond,Ruben van Engen,Spencer A. Thomas*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Monte Carlo dropout-based predictive variance for FID and embedding features shows correlations with out-of-distribution degree, highlighting limitations of ImageNet-trained FID for medical images and offering a uncertainty-based diagnostic for FID trustworthiness.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: FID relies on a natural-image pretrained feature extractor (InceptionV3 on ImageNet1K) and may fail to capture medical-image characteristics. The paper investigates how predictive uncertainty in FID and in latent embeddings relates to OOD, to assess the trustworthiness of FID in medical contexts.

Method: Apply Monte Carlo dropout to estimate predictive variance for FID and for the latent feature embeddings. Evaluate on ImageNet1K validation set with varying augmentations to simulate OOD and on other external datasets. Analyze correlations between predictive variances and the degree of distribution shift relative to training data.

Result: The magnitudes of the predictive variances exhibit varying degrees of correlation with the extent to which test inputs are out-of-distribution relative to the training data. This provides partial insight into the effectiveness of predictive variance as an indicator of FID trustworthiness.

Conclusion: Predictive variance can partly signal when FID is unreliable due to distribution shift toward medical-like data, but the correlation is not uniform. Caution is warranted when using FID for medical datasets; incorporating uncertainty estimates and possibly domain-specific features can improve assessment of synthetic image quality.

Abstract: Feature embeddings acquired from pretrained models are widely used in medical applications of deep learning to assess the characteristics of datasets; e.g. to determine the quality of synthetic, generated medical images. The Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) is one popular synthetic image quality metric that relies on the assumption that the characteristic features of the data can be detected and encoded by an InceptionV3 model pretrained on ImageNet1K (natural images). While it is widely known that this makes it less effective for applications involving medical images, the extent to which the metric fails to capture meaningful differences in image characteristics is not obviously known. Here, we use Monte Carlo dropout to compute the predictive variance in the FID as well as a supplemental estimate of the predictive variance in the feature embedding model's latent representations. We show that the magnitudes of the predictive variances considered exhibit varying degrees of correlation with the extent to which test inputs (ImageNet1K validation set augmented at various strengths, and other external datasets) are out-of-distribution relative to its training data, providing some insight into the effectiveness of their use as indicators of the trustworthiness of the FID.

</details>


### [360] [PowerGenie: Analytically-Guided Evolutionary Discovery of Superior Reconfigurable Power Converters](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21984)
*Jian Gao,Yiwei Zou,Abhishek Pradhan,Wenhao Huang,Yumin Su,Kaiyuan Yang,Xuan Zhang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: PowerGenie offers an automated, scalable framework for discovering high-performance reconfigurable power converters, combining an analytic bound framework with evolutionary finetuning of a generative model to improve design validity, novelty, and performance, demonstrated by an 8-mode converter with 23% FoM gain and SPICE-backed efficiency gains.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the exponential design space of circuit topologies and the limitations of template-based or small-scale approaches, enabling rigorous, large-scale, performance-driven discovery without extensive SPICE sizing.

Method: 1) Automated analytical framework to determine converter functionality and theoretical performance limits without component sizing or SPICE. 2) Evolutionary finetuning that co-evolves a generative model with its training distribution using fitness selection and uniqueness verification to avoid mode collapse and overfitting.

Result: PowerGenie discovers a novel 8-mode reconfigurable converter with 23% higher figure-of-merit (FoM) than the best training topology. SPICE simulations show average absolute efficiency gains of ~10% across 8 modes and up to ~17% in a single mode; higher syntax validity, function validity, and novelty rate compared to baselines.

Conclusion: Demonstrates scalable, performance-driven discovery of high-quality power-converter topologies and provides code for reproducibility.

Abstract: Discovering superior circuit topologies requires navigating an exponentially large design space-a challenge traditionally reserved for human experts. Existing AI methods either select from predefined templates or generate novel topologies at a limited scale without rigorous verification, leaving large-scale performance-driven discovery underexplored. We present PowerGenie, a framework for automated discovery of higher-performance reconfigurable power converters at scale. PowerGenie introduces: (1) an automated analytical framework that determines converter functionality and theoretical performance limits without component sizing or SPICE simulation, and (2) an evolutionary finetuning method that co-evolves a generative model with its training distribution through fitness selection and uniqueness verification. Unlike existing methods that suffer from mode collapse and overfitting, our approach achieves higher syntax validity, function validity, novelty rate, and figure-of-merit (FoM). PowerGenie discovers a novel 8-mode reconfigurable converter with 23% higher FoM than the best training topology. SPICE simulations confirm average absolute efficiency gains of 10% across 8 modes and up to 17% at a single mode. Code is available at https://github.com/xz-group/PowerGenie.

</details>


### [361] [Elign: Equivariant Diffusion Model Alignment from Foundational Machine Learning Force Fields](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21985)
*Yunyang Li,Lin Huang,Luojia Xia,Wenhe Zhang,Mark Gerstein*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Elign is a post-training framework that amortizes computational costs in E(3)-equivariant diffusion for 3D molecular conformations by (1) replacing DFT with a pretrained ML force field during inference, and (2) shifting energy guidance into training via reinforcement learning with FED-GRPO, achieving lower DFT energies/forces and improved stability with fast unguided sampling.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Ensure 3D molecular conformations respect Euclidean symmetries and thermodynamic stability while avoiding biases from semi-empirical data and reducing the computational burden of quantum-chemical evaluations.

Method: Dual amortization: (i) replace expensive DFT with a fast pretrained ML force field to provide physical signals; (ii) treat reverse diffusion as a reinforcement learning problem and train with Force–Energy Disentangled Group Relative Policy Optimization (FED-GRPO), using a potential-based energy reward and a force-based stability reward, both group-normalized and optimized independently.

Result: Generated conformations exhibit lower gold-standard DFT energies and forces and improved stability; inference remains as fast as unguided sampling since no energy evaluations are needed during generation.

Conclusion: Elign demonstrates effective training-time RL-based steering to align diffusion sampling with high-fidelity Hamiltonians, enabling fast, accurate conformations without runtime energy evaluations, and suggests broader applicability to energy-guided diffusion in molecular design.

Abstract: Generative models for 3D molecular conformations must respect Euclidean symmetries and concentrate probability mass on thermodynamically favorable, mechanically stable structures. However, E(3)-equivariant diffusion models often reproduce biases from semi-empirical training data rather than capturing the equilibrium distribution of a high-fidelity Hamiltonian. While physics-based guidance can correct this, it faces two computational bottlenecks: expensive quantum-chemical evaluations (e.g., DFT) and the need to repeat such queries at every sampling step. We present Elign, a post-training framework that amortizes both costs. First, we replace expensive DFT evaluations with a faster, pretrained foundational machine-learning force field (MLFF) to provide physical signals. Second, we eliminate repeated run-time queries by shifting physical steering to the training phase. To achieve the second amortization, we formulate reverse diffusion as a reinforcement learning problem and introduce Force--Energy Disentangled Group Relative Policy Optimization (FED-GRPO) to fine-tune the denoising policy. FED-GRPO includes a potential-based energy reward and a force-based stability reward, which are optimized and group-normalized independently. Experiments show that Elign generates conformations with lower gold-standard DFT energies and forces, while improving stability. Crucially, inference remains as fast as unguided sampling, since no energy evaluations are required during generation.

</details>


### [362] [Geometry of Drifting MDPs with Path-Integral Stability Certificates](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21991)
*Zuyuan Zhang,Mahdi Imani,Tian Lan*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A geometric, homotopy-based framework for nonstationary discounted MDPs that tracks how the optimal Bellman point moves and uses HT-RL/HT-MCTS wrappers to adapt learning/planning, yielding better tracking and lower dynamic regret, especially under oscillations and switches.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Real-world RL is frequently nonstationary, with rewards and dynamics drifting and switching. Existing theory often measures only the magnitude of change, neglecting local geometric factors (acceleration, near-ties) that drive tracking error. A local, geometric view can enable tighter stability guarantees and adaptive control.

Method: Model the environment as a differentiable homotopy path and track the induced motion of the optimal Bellman fixed point. Define a length-curvature-kink signature that captures cumulative drift, acceleration/oscillation, and nonsmoothness from near-ties. Prove a solver-agnostic path-integral stability bound and derive gap-safe feasible regions away from switch regimes. Develop HT-RL and HT-MCTS wrappers that online estimate proxies of length, curvature, and near-tie proximity from replay data and adapt learning/planning intensity accordingly.

Result: Empirical results show improved tracking and dynamic regret over matched static baselines, with the largest gains in oscillatory and switch-prone regimes.

Conclusion: The homotopy-tracking framework provides local stability certificates and adaptive mechanisms for nonstationary RL, enabling more robust performance via HT-RL and HT-MCTS in challenging environments.

Abstract: Real-world reinforcement learning is often \emph{nonstationary}: rewards and dynamics drift, accelerate, oscillate, and trigger abrupt switches in the optimal action. Existing theory often represents nonstationarity with coarse-scale models that measure \emph{how much} the environment changes, not \emph{how} it changes locally -- even though acceleration and near-ties drive tracking error and policy chattering. We take a geometric view of nonstationary discounted Markov Decision Processes (MDPs) by modeling the environment as a differentiable homotopy path and tracking the induced motion of the optimal Bellman fixed point. This yields a length-curvature-kink signature of intrinsic complexity: cumulative drift, acceleration/oscillation, and action-gap-induced nonsmoothness. We prove a solver-agnostic path-integral stability bound and derive gap-safe feasible regions that certify local stability away from switch regimes. Building on these results, we introduce \textit{Homotopy-Tracking RL (HT-RL)} and \textit{HT-MCTS}, lightweight wrappers that estimate replay-based proxies of length, curvature, and near-tie proximity online and adapt learning or planning intensity accordingly. Experiments show improved tracking and dynamic regret over matched static baselines, with the largest gains in oscillatory and switch-prone regimes.

</details>


### [363] [Negatives-Dominant Contrastive Learning for Generalization in Imbalanced Domains](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21999)
*Meng Cao,Jiexi Liu,Songcan Chen*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces Negative-Dominant Contrastive Learning (NDCL) for Imbalanced Domain Generalization (IDG) with a new generalization bound emphasizing posterior discrepancy and decision margin, and a training objective that prioritizes negatives to separate decision boundaries across domains while ensuring intra-class compactness and posterior consistency.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: IDG must handle both domain shifts and long-tailed label distributions, which jointly shape decision boundaries. Existing methods lack theoretical foundations and effectively disentangle domain and label shifts; a boundary-centric approach with theoretical backing is proposed.

Method: Derives a generalization bound for IDG highlighting posterior discrepancy and decision margin. Proposes NDCL: (1) inter-class boundary separation by using negatives as primary signal in a contrastive loss; (2) re-weighted cross-entropy for intra-class compactness; (3) prediction-centered alignment to enforce posterior consistency across domains.

Result: Empirical results on standard benchmarks demonstrate improved discriminability and robustness to label shift under domain heterogeneity. The authors provide code for reproduction at the given GitHub repository.

Conclusion: NDCL offers a principled boundary-focused approach to IDG, supported by a theoretical bound and solid empirical gains. It presents a viable direction for handling joint domain and label shifts in imbalanced settings.

Abstract: Imbalanced Domain Generalization (IDG) focuses on mitigating both domain and label shifts, both of which fundamentally shape the model's decision boundaries, particularly under heterogeneous long-tailed distributions across domains. Despite its practical significance, it remains underexplored, primarily due to the technical complexity of handling their entanglement and the paucity of theoretical foundations. In this paper, we begin by theoretically establishing the generalization bound for IDG, highlighting the role of posterior discrepancy and decision margin. This bound motivates us to focus on directly steering decision boundaries, marking a clear departure from existing methods. Subsequently, we technically propose a novel Negative-Dominant Contrastive Learning (NDCL) for IDG to enhance discriminability while enforce posterior consistency across domains. Specifically, inter-class decision-boundary separation is enhanced by placing greater emphasis on negatives as the primary signal in our contrastive learning, naturally amplifying gradient signals for minority classes to avoid the decision boundary being biased toward majority classes. Meanwhile, intra-class compactness is encouraged through a re-weighted cross-entropy strategy, and posterior consistency across domains is enforced through a prediction-central alignment strategy. Finally, rigorous yet challenging experiments on benchmarks validate the effectiveness of our NDCL. The code is available at https://github.com/Alrash/NDCL.

</details>


### [364] [Rate-Distortion Optimization for Transformer Inference](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22002)
*Anderson de Andrade,Alon Harell,Ivan V. Bajić*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A principled rate-distortion framework for lossy compression in transformer inference, learning compact encodings that trade bitrate for accuracy; shows efficiency gains on language tasks and provides an information-theoretic lens plus PAC-style bounds.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To reduce the inference cost of transformers by compressing intermediate representations across devices, enabling distributed execution while managing accuracy loss.

Method: Introduce a rate-distortion–based lossy compression scheme for transformer representations; learn encodings optimized for bitrate–accuracy trade-offs; derive bounds relating rate and entropy and provide PAC-style estimates; empirical evaluation on language benchmarks with comparisons to baseline methods.

Result: Substantial bitrate savings with improved accuracy in some cases; outperforms more complex baselines; offers a unified rate–distortion perspective for transformer representations and connects empirical performance to theoretical bounds across architectures/tasks.

Conclusion: Extends information-theoretic concepts to representation coding in transformers, defining rate–entropy gaps and providing PAC-based bounds; delivers explainability for how compression rates relate to model performance and supports communication-efficient, distributed inference.

Abstract: Transformers achieve superior performance on many tasks, but impose heavy compute and memory requirements during inference. This inference can be made more efficient by partitioning the process across multiple devices, which, in turn, requires compressing its intermediate representations. In this work, we introduce a principled rate-distortion-based framework for lossy compression that learns compact encodings that explicitly trade off bitrate against accuracy. Experiments on language benchmarks show that the proposed codec achieves substantial savings with improved accuracy in some cases, outperforming more complex baseline methods. We characterize and analyze the rate-distortion performance of transformers, offering a unified lens for understanding performance in representation coding. This formulation extends information-theoretic concepts to define the gap between rate and entropy, and derive some of its bounds. We further develop probably approximately correct (PAC)-style bounds for estimating this gap. For different architectures and tasks, we empirically demonstrate that their rates are driven by these bounds, adding to the explainability of the formulation.

</details>


### [365] [Exploring Diverse Generation Paths via Inference-time Stiefel Activation Steering](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22010)
*Dongxuan Zhu,Ly Tran Ho Khanh,Andy Yat-Ming Cheung,Man-Chung Yue,Viet Anh Nguyen*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: STARS is a training-free, inference-time intervention that uses Stiefel-based activation steering to promote diverse outputs across concurrent generation runs by orthogonally steering hidden activations on the Stiefel manifold.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Language models tend to produce a narrow set of high-probability outputs, leading to low diversity and mode collapse across parallel generations; there is a need for a lightweight, real-time method to induce diversity without retraining.

Method: At each token, STARS gathers hidden activations from concurrent generations and jointly optimizes multiple additive steering directions on the Stiefel manifold to maximize the volume of steered activations, enforcing orthogonality among steering directions via manifold constraints; this can be solved via Riemannian gradient descent, but a one-step closed-form step is proposed for low latency.

Result: Empirical benchmarks on test-case generation and scientific discovery tasks show STARS yields greater diversity than standard sampling methods without sacrificing qualitative performance.

Conclusion: STARS offers a training-free, inference-time mechanism to diversify generation trajectories by steering activations on the Stiefel manifold, achieving higher diversity with minimal latency.

Abstract: Language models often default to a narrow set of high-probability outputs, leaving their generation paths homogeneous and prone to mode collapse. Sampling-based strategies inject randomness but still struggle to guarantee diversity across multiple concurrent generation runs. We address this limitation by introducing STARS ($\textbf{St}$iefel-based $\textbf{A}$ctivation Steering for Diverse $\textbf{R}$ea$\textbf{S}$oning), a training-free, inference-time intervention method that transforms activation steering into an exploration engine. At each token, STARS collects the hidden activations of concurrent generation runs and optimizes multiple additive steering directions jointly on the Stiefel manifold. STARS maximizes the geometric volume of the steered activations, while the Stiefel manifold induces orthogonality of the steering interventions. This formulation explicitly promotes divergent activation vectors of concurrent generation runs, and implicitly promotes divergent generation trajectories. This manifold optimization formulation can be solved using a Riemannian gradient descent algorithm with convergence guarantees, but this algorithm is too time-consuming for real-time inference. To guarantee low latency, we further design a lightweight one-step update with an aggressive, closed-form stepsize. For test case generation and scientific discovery benchmarks, STARS consistently outperforms standard sampling methods, achieving greater diversity without sacrificing qualitative performance.

</details>


### [366] [Putting a Face to Forgetting: Continual Learning meets Mechanistic Interpretability](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22012)
*Sergi Masip,Gido M. van de Ven,Javier Ferrando,Tinne Tuytelaars*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A feature-centric mechanistic framework for catastrophic forgetting in continual learning, interpreting forgetting as geometric transformations of individual feature encodings that reduce representational capacity and disrupt downstream readout; supported by a tractable model, empirical validation, and practical analysis with Crosscoders on a Vision Transformer trained on sequential CIFAR-10.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current evaluation focus on last-layer performance misses the underlying mechanisms of forgetting. A geometric, feature-level description can unify theory and practice in continual learning and guide architecture design.

Method: Introduce a tractable geometric model of feature encodings, analyze transformations during sequential tasks to identify best- and worst-case scenarios, test predictions empirically, assess depth effects, and demonstrate applicability to real models via Crosscoders with a Vision Transformer trained on sequential CIFAR-10.

Result: Transformations of feature encodings can decrease the allocated capacity of features and disrupt their readout, driving forgetting; depth is detrimental; empirical results support the theoretical predictions; Crosscoders facilitate applying the framework to practical models.

Conclusion: Proposes a new, feature-centric vocabulary and mechanistic framework for continual learning that connects theory with practice and enables analysis of practical models.

Abstract: Catastrophic forgetting in continual learning is often measured at the performance or last-layer representation level, overlooking the underlying mechanisms. We introduce a mechanistic framework that offers a geometric interpretation of catastrophic forgetting as the result of transformations to the encoding of individual features. These transformations can lead to forgetting by reducing the allocated capacity of features (worse representation) and disrupting their readout by downstream computations. Analysis of a tractable model formalizes this view, allowing us to identify best- and worst-case scenarios. Through experiments on this model, we empirically test our formal analysis and highlight the detrimental effect of depth. Finally, we demonstrate how our framework can be used in the analysis of practical models through the use of Crosscoders. We present a case study of a Vision Transformer trained on sequential CIFAR-10. Our work provides a new, feature-centric vocabulary for continual learning.

</details>


### [367] [TBDFiltering: Sample-Efficient Tree-Based Data Filtering](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22016)
*Robert Istvan Busa-Fekete,Julian Zimmert,Anne Xiangyi Zheng,Claudio Gentile,Andras Gyorgy*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: An embedding-based hierarchical clustering framework selects a small, informative set of documents for LLM quality labeling, achieving query efficiency under a subtree purity assumption and outperforming classifier-based filters.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Quality and diversity of training data for LLMs are critical but current quality metrics are expensive; scalable, cheap metrics are needed to estimate document quality without querying every document.

Method: Construct text embeddings for documents and build a hierarchical clustering. Iteratively select documents to query with an LLM to estimate cluster quality. The method is proven to be query-efficient: if the clustering contains a subtree with leaf clusters that are (almost) pure, then with high probability the algorithm can predict the quality of each document after querying a small number of documents; the required number of queries scales with the size of the smallest pure-subtree, without knowing it in advance.

Result: Theoretical guarantee of query efficiency under the purity-subtree assumption; comprehensive experiments showing the method outperforms classifier-based filtering methods on quality selection for LLM training data.

Conclusion: Embedding-based hierarchical clustering offers a scalable, query-efficient approach to estimating document quality for LLM training data, enabling better quality and diversity control at scale.

Abstract: The quality of machine learning models depends heavily on their training data. Selecting high-quality, diverse training sets for large language models (LLMs) is a difficult task, due to the lack of cheap and reliable quality metrics. While querying existing LLMs for document quality is common, this is not scalable to the large number (billions) of documents used in training. Instead, practitioners often use classifiers trained on sparse quality signals. In this paper, we propose a text-embedding-based hierarchical clustering approach that adaptively selects the documents to be evaluated by the LLM to estimate cluster quality. We prove that our method is query efficient: under the assumption that the hierarchical clustering contains a subtree such that each leaf cluster in the tree is pure enough (i.e., it mostly contains either only good or only bad documents), with high probability, the method can correctly predict the quality of each document after querying a small number of documents. The number of such documents is proportional to the size of the smallest subtree with (almost) pure leaves, without the algorithm knowing this subtree in advance. Furthermore, in a comprehensive experimental study, we demonstrate the benefits of our algorithm compared to other classifier-based filtering methods.

</details>


### [368] [From Logits to Latents: Contrastive Representation Shaping for LLM Unlearning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22028)
*Haoran Tang,Rajiv Khanna*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: CLReg is a contrastive representation regularizer that reduces forget-retain representation entanglement in LLM unlearning by shaping representations to identify forget features and push them away from retain features, with minimal shifts to retained knowledge; empirically effective across benchmarks and model sizes, and does not introduce extra privacy risks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing unlearning methods often approximate retrain-from-scratch in the prediction space but can leave forgotten concepts entangled within representations, potentially leaking memory or hindering full forgetting.

Method: CLReg uses a contrastive objective to identify forget features and actively separate them from retain features in representation space, aiming to minimize interference with retain features while reducing forget-retain entanglement; includes theoretical insights linking representation shaping to entanglement reduction.

Result: Across unlearning benchmarks and LLMs of various sizes, CLReg reduces forgetting-related entanglement between forget and retain representations, facilitating mainstream unlearning methods without adding privacy risks; suggests future work on representation-space reshaping to remove forget concepts.

Conclusion: Represents a step toward representation-space-based unlearning; motivates future exploration of alignment-free or representation-focused strategies to eliminate forgotten concepts with minimal impact on retained knowledge.

Abstract: Most LLM unlearning methods aim to approximate retrain-from-scratch behaviors with minimal distribution shift, often via alignment-style objectives defined in the prediction space. While effective at reducing forgotten content generation, such approaches may act as suppression: forgotten concepts can persist in representations and remain entangled with retained knowledge. We introduce CLReg, a contrastive representation regularizer that identifies forget features while pushing them away from retain features, explicitly reducing forget-retain interference with minimal shifts on retain features. We provide first theoretical insights that relate representation shaping to entanglement reduction. Across unlearning benchmarks and LLMs of different sizes, CLReg decreases forget-retain representation entanglement that facilitates mainstream unlearning methods without positing extra privacy risks, inspiring future work that reshapes the representation space to remove forget concepts.

</details>


### [369] [The Ensemble Inverse Problem: Applications and Methods](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22029)
*Zhengyan Huan,Camila Pazos,Martin Klassen,Vincent Croft,Pierre-Hugues Beauchemin,Shuchin Aeron*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces the Ensemble Inverse Problem (EIP) and ensemble inverse generative models to perform non-iterative posterior inference by leveraging ensemble information, avoiding online forward-model calls, and generalizing across priors; demonstrated in inverse imaging, HEP, and FWI with public code.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Unfolding/inverse problems require costly forward-model iterations; need inference-time methods that incorporate prior ensemble information and robust to unseen priors; desire non-iterative posterior samplers.

Method: Proposes ensemble inverse generative models that condition on both measurements and ensemble information; train across multiple truth–observation sets from the same forward model but varying priors, enabling implicit encoding of the likelihood; inference bypasses explicit forward-model evaluations.

Result: Benchmark on synthetic and real datasets across inverse imaging, HEP and FWI; shows improved posterior inference and generalization to unseen priors; code released at GitHub.

Conclusion: Provides a non-iterative, training-time-leveraged posterior sampler for EIP, leveraging ensemble information to generalize across priors and reduce inference-time forward-model reliance.

Abstract: We introduce a new multivariate statistical problem that we refer to as the Ensemble Inverse Problem (EIP). The aim of EIP is to invert for an ensemble that is distributed according to the pushforward of a prior under a forward process. In high energy physics (HEP), this is related to a widely known problem called unfolding, which aims to reconstruct the true physics distribution of quantities, such as momentum and angle, from measurements that are distorted by detector effects. In recent applications, the EIP also arises in full waveform inversion (FWI) and inverse imaging with unknown priors. We propose non-iterative inference-time methods that construct posterior samplers based on a new class of conditional generative models, which we call ensemble inverse generative models. For the posterior modeling, these models additionally use the ensemble information contained in the observation set on top of single measurements. Unlike existing methods, our proposed methods avoid explicit and iterative use of the forward model at inference time via training across several sets of truth-observation pairs that are consistent with the same forward model, but originate from a wide range of priors. We demonstrate that this training procedure implicitly encodes the likelihood model. The use of ensemble information helps posterior inference and enables generalization to unseen priors. We benchmark the proposed method on several synthetic and real datasets in inverse imaging, HEP, and FWI. The codes are available at https://github.com/ZhengyanHuan/The-Ensemble-Inverse-Problem--Applications-and-Methods.

</details>


### [370] [Per-parameter Task Arithmetic for Unlearning in Large Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22030)
*Chengyi Cai,Zesheng Ye,Jiangchao Yao,Jianzhong Qi,Bo Han,Xiaolu Zhang,Feng Liu,Jun Zhou*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: PerTA introduces per-parameter task arithmetic to tailor forgetting vs. retention by rescaling the task vector with per-parameter weights estimated from gradients or diagonal Fisher information; it maintains TV efficiency while reducing over-forgetting and improving overall model utility.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Standard task arithmetic (TV) can cause over-forgetting by applying a uniform parameter update. Different parameters contribute differently to forgetting and retention; per-parameter adjustment aims to preserve useful knowledge while removing privacy-sensitive information.

Method: PerTA adds per-parameter scaling factors to the TV, effectively weighting each parameter's contribution to unlearning. Two estimation approaches are proposed: PerTA-grad (weights derived from gradients to quantify forgetting/retention importance) and PerTA-fisher (weights derived from diagonal Fisher information). The method is extended into a more general form and analyzed.

Result: Extensive experiments show PerTA consistently improves upon standard TV and, in many cases, surpasses training-based unlearning methods in forgetting effectiveness and overall model utility.

Conclusion: PerTA preserves the efficiency of task arithmetic while mitigating over-forgetting, offering a principled, practical framework for LLM unlearning.

Abstract: In large language model (LLM) unlearning, private information is required to be removed. Task arithmetic unlearns by subtracting a specific task vector (TV)--defined as the parameter difference between a privacy-information-tuned model and the original model. While efficient, it can cause over-forgetting by disrupting parameters essential for retaining other information. Motivated by the observation that each parameter exhibits different importance for forgetting versus retention, we propose a per-parameter task arithmetic (PerTA) mechanism to rescale the TV, allowing per-parameter adjustment. These weights quantify the relative importance of each parameter for forgetting versus retention, estimated via gradients (i.e., PerTA-grad) or the diagonal Fisher information approximation (i.e., PerTA-fisher). Moreover, we discuss the effectiveness of PerTA, extend it to a more general form, and provide further analysis. Extensive experiments demonstrate that PerTA consistently improves upon standard TV, and in many cases surpasses widely used training-based unlearning methods in both forgetting effectiveness and overall model utility. By retaining the efficiency of task arithmetic while mitigating over-forgetting, PerTA offers a principled and practical framework for LLM unlearning.

</details>


### [371] [Holographic generative flows with AdS/CFT](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22033)
*Ehsan Mirafzali,Sanjit Shashi,Sanya Murdeshwar,Edgar Shaghoulian,Daniele Venturi,Razvan Marinescu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A holography-inspired generative framework using AdS/CFT to augment flow-matching in ML, achieving faster convergence and interpretable physics on MNIST and a checkerboard dataset.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Leverage AdS/CFT geometry to provide physically meaningful inductive biases for flow-based generative models, potentially improving sample quality and convergence.

Method: Model data flow via bulk-to-boundary mapping of scalar fields in AdS; integrate AdS physics into a flow-matching algorithm; evaluate on simple synthetic checkerboard and MNIST datasets.

Result: Faster convergence and higher-quality samples compared with physics-free flow-matching baselines; provides interpretable physics-based view of the flow; demonstrates utility of AdS geometry in generative modeling.

Conclusion: Shows that holographic physics can inform new generative modeling paradigms; invites broader exploration of AdS/CFT-inspired architectures for ML tasks.

Abstract: We present a framework for generative machine learning that leverages the holographic principle of quantum gravity, or to be more precise its manifestation as the anti-de Sitter/conformal field theory (AdS/CFT) correspondence, with techniques for deep learning and transport theory. Our proposal is to represent the flow of data from a base distribution to some learned distribution using the bulk-to-boundary mapping of scalar fields in AdS. In the language of machine learning, we are representing and augmenting the flow-matching algorithm with AdS physics. Using a checkerboard toy dataset and MNIST, we find that our model achieves faster and higher quality convergence than comparable physics-free flow-matching models. Our method provides a physically interpretable version of flow matching. More broadly, it establishes the utility of AdS physics and geometry in the development of novel paradigms in generative modeling.

</details>


### [372] [Cross-Fusion Distance: A Novel Metric for Measuring Fusion and Separability Between Data Groups in Representation Space](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22036)
*Xiaolong Zhang,Jianwei Zhang,Xubo Song*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces Cross-Fusion Distance (CFD) to quantify fusion and separability between representation groups under domain shift, isolating fusion-altering geometry while ignoring fusion-preserving transformations; claims linear complexity, theoretical guarantees, and better alignment with generalization degradation than existing metrics.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current distributional distances conflate geometry changes due to fusion with scale/layout variations, obscuring true fusion among groups; a metric that isolates the relevant geometry would better diagnose representation quality under domain shift.

Method: Define CFD with invariances to fusion-preserving factors, characterize invariance/sensitivity properties, prove linear computational complexity, validate on synthetic controls, and evaluate on real datasets under domain shift with comparison to baselines.

Result: CFD demonstrates robustness to fusion-preserving variations, theoretical properties established; in synthetic experiments validated; on real-world domain-shift data, CFD correlates more with generalization degradation than alternatives.

Conclusion: CFD provides a principled, interpretable, and efficient distance for representation learning to quantify fusion between data groups under domain shift.

Abstract: Quantifying degrees of fusion and separability between data groups in representation space is a fundamental problem in representation learning, particularly under domain shift. A meaningful metric should capture fusion-altering factors like geometric displacement between representation groups, whose variations change the extent of fusion, while remaining invariant to fusion-preserving factors such as global scaling and sampling-induced layout changes, whose variations do not. Existing distributional distance metrics conflate these factors, leading to measures that are not informative of the true extent of fusion between data groups. We introduce Cross-Fusion Distance (CFD), a principled measure that isolates fusion-altering geometry while remaining robust to fusion-preserving variations, with linear computational complexity. We characterize the invariance and sensitivity properties of CFD theoretically and validate them in controlled synthetic experiments. For practical utility on real-world datasets with domain shift, CFD aligns more closely with downstream generalization degradation than commonly used alternatives. Overall, CFD provides a theoretically grounded and interpretable distance measure for representation learning.

</details>


### [373] [Making Foundation Models Probabilistic via Singular Value Ensembles](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22068)
*Mehmet Ozgur Turkoglu,Dominik J. Mühlematter,Alexander Becker,Konrad Schindler,Helge Aasen*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: SVE is a parameter-efficient implicit ensemble that uses frozen singular vectors of weight matrices as a shared knowledge basis and trains per-member singular values to create diverse ensembles. It yields uncertainty quantification close to deep ensembles with <1% base-parameter overhead, improving calibration on NLP/vision tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the high computational cost of traditional deep ensembles for estimating epistemic uncertainty in large foundation models. Seek a scalable, parameter-efficient method that preserves predictive performance and calibration.

Method: Perform SVD on weight matrices to extract singular vectors (orthogonal knowledge directions). Freeze these vectors and train per-member singular values that rescale the contribution of each direction for each ensemble member. Ensemble diversity arises from random initialization and stochastic mini-batch training while keeping a shared basis, increasing base model parameters by <1%. Validate on NLP and vision benchmarks with various backbones.

Result: SVE achieves uncertainty quantification comparable to explicit deep ensembles while keeping parameter overhead under 1% and maintaining predictive accuracy. It improves calibration across tasks and backbones in NLP and vision datasets.

Conclusion: A practical, scalable method for quantifying epistemic uncertainty in foundation models. By tying ensemble diversity to the manipulation of a shared, meaningful basis (weight space singular vectors), SVE delivers calibrated predictions with minimal parameter cost, enabling deployment in resource-constrained settings.

Abstract: Foundation models have become a dominant paradigm in machine learning, achieving remarkable performance across diverse tasks through large-scale pretraining. However, these models often yield overconfident, uncalibrated predictions. The standard approach to quantifying epistemic uncertainty, training an ensemble of independent models, incurs prohibitive computational costs that scale linearly with ensemble size, making it impractical for large foundation models. We propose Singular Value Ensemble (SVE), a parameter-efficient implicit ensemble method that builds on a simple, but powerful core assumption: namely, that the singular vectors of the weight matrices constitute meaningful subspaces of the model's knowledge. Pretrained foundation models encode rich, transferable information in their weight matrices. If the singular vectors are indeed meaningful (orthogonal) "knowledge directions". To obtain a model ensemble, we modulate only how strongly each direction contributes to the output. Rather than learning entirely new parameters, we freeze the singular vectors and only train per-member singular values that rescale the contribution of each direction in that shared knowledge basis. Ensemble diversity emerges naturally as stochastic initialization and random sampling of mini-batches during joint training cause different members to converge to different combinations of the same underlying knowledge. SVE achieves uncertainty quantification comparable to explicit deep ensembles while increasing the parameter count of the base model by less than 1%, making principled uncertainty estimation accessible in resource-constrained settings. We validate SVE on NLP and vision tasks with various different backbones and show that it improves calibration while maintaining predictive accuracy.

</details>


### [374] [Where Do the Joules Go? Diagnosing Inference Energy Consumption](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22076)
*Jae-Won Chung,Ruofan Wu,Jeff J. Ma,Mosharaf Chowdhury*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Large-scale energy-inference study reveals enormous variability across models, tasks, and configurations; introduces a framework to diagnose time/energy drivers across algorithm, software, and hardware layers; extends to throughput per watt.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Energy and time consumption in ML inference vary widely and understanding the drivers is essential for optimization in resource-constrained environments.

Method: Large-scale measurement study across 46 models, 7 tasks, and 1,858 configurations on NVIDIA H100 and B200 GPUs to quantify inference time and energy across the generative AI landscape.

Result: Energy differences span orders of magnitude: LLM task type can cause up to 25x energy variation; video generation can exceed 100x energy of image generation; GPU utilization variations yield 3–5x energy differences.

Conclusion: Proposes a framework to reason about the underlying mechanisms (memory, utilization) that govern time and energy, influenced by algorithm, software, and hardware layers, and extends to throughput per watt for datacenter efficiency.

Abstract: Energy is now a critical ML computing resource. While measuring energy consumption and observing trends is a valuable first step, accurately understanding and diagnosing why those differences occur is crucial for optimization. To that end, we begin by presenting a large-scale measurement study of inference time and energy across the generative AI landscape with 46 models, 7 tasks, and 1,858 different configurations on NVIDIA H100 and B200 GPUs. Our empirical findings span order-of-magnitude variations: LLM task type can lead to 25$\times$ energy differences, video generation sometimes consumes more than 100$\times$ the energy of images, and GPU utilization differences can result in 3--5$\times$ energy differences. Based on our observations, we present a framework for reasoning about the underlying mechanisms that govern time and energy consumption. The essence is that time and energy are determined by latent metrics like memory and utilization, which are in turn affected by various factors across the algorithm, software, and hardware layers. Our framework also extends directly to throughput per watt, a critical metric for power-constrained datacenters.

</details>


### [375] [Latent Adversarial Regularization for Offline Preference Optimization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22083)
*Enyi Jiang,Yibo Jacky Zhang,Yinglun Xu,Andreas Haupt,Nancy Amato,Sanmi Koyejo*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: GANPO introduces latent-space regularization for language-model preference optimization by adversarially aligning internal representations with a reference model, improving robustness to distributional shift and noise with modest overhead, while maintaining performance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Token-space similarity is not a reliable proxy for semantic/behavioral alignment in LM preference learning; hence a latent-space regularization signal is needed to guide policy updates more effectively.

Method: Propose GANPO, a GAN-inspired latent-space regularizer that penalizes divergence between the policy model's internal representations and a reference model. Because latent representations lack explicit probability densities, an adversarial loss is used to approximate and minimize latent-space divergence. GANPO is integrated as a regularizer into existing offline preference optimization objectives.

Result: Empirical evaluations across multiple architectures and tasks show consistent improvements with GANPO. GANPO yields more robust structural feedback under distributional shift and noise, while attaining comparable downstream performance and incurring only minor additional computational overhead.

Conclusion: Latent-space regularization via GANPO provides robust, semantically meaningful feedback for offline LM preference optimization and offers a practical, efficient enhancement over token-level regularization.

Abstract: Learning from human feedback typically relies on preference optimization that constrains policy updates through token-level regularization. However, preference optimization for language models is particularly challenging because token-space similarity does not imply semantic or behavioral similarity. To address this challenge, we leverage latent-space regularization for language model preference optimization. We introduce GANPO, which achieves latent-space regularization by penalizing divergence between the internal representations of a policy model and a reference model. Given that latent representations are not associated with explicit probability densities, we adopt an adversarial approach inspired by GANs to minimize latent-space divergence. We integrate GANPO as a regularizer into existing offline preference optimization objectives. Experiments across multiple model architectures and tasks show consistent improvements from latent-space regularization. Further, by comparing GANPO-induced inferential biases with those from token-level regularization, we find that GANPO provides more robust structural feedback under distributional shift and noise while maintaining comparable downstream performance with minor computational overhead.

</details>


### [376] [GeoNorm: Unify Pre-Norm and Post-Norm with Geodesic Optimization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22095)
*Chuanyang Zheng,Jiankai Sun,Yihang Gao,Chi Wang,Yuehao Wang,Jing Xiong,Liliang Ren,Bo Peng,Qingmei Wang,Xiaoran Shang,Mac Schwager,Anderson Schneider,Yuriy Nevmyvaka,Xiaodong Liu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: GeoNorm replaces standard normalization with geodesic updates on a manifold in Transformer models, introducing layer-wise update decay; yields consistent performance gains with negligible cost.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Normalization placement (Pre-Norm vs Post-Norm) and its optimization role remain unsettled. By viewing FFN and attention outputs as optimization update directions, the work seeks a principled, geometry-aware normalization that can enhance stability and accuracy without adding substantial overhead.

Method: Replace standard normalization with geodesic updates on a suitable manifold, interpreting FFN and attention outputs as update directions. Introduce a layer-wise update decay schedule for FFN and attention components, and integrate GeoNorm into standard Transformer architectures to compare with existing normalization schemes.

Result: Empirical results show GeoNorm consistently outperforms existing normalization methods across Transformer models, with improvements achieved without significant computational overhead and easy integration.

Conclusion: GeoNorm offers a principled, geometry-based alternative to conventional normalization in Transformers, delivering performance gains with negligible cost and potential applicability across architectures.

Abstract: The placement of normalization layers, specifically Pre-Norm and Post-Norm, remains an open question in Transformer architecture design. In this work, we rethink these approaches through the lens of manifold optimization, interpreting the outputs of the Feed-Forward Network (FFN) and attention layers as update directions in optimization. Building on this perspective, we introduce GeoNorm, a novel method that replaces standard normalization with geodesic updates on the manifold. Furthermore, analogous to learning rate schedules, we propose a layer-wise update decay for the FFN and attention components. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate that GeoNorm consistently outperforms existing normalization methods in Transformer models. Crucially, GeoNorm can be seamlessly integrated into standard Transformer architectures, achieving performance improvements with negligible additional computational cost.

</details>


### [377] [Boosting CVaR Policy Optimization with Quantile Gradients](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22100)
*Yudong Luo,Erick Delage*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Augment CVaR-PG with an expected quantile term to utilize all samples via a DP formulation; preserves CVaR objective and improves sample efficiency and performance, with empirical gains in risk-averse tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: CVaR-PG is sample inefficient due to tail-focused optimization; need a data-efficient method that leverages all sampled trajectories while maintaining CVaR risk constraints.

Method: Introduce an expected quantile term into CVaR optimization; show that quantile optimization admits dynamic programming that uses all data; establish that CVaR corresponds to the mean of the tail quantile; implement within Markovian policy class.

Result: Empirical results in risk-averse domains show substantial improvement over CVaR-PG and competitive to or better than existing methods.

Conclusion: The proposed quantile-augmented CVaR-PG improves sample efficiency and performance, preserving CVaR objective; future work could include theoretical guarantees and extensions beyond Markovian policies.

Abstract: Optimizing Conditional Value-at-risk (CVaR) using policy gradient (a.k.a CVaR-PG) faces significant challenges of sample inefficiency. This inefficiency stems from the fact that it focuses on tail-end performance and overlooks many sampled trajectories. We address this problem by augmenting CVaR with an expected quantile term. Quantile optimization admits a dynamic programming formulation that leverages all sampled data, thus improves sample efficiency. This does not alter the CVaR objective since CVaR corresponds to the expectation of quantile over the tail. Empirical results in domains with verifiable risk-averse behavior show that our algorithm within the Markovian policy class substantially improves upon CVaR-PG and consistently outperforms other existing methods.

</details>


### [378] [StepShield: When, Not Whether to Intervene on Rogue Agents](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22136)
*Gloria Felicia,Michael Eniolade,Jinfeng He,Zitha Sasindran,Hemant Kumar,Milan Hussain Angati,Sandeep Bandarupalli*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: StepShield introduces the first benchmark that evaluates when AI safety violations are detected (not just if), using temporal metrics and a large, realistic code-agent trajectory dataset. It shows substantial disparities between an LLM judge and a static analyzer in early detection and reports meaningful cost savings from early intervention.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing benchmarks measure only binary accuracy, conflating the ability to detect a violation with the opportunity to intervene early. A timing-aware evaluation clarifies safety and economic tradeoffs by quantifying when detections occur.

Method: Assembles StepShield with 9,213 code agent trajectories, including 1,278 annotated training pairs and a 7,935-trajectory test set with an 8.1% rogue rate. Introduces three temporal metrics: Early Intervention Rate (EIR), Intervention Gap, and Tokens Saved. Compares an LLM-based judge to a static analyzer. Demonstrates economic impact via a cascaded HybridGuard detector and releases code/data under Apache 2.0.

Result: LLM-based judge attains 59% EIR, while a static analyzer achieves 26% (a 2.3× gap not captured by standard accuracy). Early detection with HybridGuard reduces monitoring costs by 75% and is projected to save $108M over five years at an enterprise scale.

Conclusion: Shifting evaluation from 'whether' to 'when' enables safer and more economically viable AI agents. StepShield provides a rigorous, timing-aware benchmark with open-source data and tools to catalyze further research and practical deployment.

Abstract: Existing agent safety benchmarks report binary accuracy, conflating early intervention with post-mortem analysis. A detector that flags a violation at step 8 enables intervention; one that reports it at step 48 provides only forensic value. This distinction is critical, yet current benchmarks cannot measure it. We introduce StepShield, the first benchmark to evaluate when violations are detected, not just whether. StepShield contains 9,213 code agent trajectories, including 1,278 meticulously annotated training pairs and a 7,935-trajectory test set with a realistic 8.1% rogue rate. Rogue behaviors are grounded in real-world security incidents across six categories. We propose three novel temporal metrics: Early Intervention Rate (EIR), Intervention Gap, and Tokens Saved. Surprisingly, our evaluation reveals that an LLM-based judge achieves 59% EIR while a static analyzer achieves only 26%, a 2.3x performance gap that is entirely invisible to standard accuracy metrics. We further show that early detection has direct economic benefits: our cascaded HybridGuard detector reduces monitoring costs by 75% and projects to $108M in cumulative savings over five years at enterprise scale. By shifting the focus of evaluation from whether to when, StepShield provides a new foundation for building safer and more economically viable AI agents. The code and data are released under an Apache 2.0 license.

</details>


### [379] [Prior-Informed Flow Matching for Graph Reconstruction](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22107)
*Harvey Chen,Nicolas Zilberstein,Santiago Segarra*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: PIFM combines prior-informed initial adjacency estimates with rectified continuous-time flow matching to reconstruct graphs from partial observations, guided by permutation-equivariant distortion-perception theory, yielding improved reconstruction accuracy over classical embeddings and generative baselines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reconstructing graphs from partial observations requires both local information (from embeddings) and global structural consistency. Classical embeddings lack global coherence, while generative models struggle to incorporate strong structural priors. A method that fuses priors with principled flow-based refinement can achieve more accurate, globally consistent reconstructions.

Method: Form an informed initial adjacency using priors (e.g., graphons, GraphSAGE, node2vec) in a permutation-equivariant framework. Apply rectified continuous-time flow matching to refine the estimate toward the true distribution of clean graphs and learn a global coupling, thereby incorporating structural priors into a conditional flow model for graph reconstruction.

Result: Empirical evaluation across multiple datasets shows that PIFM consistently improves upon classical embeddings and outperforms state-of-the-art generative baselines in reconstruction accuracy.

Conclusion: PIFM provides a principled framework that integrates embedding-based priors with flow-based refinement, achieving higher reconstruction accuracy and global consistency in graph reconstruction tasks.

Abstract: We introduce Prior-Informed Flow Matching (PIFM), a conditional flow model for graph reconstruction. Reconstructing graphs from partial observations remains a key challenge; classical embedding methods often lack global consistency, while modern generative models struggle to incorporate structural priors. PIFM bridges this gap by integrating embedding-based priors with continuous-time flow matching. Grounded in a permutation equivariant version of the distortion-perception theory, our method first uses a prior, such as graphons or GraphSAGE/node2vec, to form an informed initial estimate of the adjacency matrix based on local information. It then applies rectified flow matching to refine this estimate, transporting it toward the true distribution of clean graphs and learning a global coupling. Experiments on different datasets demonstrate that PIFM consistently enhances classical embeddings, outperforming them and state-of-the-art generative baselines in reconstruction accuracy.

</details>


### [380] [Physics Informed Reconstruction of Four-Dimensional Atmospheric Wind Fields Using Multi-UAS Swarm Observations in a Synthetic Turbulent Environment](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22111)
*Abdullah Tasim,Wei Sun*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Coordinated UAS swarm combines Bi-LSTM-based local wind estimation with a physics-informed neural network to reconstruct 4D wind fields; achieves sub-0.2 m/s RMSE under moderate winds and preserves mean flow and vertical shear, without fixed sensors.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
