Motivation: Address spatio-temporal gaps in lower-atmosphere wind measurements; conventional sensors are sparse and fixed; UAS swarms can provide distributed in situ data, enabling dense 4D wind-field reconstruction.

Method: Estimate local wind components from UAS dynamics using a bidirectional LSTM (Bi-LSTM); then assimilate these estimates into a physics-informed neural network (PINN) to reconstruct a continuous wind field in space and time. Data are generated from a synthetic turbulence environment and high-fidelity multirotor simulation for training and evaluation. Performance is reported across wind regimes and UAS configurations (best with five UAS).

Result: Local wind estimation RMSE (north/east): 0.064–0.062 m/s (low wind) to 0.271–0.273 m/s (high wind); vertical RMSE: 0.029–0.091 m/s. PINN reconstruction captures dominant spatial/temporal structure up to 1000 m altitude; mean wind RMSE under moderate wind: 0.118–0.154 m/s, with lowest error using five UAS. Demonstrates accurate, scalable 4D wind-field reconstruction without dedicated wind sensors or fixed infrastructure.

Conclusion: Coordinated UAS measurements enable accurate 4D wind-field reconstruction and scalable deployment in the lower atmosphere, avoiding fixed instrumentation while preserving mean flow and vertical shear.

Abstract: Accurate reconstruction of atmospheric wind fields is essential for applications such as weather forecasting, hazard prediction, and wind energy assessment, yet conventional instruments leave spatio-temporal gaps within the lower atmospheric boundary layer. Unmanned aircraft systems (UAS) provide flexible in situ measurements, but individual platforms sample wind only along their flight trajectories, limiting full wind-field recovery. This study presents a framework for reconstructing four-dimensional atmospheric wind fields using measurements obtained from a coordinated UAS swarm. A synthetic turbulence environment and high-fidelity multirotor simulation are used to generate training and evaluation data. Local wind components are estimated from UAS dynamics using a bidirectional long short-term memory network (Bi-LSTM) and assimilated into a physics-informed neural network (PINN) to reconstruct a continuous wind field in space and time. For local wind estimation, the bidirectional LSTM achieves root-mean-square errors (RMSE) of 0.064 and 0.062 m/s for the north and east components in low-wind conditions, increasing to 0.122 to 0.129 m/s under moderate winds and 0.271 to 0.273 m/s in high-wind conditions, while the vertical component exhibits higher error, with RMSE values of 0.029 to 0.091 m/s. The physics-informed reconstruction recovers the dominant spatial and temporal structure of the wind field up to 1000 m altitude while preserving mean flow direction and vertical shear. Under moderate wind conditions, the reconstructed mean wind field achieves an overall RMSE between 0.118 and 0.154 m/s across evaluated UAS configurations, with the lowest error obtained using a five-UAS swarm. These results demonstrate that coordinated UAS measurements enable accurate and scalable four-dimensional wind-field reconstruction without dedicated wind sensors or fixed infrastructure.

</details>


### [381] [Learning Hamiltonian Flow Maps: Mean Flow Consistency for Large-Timestep Molecular Dynamics](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22123)
*Winfried Ripken,Michael Plainer,Gregor Lied,Thorben Frank,Oliver T. Unke,Stefan Chmiela,Frank Noé,Klaus Robert Müller*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Learn Hamiltonian Flow Maps by predicting time-averaged (mean) phase-space evolution over a chosen Δt with a Mean Flow consistency constraint, enabling stable large-timestep updates beyond classic integrators.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Overcome the timestep bottleneck in long-time Hamiltonian simulations, reduce reliance on expensive trajectory generation, and enable stable integration using mean-flow dynamics even with trajectory-free data.

Method: Train models to predict the mean phase-space evolution over Δt and enforce a Mean Flow consistency condition for time-averaged Hamiltonian dynamics. This allows training on independent phase-space samples without future-state access, avoiding trajectory generation. The approach is validated on diverse Hamiltonian systems and leverages MLFF datasets for molecular dynamics.

Result: The framework achieves stable, large-timestep updates with performance improvements in molecular dynamics using MLFFs, while maintaining comparable training/inference costs and enabling training directly on trajectory-free MLFF data.

Conclusion: Mean Flow constraints enable accurate, stable long-time integration of Hamiltonian systems with large time steps and reduced data requirements, with broad applicability including MLFF-based MD.

Abstract: Simulating the long-time evolution of Hamiltonian systems is limited by the small timesteps required for stable numerical integration. To overcome this constraint, we introduce a framework to learn Hamiltonian Flow Maps by predicting the mean phase-space evolution over a chosen time span $Δt$, enabling stable large-timestep updates far beyond the stability limits of classical integrators. To this end, we impose a Mean Flow consistency condition for time-averaged Hamiltonian dynamics. Unlike prior approaches, this allows training on independent phase-space samples without access to future states, avoiding expensive trajectory generation. Validated across diverse Hamiltonian systems, our method in particular improves upon molecular dynamics simulations using machine-learned force fields (MLFF). Our models maintain comparable training and inference cost, but support significantly larger integration timesteps while trained directly on widely-available trajectory-free MLFF datasets.

</details>


### [382] [Late Breaking Results: Conversion of Neural Networks into Logic Flows for Edge Computing](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22151)
*Daniel Stein,Shaoyi Huang,Rolf Drechsler,Bing Li,Grace Li Zhang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Convert neural networks to logic flows for CPU execution by translating models into equivalent decision trees, extracting constant-leaf decision paths, and compressing them into if-else logic with fewer MACs; achieves up to 14.9% latency reduction on simulated RISC-V without accuracy loss. Open-source implementation NN2Logic.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: CPUs are not well-suited for large-scale MAC operations; resource-constrained edge devices require efficient NN inference without relying on GPUs. The work aims to improve CPU inference efficiency by replacing MAC-heavy computation with logic-flow execution.

Method: Transform the neural network into an equivalent decision tree representation, identify decision paths with leaves of constant values, select and compress these paths into logic flows represented as if-else structures, thereby reducing the number of MAC operations during inference.

Result: Latency is reduced by up to 14.9% on a simulated RISC-V CPU without any degradation in accuracy; the authors provide an open-source reference implementation (NN2Logic).

Conclusion: Logic-flow based execution is a viable approach to enhance NN inference efficiency on CPUs on resource-constrained devices, preserving accuracy while reducing computation and latency; the method is reproducible via the provided open-source tool.

Abstract: Neural networks have been successfully applied in various resource-constrained edge devices, where usually central processing units (CPUs) instead of graphics processing units exist due to limited power availability. State-of-the-art research still focuses on efficiently executing enormous numbers of multiply-accumulate (MAC) operations. However, CPUs themselves are not good at executing such mathematical operations on a large scale, since they are more suited to execute control flow logic, i.e., computer algorithms. To enhance the computation efficiency of neural networks on CPUs, in this paper, we propose to convert them into logic flows for execution. Specifically, neural networks are first converted into equivalent decision trees, from which decision paths with constant leaves are then selected and compressed into logic flows. Such logic flows consist of if and else structures and a reduced number of MAC operations. Experimental results demonstrate that the latency can be reduced by up to 14.9 % on a simulated RISC-V CPU without any accuracy degradation.
  The code is open source at https://github.com/TUDa-HWAI/NN2Logic

</details>


### [383] [Discovering Hidden Gems in Model Repositories](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22157)
*Jonathan Kahana,Eliahu Horwitz,Yedid Hoshen*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Hidden gems in fine-tuned models exist; a bandit-based search rapidly uncovers high-performance models overlooked by popularity, achieving 50x faster discovery.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Assess whether repository usage concentration reflects efficient market selection or systematic neglect of superior models; quantify performance gaps and propose an efficient discovery method.

Method: Evaluate >2,000 models to identify underappreciated checkpoints; highlight Llama-3.1-8B; formulate model discovery as a Multi-Armed Bandit problem; accelerate Sequential Halving via shared query sets and aggressive eliminations; achieve query-efficient selection (~50 queries per candidate).

Result: Unpopular fine-tunes significantly outperform popular ones; math accuracy improves from 83.2% to 96.0% without extra inference cost; discovery speed increased by over 50x.

Conclusion: Popularity-based selection may miss superior models; a bandit-based approach can surface high-performing fine-tunes efficiently, broadening access to better models.

Abstract: Public repositories host millions of fine-tuned models, yet community usage remains disproportionately concentrated on a small number of foundation checkpoints. We investigate whether this concentration reflects efficient market selection or if superior models are systematically overlooked. Through an extensive evaluation of over 2,000 models, we show the prevalence of "hidden gems", unpopular fine-tunes that significantly outperform their popular counterparts. Notably, within the Llama-3.1-8B family, we find rarely downloaded checkpoints that improve math performance from 83.2% to 96.0% without increasing inference costs. However, discovering these models through exhaustive evaluation of every uploaded model is computationally infeasible. We therefore formulate model discovery as a Multi-Armed Bandit problem and accelerate the Sequential Halving search algorithm by using shared query sets and aggressive elimination schedules. Our method retrieves top models with as few as 50 queries per candidate, accelerating discovery by over 50x.

</details>

# cs.RO [[Back]](#toc)

### [384] [Quick Heuristic Validation of Edges in Dynamic Roadmap Graphs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.20968)
*Yulie Arad,Stav Ashur,Nancy M. Amato*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Introduces Red-Green-Gray paradigm to classify roadmap edges in dynamic environments using cheap heuristics, enabling fast semi-lazy updates with competitive runtimes and higher accuracy vs Leven & Hutchinson.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Maintain up-to-date, valid motion-planning roadmaps in non-static environments while minimizing expensive collision checks.

Method: Extend SPITE-based framework with three-state labeling (red/invalid, green/valid, gray/unknown), using cheap geometric heuristics to approximate robot swept volumes and perform lazy collision checks; label a subset of edges; compare against Leven & Hutchinson; report accuracy improvements and comparable runtimes.

Result: Preliminary experiments show higher accuracy and the ability to correctly identify invalid edges, with update runtimes similar to the baseline.

Conclusion: Red-Green-Gray provides an efficient semi-lazy roadmap update mechanism for dynamic environments; future work includes scaling to larger graphs, robust geometry handling, and exploration of additional heuristics.

Abstract: In this paper we tackle the problem of adjusting roadmap graphs for robot motion planning to non-static environments. We introduce the "Red-Green-Gray" paradigm, a modification of the SPITE method, capable of classifying the validity status of nodes and edges using cheap heuristic checks, allowing fast semi-lazy roadmap updates. Given a roadmap, we use simple computational geometry methods to approximate the swept volumes of robots and perform lazy collision checks, and label a subset of the edges as invalid (red), valid (green), or unknown (gray). We present preliminary experimental results comparing our method to the well-established technique of Leven and Hutchinson, and showing increased accuracy as well as the ability to correctly label edges as invalid while maintaining comparable update runtimes.

</details>


### [385] [Meta-ROS: A Next-Generation Middleware Architecture for Adaptive and Scalable Robotic Systems](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21011)
*Anshul Ranjan,Anoosh Damodar,Neha Chougule,Dhruva S Nayak,Anantharaman P. N,Shylaja S S*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Meta-ROS is a new middleware for robotics that aims to simplify integration and improve cross-platform performance. It leverages Zenoh and ZeroMQ to enable low-latency, high-throughput communication across diverse hardware, supporting audio, image, and video data. Benchmarking against ROS1/ROS2 shows up to 30% higher throughput, reduced latency, and better resource usage, along with robust hardware support and a developer-friendly design.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current robotics middleware like ROS2 suffers from complexity and interoperability challenges that hinder adoption by new developers and multi-platform deployments. There is a need for a streamlined, performant, cross-platform solution that can handle diverse data types in real-time robotic AI contexts.

Method: Design and implementation of Meta-ROS as a middleware framework. It uses modern communication protocols (Zenoh, ZeroMQ) to enable efficient cross-platform messaging. It supports multiple data types (audio, images, video) and was evaluated against ROS1 and ROS2 through performance benchmarks focusing on throughput, latency, and resource usage, as well as hardware compatibility and developer usability.

Result: Empirical evaluation indicates Meta-ROS achieves up to 30% higher throughput than ROS2, with significantly lower message latency and optimized resource usage. The framework also demonstrates robust hardware support and a developer-centric design that facilitates integration and ease of use.

Conclusion: Meta-ROS presents a compelling option for real-time robotics AI by delivering performance gains and improved usability over existing ROS-based middlewares, suggesting strong potential for broader adoption while highlighting the need for further real-world validation across platforms and workloads.

Abstract: The field of robotics faces significant challenges related to the complexity and interoperability of existing middleware frameworks, like ROS2, which can be difficult for new developers to adopt. To address these issues, we propose Meta-ROS, a novel middleware solution designed to streamline robotics development by simplifying integration, enhancing performance, and ensuring cross-platform compatibility. Meta-ROS leverages modern communication protocols, such as Zenoh and ZeroMQ, to enable efficient and low-latency communication across diverse hardware platforms, while also supporting various data types like audio, images, and video. We evaluated Meta-ROS's performance through comprehensive testing, comparing it with existing middleware frameworks like ROS1 and ROS2. The results demonstrated that Meta-ROS outperforms ROS2, achieving up to 30% higher throughput, significantly reducing message latency, and optimizing resource usage. Additionally, its robust hardware support and developer-centric design facilitate seamless integration and ease of use, positioning Meta-ROS as an ideal solution for modern, real-time robotics AI applications.

</details>


### [386] [Track-centric Iterative Learning for Global Trajectory Optimization in Autonomous Racing](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21027)
*Youngim Nam,Jungbin Kim,Kyungtae Kang,Cheolhyeon Kwon*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A track-centric, wavelet-parametrized, Bayesian-optimized full-horizon trajectory learning framework for lap-time minimization under uncertain dynamics, iteratively refining the trajectory with real-world data.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the computational burden of full-horizon optimization and the mismatch between learned dynamics at the tracking level vs the trajectory itself; integrate trajectory optimization with dynamics learning to improve robustness and lap time.

Method: Represent trajectories in a track-agnostic space using wavelet transform; explore this space efficiently with Bayesian optimization; evaluate candidates by simulating with learned dynamics; iteratively deploy optimized trajectories to collect real-world data for updating dynamics and refining trajectories.

Result: Simulation and real-world experiments show up to 20.7% lap-time improvement over a nominal baseline and consistent outperforming of state-of-the-art methods.

Conclusion: A track-centric learning-optimization framework can effectively reduce lap time by coupling trajectory optimization with dynamics learning, mitigating model mismatch and achieving robust performance gains.

Abstract: This paper presents a global trajectory optimization framework for minimizing lap time in autonomous racing under uncertain vehicle dynamics. Optimizing the trajectory over the full racing horizon is computationally expensive, and tracking such a trajectory in the real world hardly assures global optimality due to uncertain dynamics. Yet, existing work mostly focuses on dynamics learning at the tracking level, without updating the trajectory itself to account for the learned dynamics. To address these challenges, we propose a track-centric approach that directly learns and optimizes the full-horizon trajectory. We first represent trajectories through a track-agnostic parametric space in light of the wavelet transform. This space is then efficiently explored using Bayesian optimization, where the lap time of each candidate is evaluated by running simulations with the learned dynamics. This optimization is embedded in an iterative learning framework, where the optimized trajectory is deployed to collect real-world data for updating the dynamics, progressively refining the trajectory over the iterations. The effectiveness of the proposed framework is validated through simulations and real-world experiments, demonstrating lap time improvement of up to 20.7% over a nominal baseline and consistently outperforming state-of-the-art methods.

</details>


### [387] [Multi-Robot Decentralized Collaborative SLAM in Planetary Analogue Environments: Dataset, Challenges, and Lessons Learned](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21063)
*Pierre-Yves Lajoie,Karthik Soma,Haechan Mark Bong,Alice Lemieux-Bourque,Rongge Zhang,Vivek Shankar Varadharajan,Giovanni Beltrame*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Three-robot C-SLAM experiments on Mars-analogue terrain using ad hoc networking; reveals how limited/intermittent communications affect performance and provides a dataset with real-time inter-robot throughput and latency to spur research on communication-constrained decentralized multirobot SLAM.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Enable robust multi-robot exploration in unknown planetary environments without fixed localization/communication infrastructure; understand how communication constraints and planetary localization challenges impact C-SLAM; provide a benchmark dataset for future work.

Method: Experimental study with three robots operating on Mars-analogue terrain connected via an ad hoc network; analyze C-SLAM performance under limited/intermittent communication; characterize localization challenges in planetary-like environments; collect and publish a dataset including real-time peer-to-peer throughput and latency metrics.

Result: Provides insights and lessons on the impact of communication constraints on C-SLAM; identifies localization challenges specific to planetary-like terrains; introduces a new dataset to support future research and benchmarking in communication-constrained decentralized multirobot SLAM.

Conclusion: The work advances understanding of decentralized C-SLAM under communication constraints for planetary exploration and provides a publicly available dataset to foster further research; highlights the need for robust communication-aware SLAM algorithms and larger-scale experiments.

Abstract: Decentralized collaborative simultaneous localization and mapping (C-SLAM) is essential to enable multirobot missions in unknown environments without relying on preexisting localization and communication infrastructure. This technology is anticipated to play a key role in the exploration of the Moon, Mars, and other planets. In this article, we share insights and lessons learned from C-SLAM experiments involving three robots operating on a Mars analogue terrain and communicating over an ad hoc network. We examine the impact of limited and intermittent communication on C-SLAM performance, as well as the unique localization challenges posed by planetary-like environments. Additionally, we introduce a novel dataset collected during our experiments, which includes real-time peer-to-peer inter-robot throughput and latency measurements. This dataset aims to support future research on communication-constrained, decentralized multirobot operations.

</details>


### [388] [WheelArm-Sim: A Manipulation and Navigation Combined Multimodal Synthetic Data Generation Simulator for Unified Control in Assistive Robotics](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21129)
*Guangping Liu,Tipu Sultan,Vittorio Di Giorgio,Nick Hawkins,Flavio Esposito,Madi Babaiasl*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Proposes WheelArm, an integrated cycle for wheelchair and robotic arm control; introduces WheelArm-Sim in Isaac Sim for synthetic data; creates a multimodal dataset (13 tasks, 232 trajectories, 67,783 samples) and shows a baseline action-prediction model on mustard-picking, demonstrating feasibility of data-driven integrated control.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Addresses the gap in unified control of wheelchair-mounted robotic arms (WMRAs) and wheelchairs using machine learning by proposing an integrated cyber-physical system (CPS) and a large synthetic dataset to enable data-driven development.

Method: Introduce WheelArm as an integrated CPS; develop WheelArm-Sim in Isaac Sim for synthetic data; collect a combined manipulation-and-navigation dataset across 13 tasks (232 trajectories, 67,783 samples); train a baseline action-prediction model on the mustard-picking task as a proof-of-concept.

Result: WheelArm-Sim can generate a sizable multimodal dataset suitable for ML; the baseline mustard-picking model demonstrates feasibility of learning integrated control from synthetic data; dataset size and task diversity support data-driven development.

Conclusion: WheelArm-Sim demonstrates the feasibility of data-driven, integrated control for wheelchair and robotic arm systems. The dataset provides a foundation for future learning-based approaches and real-world transfer studies, advancing unified control in assistive robotics.

Abstract: Wheelchairs and robotic arms enhance independent living by assisting individuals with upper-body and mobility limitations in their activities of daily living (ADLs). Although recent advancements in assistive robotics have focused on Wheelchair-Mounted Robotic Arms (WMRAs) and wheelchairs separately, integrated and unified control of the combination using machine learning models remains largely underexplored. To fill this gap, we introduce the concept of WheelArm, an integrated cyber-physical system (CPS) that combines wheelchair and robotic arm controls. Data collection is the first step toward developing WheelArm models. In this paper, we present WheelArm-Sim, a simulation framework developed in Isaac Sim for synthetic data collection. We evaluate its capability by collecting a manipulation and navigation combined multimodal dataset, comprising 13 tasks, 232 trajectories, and 67,783 samples. To demonstrate the potential of the WheelArm dataset, we implement a baseline model for action prediction in the mustard-picking task. The results illustrate that data collected from WheelArm-Sim is feasible for a data-driven machine learning model for integrated control.

</details>


### [389] [InspecSafe-V1: A Multimodal Benchmark for Safety Assessment in Industrial Inspection Scenarios](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21173)
*Zeyi Liu,Shuang Liu,Jihai Min,Zhaoheng Zhang,Jun Cen,Pengyu Han,Songqiao Hu,Zihan Meng,Xiao He,Donghua Zhou*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: InspecSafe-V1 is the first multimodal benchmark for industrial inspection safety, derived from real-world robotic operations, covering 5 scenarios with 41 robots across 2,239 sites, 5,013 instances; it provides pixel-level object annotations, semantic scene descriptions, safety level labels, and seven modalities (IR video, audio, depth, radar, gas, temperature, humidity) to enable multimodal anomaly detection and safety reasoning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Public datasets in industrial perception are limited by simulated data, single-modality sensing, and lack of fine-grained, object-level labels, hindering robust scene understanding and safety reasoning for industrial foundation models.

Method: Dataset construction from routine operations: 41 wheeled/rail-mounted robots, 2,239 sites, 5,013 inspections; annotations include pixel-level segmentation for key objects, semantic scene descriptions, and safety level labels; multimodal sensing with seven synchronized modalities to support cross-modal fusion and safety assessment.

Result: Release of a large-scale multimodal industrial inspection safety dataset with 5,013 instances, 7 modalities, and 41 robots across five industrial scenarios, enabling multimodal anomaly recognition and safety reasoning.

Conclusion: InspecSafe-V1 constitutes a foundational benchmark that enables robust multimodal perception and safety assessment for industrial AI systems, promoting development of industrial foundation models and reliable autonomous inspection.

Abstract: With the rapid development of industrial intelligence and unmanned inspection, reliable perception and safety assessment for AI systems in complex and dynamic industrial sites has become a key bottleneck for deploying predictive maintenance and autonomous inspection. Most public datasets remain limited by simulated data sources, single-modality sensing, or the absence of fine-grained object-level annotations, which prevents robust scene understanding and multimodal safety reasoning for industrial foundation models. To address these limitations, InspecSafe-V1 is released as the first multimodal benchmark dataset for industrial inspection safety assessment that is collected from routine operations of real inspection robots in real-world environments. InspecSafe-V1 covers five representative industrial scenarios, including tunnels, power facilities, sintering equipment, oil and gas petrochemical plants, and coal conveyor trestles. The dataset is constructed from 41 wheeled and rail-mounted inspection robots operating at 2,239 valid inspection sites, yielding 5,013 inspection instances. For each instance, pixel-level segmentation annotations are provided for key objects in visible-spectrum images. In addition, a semantic scene description and a corresponding safety level label are provided according to practical inspection tasks. Seven synchronized sensing modalities are further included, including infrared video, audio, depth point clouds, radar point clouds, gas measurements, temperature, and humidity, to support multimodal anomaly recognition, cross-modal fusion, and comprehensive safety assessment in industrial environments.

</details>


### [390] [Disturbance-Aware Flight Control of Robotic Gliding Blimp via Moving Mass Actuation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21188)
*Hao Cheng,Feitian Zhang*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A moving-mass LTA flight control framework combining real-time wind estimation with disturbance-aware MPC to robustly regulate attitude and heading under wind, outperforming PID.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: LTA platforms offer long endurance but are highly wind-sensitive; there is a lack of disturbance-aware control frameworks. Moving-mass actuation provides a means to generate both inertial and aerodynamic moments for stability.

Method: A 2-DoF moving-mass mechanism is used in conjunction with a moving horizon estimator (MHE) to infer real-time wind perturbations, which are fed to a model predictive controller (MPC) to achieve robust trajectory and heading control under varying wind conditions.

Result: Flight experiments under headwind and crosswind show the MHE-MPC framework significantly outperforms a baseline PID controller in maintaining stability and tracking under disturbances.

Conclusion: Disturbance-aware MHE-MPC control with moving-mass actuation enhances LTA flight stability in disturbance-prone environments, validated by extensive flight tests.

Abstract: Robotic blimps, as lighter-than-air (LTA) aerial systems, offer long endurance and inherently safe operation but remain highly susceptible to wind disturbances. Building on recent advances in moving mass actuation, this paper addresses the lack of disturbance-aware control frameworks for LTA platforms by explicitly modeling and compensating for wind-induced effects. A moving horizon estimator (MHE) infers real-time wind perturbations and provides these estimates to a model predictive controller (MPC), enabling robust trajectory and heading regulation under varying wind conditions. The proposed approach leverages a two-degree-of-freedom (2-DoF) moving-mass mechanism to generate both inertial and aerodynamic moments for attitude and heading control, thereby enhancing flight stability in disturbance-prone environments. Extensive flight experiments under headwind and crosswind conditions show that the integrated MHE-MPC framework significantly outperforms baseline PID control, demonstrating its effectiveness for disturbance-aware LTA flight.

</details>


### [391] [Deep QP Safety Filter: Model-free Learning for Reachability-based Safety Filter](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21297)
*Byeongjun Kim,H. Jin Kim*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A data-driven safety layer for black-box dynamics that learns a QP-based safety filter by combining Hamilton-Jacobi reachability with model-free learning; the learned safety critic converges to the viscosity solution (and its derivative) even for non-smooth value functions, improving safety and learning efficiency across diverse systems.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Safe control for unknown or black-box dynamical systems where explicit models are unavailable. The goal is to enforce safety constraints while enabling efficient RL, without relying on accurate dynamics models.

Method: Learn a Quadratic-Program safety filter using two neural networks trained with contraction-based losses on the safety value (and its derivatives) derived from Hamilton-Jacobi reachability; no model knowledge is used. The approach ensures convergence to the viscosity solution of the HJ PDE, even in non-smooth cases, in the exact setting.

Result: Empirically reduces pre-convergence failures and accelerates learning to higher returns across diverse dynamical systems, including a hybrid system, outperforming strong baselines.

Conclusion: Provides a principled, practical route to safe, model-free control by integrating HJ reachability with model-free learning to produce a data-driven safety filter that preserves safety while enhancing learning efficiency.

Abstract: We introduce Deep QP Safety Filter, a fully data-driven safety layer for black-box dynamical systems. Our method learns a Quadratic-Program (QP) safety filter without model knowledge by combining Hamilton-Jacobi (HJ) reachability with model-free learning. We construct contraction-based losses for both the safety value and its derivatives, and train two neural networks accordingly. In the exact setting, the learned critic converges to the viscosity solution (and its derivative), even for non-smooth values. Across diverse dynamical systems -- even including a hybrid system -- and multiple RL tasks, Deep QP Safety Filter substantially reduces pre-convergence failures while accelerating learning toward higher returns than strong baselines, offering a principled and practical route to safe, model-free control.

</details>


### [392] [HPTune: Hierarchical Proactive Tuning for Collision-Free Model Predictive Control](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21346)
*Wei Zuo,Chengyang Li,Yikun Wang,Bingyang Cheng,Zeyi Ren,Shuai Wang,Derrick Wing Kwan Ng,Yik-Chung Wu*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Hierarchical proactive tuning (HPTune) for MPC motion planners extends parameter tuning to non-executed actions via fast- and slow-level tuning, improving tuning efficiency and safety in complex environments; Doppler LiDAR integration aids predictive estimates.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Myopic parameter tuning based on executed actions suffers from sparse failure events, hindering rapid adaptation; proactive evaluation of non-executed actions addresses data sparsity and accelerates tuning.

Method: Introduce HPTune with a fast-level tuner using risk indicators from predictive closing speed and predictive proximity distance, and a slow-level tuner using an extended evaluation loss for backpropagation; fuse with Doppler LiDAR to obtain obstacle velocities; validated in high-fidelity simulation.

Result: HPTune achieves efficient MPC parameter tuning and outperforms baselines in complex environments; enables situation-tailored, safe and agile collision avoidance.

Conclusion: Hierarchical, proactive parameter tuning with sensor-augmented perception enables adaptable, safe motion planning in MPC frameworks; the approach leverages non-executed-action data and backpropagation for sustained performance gains.

Abstract: Parameter tuning is a powerful approach to enhance adaptability in model predictive control (MPC) motion planners. However, existing methods typically operate in a myopic fashion that only evaluates executed actions, leading to inefficient parameter updates due to the sparsity of failure events (e.g., obstacle nearness or collision). To cope with this issue, we propose to extend evaluation from executed to non-executed actions, yielding a hierarchical proactive tuning (HPTune) framework that combines both a fast-level tuning and a slow-level tuning. The fast one adopts risk indicators of predictive closing speed and predictive proximity distance, and the slow one leverages an extended evaluation loss for closed-loop backpropagation. Additionally, we integrate HPTune with the Doppler LiDAR that provides obstacle velocities apart from position-only measurements for enhanced motion predictions, thus facilitating the implementation of HPTune. Extensive experiments on high-fidelity simulator demonstrate that HPTune achieves efficient MPC tuning and outperforms various baseline schemes in complex environments. It is found that HPTune enables situation-tailored motion planning by formulating a safe, agile collision avoidance strategy.

</details>


### [393] [Towards Bridging the Gap between Large-Scale Pretraining and Efficient Finetuning for Humanoid Control](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21363)
*Weidong Huang,Zhehan Li,Hangxin Liu,Biao Hou,Yao Su,Jingwen Zhang*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: SAC with large-batch updates and high Update-To-Data (UTD) ratio enables scalable pretraining of humanoid locomotion policies and safe, sample-efficient adaptation via model-based finetuning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the sample inefficiency of on-policy methods for humanoid control and close the gap between large-scale pretraining and efficient finetuning, aiming for zero-shot real-robot deployment.

Method: Pretrain off-policy Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) using large batch updates and high UTD to train humanoid locomotion policies in simulation. For adaptation, collect data with a deterministic policy in new environments while performing stochastic exploration through a physics-informed world model, enabling model-based fine-tuning for new tasks/environments.

Result: SAC-pretrained policies enable zero-shot deployment on real robots. In new environments and out-of-distribution tasks, finetuning via model-based methods is effective. Separating exploration (world model) from data collection (deterministic policy) mitigates risk during adaptation while preserving exploratory coverage.

Conclusion: This approach achieves wall-clock efficiency during large-scale pretraining through simulation and leverages model-based learning for sample-efficient fine-tuning, bridging the gap between pretraining and adaptation for humanoid locomotion.

Abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) is widely used for humanoid control, with on-policy methods such as Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) enabling robust training via large-scale parallel simulation and, in some cases, zero-shot deployment to real robots. However, the low sample efficiency of on-policy algorithms limits safe adaptation to new environments. Although off-policy RL and model-based RL have shown improved sample efficiency, the gap between large-scale pretraining and efficient finetuning on humanoids still exists. In this paper, we find that off-policy Soft Actor-Critic (SAC), with large-batch update and a high Update-To-Data (UTD) ratio, reliably supports large-scale pretraining of humanoid locomotion policies, achieving zero-shot deployment on real robots. For adaptation, we demonstrate that these SAC-pretrained policies can be finetuned in new environments and out-of-distribution tasks using model-based methods. Data collection in the new environment executes a deterministic policy while stochastic exploration is instead confined to a physics-informed world model. This separation mitigates the risks of random exploration during adaptation while preserving exploratory coverage for improvement. Overall, the approach couples the wall-clock efficiency of large-scale simulation during pretraining with the sample efficiency of model-based learning during fine-tuning.

</details>


### [394] [Towards Space-Based Environmentally-Adaptive Grasping](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21394)
*Leonidas Askianakis,Aleksandr Artemov*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Latent-space policy learning for space grasping using SAC in a multimodal latent representation; achieves >95% success in under 1M steps; faster and more robust than visual baselines under open-loop single-shot conditions.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Robotic manipulation in unstructured, high-variance environments suffers from high-dimensional actions, sparse rewards, and poor generalization. Space grasping presents extreme conditions requiring sample-efficient, robust policies.

Method: Train policies in a learned latent manifold that fuses multiple modalities into a structured representation. Use GPU-accelerated physics simulation to create single-shot manipulation tasks. Apply Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) RL in latent space with continuous control.

Result: Achieves over 95% task success in under 1M environment steps. Demonstrates faster convergence than representative visual baselines under same open-loop single-shot conditions. Latent-space reasoning yields improved sample efficiency and robustness to novel object/gripper geometries, clutter, and sensor configurations.

Conclusion: Explicit latent-space reasoning enhances sample efficiency and robustness for grasping under variable conditions. Identifies current limitations and outlines future directions toward fully adaptive and generalizable space grasping in extreme conditions.

Abstract: Robotic manipulation in unstructured environments requires reliable execution under diverse conditions, yet many state-of-the-art systems still struggle with high-dimensional action spaces, sparse rewards, and slow generalization beyond carefully curated training scenarios. We study these limitations through the example of grasping in space environments. We learn control policies directly in a learned latent manifold that fuses (grammarizes) multiple modalities into a structured representation for policy decision-making. Building on GPU-accelerated physics simulation, we instantiate a set of single-shot manipulation tasks and achieve over 95% task success with Soft Actor-Critic (SAC)-based reinforcement learning in less than 1M environment steps, under continuously varying grasping conditions from step 1. This empirically shows faster convergence than representative state-of-the-art visual baselines under the same open-loop single-shot conditions. Our analysis indicates that explicitly reasoning in latent space yields more sample-efficient learning and improved robustness to novel object and gripper geometries, environmental clutter, and sensor configurations compared to standard baselines. We identify remaining limitations and outline directions toward fully adaptive and generalizable grasping in the extreme conditions of space.

</details>


### [395] [DSCD-Nav: Dual-Stance Cooperative Debate for Object Navigation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21409)
*Weitao An,Qi Liu,Chenghao Xu,Jiayi Chai,Xu Yang,Kun Wei,Cheng Deng*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Dual-Stance Cooperative Debate Navigation (DSCD-Nav) introduces two evaluation stances (TSU and SIB) and a Navigation Consensus Arbitration (NCA) to replace single-pass scoring, improving decision reliability under partial observability. It demonstrates gains in success and path efficiency with less exploration on HM3Dv1/2 and MP3D.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Overconfident long-horizon errors and redundant exploration in navigation systems arise from single-pass scoring in zero-shot perception and reasoning. There is a need for more reliable action evaluation under partial observability using complementary objectives.

Method: Construct two complementary evaluation stances: Task-Scene Understanding (TSU) prioritizes goal progress from scene-layout cues; Safety-Information Balancing (SIB) emphasizes risk and information value. The stances debate and cross-check their top candidates with cue-grounded arguments. A Navigation Consensus Arbitration (NCA) aggregates both sides' evidence, with optional lightweight micro-probing to verify uncertain choices.

Result: Empirical validation on HM3Dv1, HM3Dv2, and MP3D shows consistent improvements in success and path efficiency while reducing exploration redundancy.

Conclusion: Stance-based, evidence-grounded arbitration enhances action reliability in navigation under partial observability, yielding more efficient and robust indoor service robot navigation.

Abstract: Adaptive navigation in unfamiliar indoor environments is crucial for household service robots. Despite advances in zero-shot perception and reasoning from vision-language models, existing navigation systems still rely on single-pass scoring at the decision layer, leading to overconfident long-horizon errors and redundant exploration. To tackle these problems, we propose Dual-Stance Cooperative Debate Navigation (DSCD-Nav), a decision mechanism that replaces one-shot scoring with stance-based cross-checking and evidence-aware arbitration to improve action reliability under partial observability. Specifically, given the same observation and candidate action set, we explicitly construct two stances by conditioning the evaluation on diverse and complementary objectives: a Task-Scene Understanding (TSU) stance that prioritizes goal progress from scene-layout cues, and a Safety-Information Balancing (SIB) stance that emphasizes risk and information value. The stances conduct a cooperative debate and make policy by cross-checking their top candidates with cue-grounded arguments. Then, a Navigation Consensus Arbitration (NCA) agent is employed to consolidate both sides' reasons and evidence, optionally triggering lightweight micro-probing to verify uncertain choices, preserving NCA's primary intent while disambiguating. Experiments on HM3Dv1, HM3Dv2, and MP3D demonstrate consistent improvements in success and path efficiency while reducing exploration redundancy.

</details>


### [396] [Singularity-Free Lie Group Integration and Geometrically Consistent Evaluation of Multibody System Models Described in Terms of Standard Absolute Coordinates](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21413)
*Andreas Mueller*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A bridging framework that enables Lie group-based time integration for multibody systems described in absolute coordinates, using SO(3)×R3 and SE(3) representations with local–global transition maps (LGT) to update global coordinates.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Classical MBS modeling in absolute coordinates faces singularity issues in spatial motion parameterization. Although Lie group integration respects geometry and avoids singularities, it is not readily compatible with standard EOM formulations; a way to interface Lie group methods with existing absolute-coordinate codes is needed.

Method: Introduce a twofold contribution: (1) a framework to interface Lie group integrators with standard EOM formulations for MBS described in absolute coordinates; (2) a method to incorporate rigid-body geometry into EOM evaluation when using vector-space integrators. Represent rigid body motions with direct/semidirect product groups SO(3)×R3 and SE(3). Central to the approach is the local-global transition (LGT) map, enabling updates of global absolute coordinates from local Lie-group coordinates, specific to the chosen absolute coordinates and Lie group.

Result: Provides a concrete method to describe MBS in absolute coordinates while employing Lie group integrators, through the LGT map that ties local Lie-group updates to global coordinates, and demonstrates compatibility with standard MBS simulation frameworks.

Conclusion: The proposed LGT-based framework enables geometry-respecting, singularity-free integration within existing MBS codes by marrying absolute-coordinate EOM with Lie-group time integrators.

Abstract: A classical approach to the multibody systems (MBS) modeling is to use absolute coordinates, i.e., a set of (possibly redundant) coordinates that describe the absolute position and orientation of the individual bodies with respect to an inertial frame (IFR). A well-known problem for the time integration of the equations of motion (EOM) is the lack of a singularity-free parameterization of spatial motions, which is usually tackled by using unit quaternions. Lie group integration methods were proposed as an alternative approach to the singularity-free time integration. At the same time, Lie group formulations of EOM naturally respect the geometry of spatial motions during integration. Lie group integration methods, operating directly on the configuration space Lie group, are incompatible with standard formulations of the EOM, and cannot be implemented in existing MBS simulation codes without a major restructuring. The contribution of this paper is twofold: (1) A framework for interfacing Lie group integrators to standard EOM formulations is presented. It allows describing MBS in terms of various absolute coordinates and at the same using Lie group integration schemes. (2) A method for consistently incorporating the geometry of rigid body motions into the evaluation of EOM in absolute coordinates integrated with standard vector space integration schemes. The direct product group and the semidirect product group SO(3)xR3 and the semidirect product group SE(3) are used for representing rigid body motions. The key element is the local-global transitions (LGT) transition map, which facilitates the update of (global) absolute coordinates in terms of the (local) coordinates on the Lie group. This LGT map is specific to the absolute coordinates, the local coordinates on the Lie group, and the Lie group used to represent rigid body configurations.

</details>


### [397] [Spotlighting Task-Relevant Features: Object-Centric Representations for Better Generalization in Robotic Manipulation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21416)
*Alexandre Chapin,Bruno Machado,Emmanuel Dellandréa,Liming Chen*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Slot-based Object-Centric Representations (SBOCR) improve generalization in robotic manipulation by clustering dense features into a fixed set of object-like slots, reducing noise while preserving task-relevant information; they outperform global and dense representations under distribution shifts, even without task-specific pretraining.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address generalization under visual distribution shifts (lighting, texture, distractors) by reducing mixed task-relevant/irrelevant information in pre-trained encoders through an object-centric representation.

Method: Benchmark SBOCR against global and dense representations across simulated and real-world manipulation tasks. Build a fixed number of slots from dense features to form an intermediate object-centric representation, and evaluate generalization under diverse visual conditions without requiring task-specific pretraining.

Result: SBOCR-based policies outperform both dense and global representations under distribution shifts across tasks of varying complexity; improvement persists without task-specific pretraining, indicating effective noise reduction and retention of essential task information.

Conclusion: Slot-based object-centric representations are a promising direction for robust visual representations in dynamic robotic environments, suggesting further exploration and integration with learning systems to enhance generalization.

Abstract: The generalization capabilities of robotic manipulation policies are heavily influenced by the choice of visual representations. Existing approaches typically rely on representations extracted from pre-trained encoders, using two dominant types of features: global features, which summarize an entire image via a single pooled vector, and dense features, which preserve a patch-wise embedding from the final encoder layer. While widely used, both feature types mix task-relevant and irrelevant information, leading to poor generalization under distribution shifts, such as changes in lighting, textures, or the presence of distractors. In this work, we explore an intermediate structured alternative: Slot-Based Object-Centric Representations (SBOCR), which group dense features into a finite set of object-like entities. This representation permits to naturally reduce the noise provided to the robotic manipulation policy while keeping enough information to efficiently perform the task. We benchmark a range of global and dense representations against intermediate slot-based representations, across a suite of simulated and real-world manipulation tasks ranging from simple to complex. We evaluate their generalization under diverse visual conditions, including changes in lighting, texture, and the presence of distractors. Our findings reveal that SBOCR-based policies outperform dense and global representation-based policies in generalization settings, even without task-specific pretraining. These insights suggest that SBOCR is a promising direction for designing visual systems that generalize effectively in dynamic, real-world robotic environments.

</details>


### [398] [Nimbus: A Unified Embodied Synthetic Data Generation Framework](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21449)
*Zeyu He,Yuchang Zhang,Yuanzhen Zhou,Miao Tao,Hengjie Li,Yang Tian,Jia Zeng,Tai Wang,Wenzhe Cai,Yilun Chen,Ning Gao,Jiangmiao Pang*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Nimbus is a modular, scalable synthetic data framework that unifies heterogeneous navigation and manipulation pipelines through a four-layer, asynchronous architecture, yielding 2–3x end-to-end throughput gains and robust large-scale operation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Generalizable embodied AI requires vast, diverse synthetic data; current data-generation pipelines are fragmented, task-specific, and unstable, limiting throughput and scalability for foundation-model training.

Method: Nimbus adopts a four-layer architecture with a decoupled execution model that separates trajectory planning, rendering, and storage into asynchronous stages. It employs dynamic pipeline scheduling, global load balancing, distributed fault tolerance, and backend-specific rendering optimizations to maximize CPU/GPU/I/O resource utilization.

Result: Empirical evaluation shows Nimbus delivers 2–3× higher end-to-end throughput than unoptimized baselines and remains robust for long-term operation in large-scale distributed environments.

Conclusion: Nimbus provides a unified, efficient, and resilient foundation for cross-domain synthetic data generation, serving as the production backbone for the InternData suite and enabling scalable data synthesis for foundation-model training.

Abstract: Scaling data volume and diversity is critical for generalizing embodied intelligence. While synthetic data generation offers a scalable alternative to expensive physical data acquisition, existing pipelines remain fragmented and task-specific. This isolation leads to significant engineering inefficiency and system instability, failing to support the sustained, high-throughput data generation required for foundation model training. To address these challenges, we present Nimbus, a unified synthetic data generation framework designed to integrate heterogeneous navigation and manipulation pipelines. Nimbus introduces a modular four-layer architecture featuring a decoupled execution model that separates trajectory planning, rendering, and storage into asynchronous stages. By implementing dynamic pipeline scheduling, global load balancing, distributed fault tolerance, and backend-specific rendering optimizations, the system maximizes resource utilization across CPU, GPU, and I/O resources. Our evaluation demonstrates that Nimbus achieves a 2-3X improvement in end-to-end throughput compared to unoptimized baselines and ensuring robust, long-term operation in large-scale distributed environments. This framework serves as the production backbone for the InternData suite, enabling seamless cross-domain data synthesis.

</details>


### [399] [4D-CAAL: 4D Radar-Camera Calibration and Auto-Labeling for Autonomous Driving](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21454)
*Shanliang Yao,Zhuoxiao Li,Runwei Guan,Kebin Cao,Meng Xia,Fuping Hu,Sen Xu,Yong Yue,Xiaohui Zhu,Weiping Ding,Ryan Wen Liu*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Unified 4D radar–camera calibration and auto-labeling via a dual-purpose calibration target; robust correspondence matching; automatic transfer of camera annotations to radar point clouds.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Calibrating 4D radar with cameras is difficult due to modality-specific targets and manual labeling; a single, unified approach reduces effort and improves alignment for robust multi-modal perception in autonomous driving.

Method: Introduce a dual-purpose calibration target with a front checkerboard for camera detection and a back surface corner reflector for radar detection. Develop a robust correspondence matching that links the checkerboard center to the strongest radar reflection point. Use calibrated extrinsics to transfer camera-based annotations to radar via geometric projection and multi-feature optimization for auto-labeling.

Result: Demonstrates high calibration accuracy and substantial reduction in manual annotation effort across extensive experiments, accelerating development of multi-modal perception systems.

Conclusion: Offers a scalable, unified calibration and auto-labeling framework that simplifies 4D radar–camera fusion and expedites the creation of annotated radar datasets for autonomous driving.

Abstract: 4D radar has emerged as a critical sensor for autonomous driving, primarily due to its enhanced capabilities in elevation measurement and higher resolution compared to traditional 3D radar. Effective integration of 4D radar with cameras requires accurate extrinsic calibration, and the development of radar-based perception algorithms demands large-scale annotated datasets. However, existing calibration methods often employ separate targets optimized for either visual or radar modalities, complicating correspondence establishment. Furthermore, manually labeling sparse radar data is labor-intensive and unreliable. To address these challenges, we propose 4D-CAAL, a unified framework for 4D radar-camera calibration and auto-labeling. Our approach introduces a novel dual-purpose calibration target design, integrating a checkerboard pattern on the front surface for camera detection and a corner reflector at the center of the back surface for radar detection. We develop a robust correspondence matching algorithm that aligns the checkerboard center with the strongest radar reflection point, enabling accurate extrinsic calibration. Subsequently, we present an auto-labeling pipeline that leverages the calibrated sensor relationship to transfer annotations from camera-based segmentations to radar point clouds through geometric projection and multi-feature optimization. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method achieves high calibration accuracy while significantly reducing manual annotation effort, thereby accelerating the development of robust multi-modal perception systems for autonomous driving.

</details>


### [400] [DexTac: Learning Contact-aware Visuotactile Policies via Hand-by-hand Teaching](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21474)
*Xingyu Zhang,Chaofan Zhang,Boyue Zhang,Zhinan Peng,Shaowei Cui,Shuo Wang*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: DexTac integrates rich visuo-tactile data from kinesthetic demonstrations into a policy for contact-aware dexterous manipulation, achieving high success on a unimanual injection task and outperforming force-only baselines in high-precision syringe scenarios.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To overcome the limited and low-dimensional tactile information in existing dexterous manipulation datasets and learning pipelines by incorporating multi-dimensional tactile priors (contact force distributions and spatial contact regions) learned from human demonstrations.

Method: DexTac uses kinesthetic teaching to collect visuo-tactile data (multi-dimensional tactile signals) directly from human demonstrations and fuses these modalities into a policy network that selects and maintains optimal contact regions during complex interactions.

Result: On a challenging unimanual injection task, DexTac attains a 91.67% success rate; in high-precision, small-scale syringe scenarios, it outperforms force-only baselines by 31.67%.

Conclusion: Learning multi-dimensional tactile priors from human demonstrations is critical for achieving robust, human-like dexterous manipulation in contact-rich environments.

Abstract: For contact-intensive tasks, the ability to generate policies that produce comprehensive tactile-aware motions is essential. However, existing data collection and skill learning systems for dexterous manipulation often suffer from low-dimensional tactile information. To address this limitation, we propose DexTac, a visuo-tactile manipulation learning framework based on kinesthetic teaching. DexTac captures multi-dimensional tactile data-including contact force distributions and spatial contact regions-directly from human demonstrations. By integrating these rich tactile modalities into a policy network, the resulting contact-aware agent enables a dexterous hand to autonomously select and maintain optimal contact regions during complex interactions. We evaluate our framework on a challenging unimanual injection task. Experimental results demonstrate that DexTac achieves a 91.67% success rate. Notably, in high-precision scenarios involving small-scale syringes, our approach outperforms force-only baselines by 31.67%. These results underscore that learning multi-dimensional tactile priors from human demonstrations is critical for achieving robust, human-like dexterous manipulation in contact-rich environments.

</details>


### [401] [Don't double it: Efficient Agent Prediction in Occlusions](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21504)
*Anna Rothenhäusler,Markus Mazzola,Andreas Look,Raghu Rajan,Joschka Bödecker*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: MatchInformer enforces a one-to-one prediction-ground-truth mapping for occluded agent reasoning, reduces redundancy via Hungarian matching, refines trajectories by decoupling heading from motion, and uses MCC for robust occupancy evaluation, achieving superior results on Waymo Open Motion Dataset.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Occluded traffic agents create unseen or partially visible entities, leading to incomplete planning and redundant predictions. Redundant results increase computation and complicate downstream decision-making; robust, non-ambiguous predictions are essential for safe autonomous driving.

Method: Extends SceneInformer with Hungarian Matching to enforce one-to-one correspondences between predictions and ground truth. Decouples an agent's heading from its motion to improve trajectory interpretation. Evaluates occupancy with Matthews Correlation Coefficient to handle class imbalance. Trains and tests on the Waymo Open Motion Dataset.

Result: Improved occlusion reasoning and trajectory accuracy compared to prior methods, with reduced duplicate predictions and more robust occupancy evaluation on the Waymo Open Motion Dataset.

Conclusion: Integrating Hungarian matching and heading-motion decoupling yields more reliable and interpretable predictions for occluded agents; MCC is a robust metric under imbalance, enhancing evaluation of occupancy predictions.

Abstract: Occluded traffic agents pose a significant challenge for autonomous vehicles, as hidden pedestrians or vehicles can appear unexpectedly, yet this problem remains understudied. Existing learning-based methods, while capable of inferring the presence of hidden agents, often produce redundant occupancy predictions where a single agent is identified multiple times. This issue complicates downstream planning and increases computational load. To address this, we introduce MatchInformer, a novel transformer-based approach that builds on the state-of-the-art SceneInformer architecture. Our method improves upon prior work by integrating Hungarian Matching, a state-of-the-art object matching algorithm from object detection, into the training process to enforce a one-to-one correspondence between predictions and ground truth, thereby reducing redundancy. We further refine trajectory forecasts by decoupling an agent's heading from its motion, a strategy that improves the accuracy and interpretability of predicted paths. To better handle class imbalances, we propose using the Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC) to evaluate occupancy predictions. By considering all entries in the confusion matrix, MCC provides a robust measure even in sparse or imbalanced scenarios. Experiments on the Waymo Open Motion Dataset demonstrate that our approach improves reasoning about occluded regions and produces more accurate trajectory forecasts than prior methods.

</details>


### [402] [IROS: A Dual-Process Architecture for Real-Time VLM-Based Indoor Navigation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21506)
*Joonhee Lee,Hyunseung Shin,Jeonggil Ko*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: IROS is a real-time indoor navigation framework that blends fast reflexes with selective VLM-based reasoning on-device, achieving 66% latency reduction and improved decision accuracy compared to continuous VLM navigation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: There is a need to reconcile fast, robust semantic understanding for indoor robotics: classical SLAM offers reliable localization but lacks semantic cues; VLA models are reactive; full VLMs incur high latency. IROS aims to provide real-time, semantically grounded navigation on low-cost hardware.

Method: Dual Process-inspired architecture: System One uses lightweight perceptual modules for fast reflexive decisions; System Two invokes compact VLMs only when deliberative reasoning is necessary. Augments compact VLMs with spatial and textual cues for richer grounding. Implemented on on-device hardware and evaluated in five real-world buildings, comparing against continuous VLM-based navigation.

Result: Reported 66% reduction in latency and improved decision accuracy versus continuous VLM navigation; demonstrated real-time performance on low-cost hardware and robust navigation through integration of spatial/textual cues.

Conclusion: IROS shows that separating fast perceptual decisions from selective, on-demand VLM reasoning enables real-time, context-aware indoor navigation on-device, with potential applicability to other context-rich perception tasks. Future work may address hardware dependency, robustness to signage variability, and broader generalization across environments.

Abstract: Indoor mobile robot navigation requires fast responsiveness and robust semantic understanding, yet existing methods struggle to provide both. Classical geometric approaches such as SLAM offer reliable localization but depend on detailed maps and cannot interpret human-targeted cues (e.g., signs, room numbers) essential for indoor reasoning. Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models introduce semantic grounding but remain strictly reactive, basing decisions only on visible frames and failing to anticipate unseen intersections or reason about distant textual cues. Vision-Language Models (VLMs) provide richer contextual inference but suffer from high computational latency, making them unsuitable for real-time operation on embedded platforms. In this work, we present IROS, a real-time navigation framework that combines VLM-level contextual reasoning with the efficiency of lightweight perceptual modules on low-cost, on-device hardware. Inspired by Dual Process Theory, IROS separates fast reflexive decisions (System One) from slow deliberative reasoning (System Two), invoking the VLM only when necessary. Furthermore, by augmenting compact VLMs with spatial and textual cues, IROS delivers robust, human-like navigation with minimal latency. Across five real-world buildings, IROS improves decision accuracy and reduces latency by 66% compared to continuous VLM-based navigation.

</details>


### [403] [Training slow silicon neurons to control extremely fast robots with spiking reinforcement learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21548)
*Irene Ambrosini,Ingo Blakowski,Dmitrii Zendrikov,Cristiano Capone,Luna Gava,Giacomo Indiveri,Chiara De Luca,Chiara Bartolozzi*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A compact neuromorphic spiking neural network on a mixed-signal chip learns real-time air-hockey control via reinforcement learning, using a fixed random reservoir and a local e-prop readout, in a hardware-in-the-loop setup.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To achieve split-second, energy-efficient decision making for fast-paced robotic tasks and demonstrate brain-inspired hardware with on-line learning capabilities.

Method: A mixed-signal neuromorphic processor implements a small spiking network with fixed random connectivity to capture task temporal structure. The readout uses a local e-prop learning rule and reinforcement learning; training occurs in a hardware-in-the-loop setup combining a computer with the neuromorphic chip.

Result: The system achieves real-time learning and successful puck interactions with a very small number of trials, enabling practical, on-line training of SNNs for robotic control.

Conclusion: This work demonstrates that brain-inspired hardware and learning rules can address fast interaction tasks and support continuous learning in intelligent machines, bridging neuroscience-inspired hardware with real-world robotics.

Abstract: Air hockey demands split-second decisions at high puck velocities, a challenge we address with a compact network of spiking neurons running on a mixed-signal analog/digital neuromorphic processor. By co-designing hardware and learning algorithms, we train the system to achieve successful puck interactions through reinforcement learning in a remarkably small number of trials. The network leverages fixed random connectivity to capture the task's temporal structure and adopts a local e-prop learning rule in the readout layer to exploit event-driven activity for fast and efficient learning. The result is real-time learning with a setup comprising a computer and the neuromorphic chip in-the-loop, enabling practical training of spiking neural networks for robotic autonomous systems. This work bridges neuroscience-inspired hardware with real-world robotic control, showing that brain-inspired approaches can tackle fast-paced interaction tasks while supporting always-on learning in intelligent machines.

</details>


### [404] [AIR-VLA: Vision-Language-Action Systems for Aerial Manipulation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21602)
*Jianli Sun,Bin Tian,Qiyao Zhang,Chengxiang Li,Zihan Song,Zhiyong Cui,Yisheng Lv,Yonglin Tian*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: AIR-VLA is the first VLA benchmark for aerial manipulation, combining a physics-based simulator with a 3000-demonstration multimodal dataset to evaluate VLA and VLM models on UAV mobility, manipulator control, and long-horizon planning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Aerial Manipulation Systems (AMS) introduce floating-base dynamics, tight UAV-manipulator coupling, and long-horizon tasks, which challenge existing VLA/2D-mobile benchmarks. A standard benchmark and dataset are needed to study VLA transfer to aerial platforms and to catalyze general-purpose aerial robotics research.

Method: Construct a physics-based simulation environment and release a high-quality multimodal dataset of 3000 manually teleoperated demonstrations covering base manipulation, object/spatial understanding, semantic reasoning, and long-horizon planning. Systematically evaluate mainstream VLA models and state-of-the-art VLM models using aerial-specific, multi-dimensional metrics.

Result: Demonstrates feasibility of transferring VLA paradigms to aerial systems and delineates current models' capabilities and limits in UAV mobility, manipulator control, and high-level planning. AIR-VLA provides a standardized testbed and data foundation for future general-purpose aerial robotics research.

Conclusion: AIR-VLA establishes a standardized benchmark and data resource for advancing research in general-purpose aerial robotics, with the dataset and platform to support future studies and model development.

Abstract: While Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models have achieved remarkable success in ground-based embodied intelligence, their application to Aerial Manipulation Systems (AMS) remains a largely unexplored frontier. The inherent characteristics of AMS, including floating-base dynamics, strong coupling between the UAV and the manipulator, and the multi-step, long-horizon nature of operational tasks, pose severe challenges to existing VLA paradigms designed for static or 2D mobile bases. To bridge this gap, we propose AIR-VLA, the first VLA benchmark specifically tailored for aerial manipulation. We construct a physics-based simulation environment and release a high-quality multimodal dataset comprising 3000 manually teleoperated demonstrations, covering base manipulation, object & spatial understanding, semantic reasoning, and long-horizon planning. Leveraging this platform, we systematically evaluate mainstream VLA models and state-of-the-art VLM models. Our experiments not only validate the feasibility of transferring VLA paradigms to aerial systems but also, through multi-dimensional metrics tailored to aerial tasks, reveal the capabilities and boundaries of current models regarding UAV mobility, manipulator control, and high-level planning. AIR-VLA establishes a standardized testbed and data foundation for future research in general-purpose aerial robotics. The resource of AIR-VLA will be available at https://anonymous.4open.science/r/AIR-VLA-dataset-B5CC/.

</details>


### [405] [From Instruction to Event: Sound-Triggered Mobile Manipulation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21667)
*Hao Ju,Shaofei Huang,Hongyu Li,Zihan Ding,Si Liu,Meng Wang,Zhedong Zheng*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Shifts mobile manipulation from instruction-driven to sound-triggered autonomy using Habitat-Echo; introduces a data platform for acoustic-physical interaction and a baseline with a planner and policies; demonstrates robustness in dual-source acoustic interference.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Overcome limitations of instruction-driven agents that rely on predefined commands, restricting autonomy and responsiveness to dynamic auditory events.

Method: Develop Habitat-Echo, a data platform integrating acoustic rendering with physical interaction; propose a hierarchical baseline consisting of a high-level task planner and low-level policy models to perceive, plan, and act in response to sound-emitting objects without explicit instructions; evaluate in diverse scenarios including dual-source interference.

Result: The baseline enables agents to actively detect and respond to auditory events without case-by-case instructions; in a dual-source scenario, the agent isolates the primary source from interference to perform the first interaction and then manipulates the secondary object, demonstrating robustness.

Conclusion: Sound-triggered mobile manipulation is viable; the proposed framework provides autonomy and robustness to acoustic interference, and the Habitat-Echo platform supports further research in auditory-driven manipulation.

Abstract: Current mobile manipulation research predominantly follows an instruction-driven paradigm, where agents rely on predefined textual commands to execute tasks. However, this setting confines agents to a passive role, limiting their autonomy and ability to react to dynamic environmental events. To address these limitations, we introduce sound-triggered mobile manipulation, where agents must actively perceive and interact with sound-emitting objects without explicit action instructions. To support these tasks, we develop Habitat-Echo, a data platform that integrates acoustic rendering with physical interaction. We further propose a baseline comprising a high-level task planner and low-level policy models to complete these tasks. Extensive experiments show that the proposed baseline empowers agents to actively detect and respond to auditory events, eliminating the need for case-by-case instructions. Notably, in the challenging dual-source scenario, the agent successfully isolates the primary source from overlapping acoustic interference to execute the first interaction, and subsequently proceeds to manipulate the secondary object, verifying the robustness of the baseline.

</details>


### [406] [CoFreeVLA: Collision-Free Dual-Arm Manipulation via Vision-Language-Action Model and Risk Estimation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21712)
*Xuanran Zhai,Binkai Ou,Yemin Wang,Hui Yi Leong,Qiaojun Yu,Ce Hao,Yaohua Liu*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: CoFreeVLA augments Vision-Language Action models with a short-horizon self-collision risk estimator to gate dangerous commands, enabling safer dual-arm manipulation and improved success on PiPER tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Safety concerns in dual-arm manipulation due to under-modeled self-collisions between arms and grasped objects; a lightweight, proprioception- and vision-informed risk estimator can prevent unsafe commands and guide safer policy refinement.

Method: Integrates an end-to-end VLA with a short-horizon collision risk estimator that uses proprioception, visual embeddings, and planned actions. The estimator gates risky commands, applies risk-guided adjustments to recover safe states, and guides policy refinement for safer rollouts. Pre-training uses model-based collision labels; post-training calibrates with real robot rollouts. Evaluated on five bimanual tasks with the PiPER robot arm.

Result: The approach reduces self-collisions and improves task success rates compared with RDT and APEX across five bimanual tasks on PiPER.

Conclusion: Risk-aware architecture like CoFreeVLA can enhance safety in dual-arm manipulation by gating risky actions and calibrating both the perception-to-action mapping and policy rollouts; pre-training on model-based signals combined with post-training real-world calibration yields practical gains.

Abstract: Vision Language Action (VLA) models enable instruction following manipulation, yet dualarm deployment remains unsafe due to under modeled selfcollisions between arms and grasped objects. We introduce CoFreeVLA, which augments an endtoend VLA with a short horizon selfcollision risk estimator that predicts collision likelihood from proprioception, visual embeddings, and planned actions. The estimator gates risky commands, recovers to safe states via risk-guided adjustments, and shapes policy refinement for safer rollouts. It is pre-trained with model-based collision labels and posttrained on real robot rollouts for calibration. On five bimanual tasks with the PiPER robot arm, CoFreeVLA reduces selfcollisions and improves success rates versus RDT and APEX.

</details>


### [407] [Disentangling perception and reasoning for improving data efficiency in learning cloth manipulation without demonstrations](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21713)
*Donatien Delehelle,Fei Chen,Darwin Caldwell*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Efficient, modular RL for cloth manipulation reduces model size and training time, achieving better performance than baselines on SoftGym and enabling sim-to-real transfer with a smaller model.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Cloth manipulation is challenging due to high-dimensional state space, complex dynamics, and self-occlusion; RL is promising but data-intensive; end-to-end vision-based policies incur high computational costs and lossy state representations.

Method: Proposes a modular, efficient RL approach with careful design choices to shrink model size and training time when learning in simulation; emphasizes simulation-trained models transferred to the real world; evaluated on SoftGym against baselines.

Result: Significant performance improvements over available baselines on SoftGym with a substantially smaller model.

Conclusion: A modular, simulation-first RL design can achieve robust cloth manipulation performance with reduced computation and successful sim-to-real transfer, challenging end-to-end image-based approaches.

Abstract: Cloth manipulation is a ubiquitous task in everyday life, but it remains an open challenge for robotics.
