The difficulties in developing cloth manipulation policies are attributed to the high-dimensional state space, complex dynamics, and high propensity to self-occlusion exhibited by fabrics. As analytical methods have not been able to provide robust and general manipulation policies, reinforcement learning (RL) is considered a promising approach to these problems. However, to address the large state space and complex dynamics, data-based methods usually rely on large models and long training times. The resulting computational cost significantly hampers the development and adoption of these methods. Additionally, due to the challenge of robust state estimation, garment manipulation policies often adopt an end-to-end learning approach with workspace images as input. While this approach enables a conceptually straightforward sim-to-real transfer via real-world fine-tuning, it also incurs a significant computational cost by training agents on a highly lossy representation of the environment state. This paper questions this common design choice by exploring an efficient and modular approach to RL for cloth manipulation. We show that, through careful design choices, model size and training time can be significantly reduced when learning in simulation. Furthermore, we demonstrate how the resulting simulation-trained model can be transferred to the real world. We evaluate our approach on the SoftGym benchmark and achieve significant performance improvements over available baselines on our task, while using a substantially smaller model.

</details>


### [408] [Flocking behavior for dynamic and complex swarm structures](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21772)
*Carmen D. R. Pita-Romero,Pedro Arias-Perez,Miguel Fernandez-Cortizas,Rafael Perez-Segui,Pascual Campoy*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Proposes a virtual-centroid based flocking framework to coordinate multi-UAV formations, enabling dynamic agent counts and formations with validated simulations and real-world tests.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Maintaining complex UAV formations and trajectories is challenging; a flexible, scalable control framework is needed to adapt to varying fleet sizes and formation shapes.

Method: Extends classical virtual-based flocking by introducing a theoretical framework around a Virtual Centroid to dynamically control the number of agents and the formation structure while preserving flocking behavior.

Result: Simulation studies and real-world experiments demonstrate the approach’s effectiveness, showing its simplicity even for complex formations and trajectories.

Conclusion: A flexible, centroid-based approach provides easy development of complex UAV formations and trajectories, accommodating dynamic agent counts and structures.

Abstract: Maintaining the formation of complex structures with multiple UAVs and achieving complex trajectories remains a major challenge. This work presents an algorithm for implementing the flocking behavior of UAVs based on the concept of Virtual Centroid to easily develop a structure for the flock. The approach builds on the classical virtual-based behavior, providing a theoretical framework for incorporating enhancements to dynamically control both the number of agents and the formation of the structure. Simulation tests and real-world experiments were conducted, demonstrating its simplicity even with complex formations and complex trajectories.

</details>


### [409] [GAZELOAD A Multimodal Eye-Tracking Dataset for Mental Workload in Industrial Human-Robot Collaboration](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21829)
*Bsher Karbouj,Baha Eddin Gaaloul,Jorg Kruger*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: GAZELOAD: a synchronized multimodal dataset for mental workload estimation in industrial human-robot collaboration, with eye-tracking metrics, environmental data, and task/robot context, from 26 participants across two cobots, using 250 ms aggregated features and self-reported workload ratings (1-10).


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To enable robust mental workload estimation in realistic industrial HRC by providing labeled, multimodal data and to investigate how environmental factors (e.g., lighting) affect eye-based workload markers.

Method: Lab assembly testbed; 26 participants; two collaborative robots (UR5, Franka Emika Panda); Meta ARIA smart glasses; synchronized eye-tracking metrics (pupil diameter, fixations, saccades, gaze, gaze transition entropy, fixation dispersion index) with environmental (illuminance) and task/robot context (bench, task block, induced faults); workload manipulations via task difficulty and ambient conditions; data aggregated in 250 ms windows; includes environmental logs and self-reported workload on a 1–10 Likert scale; organized per participant with documentation.

Result: The dataset provides synchronized ocular metrics, environmental measurements, task/robot context, and workload labels, enabling development and benchmarking of mental workload estimation algorithms, feature extraction, and temporal modeling in realistic industrial HRC scenarios; it also supports studying the influence of lighting on eye-based workload markers. No model results are reported in the abstract.

Conclusion: GAZELOAD constitutes a practical resource for researchers to develop, validate, and compare workload estimation approaches in industrial HRC and to examine environmental effects on eye-tracking markers.

Abstract: This article describes GAZELOAD, a multimodal dataset for mental workload estimation in industrial human-robot collaboration. The data were collected in a laboratory assembly testbed where 26 participants interacted with two collaborative robots (UR5 and Franka Emika Panda) while wearing Meta ARIA smart glasses. The dataset time-synchronizes eye-tracking signals (pupil diameter, fixations, saccades, eye gaze, gaze transition entropy, fixation dispersion index) with environmental real-time and continuous measurements (illuminance) and task and robot context (bench, task block, induced faults), under controlled manipulations of task difficulty and ambient conditions. For each participant and workload-graded task block, we provide CSV files with ocular metrics aggregated into 250 ms windows, environmental logs, and self-reported mental workload ratings on a 1-10 Likert scale, organized in participant-specific folders alongside documentation. These data can be used to develop and benchmark algorithms for mental workload estimation, feature extraction, and temporal modeling in realistic industrial HRC scenarios, and to investigate the influence of environmental factors such as lighting on eye-based workload markers.

</details>


### [410] [LLM-Driven Scenario-Aware Planning for Autonomous Driving](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21876)
*He Li,Zhaowei Chen,Rui Gao,Guoliang Li,Qi Hao,Shuai Wang,Chengzhong Xu*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: An LLM-driven adaptive planning framework (LAP) for hybrid planner switching in autonomous driving that toggles between high-speed and precise driving, optimized via tree-search MPC and alternating minimization to improve trajectory generation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current HPSF approaches struggle with unreliable mode transitions and inefficient driving in dense traffic due to heuristic scene recognition and low-frequency control updates.

Method: LAP uses an LLM for scene understanding and integrates its inference into a joint optimization of mode configuration and motion planning. The optimization is solved by a combination of tree-search model predictive control and alternating minimization. Implemented in Python on ROS.

Result: In high-fidelity simulations, LAP outperforms benchmarks in driving time and success rate.

Conclusion: LLM-driven adaptive planning can enhance HPSF for autonomous driving by enabling context-aware mode switching and improved trajectory generation, with practical feasibility demonstrated in ROS-based simulations.

Abstract: Hybrid planner switching framework (HPSF) for autonomous driving needs to reconcile high-speed driving efficiency with safe maneuvering in dense traffic. Existing HPSF methods often fail to make reliable mode transitions or sustain efficient driving in congested environments, owing to heuristic scene recognition and low-frequency control updates. To address the limitation, this paper proposes LAP, a large language model (LLM) driven, adaptive planning method, which switches between high-speed driving in low-complexity scenes and precise driving in high-complexity scenes, enabling high qualities of trajectory generation through confined gaps. This is achieved by leveraging LLM for scene understanding and integrating its inference into the joint optimization of mode configuration and motion planning. The joint optimization is solved using tree-search model predictive control and alternating minimization. We implement LAP by Python in Robot Operating System (ROS). High-fidelity simulation results show that the proposed LAP outperforms other benchmarks in terms of both driving time and success rate.

</details>


### [411] [Multi-Modular MANTA-RAY: A Modular Soft Surface Platform for Distributed Multi-Object Manipulation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21884)
*Pratik Ingle,Jørn Lambertsen,Kasper Støy,Andres Faina*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Modular, reduced-actuation MANTA-RAY scales manipulation across surface modules, validated by simulation (3x3/4x4) and a 2x2 prototype.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reduce actuator density and DOF of dense soft-robotic surfaces while preserving manipulation performance, enabling scalable handling of fragile and heterogeneous objects.

Method: Introduce a distributed, modular MANTA-RAY platform with object passing between modules and a geometric transformation driven PID controller that maps tilt-angle controls directly to actuator commands. Avoids data-driven training. Evaluate in simulation across 3x3 and 4x4 configurations and validate with a physical 2x2 prototype.

Result: The multi-module platform manipulates objects with varied geometries, masses, and textures (including fragile items like eggs and apples). Demonstrates parallel manipulation and improved scalability across larger areas.

Conclusion: A modular, reduced-actuation MANTA-RAY maintains performance, enabling scalable, coordinated manipulation over larger surfaces and showing potential for practical, real-world applications.

Abstract: Manipulation surfaces control objects by actively deforming their shape rather than directly grasping them. While dense actuator arrays can generate complex deformations, they also introduce high degrees of freedom (DOF), increasing system complexity and limiting scalability. The MANTA-RAY (Manipulation with Adaptive Non-rigid Textile Actuation with Reduced Actuation densitY) platform addresses these challenges by leveraging a soft, fabric-based surface with reduced actuator density to manipulate fragile and heterogeneous objects. Previous studies focused on single-module implementations supported by four actuators, whereas the feasibility and benefits of a scalable, multi-module configuration remain unexplored. In this work, we present a distributed, modular, and scalable variant of the MANTA-RAY platform that maintains manipulation performance with a reduced actuator density. The proposed multi-module MANTA-RAY platform and control strategy employs object passing between modules and a geometric transformation driven PID controller that directly maps tilt-angle control outputs to actuator commands, eliminating the need for extensive data-driven or black-box training. We evaluate system performance in simulation across surface configurations of varying modules (3x3 and 4x4) and validate its feasibility through experiments on a physical 2x2 hardware prototype. The system successfully manipulates objects with diverse geometries, masses, and textures including fragile items such as eggs and apples as well as enabling parallel manipulation. The results demonstrate that the multi-module MANTA-RAY improves scalability and enables coordinated manipulation of multiple objects across larger areas, highlighting its potential for practical, real-world applications.

</details>


### [412] [Information Filtering via Variational Regularization for Robot Manipulation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21926)
*Jinhao Zhang,Wenlong Xia,Yaojia Wang,Zhexuan Zhou,Huizhe Li,Yichen Lai,Haoming Song,Youmin Gong,Jie Me*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Variational Regularization (VR) enhances diffusion-based visuomotor policies by adding a timetable-conditioned Gaussian bottleneck over backbone features and a KL penalty, reducing task-irrelevant noise and achieving state-of-the-art results on RoboTwin2.0, Adroit, and MetaWorld with notable accuracy gains; inference-time feature masking reveals latent noise in intermediate representations.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Oversized denoising decoders in diffusion-based visuomotor policies introduce redundancy and noise in intermediate features. Additionally, randomly masking backbone features at inference suggests significant task-irrelevant information in features. There is a need for a lightweight regularization that adaptively constrains information flow to backbone representations.

Method: Introduce Variational Regularization (VR): a lightweight module that imposes a timestep-conditioned Gaussian distribution over backbone features and adds a KL-divergence regularizer, forming an adaptive information bottleneck. The module can be integrated with existing diffusion-based visuomotor policies. The observation of inference-time feature masking motivates a concise, information-theoretic constraint rather than increasing model capacity.

Result: Empirical evaluation on RoboTwin2.0, Adroit, and MetaWorld shows that VR improves success rate by 6.1 percentage points on RoboTwin2.0 and 4.1 percentage points on Adroit/MetaWorld compared to the baseline DP3, achieving new state-of-the-art results. Real-world experiments confirm practical effectiveness. Code will be released.

Conclusion: VR provides an effective, lightweight regularization to suppress task-irrelevant information in backbone features, enabling better performance for diffusion-based visuomotor policies without substantial computational burden and with positive sim-to-real transfer.

Abstract: Diffusion-based visuomotor policies built on 3D visual representations have achieved strong performance in learning complex robotic skills. However, most existing methods employ an oversized denoising decoder. While increasing model capacity can improve denoising, empirical evidence suggests that it also introduces redundancy and noise in intermediate feature blocks. Crucially, we find that randomly masking backbone features at inference time (without changing training) can improve performance, confirming the presence of task-irrelevant noise in intermediate features. To this end, we propose Variational Regularization (VR), a lightweight module that imposes a timestep-conditioned Gaussian over backbone features and applies a KL-divergence regularizer, forming an adaptive information bottleneck. Extensive experiments on three simulation benchmarks (RoboTwin2.0, Adroit, and MetaWorld) show that, compared to the baseline DP3, our approach improves the success rate by 6.1% on RoboTwin2.0 and by 4.1% on Adroit and MetaWorld, achieving new state-of-the-art results. Real-world experiments further demonstrate that our method performs well in practical deployments. Code will released.

</details>


### [413] [MoE-ACT: Improving Surgical Imitation Learning Policies through Supervised Mixture-of-Experts](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21971)
*Lorenzo Mazza,Ariel Rodriguez,Rayan Younis,Martin Lelis,Ortrun Hellig,Chenpan Li,Sebastian Bodenstedt,Martin Wagner,Stefanie Speidel*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A supervised Mixture-of-Experts on top of an action-decoder (ACT) enables efficient long-horizon surgical manipulation from <150 demonstrations using stereo endoscopy; outperforms Vision-Language-Action models and standard ACT, with strong generalization including unseen viewpoints and zero-shot ex vivo porcine tissue; qualitative in vivo results reported.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address data scarcity, constrained workspaces, and stringent safety/predictability requirements in surgical robotics by enabling robust, data-efficient learning for phase-structured manipulation tasks.

Method: Train a lightweight action decoder policy (ACT) augmented with a supervised Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architecture on top of ACT. Use stereo endoscopic images and <150 demonstrations to learn long-horizon bowel grasping and retraction, evaluated against state-of-the-art Vision-Language-Action models and the standard ACT baseline. Assess in-distribution performance and robustness to out-of-distribution factors (novel grasp locations, reduced illumination, occlusions), generalization to unseen viewpoints, and zero-shot transfer to ex vivo porcine tissue, with qualitative in vivo surgery rollouts.

Result: MoE-augmented ACT yields higher success rates in-distribution and significantly better robustness in out-of-distribution scenarios than ACT alone; Vision-Language-Action models fail to acquire the task. The approach generalizes to unseen viewpoints and transfers zero-shot to ex vivo porcine tissue. Qualitative preliminary in vivo porcine results are reported."

Conclusion: Supervised MoE augmentation of ACT improves data efficiency, generalization, and robustness for phase-structured surgical manipulation, offering a promising path toward safer and more deployable in vivo robotic surgery. Further rigorous quantitative validation and safety evaluations are needed.

Abstract: Imitation learning has achieved remarkable success in robotic manipulation, yet its application to surgical robotics remains challenging due to data scarcity, constrained workspaces, and the need for an exceptional level of safety and predictability. We present a supervised Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architecture designed for phase-structured surgical manipulation tasks, which can be added on top of any autonomous policy. Unlike prior surgical robot learning approaches that rely on multi-camera setups or thousands of demonstrations, we show that a lightweight action decoder policy like Action Chunking Transformer (ACT) can learn complex, long-horizon manipulation from less than 150 demonstrations using solely stereo endoscopic images, when equipped with our architecture. We evaluate our approach on the collaborative surgical task of bowel grasping and retraction, where a robot assistant interprets visual cues from a human surgeon, executes targeted grasping on deformable tissue, and performs sustained retraction. We benchmark our method against state-of-the-art Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models and the standard ACT baseline. Our results show that generalist VLAs fail to acquire the task entirely, even under standard in-distribution conditions. Furthermore, while standard ACT achieves moderate success in-distribution, adopting a supervised MoE architecture significantly boosts its performance, yielding higher success rates in-distribution and demonstrating superior robustness in out-of-distribution scenarios, including novel grasp locations, reduced illumination, and partial occlusions. Notably, it generalizes to unseen testing viewpoints and also transfers zero-shot to ex vivo porcine tissue without additional training, offering a promising pathway toward in vivo deployment. To support this, we present qualitative preliminary results of policy roll-outs during in vivo porcine surgery.

</details>


### [414] [Macro-Scale Electrostatic Origami Motor](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.21976)
*Alex S. Miller,Leo McElroy,Jeffrey H. Lang*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: First macro-scale origami rotary motor that folds flat and unfurls to operate, using corona discharge to produce torque. Demonstrates expansion 2.5:1, top speed 1440 rpm at -29 kV, and max torque >0.15 mN·m with active torque density 0.04 Nm/kg.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Fill a gap in foldable robotics by delivering a macro-scale continuous rotary actuator integrated into origami folding media, enabling rotary motion rather than only linear/folding actuation.

Method: Developed a foldable origami motor architecture that can be folded flat and unfurled; employs corona discharge as the torque source; characterized expansion ratio, speed, torque, and torque density under high voltage.

Result: Expansion ratio 2.5:1; top speed 1440 rpm at -29 kV; maximum output torque >0.15 mN·m; active torque density 0.04 Nm/kg.

Conclusion: Demonstrates the feasibility of a macro-scale origami rotary motor actuated by corona discharge; introduces a novel approach to integrated, foldable rotation for macro origami robotics; future work should address efficiency, control strategies, safety of high voltage, durability, and scalability.

Abstract: Foldable robots have been an active area of robotics research due to their high volume-to-mass ratio, easy packability, and shape adaptability. For locomotion, previously developed foldable robots have either embedded linear actuators in, or attached non-folding rotary motors to, their structure. Further, those actuators directly embedded in the structure of the folding medium all contributed to linear or folding motion, not to continuous rotary motion. On the macro-scale there has not yet been a folding continuous rotary actuator. This paper details the development and testing of the first macro-scale origami rotary motor that can be folded flat, and then unfurled to operate. Using corona discharge for torque production, the prototype motor achieved an expansion ratio of 2.5:1, reached a top speed of 1440 rpm when driven at -29 kV, and exhibited a maximum output torque over 0.15 mN m with an active component torque density of 0.04 Nm/kg.

</details>


### [415] [PocketDP3: Efficient Pocket-Scale 3D Visuomotor Policy](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22018)
*Jinhao Zhang,Zhexuan Zhou,Huizhe Li,Yichen Lai,Wenlong Xia,Haoming Song,Youmin Gong,Jie Me*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: PocketDP3: a compact 3D diffusion policy using a Diffusion Mixer (DiM) built on MLP-Mixer blocks to replace heavy conditional U-Net decoders, achieving state-of-the-art results with <1% of the parameters and enabling two-step inference.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Architectural mismatch in 3D diffusion policies: small point-cloud encoders are paired with large decoders, causing parameter waste. A pocket-scale, efficient diffusion policy aims to preserve performance while enabling real-time deployment.

Method: Replace the heavy conditional U-Net decoder with a lightweight Diffusion Mixer (DiM) based on MLP-Mixer blocks, enabling efficient fusion across temporal and channel dimensions. Supports two-step inference without extra distillation. Trained on compact 3D scene representations and evaluated on RoboTwin2.0, Adroit, and MetaWorld; real-world transfer demonstrated; code to be released.

Result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance on three benchmarks (RoboTwin2.0, Adroit, MetaWorld) with less than 1% of the parameters of prior methods and faster inference; real-world experiments validate practicality and transferability.

Conclusion: Demonstrates that compact diffusion policies can match or exceed prior performance with drastically reduced parameters, enabling real-time deployment. The DiM-based design offers efficient temporal-channel fusion and may generalize to broader 3D manipulation tasks; code release will facilitate reproducibility.

Abstract: Recently, 3D vision-based diffusion policies have shown strong capability in learning complex robotic manipulation skills. However, a common architectural mismatch exists in these models: a tiny yet efficient point-cloud encoder is often paired with a massive decoder. Given a compact scene representation, we argue that this may lead to substantial parameter waste in the decoder. Motivated by this observation, we propose PocketDP3, a pocket-scale 3D diffusion policy that replaces the heavy conditional U-Net decoder used in prior methods with a lightweight Diffusion Mixer (DiM) built on MLP-Mixer blocks. This architecture enables efficient fusion across temporal and channel dimensions, significantly reducing model size. Notably, without any additional consistency distillation techniques, our method supports two-step inference without sacrificing performance, improving practicality for real-time deployment. Across three simulation benchmarks--RoboTwin2.0, Adroit, and MetaWorld--PocketDP3 achieves state-of-the-art performance with fewer than 1% of the parameters of prior methods, while also accelerating inference. Real-world experiments further demonstrate the practicality and transferability of our method in real-world settings. Code will be released.

</details>


### [416] [mjlab: A Lightweight Framework for GPU-Accelerated Robot Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22074)
*Kevin Zakka,Qiayuan Liao,Brent Yi,Louis Le Lay,Koushil Sreenath,Pieter Abbeel*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Lightweight GPU-accelerated robot-learning framework with modular components and easy setup, built on MuJoCo Warp.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To lower entry barriers for robot-learning research by providing GPU-enabled physics, composable observation/reward/event blocks, and minimal setup friction.

Method: Adopts Isaac Lab's manager-based API for composing modular blocks of observations, rewards, and events; integrates MuJoCo Warp for GPU-accelerated physics; aims for a one-command install with minimal dependencies; exposes native MuJoCo data structures; includes reference implementations for velocity tracking, motion imitation, and manipulation tasks.

Result: A functional, open-source framework enabling fast iteration in robot-learning research: GPU-accelerated simulation, modular environments, easy setup, direct access to MuJoCo data, and built-in task implementations.

Conclusion: mjlab provides an accessible, extensible platform for rapid development and experimentation in robot learning by combining GPU-accelerated physics with reusable, modular components.

Abstract: We present mjlab, a lightweight, open-source framework for robot learning that combines GPU-accelerated simulation with composable environments and minimal setup friction. mjlab adopts the manager-based API introduced by Isaac Lab, where users compose modular building blocks for observations, rewards, and events, and pairs it with MuJoCo Warp for GPU-accelerated physics. The result is a framework installable with a single command, requiring minimal dependencies, and providing direct access to native MuJoCo data structures. mjlab ships with reference implementations of velocity tracking, motion imitation, and manipulation tasks.

</details>


### [417] [ReactEMG Stroke: Healthy-to-Stroke Few-shot Adaptation for sEMG-Based Intent Detection](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22090)
*Runsheng Wang,Katelyn Lee,Xinyue Zhu,Lauren Winterbottom,Dawn M. Nilsen,Joel Stein,Matei Ciocarlie*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Healthy-domain pretraining with small stroke data improves robust sEMG-based intent detection and reduces calibration needs for post-stroke rehabilitation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reduce calibration burden and improve robustness of sEMG-based intent detection in stroke, which is brittle and highly variable; leverage transferable healthy EMG representations.

Method: Pretrain on large-scale able-bodied sEMG, then adapt per-stroke using minimal subject data; compare adaptation strategies (head-only tuning, LoRA adapters, full fine-tuning); dataset from 3 chronic stroke participants; evaluation with distribution shifts (within-session drift, posture change, armband repositioning).

Result: Healthy-pretrained adaptation improves stroke intent detection over zero-shot and stroke-only training; best methods raise average transition accuracy 0.42→0.61 and raw accuracy 0.69→0.78.

Conclusion: Transferring reusable healthy-domain EMG representations can reduce calibration burden and improve robustness for real-time post-stroke intent detection.

Abstract: Surface electromyography (sEMG) is a promising control signal for assist-as-needed hand rehabilitation after stroke, but detecting intent from paretic muscles often requires lengthy, subject-specific calibration and remains brittle to variability. We propose a healthy-to-stroke adaptation pipeline that initializes an intent detector from a model pretrained on large-scale able-bodied sEMG, then fine-tunes it for each stroke participant using only a small amount of subject-specific data. Using a newly collected dataset from three individuals with chronic stroke, we compare adaptation strategies (head-only tuning, parameter-efficient LoRA adapters, and full end-to-end fine-tuning) and evaluate on held-out test sets that include realistic distribution shifts such as within-session drift, posture changes, and armband repositioning. Across conditions, healthy-pretrained adaptation consistently improves stroke intent detection relative to both zero-shot transfer and stroke-only training under the same data budget; the best adaptation methods improve average transition accuracy from 0.42 to 0.61 and raw accuracy from 0.69 to 0.78. These results suggest that transferring a reusable healthy-domain EMG representation can reduce calibration burden while improving robustness for real-time post-stroke intent detection.

</details>


### [418] [DynamicVLA: A Vision-Language-Action Model for Dynamic Object Manipulation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.22153)
*Haozhe Xie,Beichen Wen,Jiarui Zheng,Zhaoxi Chen,Fangzhou Hong,Haiwen Diao,Ziwei Liu*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: DynamicVLA is a compact 0.4B Vision-Language-Action model for dynamic object manipulation, enabling continuous inference and latent-aware action streaming, paired with the Dynamic Object Manipulation (DOM) benchmark (200k synthetic episodes across 2.8k scenes and 206 objects, plus 2k real-world episodes). It shows faster response, improved perception, and better generalization across embodiments.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Dynamic object manipulation remains challenging for VLA models due to the need for rapid perception, temporal anticipation, and continuous control in dynamic scenarios. A lack of dynamic manipulation datasets further hampers progress. A compact, fast, and temporally aligned VLA framework is needed to bridge perception and action in dynamic contexts.

Method: Three core designs: (1) a compact 0.4B VLA with a convolutional vision encoder for spatially efficient, structurally faithful encoding and fast multimodal inference; (2) Continuous Inference enabling overlapping reasoning and execution to reduce latency and adapt to object motion in real time; (3) Latent-aware Action Streaming to align perception and action temporally, reducing gaps between perception and execution. Dataset contribution includes the Dynamic Object Manipulation (DOM) benchmark built from scratch with an auto data-collection pipeline gathering 200K synthetic episodes over 2.8K scenes and 206 objects, plus fast collection of 2K real-world episodes without teleoperation.

Result: Extensive evaluations report remarkable improvements in response speed, perception accuracy, and generalization for dynamic object manipulation, showing DynamicVLA as a unified framework that generalizes across different embodiments.

Conclusion: DynamicVLA fills the missing foundation for dynamic manipulation data and tasks, offering a unified framework with a rich DOM benchmark that supports rapid, temporally aligned perception and action across embodiments.

Abstract: Manipulating dynamic objects remains an open challenge for Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models, which, despite strong generalization in static manipulation, struggle in dynamic scenarios requiring rapid perception, temporal anticipation, and continuous control. We present DynamicVLA, a framework for dynamic object manipulation that integrates temporal reasoning and closed-loop adaptation through three key designs: 1) a compact 0.4B VLA using a convolutional vision encoder for spatially efficient, structurally faithful encoding, enabling fast multimodal inference; 2) Continuous Inference, enabling overlapping reasoning and execution for lower latency and timely adaptation to object motion; and 3) Latent-aware Action Streaming, which bridges the perception-execution gap by enforcing temporally aligned action execution. To fill the missing foundation of dynamic manipulation data, we introduce the Dynamic Object Manipulation (DOM) benchmark, built from scratch with an auto data collection pipeline that efficiently gathers 200K synthetic episodes across 2.8K scenes and 206 objects, and enables fast collection of 2K real-world episodes without teleoperation. Extensive evaluations demonstrate remarkable improvements in response speed, perception, and generalization, positioning DynamicVLA as a unified framework for general dynamic object manipulation across embodiments.

</details>
